HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The leading indicators rose a modest 0.2 percent in March, the third straight gain. Many analysts have been busy raising estimates for overall growth, with 3 percent for the year no longer regarded as unduly optimistic, but most continued to point to relatively sluggish expansion in coming quarters. [Page D1.]
Orders to U.S. factories recorded their sharpest advance in five months in March. [D5.] 
 New jobless claims held steady in mid-April, suggesting that the tentative recovery is starting to buoy the labor market. [D5.]
The need for involvement in prenatal and maternal health care to insure that the U.S. work force is prepared to compete globally was cited by business leaders at a conference. [D6.]
In a polluted part of the Everglades, a system of tradable pollution credits has been proposed that would give farm owners incentives to use the cheapest cleanup methods. [B18.]
Companies in New York are paying bills more quickly, a sign of improvement in the local economy. [B3.]
 
Companies
McDonnell Douglas, unveiling its design for a new four-engine jumbo jet, said it expected development costs to be 12 percent higher than it had estimated for a three-engine design. [D1.]
Chrysler reported sharply improved results, but it still posted a loss of $13 million, compared with a loss of $598 million. [D1.]
UAL reported a quarterly loss of $92.3 million, an improvement from the $157 million loss it posted in the '91 quarter. It also promoted J. C. Pope to president and chief operating officer. [D4.]
With Sprinkl'ins, Dannon is trying to do for yogurt what Calvin Klein did for jeans: market an adult product to children. [D1.]
BellSouth and Dow Jones said they would expand a cooperative venture they announced last month. [D4.]
The disappearance of Exxon International's president, Sidney J. Reso, remained a mystery. [B1.]
The public areas at the base of the former A.T.& T. headquarters would be reduced and altered under a plan by Sony, which is moving in. [B1.]
A vote on a contract involving The New York Times and truck drivers was delayed by a judge. [B6.]
 
International
Talks between Brazil and its bankers took a big step forward when Brazilian officials agreed that some of the $14 billion they hold in reserve would be used as part of a new agreement. [D1.]
The European Community said it had no immediate plans to reduce soybean subsidies. [D2.]
A Bhopal judge ruled that all of Union Carbide's Indian assets would be seized. [D7.]
An unusual Japanese Government program helps smaller American companies sell to Japan. [D1.]
 
Markets
Stock prices staged a broad rally on encouraging economic news, lifting the Dow to 3,359.12, up 25.94. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in slow trading. [D13.]
Coffee prices tumbled to the lowest levels in 17 years on perceptions of an oversupply. [D14.] The dollar fell. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
The euphoria that greeted the downfall of Communism has given way to anxiety that it will take years for a transition to market economies. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Nuisance fees are rising for brokerage-house clients, and investors can expect higher charges yet. Market Place. [D6.]
The "hidden pleasure" ads for Seagram's Gin are being credited with helping the brand achieve unusual growth. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Baker, on Hill, Passes Hat for Russia

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d went to Capitol Hill today to tell Congress it "absolutely must" move quickly to authorize the Administration's package of aid to Russia, and to head off efforts by some lawmakers to attach special interest riders to the bill.
But Mr. Baker was told that if the Administration wanted Congress to approve the United States contribution to the $24 billion international aid plan for the former Soviet republics, the President would have to take a much more active lobbying role. 
 While most lawmakers agree that there is still a majority in support of the Russian aid package, that majority is beginning to wilt a bit in the heat of the election season.
Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, noted that the Administration had asked that the legislation be finished in time for the visit of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to Washing on June 16 and 17.
"That's quite a tall order," Mr. Fascell told Mr. Baker at the start of his testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
 
Jobs 'Must Come First'
 Mr. Fascell, the committee chairman, added: "I want to say it's going to take your best efforts politically, and I know you are already hard at work at that. But may I venture that it's going to take more than that. I think it's going to take the personal intercession of the President of the United States to help us with this very vital program that we consider in our best interest."
Mr. Baker's appearance on Capitol Hill to drum up support for the Freedom Support Act, the Administration's contribution to the $24 billion international aid package for Russia and other republics, coincided with the circulation of a letter by the House Democratic whip, David E. Bonior of Michigan, urging lawmakers not to support the package until the President has a more effective domestic policy. Mr. Bonior's office said that he had already collected close to 100 signatures on the letter to the President, which he plans to send to the White House on Tuesday.
The letter says: "Dear Mr. President: Last week you announced that the time has come for the United States to provide billions in aid to the former Soviet republics. Today we are writing you with a very simple message: jobs for Americans must come first. We cannot support your plan for additional assistance to the former Soviet republics until you have first addressed the issue of jobs and economic growth for America. Specifically, we are calling on you to support an extension of unemployment benefits and an accelerated jobs program for America."
Many Democrats on the Foreign Affairs Committee, at least, disassociated themselves from the letter. Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana said jobs and the Russian aid package were both important to the country, but to link them might jeopardize passage of the aid bill, and therefore he would not endorse the Bonior move.
The Freedom Support Act would authorize appropriations for a variety of aid programs, including American participation in a $6 billion currency stabilization fund for Russia and a $12 billion increase in the American share of financing for the International Monetary Fund, which in turn, would lend the money to Russia.
 
A Plea on Amendments
 "In my private discussions with members of the House," Mr. Baker said, "I have been told repeatedly this is an issue that is too important for partisan politics, that they agree with me that this is a once-in-a-century opportunity to advance our national interest. We hope those sentiments which have been expressed in private will be expressed just as honestly and openly in public."
Mr. Baker said that he particularly hoped that lawmakers would oppose any efforts by their colleagues to attach amendments, "which, however well intentioned, could insure the legislation's defeat."
On March 11, for instance, six conservative Republican senators sent a letter to President Bush expressing their "concern" that the former Soviet Union was secretly retaining a covert force of the SS-20 and SS-23 misslies it was supposed to declare as part of the Intermediate Range Ballistic Missile Treaty.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mixed in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in slow trading yesterday in a session sprinkled with rumors about Argentina and its willingness to buy 30-year zero-coupon bonds in the open market.
The thought that Argentina may buy large quantities of zero-coupon securities as part of a commercial bank debt-restructuring plan was officially raised by the Treasury on Wednesday, even though the issue had been a topic of conversation in the credit markets for weeks. 
 The rumors continued to fly yesterday about whether the open-market purchases would take place, and bond prices reacted to all of them.
 
Jobless Claims Unchanged
 Traders said, however, that the most important piece of information was the weekly report on initial unemployment claims, which were unchanged at just over 400,000 in the week ended April 18.
Traders had feared that unemployment claims, which had fallen for three consecutive weeks, would post another decline, providing further evidence of improvement in labor markets that could strengthen the economy enough to reignite inflation.
"The claims numbers were a relief," a government bond trader said.
Reports released yesterday on new factory orders and the Government's index of leading economic indicators had little impact on trading. Analysts said they were consistent with a halting recovery.
"There is nothing in these numbers to suggest the economy is firing on all cylinders," said Stuart G. Hoffman, senior economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh.
 
Quarterly Refunding
 Although Treasury bond prices posted the biggest gains of the session, traders said further gains would probably be limited in the final run-up to next week's quarterly refunding auctions.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 99 5/8, up 11/32 , to yield 8.03 percent, compared with 8.05 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, up 5/32 , to yield 7.57 percent. The 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 9931/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 6.88 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9929/32 , unchanged on the day, to yield 5.42 percent.
The Treasury held an auction of new one-year bills yesterday, and they were sold at an average discount rate of 4.20 percent, down from an average rate of 4.34 percent at the last one-year bill sale on April 2.
 
Rates on Treasury Bills
 Rates on outstanding short-term Treasury bills fell slightly. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.68 percent late yesterday, down two basis points, or two-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.81 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Baxter International Inc. offered $200 million worth of five-year notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 7 1/2 percent notes were priced at $100, or par, 59 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable securities are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Corporate bond traders said prices of most outstanding investment-grade issues were unchanged on the day. And prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt municipal bonds were also little changed, market participants said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply that it tracks on a weekly basis rose during the week ended April 20. The broadest measure, M-3, fell by $4.9 billion.
The drop in M-3 and the $1.6 billion rise in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, were somewhat weaker than analysts had anticipated. Nevertheless, the report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
As Political Campaigns Turn Negative, the Press Is Given a Negative Rating

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
The bitter Presidential race pictured this year on television has been blamed for ills ranging from Gov. Bill Clinton's negative polls to the scant primary turnout in most states. But it could be the news media that sustain the most damage if the campaign turns out to be another overwhelmingly negative race.
Social scientists studying the election say that voters are increasingly blaming the news media -- newspapers, magazines and, most powerfully, television -- for what they see as the degeneration of Presidential politics. In a burst of apparent self-loathing, even the press seems to have been swept up in this wave of anti-press sentiment. 
 Four years ago, 60 percent of the commentators assessing campaign coverage on the network news gave the press a negative rating, according to a study by the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington. This year, the proportion of negative assessments jumped to 90 percent.
"In American politics, there's a tendency to be suspicious of power brokers no matter who they are," said Darrell West, a professor of political science at Brown University in Providence, R.I. "It used to be this was the back-room politicians, and people were very upset with them. Now people are becoming more suspicious of the media. They see the media as part of the establishment, and that's not a great position to be in."
 
Attack Ads (Against the Press)
 Professor West noted that a few candidates, including Governor Clinton of Arkansas, had used television commercials this year explicitly attacking the news media, breaking a longstanding taboo.
"Even the media haters like Richard Nixon never dared run an ad against the press," he said.
Voters increasingly seem to view the campaign as a function of what news organizations choose to report rather than the other way around. In a January poll by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press in Washington, 58 percent of the respondents said news organizations had "too much" influence on who became President, as against 51 percent who said that at the start of 1988.
"Press-bashing used to be ideological," said Todd Gitlin, a professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley. "It was from the right, like from Goldwater and Nixon, or from the left over the Vietnam War. But this is different. I think people are tired of knowing more about Gennifer Flowers than about the defense budget the Senate passed that day."
 
How News Reporting Rates
 In a recent survey of Boston-area residents, Mr. West found that roughly half the respondents rated the reporting on this year's campaign as "poor" or "fair." A recent nationwide poll by the Center for the People and the Press showed Americans to have a more benevolent view of the news media but one that is nevertheless souring.
In the center's poll, 65 percent of the respondents rated the reporting on the campaign as "excellent" or "good," down from 71 percent in 1988. The proportion of respondents who rated the coverage "fair" or "poor" was 33 percent, up from 22 percent four years ago.
Just as politicians tend to fare badly in hard times, journalists, too, may be suffering from side effects of the recession. Many news executives say that if the public blames the news media for its disappointment with the race so far, it is blaming the wrong party.
"I'm continually impressed with how little we can do about the tone of a campaign," said Tom Hannon, political director for the Cable News Network. "The tenor seems beyond the control of any news organization. The process moves along; the media are essentially passive, despite appearances to the contrary."
Social scientists agree that much of the criticism of news organizations is probably a result of general disgruntlement with the economy and the political process. But they say, and some journalists concur, that long-term trends are at work that may also be undermining Americans' faith in the news media.
 
Standards of Privacy
 As in the last campaign, when Gary Hart's love life became a national news event, news organizations this year are once again struggling with a changing standard of privacy for public officials. To many reporters, Governor Clinton often seemed to be inviting scrutiny of his private life by equivocating when questioned by journalists. But this struggle between public and private makes many Americans uncomfortable -- they are at once curious and disgusted, researchers say -- and has probably contributed to the growing complaints about the coverage.
At the same time, the structure of the news reporting itself is changing.
While once the major newspapers and the network television news programs set the agenda for the campaign coverage, this year the newspapers and the networks often seemed to be responding to supermarket tabloids and television talk shows. Governor Clinton and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California put in appearances in New York not only with the standard newscasters and editorial boards, but also with Don Imus, the radio personality, and with Phil Donahue. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, has conducted virtually most of his campaign on "Larry King Live."
Local newscasts have also assumed greater influence in recent years, and this, too, has changed the nature of campaign coverage. "The day of the network news being the horse that pulls the cart is over," said Lane Venardos, executive producer of special events for CBS. "We're either being pulled, or at best we're running alongside."
When voters criticize the news media, they tend to lump together the most sedate and the most sensational outlets, from newspapers to the local news to "tabloid" television programs like "A Current Affair," social scientists say. "People get their news in a remarkably haphazard way," said Tim Cook, a professor of political science at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., who is studying local news coverage of the election.
 
Focus on the Networks
 When professional critics talk about the role of news organizations in the campaign, however, they tend to focus on the network news.
The networks' initial commitment to reporting on the campaign in a substantive way can be seen in the early emphasis of their broadcasts. Reports about policy made up 45 percent of the coverage in the weeks leading up to the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 18, according to the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington.
But in the weeks after New Hampshire, when voters in dozens of other states began to attend to their own primary contests, the focus of the reporting shifted to the daily back and forth among the candidates. The proportion of policy reports dropped to 19 percent.
"The evidence is clear that the networks tried to do the right thing," said Marvin Kalb, director of the Shorenstein Barone Center on Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University. Early in the campaign, he noted, the networks agreed to provide prime time slots for debates and to broadcast in-depth features on the candidates.
But after the New Hampshire primary, he said, "You could see the descent on a day-to-day basis. The sound bites decreased. Substance became character. They allowed themselves to be seduced by the obvious: sex, sleaze, draft."
 
'Taken Aback' by 'Donahue'
 Network news executives call such criticism a clear case of blaming the messenger for an unwelcome message. It was not the networks' fault that name-calling became the principal campaign theme, they say; it was the candidates'.
"I think it's much improved over '88," Tim Russert, senior vice president of NBC News, said of the reporting this year. "But the tone of the campaign forced us to cover the shooting back and forth. We started out very much on the issues, but when the candidates got off the issues and got into the attacks and counterattacks, we had to go with them."
But even network executives confessed that they were "taken aback" by the debate on the "Donahue" show April 6, the day before the New York primary, when Governor Clinton and Mr. Brown questioned each other without a moderator.
"It was so interesting that on 'Donahue,' with no interlocutor, all the talk was about issues, as opposed to when somebody else was asking the questions, and then there were absolutely no issues involved," Mr. Venardos of CBS said.
To be sure, even the most vehement critics of the campaign reporting this year give the networks credit for some gains over 1988. For example, there has been little reporting of the kind of photogenic events, like flag factory visits, that were so popular with the Bush campaign four years ago.
But the soul searching that followed the 1988 campaign, and the efforts this year to elevate the public debate, make this year's lapses all the more significant in the eyes of critics. They question whether the unwritten rules of journalism in general, and television journalism in particular, allow for the kind of consistently substantive reporting that news executives insisted they wanted to provide.
Since issues like the economy and health care remain constant, these critics argue, they will inevitably be sacrificed to the latest scandal by an industry that values newness and drama above public policy.
"The classic pattern we always see is before the public begins to focus, the media provides substance," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution. "As soon as the race gears up, the focus shifts to the horse race and the scandals. Once voters finally begin paying attention, they see the slash and burn and nothing else. So basically what we get is a vicious cycle."
 
Stressing Early Reporting
 Mr. Mann and other critics have also expressed growing concern about the disproportionate influence of early reporting. Candidates, they argue, once categorized by the news media, tend to receive only reporting that will reinforce that initial representation.
"You can empirically demonstrate that each candidate carves out a sort of niche," said S. Robert Lichter, co-director of the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington. "Each candidate gets defined in certain terms, and then everything is built around that initial definition. Once reporters decided that the character issue was most important for Bill Clinton, that's what was newsworthy. In theory, in a different world, Clinton could have been defined as a very issue-oriented candidate."
Out of the 189 reports on Mr. Clinton that were broadcast on network news leading up to the New York primary, more than half involved a discussion of "character," according to Mr. Lichter's organization. In contrast, out of the 85 reports featuring Mr. Brown, only 6 percent discussed "character."
If news organizations were to change their habits, of course, there is no guarantee that the public or even news media experts would respond enthusiastically. News executives argue, and some social scientists agree, that reporting of the campaign reflects the public's real tastes, rather than the idealized preferences they profess in public opinion surveys.
"People are both turned off by the media and attracted to it at the same time," Mr. West of Brown University said. If campaign reporting remained fixed on the weighty issues and ignored the scandals, he said, "it would probably be pretty boring."

HEADLINE: Dow Soars 25.94 to Second-Highest Close

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices staged a broad rally yesterday on encouraging economic news, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to its second-highest close.
The Dow jumped 25.94 points to close at 3,359.12 in heavy volume. The finish was just shy of the record of 3,366.50 set on April 16. 
Advancing issues more than doubled declining ones, 1,198 to 562, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Big Board's volume totaled 223.6 million shares, against 206.8 million on Wednesday, and the exchange's composite index rose 1.72 points to end at 228.30.
 
'Best of All Worlds'
 Traders looked at the latest economic news, which pointed to a slow climb out of the recession, and determined that "maybe the best of all worlds is a mediocre world -- a slow, sluggish recovery," said Jack Solomon, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company.
"A lot of companies have gotten lean and mean, and they don't need a fat-cat type of recovery because they've fired people and closed plants," he said.
The broader market was also higher. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.93 points, to 414.95, while the American Stock Exchange index finished 4.83 higher at 390.61. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index jumped 8.74 points, to 578.68.
Traders started yesterday's session in a positive mood after the Dow's rise of 25.26 on Wednesday. They were further encouraged by the latest economic reports from the Federal Government.
The index of leading economic indicators, the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge, edged up two-tenths of a percent in March, signaling slow but continued growth for later this year.
 
Other Data, Bonds Help
 The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits was unchanged during the third week in April, the fourth straight week without an increase.
The Commerce Department said orders to American factories jumped 1.6 percent in March, the largest rise in five months, which was far better than expected. Further signs of strength in manufacturing came from purchasing managers in the Midwest.
A stronger bond market added fuel to the rally.
Chrysler was one of the Big Board's most-active issues, falling 3/8, to 19 1/4, on a volume of 3.4 million shares. The No. 3 car maker said it had lost $13 million in the first quarter. Also on the active list was Ford Motor, which was down 3/8 at 45 3/8, after announcing a profit for the quarter on Wednesday.
 
I.B.M., Time Warner Up
 I.B.M. gained 2 5/8, to 90 3/4, and Time Warner rose 1 5/8, to 106, on news that they were working on a venture that would combine I.B.M.'s technological expertise with Time Warner's cable television system.
Du Pont was up 1 5/8, to 54 1/4, on surprisingly good earnings, while the General Re Corporation, an insurer, fell 7 3/8, to 81.
Oil stocks were on the rise, as crude prices soared to their highest level of the year.
Amoco was up 7/8, to 48 1/2; ARCO gained 2 3/4, to 111 1/2; Chevron rose 1 3/8, to 69 3/4; Exxon finished 3/4 higher at 60, and Mobil was up 3/4, to 64 5/8.
In addition, Occidental Petroleum rose 7/8, to 20 3/4; Pennzoil was up 1 5/8, to 48 3/8, and Texaco gained 1 3/4, to 62 1/4.

HEADLINE: Their Image Poisoned, The Serbs Voice Dismay

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30

 BODY:
Over an embassy dinner here the other day, a middle-aged woman who is a professor at one of Belgrade's leading universities spoke up passionately on the subject of Serbia and its battered image in the world.
"In 1914, we had so many friends in Europe and the United States, and again in 1941," she said, referring to the years when World War I and World War II erupted in the Balkans, and the Serbs aligned themselves with the Western allies. "In 1948, when Tito broke with Stalin, it was the same. Now, I have to ask myself, why do we not have any allies at all? Are we so terrible that the whole world has to turn its back on us?" 
 For 10 months, Serbia has borne the brunt of Western condemnation for fanning the civil wars in Croatia and in Bosnia and Herzegovina, two of the four republics of the old Communist Yugoslavia that have declared themselves independent. Over the last month, relentless offensives by Serbian paramilitary groups and by the Yugoslav Army, backing Bosnian Serbs in a contest for Bosnian territory, have brought the United States and the European Community to the brink of imposing diplomatic and economic sanctions on Serbia.
For the moment, the threat has receded. On Monday, Serbia joined the mountainous republic of Montenegro in proclaiming a new Yugoslav state less than half the size of Communist Yugoslavia, with a Constitution that defined the new state's territory as that of Serbia and Montenegro only. This was accompanied by a declaration that the new Yugoslavia has "no territorial claims" on its neighboring republics, a pledge to settle all disputes peacefully, and statements by senior Serbian officials that they expect Bosnian Serbs to become loyal citizens of an independent Bosnian state.
If the pledges are honored, Serbia, accounting for 9.8 million of the 10.5 million inhabitants of the new Yugoslavia, stands a strong chance of having the new Yugoslav state recognized by the Western powers, and eventually of regaining the renown Serbia has long enjoyed in the Western world.
Serbian offensives in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have resulted in large numbers of civilian casualties, including summary executions of groups of men, women and children. But before then, Serbia was associated in Balkan history as much as anything with its struggles for freedom -- against the Ottoman Empire during nearly 500 years of Turkish rule, on the Allies' side in World War I, and against the Nazis in World War II.
For many Serbs, the poisoning of Serbia's image has been deeply painful, worse even than the steep plunge in living standards brought about by the old Yugoslavia's violent disintegration. Little pleases a Serb more than lingering over cups of thick Turkish coffee or thimble-glasses of shlivovica, a powerful plum brandy, telling visitors of the legends of old Serbia, beginning with the Battle of Kosovo in 1389 in which a Serb army went down to a glorious defeat by the invading Turks.
From Kosovo to Jasenovac, the World War II death camp in Croatia where hundreds of thousands of Serbs, Jews and gypsies were killed by the Ustashe fascists who ruled Croatia for the Nazis, the Serbs' sense of themselves as a people victimized by history has grown. Many Serbs believe that the fighting in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, on behalf of Serbs living outside Serbia, is a continuation of that history, a new example of Serbs having to take to arms to defend their homes, their Eastern Orthodox religion and their culture.
Among Croats in Croatia, and the Muslim Slavs and Croats who form the majority in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as among Westerners who have witnessed the fighting, this version of events is seen as a distortion. In this view, the notion of Serbs outside Serbia as mortally threatened by other ethnic groups has enabled some Serbs to support, or at least to rationalize, policies under which Serb paramilitary units have engaged in a campaign of terror against civilians, and the Serb-led Yugoslav Army has shelled ancient towns like Dubrovnik, Sarajevo and Vukovar.
In Serbia, too, the months of fighting have eroded popular support, even among people who backed the idea of supporting the Bosnian and Croatian Serbs. At least 100,000 young Serbian men have fled abroad or into hiding to avoid conscription into the Yugoslav Army, and many conversations with Serbs in Serbia quickly turn to expressions of disgust at outrages by Serbian forces. While most Serbs insist that the atrocities have been matched by the Croats and the Muslim Slavs, there is a strong sense among Serbs that what has happened has besmirched Serbia's name.
 
Dismay Is Widespread
 The dismay has spread even among those considered to be supporters of Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President. Dobrica Cosic, the writer of novels about Serbia in the two world wars, said that while the fighting in Bosnia and Croatia had been started by the Croats and Muslim Slavs, Serbia would rue what it had done in response.
"I cannot accept that we Serbs are satanists and criminals and barbarians," he said, referring to what he described as one-sided Western reporting on the fighting. "But I am deeply unhappy that our role has been tainted by these criminal acts."
To many Serbs, blame for what has happened rests heavily with Mr. Milosevic, who runs an authoritarian Government like the Communist one that ruled here for 45 years. Mr. Milosevic first showed his colors in the early 1980's with inflammatory rallies in Kosovo, an autonomous region of Serbia where Serbs and Montenegrins are outnumbered nearly 10 to 1 by ethnic Albanians. When Communism's collapse across Eastern Europe ignited nationalist passions in all of the Yugoslav republics, the 52-year-old Serbian leader inflamed the situation by declaring that all Serbs had the right to live under Serbian rule.
To many Serbs, this was dangerous, since it implied the wholesale redrawing of the Balkan map, extending Serbia's borders to enfold the 580,000 Serbs scattered across Croatia and the 1.4 million Serbs who live in even more dispersed communities across Bosnia.
 
Reunion 'an Impossible Dream'
 For Bogdan Bogdanovic, a Serbian architect, the sense of the vulnerability of Serbs was heightened by the commission he received to design the monument to the victims of fascism at Jasenovac, the wartime death camp. He described the idea of reuniting Serbs under one government as "an impossible dream," adding, "The only way that could ever have been accomplished was by war."
Because Serbs are the most widely dispersed of the Balkan peoples, Serbian intellectuals were a major force from the early 19th century behind the idea of a nation that would unite all south Slavs. That idea became reality in 1918, with the formation of the first Yugoslavia, a kingdom that ended with the Nazi invasion in 1941. On Monday, at the ceremony that marked the formal end of the second Yugoslavia, the one founded as a Communist state in 1946, at least one Serbian present said Mr. Milosevic, by making the survival of the second Yugoslavia impossible with his aggressive Serbian nationalism, had done more to undermine the Serbs' search for security than any other figure in Serbian history.
Many Serbs, including Mr. Cosic, the novelist, believe that the nations formed from Yugoslavia's break-up will rebuild some of the links that have been shattered, perhaps in a confederation of independent states similar to that formed from the republics of the former Soviet Union. But they also say the task will have been made much harder by the blood spilled in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. In the meantime, Serbs in both republics must live with the consequences of what has been done on their behalf, and many Serbs in Serbia acknowledge that the Bosnian and Croatian Serbs are worse off now than they were before the fighting started.
In Croatia, at least 300,000 Serbs have been driven from their homes as refugees, dozens of predominantly Serbian towns and villages have been devastated, and Serbia has signed a United Nations-brokered cease-fire, undertaking to withdraw or disarm all Serbian forces.
In Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a mass migration still under way, about 500,000 people have become refugees, many of them Serbs, and the harmony that existed between Serbs, Croats and Muslim Slavs in many of the towns seized by Serbian forces has been brutally disrupted.

HEADLINE: House Votes Lean Budget But Short of Weicker Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 30

 BODY:
Connecticut's House of Representatives tonight approved a budget that imposes deep cuts in welfare, education aid to municipalities and other social programs, but that stops short on many of the more ambitious spending overhauls proposed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. The vote was 85 to 66.
Majority Democrats said that the compromises were a key to passing a budget at all, and that cutting any more would have ravaged the poor and the already troubled cities that would have had to pick up the burden. Republicans, who supported Mr. Weicker's initial proposal, called the revised budget a betrayal. 
 "What happened to the year of reform, my friends?" asked Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican from Darien and the ranking member on the Appropriations Committee. "The reforms disappeared and the year is still here."
The $8.08 billion budget would not remove people from General Assistance welfare rolls after six months, as Mr. Weicker wanted. Instead, indigent residents would get nine months of relief and be offered a series of job training programs. Adding those to the budget cost $52 million.
 
Total Is Near Weicker's
 Altogether the House added more than $250 million to Mr. Weicker's original budget, primarily by changing the formula on contributions to the state pension fund and by reducing payments on bonds issued last year. But cuts in other mostly nonsocial spending programs, including the Department of Correction, which runs the prison system, left the bottom line fairly close to Mr. Weicker's.
The budget avoids a statewide tax increase -- a priority from the beginning in a year when all 187 members of the General Assembly are up for re-election -- although municipal officials have said for months that the contention of avoiding a tax rise is a sham because local property taxes will have to go up anyway to compensate for many of the cuts.
Supporters also argued tonight in selling their plan that it was still tough, even if it was not quite in the Governor's league. General assistance recipients judged employable, for instance, would from the start get $60 a month less than people deemed unemployable. The categories take into consideration physical and mental abilities to obtain and hold a job.
Overall, benefits would be cut to $296 to $356 a month after July 1, from $400 to $450 a month now. Local communities, which now pay 10 percent of general assistance costs, would pay 20 percent; Mr. Weicker had wanted a 33.3 percent contribution from the towns.
 
Sharp Cuts in School Aid
 Many communities would also see sharp cuts in education aid because of changes in formulas. Many affluent suburbs of Hartford, and those across Fairfield County, would see their education cost-sharing grants fall more than 90 percent. But those levels are also a moderation: Under Mr. Weicker's plan, some towns would have ended up owing education money to the state.
Last year, Mr. Weicker, a third-party independent Governor, proposed an overhaul of the tax system, then vetoed three budgets until he got the one he wanted. He declined to comment in detail early today about the House budget because he said he had not had a chance to study it.
But in comments to reporters earlier in the day, Mr. Weicker praised lawmakers for their work in reaching a budget agreement. By contrast, last year Mr. Weicker was more likely to disparage lawmakers for their lack of backbone, and he made his intentions to veto the budget plainly known well in advance.
Senate leaders, who said the budget would probably be considered on Friday in their chamber, said tonight that the bill might be amended and sent back to the House, but that the basic agreement over the plan reached earlier this week was still holding up.
 
Shaking Heads in Wonder
 And that in itself had lawmakers shaking their heads in wonder. Many legislators had said earlier this year that a budget agreement would simply be impossible. With both parties fractured by last year's prolonged struggle over the question of imposing a tax on wages, they said that building a majority around deep spending cuts would simply open old wounds. The wage tax was passed in August by a slim bipartisan majority, and lawmakers were in special session as recently as December trying to repeal it.
But it was clear tonight inside the ornate Hall of the House as the eight hour debate wore on that the mechanics and internal politics of the legislature had reverted to traditional party lines. Democrats voted in lock step to defeat several Republican amendments, and every time the unbroken line of red lights appeared on the voting boards, members of the majority broke into cheers.
Democrats control the House 87 seats to 64 for the Republicans. Mr. Weicker's independent party, called A Connecticut Party, has no representation in the House.
"One of the things that I feel proudest of is that we have been able to bring the process back to a semblance of order," said Representative William R. Dyson, a Democrat from New Haven and the co-chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
But within the Democratic majority, there were still some echoes of last year's fights. The moderate Democrats, who crossed the aisle last year to form a majority coalition with the Republicans in vote after vote, balked only this week over a last-minute concern about the deferral of the pension-fund payment.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
H.I.V. ON THE RISE AMONG BLACK WOMEN
The rate of H.I.V. infection has risen among black women having babies in New York City, while it has dropped sharply among white and Hispanic mothers, the State Health Department said. The finding prompted a health official to warn that unless AIDS education efforts among blacks are more successful, "AIDS in future generations may be primarily a disease of black people." B3.
 
SIGNS OF AN ECONOMIC TURNAROUND
The financial vise that has been gripping many New York City companies may finally be easing, according to recent data collected by Dun & Bradstreet Information Services. The data provide new evidence that the local economy may be improving, and, surprisingly, at a faster rate than the rest of the nation. B3.
 
CUOMO'S MAN FROM LIMERICK 
 It's a long way from the thatch-roofed cottage in Limerick, Ireland, where Michael J. Dowling grew up to the office in Albany where he serves as Governor Cuomo's director of health, education and human services. But Mr. Dowling's journey out of poverty left him with both a personal compassion for the poor and a pragmatic approach to government that has left a lasting imprint on New York's social policy. B4.
 
TROUBLE FOR GOTTI'S LAWYER
John Gotti's longtime lawyer, Bruce Cutler, has been ordered to appear in court to face an unusual charge of criminal contempt for public comments he made before the recent Gotti trial. Among other things, Mr. Cutler was quoted as saying that the Government was engaging in a "continuing vendetta" against Mr. Gotti, that "they threw the Constitution out the window" in his case, that the Government's witnesses were "bums" and that "John Gotti is loved more than anyone else in the city." B3.
 
Livery-cab drivers seek police protection. B6.

DEATH PENALTY DRAWS SUPPORT
By overwhelming margins, the New Jersey Assembly adopted a package of bills to make it more difficult for state courts to overturn death sentences. Among them is a proposed amendment to the state constitution declaring that the death penalty is not cruel and unusual punishment. B5.
 
AT ODDS OVER THE COMMUTER TAX
A decision by Republicans in the New Jersey Senate to call off a threatened commuter tax war with New York City has touched off a fight with a Democratic state senator who wants to proceed with a retaliatory tax. "Why should New Jersey pull its punch now?" said Senator Robert Menendez, who is running for Congress. "We shouldn't let our guard down." A Republican Senator, declaring the commuter tax war "a dead issue," accused Mr. Menendez of political grandstanding. B5.
 
A RULING ON HOW WETLANDS ARE TAXED
In a decision that could cost municipalities millions of dollars, a state tax court judge has ruled that New Jersey's wetlands must be taxed as undevelopable land, not on its potential commercial value. The case involved a 240-acre tract in the Meadowlands, near Giants Stadium, and the judge reduced its assessed valued to $1 million, from $20 million. B5.

HEADLINE: Bigger Business Role Urged in Prenatal and Maternal Care

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Business is increasingly recognizing that the health of employees is as important as fever lines on stock charts in determining long-term competitiveness and profitability.
At the Corporate Summit for Children today, some 200 business leaders cited the need for involvement by Corporate America in prenatal and maternal health care to insure that the nation's work force can compete in the global economy. 
 For most employers, expenses related to childbirth are the largest single portion of health-care costs, ranging from 10 to 49 percent. Because nearly 60 percent of women with children now remain in the work force, low birth weight, lack of immunization and poor overall health care can continue to contribute to a company's health-care costs long after a child is born.
"Business is spending $800 billion on health care, and we're not getting our money's worth," said Dr. Mary Jane England, president of the Washington Business Group on Health, a national not-for-profit organization of employers interested in health issues.
The Cigna Corporation, a large operator of employee health-insurance plans and the sponsor of the conference, released two studies that said problem births cost American businesses $5.6 billion each year in insured health-care costs for mothers and infants. Another $4 billion is passed along to businesses through insurance costs to pay for uncompensated health care for America's poorest mothers and their newborns. About 34 million Americans are not covered by any insurance, including 11 million children.
G. Robert O'Brien, a Cigna executive vice president, said the studies by Georgia State University and the Center for Health Policy Studies in Maryland showed that "strong prenatal education and care programs for all women will ultimately save billions of dollars and, more importantly, save thousands of infants' lives."
 
More Cost Efficient
 Dr. England and other health officials and business leaders at the conference emphasized that preventive care was more cost efficient than later medical care. Part of the purpose of the conference, she said, was to honor corporations that have innovative health plans. These included Honeywell, I.B.M. and Levi Strauss.
Yet last year, many businesses were vocal opponents of the Family and Medical Leave Act, legislation in Congress that would have provided some preventive-health care options. Dr. England said that while large corporations recognized a connection between health care and performance, small businesses were often put off by the cost.
National health-care reform has become an issue of national debate in the last decade as the costs of care and insurance spiraled. President Bush and both the leading Democratic presidential candidates are offering health-care plans.
Plans under discussion include everything from replacing the present system with a universal system similar to one in Canada to reforms that would require employers to pay for health care for their workers or pay into an overall fund.
Last year, executives from A.T.& T., Honeywell and BellSouth urged Congress to increase spending for Federal programs that promote better nutrition for pregnant woman and infants.
At today's conference, Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida said businesses in his state had recognized the connection and helped lobby for new money for a prenatal program.
Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, said Florida had added $91 million to a prenatal program in its 1990 budget at a time when $2 billion was being cut. In the following 18 months, the state's infant mortality rate dropped from 9.5 percent to 8.9 percent.
"We think there is a definite causal connection," Mr. Chiles said. Florida is one of several states experimenting with voluntary universal coverage.
Mr. Chiles, chairman of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, said that everyone had a stake in providing access to care for all children and pregnant women.
He added that today's conference was a starting point for further involvement by the business community. "This is not a one-shot deal," the Governor said, "but rather the beginning of a movement to improve the health and well-being of children and families."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Coffee Prices at 17-Year Low As Oversupply Is Perceived

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Coffee prices tumbled yesterday to the lowest levels in 17 years on widespread perceptions of a world oversupply that could send prices lower still.
 The fall came despite a lower forecast for Brazil's crop, the world's largest, by the commodity trade house E. D. & F. Man. The estimate for Brazil's 1992-93 crop predicted a harvest of 18.7 million 60-pound bags, a figure that was at the low end of other recent estimates.
 
 July coffee declined 1.30 cents, to 62.90 cents a pound, in heavy trading at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. Prices have not been this low since the summer of 1975.
 The expiring May contract in sugar futures led the slide in sugar prices, as speculators sold futures to avoid the obligation to make delivery.
 May sugar lost 0.46 cent to close at 9.45 cents a pound.
 Traders said the weak close could signal lower sugar prices ahead for succeeding contracts. "I think this will be viewed negatively," one said.
 At New York's Commodity Exchange, July silver edged above the $4-an-ounce level, rising 3.2 cents, to $4.0125.
 Gold also advanced, although traders said the rally might be short-lived. June gold firmed $1.50, to $337.90 an ounce.
"There is no interest in the market," said a Merrill Lynch analyst, William O'Neill.
 Platinum was the strongest of the three precious metals, as Japanese investors were rumored to be active overnight and optimism about a rebounding United States economy generated interest in the metal.
 A 1.6 percent rise in March factory orders strengthened sentiment that more platinum will soon be needed by industry.
 July platinum rose $4.60, to $347.40 an ounce, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 Technical factors and a spurt of buying by commodity funds lifted energy futures at the same trading exchange.
 Light sweet crude oil gained 8 cents, to $20.85 a barrel. "The market clearly wants to challenge $21" in the June contract, one trader said.
 May heating oil, on the final day of trading before the contract expired, advanced 0.88 cent, to 57.85 cents a gallon. May gasoline, which also expired at the close, rose 0.42 cent, to 63.16 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Companies in New York Are Paying Bills More Swiftly, Data Show

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
The financial vise that has been gripping many New York City companies may finally be easing, according to recent data collected by Dun & Bradstreet Information Services. The data provide new evidence that the local economy may be improving, and, surprisingly, at a faster rate than the rest of the nation.
"We're finally seeing some turnaround," said David Kresge, a vice president at the company. Mr. Kresge bases his optimism on two measures that are showing improvement: the speed with which companies have been paying their bills and the number of companies that are expected to have credit problems over the next 6 to 12 months. 
 The improvement is good news at a time when many economic forecasters are still maintaining that New York -- hard hit by cutbacks in service industries and manufacturing -- will likely lag behind the rest of the nation in recovering from the recession.
Throughout 1990, companies in New York City generally paid their bills at about the same rate as companies nationally. However, in 1991, the cash available to New York companies apparently deteriorated sharply, for businesses began paying their suppliers at substantially slower rates than their national counterparts. Now that trend seems to have reversed.
 
A Ripple of Late Payments
 Late payments can have a severe ripple effect: because some companies cannot pay their suppliers, their suppliers, in turn, cannot pay the companies that were servicing them, and so on. The end result is often bankruptcies, particularly for small companies that do not have the financial cushion to survive long periods without being paid for work that has often already been performed. Indeed, bankruptcies in New York City rose sharply in 1991, claiming 2,423 victims, a 78 percent increase over the previous year.
Since the end of last year, however, Dun & Bradstreet has detected considerable improvement in the rate at which companies in the city are paying their bills.
Although the percentage of those paying more slowly than they were previously still exceeds the number that are paying more promptly, the population of slower-paying companies is shrinking. The data are based on the actual bill-paying performance of about 125,000 companies in the city that is provided to Dun & Bradstreet by suppliers, rather than by companies themselves.
Dun & Bradstreet also has developed a computer model to help it identify companies that are likely to have problems paying their bills in the future. By that measure, the financial fortunes of New York City businesses also seem to be improving, leading Mr. Kresge to believe that the improvement evident in the historical data will continue.
 
Worse Record Nationally
 In a normal economy, Dun & Bradstreet has identified about 30 percent of all companies nationally as being high-risk billpayers, that is, likely to pay bills after 90 days or longer. Last December, 40 percent more New York businesses than normal fell into that high-risk category. But by March, that percentage had fallen to 27 percent greater than normal.
Mr. Kresge found that the prospects for New York companies' bill-paying performance are substantially brighter than those for the nation as a whole. In March, 33 percent more companies than normal were expected to have trouble paying their bills over the next 6 to 12 months, the same level reported in December.
"Over one-quarter of the firms we looked at nationally have at least one bill that is past due by at least 90 days," said Mr. Kresge. "That's really very late."

HEADLINE: Expensive Homes;
Move-Up Buyers May Be Returning

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: RANDOLPH, N.J.

 BODY:
After a slow start, the pace of sales at two expensive single-family home communities in western Morris County is picking up, suggesting that move-up buyers, long absent from the market, are returning.
"It is still a tough sell, but the projects are moving," said Andrew B. Abramson, president of the Value Group of Clifton, the developer. 
 Mr. Abramson credits the rise in sales to lower interest rates and to increasing buyer confidence in the economy. He also said that the willingness of first-time buyers to purchase existing homes had "eased the logjam" for move-up buyers, who had been unable to purchase new homes until they had sold their old ones.
A total of 56 semi-custom, four- and five-bedroom, mostly colonial-style homes are planned at the two communities, which are a 75-minute drive from Manhattan. They have from 2,800 to 5,000 square feet of space and such standard features as a fireplace, three-car garage and two-story entrance. The architects are Kitchen & Associates of Westmont and Stern, Ring & Associates of Livingston, both in New Jersey.
At the 50-acre Rickland Estates at Shongum in Randolph, not far from the intersection of Route 10 and Franklin Road, the 32 homes sit on 1- to 1.5-acre lots and cost from $397,900 to $627,900. Since sales began in early 1991, contracts have been signed or are pending on 17 homes, seven of them in the last four months, said Mary Boorman, director of sales and marketing at the Value Group.
At the 75-acre Rickland Estates at Flanders in Mount Olive close to Route 46, there are 24 homes on two- to five-acre wooded lots. Because it is farther west where land is less expensive, these houses carry lower price tags -- $289,000 to $400,000. In the six months since sales began, contracts have been signed on four homes.
The two projects, Mr. Abramson said, offer the same basic house with a range of extras to draw additional buyers. Selling prices are negotiable -- now about 1 percent off the selling price, down from 4 percent last year, Ms. Boorman said.
"A pent-up demand from buyers has spurred sales for new and existing houses in all price ranges," said Gail Goggin, president of the Morris County Board of Realtors. "They have more faith in the economy and recognize that now is a favorable time to buy."
Last month there were 324 sales in the county, up from 219 a year ago, she said, adding that the average sales price of all forms of housing was $235,189.
The market's modest improvement has led a cadre of builders with financial strength to return to home construction. State figures show that 1,103 housing permits were issued in the county last year, up from 733 in 1990. And in the first two months of this year the number swelled to 381 from 55 for the 1991 period.
There are two primary appeals to living in the 477-square-mile county. It is only an hour's drive from midtown Manhattan, easily accessible over interconnecting Routes 80, 287 and 46. There are also job possibilities in the myriad office buildings in the area. Projections are that by the year 2000 the population in the county will grow by 15,120, to 436,473, and it will gain 304,100 new jobs.
Officials in both Randolph and Mount Olive, in the western part of Morris County, said activity was on the rise, with some builders rekindling developments stalled by the recession and others looking to take over troubled projects. To prepare for the next round of growth, master plans are being revised that call for, among other things, limiting high-density development and preserving open space.
Some of the undeveloped land in the communities is subject to environmental constraints to protect wetlands and steep slopes. Those areas are protected by state law or local ordinances and will help keep development in check.
The Value Group, using its own equity, purchased the two tracts for $3.7 million in 1989 and 1990. The land came with already approved site plans made by the prior owners. The company got a $6 million construction loan from the Valley National Bank of Wayne, N.J. The homes, which take six months to construct, are being built at a pace that keeps production just two houses ahead of sales.
Five models are being offered at both projects, and for an additional cost buyers can customize their homes. Residents at Rickland Estates at Shongum can go swimming and boating at the 80-acre Shongum Lake, half a mile away. The entrance fee is about $550 and annual dues are $200.
John and Nancy Soriano, both 36 years old, sold their four-bedroom house in Mount Olive and expect to move into a larger one at Rickland Estate at Shongum in August. He is a physician and she cares for their four children. "We needed more space, and, with interest rates favorable, it was an appropriate time for us to buy," Mrs. Soriano said. "Otherwise, we could not afford this much of a house."

HEADLINE: Panel Votes to Preserve 2 Seawolf Submarines

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to preserve two Seawolf submarines President Bush wanted to eliminate but still cut $424 million more in Federal spending than the Administration had proposed.
The committee action reflected conflicting trends. Members of Congress are forced to demonstrate support for programs that provide jobs. But they also want to appear to be greater cutters of pork-barrel spending than the President and to back a balanced Federal budget. 
 President Bush proposed four bills by which Congress would take back money it had already appropriated, covering more than 100 programs totaling $7.86 billion. The Senate panel voted 19 to 9 to augment those cuts, known as recisions, with additional cuts of $189 million in domestic spending, $172 million in international aid and $63 million in military spending.
The committee decided to go ahead with constructing the Seawolf submarines at a cost of $2.9 billion by cutting $1.3 billion in Strategic Defense Initiative research and $1 billion in B-2 bomber expenditures instead.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is chairman of the committee, said Mr. Bush "threw down the gauntlet" by proposing the cutbacks and Congress was forced to react.
Among the items cut by the committee were more than $500 million in excess Defense Department inventories and executive salaries, as well as hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of Federal grants, including some for studies like one on the mating behavior of swordfish and another on ways of measuring patients' fear of dentists.
The committee decided to cut permanently $39 million in military aid to Peru, which the Administration had merely suspended in protest of President Alberto K. Fujimori's dissolving his country's Congress and judiciary April 5.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said that money could go toward paying compensation to the family of an airman who was killed when Peruvian combat planes opened fire on an American military aircraft last week.
The hottest debate was over the two submarines, part of the Seawolf program being phased out by the Administration. Several Republicans argued that in the post-cold-war world the United States needs sophisticated antimissile defenses in the sky far more than sophisticated submarines under the oceans.
But the Democratic majority disagreed, in part because the Seawolf program provides more jobs. Senator Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, estimated that the committee action could save 7,500 jobs, most of them in Connecticut, or 3,500 more than are jeopardized by the accompanying cuts in the "Star Wars" and B-2 programs. The submarines are to be built in Groton, Conn., by the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics Corporation.
Republican Senators Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, Don Nickles of Oklahoma and Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York joined the Democrats in voting for the Democratic alternative.
"Congress is finally getting the message that we better wake up and get a grip on spending," said Mr. D'Amato, explaining his vote in an interview. "I predict a constitutional amendment will be passed and eventually lead the Congress to make decisions it was heretofore unlikely to make, especially with the growth of entitlements."
Still, the New York Republican was quick to take credit in a news release after the committee meeting for removing a cut of upgraded engines for F-14 warplanes that was planned for Grumman Corporation. The reduction would have cost the Long Island economy $143 million over five years, he said. He also noted that the Seawolf program would benefit subcontractors in Syracuse, Buffalo, Westchester, Elmira and Long Island.
 
The Next Steps
 Before the Democratic bill can be enacted it must be passed by the full Senate and reconciled with a House version.
On Wednesday, the House Appropriations Committee considered three of the four Administration measures and proposed adding $100 million more in cuts than the White House had asked for. The House committee voted to save one of the two Seawolf submarines.
Whatever cuts are eventually passed will be too small to significantly dent the nearly $400 billion budget deficit. The cuts made will affect programs in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
Next Campaign Stop Is Indiana, a Friendly State (to Clinton, That Is)

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, April 30

 BODY:
It is a wonder that Edmund G. Brown Jr. even bothers with Indiana.
This is one of the few states where party organizations retain most of their power, and Gov. Evan Bayh has thrown the Democratic Party apparatus solidly behind the former California Governor's front-running rival for the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. 
 The popular, 35-year-old Mr. Bayh is not the only heavy hitter working hard for Mr. Clinton in the run-up to the state's primary on Tuesday; so is the executive director of the state party, Ann Delaney, who refers to the Clinton campaign as "we." Her husband, Edward O. Delaney, is listed as Mr. Clinton's state coordinator. Three of the state's eight Democratic members of the House, including the highly influential Representative Lee H. Hamilton, are also in the Arkansan's corner.
Mr. Clinton, who has made only one appearance here so far, has offices in four cities in the state; Mr. Brown has none. Mr. Clinton comes into the Indiana campaign with all the advantages of solid victories in New York and Pennsylvania; Mr. Brown has not won since Connecticut on March 24.
 
Cautious Kind of Voters
 And to top it all off, Indiana is Mr. Clinton's kind of state.
Hoosiers are a culturally cautious lot, more turned off than voters in many other states by the former California Governor's interest in Buddhism and his unconventional dress. A visitor hears the mocking nickname "Governor Moonbeam" everywhere. What's more, the southern half of the state behaves politically like a Southern state, giving Indiana as a whole a decidedly conservative cast.
"There's not a lot of anti-incumbent, anti-insider sentiment here, so Brown can't count on that," said Mary Beth Schneider, The Indianapolis Star's politics writer. "We don't have anyone in the House who wrote 300 bad checks, we don't have anyone who beat up on Anita Hill and we don't have a Governor who's raised taxes."
Governor Bayh has, in fact, led a major Democratic comeback in the state by holding the line on major taxes and cutting government spending. Republicans now hold the two Senate seats and a one-vote majority in the State Senate, but not much else.
Mr. Brown, who qualified for the ballot in Indiana only when the sheet-metal workers' union agreed at the last minute to circulate his petitions, presses on anyway. He flew directly to Indianapolis from Pennsylvania for a rally Tuesday night, and he is to be back this weekend, with stops scheduled for Fort Wayne and for northwest Indiana, near Chicago.
"Clinton is getting very close, but he's not there yet," he acknowledged here this week. "We're here because in a democratic society there's got to be a debate. Issues have got to be raised and fought over."
 
Little Behind Candidacy
 As he had in his final speech in Philadelphia, the former California Governor looked beyond the current test, even beyond the June 2 primary in his own state, which will end the long series of nominating battles. After "the last gavel" of the Democratic National Convention, he said, "we build a movement and a cause to restore real democracy based on the American people controlling their government."
But every politician and political observer interviewed here agreed with the comment of Mrs. Delaney, the party executive director, who said of the Brown campaign, "There's nothing there but the candidate himself."
"I'd be very startled if Clinton didn't roll up a very impressive margin in percentage terms, although the turnout will be very low and a lot of people will vote for him without much conviction," said Prof. Leroy Rieselbach of Indiana University's political science department. "Brown doesn't generate much excitement, except in the academic enclaves around Purdue, Notre Dame and this place, and even here it's not very much."
Indiana, which chooses 77 Democratic delegates, is one of three states with primaries scheduled Tuesday. North Carolina chooses 84 and the District of Columbia chooses 17.
With his Pennsylvania victory, even slightly clouded as it was by many Democrats' continuing doubts about his electability, Mr. Clinton appears to be unstoppable, even if Mr. Brown were to win California, which most party leaders think less and less likely. But Mr. Clinton is holding to his intention of campaigning everywhere, partly to introduce himself to voters for the fall campaign against President Bush and probably H. Ross Perot.
"People in Indiana want to participate," said Jeffrey Watson, Mr. Clinton's state director. "They don't want to be taken for granted. So we will make every effort to let voters here get to know Governor Clinton."
So Mr. Clinton will campaign in New Albany, across the Ohio River from Louisville, Ky., on Sunday, then head to Indianapolis for appearances on Monday. A stop at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend is also under discussion, Mr. Watson said.
Occasionally in the past, Indiana has had spirited Presidential primaries. A notable example was the turbulent 1968 campaign, when Robert F. Kennedy defeated Eugene J. McCarthy and Gov. Roger Branigin, running as a stand-in for Lyndon B. Johnson in an effort to stop Mr. Kennedy. The Indianapolis newspapers, owned by Vice President Dan Quayle's family, took a harshly anti-Kennedy line.
But alas, no such zesty melodrama is likely to develop this time. Neither candidate has run any television commercials, and it seems doubtful that either will. No television confrontations are scheduled. About the biggest excitement of the primary, one leading Democrat said, has been the appearance in the last few days of big red "Perot" buttons on a lot of lapels in downtown Indianapolis.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Down Marginally Despite Favorable Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell marginally in quiet dealings yesterday, with traders ignoring economic news that might otherwise have benefited the currency.
Dollar trading was virtually unaffected by several reports that showed an improving economy. Such reports often strengthen the dollar. 
 John McCarthy, chief currency dealer for Algemene Bank Nederland in New York, attributed some of the dollar's decline to traders who were selling the currency to take profits. He also said technical factors played a role.
In addition, some traders trimmed their holdings in the face of a three-day May Day holiday in Europe that starts today.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 133.38 Japanese yen, from 133.07 on Tuesday. The Japanese market was closed Wednesday for a national holiday. In London, the dollar fell to 133.32 yen. In New York, the dollar weakened to 133.25 yen, from 133.50 late Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7755, from $1.7700 late Wednesday. In New York, one pound cost $1.7780, more expensive than $1.7725 the day before.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with rates late Wednesday, included: 1.6480 marks, down from 1.6575; 1.5105 Swiss francs, down from 1.5210; 1.1924 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1946; 5.5600 French francs, down from 5.5875, and 1,239 lire, down from 1,246.00.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.6530 German marks, down from 1.6560; 1.5175 Swiss francs, down from 1.5220; 5.5770 French francs, down from 5.5845; 1,241.75 Italian lire, down from 1,245.75; 1.1964 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1940.
