HEADLINE: A Free-Enterprise Plan for an Everglades Cleanup

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
Civilization is nowhere to be seen in the center of the state's Water Conservation Area 2A, a part of the Everglades just 20 miles west of the shopping malls and golf courses of suburban Palm Beach County. A half-dozen wading birds stalk their prey in the clear, shallow lagoon, a blue-gray contrast to the wet prairie of pale-green sawgrass stretching to the horizon.
A few miles north, though, closer to the pumps that drain irrigation water from sugar and vegetable farms into the great marsh, the scene is very different. Dense stands of cattails, nourished by traces of phosphorus used to fertilize lettuce, celery and sugar cane, have overwhelmed competing plants. The water is clouded with cattail debris, denying life-sustaining sunlight to the algae that anchor the Everglades' fragile food chain. 
 To many Floridians, this cattail invasion is a symbol of Big Agriculture's indifference to the environment. And they see the 1991 legal settlement requiring the state to purify the runoff at the farm owners' expense as a triumph of decency over greed.
 
Looking to Cut Costs by 75%
 But to economists working far from the rough-and-tumble of Florida's interest-group politics, the mandate to get the phosphorus out of Everglades waters is an opportunity to show that free markets can slash the cost of keeping America green. They have proposed a system of tradable pollution credits that would give farm owners incentives to find and use the cheapest possible phosphorus-removal methods. They contend that the plan, which they hope will win state approval, could get the job done for less than a quarter of the cost of a government cleanup.
Washington has given its stamp of approval to similar cost-conscious approaches for containing smog in Los Angeles and limiting emissions of acid rain nationwide. And the Everglades plan is already winning cautious praise from the Bush Administration.
"People want to realize both economic goals and environmental aspirations," said William K. Reilly, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency. "Trading is one of the most promising strategies."
 
Thousands of Jobs at Stake
 With thousands of jobs on the line in Florida's bitterly poor farm country, the South Florida Water Management District also seems ready to listen to alternatives to regulation-as-usual. "It doesn't matter how we get to the goal," said Peter Rhoads, the administrator of the cleanup, "as long as we get there soon."
The unique ecology of the Everglades is a product of the state's pancake-flat geography and subtropical seasons of wet and dry. During the rainy summer months, rivers from the north fill Lake Okeechobee, in the center of the state. From there, the water slowly drains south to the sea.
Before human intervention, the lake simply overflowed its southern bank each year, transforming all but a narrow ridge along the east coast of South Florida into what the environmentalist Marjory Stoneman Douglas called a "river of grass." Today, 1,400 miles of canals, built largely at Federal expense over the last 70 years, channel the water through a half-million acres of farmland and an equal area of suburban sprawl. The portion that does not evaporate ends up in the Everglades marsh, now protected by the state and Federal authorities in a series of parks and conservation areas.
 
Difficulty Mimicking Nature
 This multibillion-dollar plumbing system prevents floods, irrigates farms that produce much of the nation's sugar cane and winter vegetables and helps to slake the thirst of greater Miami. But it cannot precisely mimic nature in sustaining the wetlands. And for decades, environmentalists have asserted that the decline in both the quality and quantity of water entering protected areas is slowly degrading the Everglades into a garden-variety swamp.
In 1988, they got the ear of the United States Attorney in Miami, who sued the State of Florida to prevent phosphorus-laden water from reaching the jewel in the Everglades crown, the Everglades National Park. And in spite of protests from farm groups, the state settled the suit last July with a promise to convert a wide swath of agricultural land into filtration marshes. These "storm-water treatment areas" would be filled with phosphorus-gobbling plants that would remove virtually all the offending nutrient before it reached the part of the Everglades the state is trying to protect.
A 3,700-acre prototype is now under construction. But to remove the 100 tons of phosphorus as required in the legal settlement, the Water Management District plans to expand the filtration area to a total of 35,000 acres now used for farming.
 
Cost Estimated at $380 Million
 Paul Muncy, the district's financial expert, estimates that the acquisition of the land and the construction of the marshes could come to $380 million. A 1991 state law gives the district the authority to pass most of the costs on to the farm owners, through charges on each ton of phosphorus they discharge into public canals.
Such numbers are the stuff of nightmares for local farm owners, from vegetable growers with a few acres to mighty agribusinesses. Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute who is a consultant to the United States Sugar Corporation, the largest of the growers, estimates that the interest on bonds used to finance the treatment areas, plus operating expenses, would run to at least $34 million a year. That comes to $340,000 for each ton of phosphorus removed, a level at which Bob Buker, a vice president of the company, said, "all winter vegetables would become uneconomic."
Mr. Hahn, at the behest of United States Sugar, developed an alternative. Under the plan, the Water Management District would set a ceiling on total discharges of phosphorus and assign discharge credits to each farm in proportion to its acreage or historical rate of pollution. Farm owners would be free to meet their limit any way they liked, either cutting runoffs on their own or buying credits from others prepared to run super-clean operations.
 
Variety of Cheap Fixes
 The approach is attractive to Mr. Buker, because he is certain that United States Sugar can cut phosphorus output for a small fraction of the $340,000 a ton the Water Management District is likely to charge. The company runs two sugar mills, which could isolate several tons of phosphorus each year for just a few thousand dollars a ton. But every farm owner could probably count on finding a few relatively cheap fixes.
One is to monitor farm water levels more closely, thereby pumping a lower volume of dissolved phosphorus into public canals and stirring up a smaller volume of phosphorus-laden sediment from canal bottoms. Better pumping practices alone, Mr. Buker reckons, could reduce the amount of phosphorus reaching the Everglades by 58 tons a year, at a cost of just $13,000 a ton.
Another is to line canals with limestone, which chemically traps phosphorus dissolved in water. Potential savings: 42 tons at $147,000 a ton -- big money, indeed, but far less than the Water Management District would charge.
 
Agribusiness Figures at Issue
 Experts will no doubt dispute Mr. Buker's figures on both the potential reductions in phosphorus and cost savings from specific cleanup technologies. But one advantage of a system of trading pollution credits, Mr. Hahn notes, is that regulators do not call balls and strikes but certify only that the game was played by the rules.
Mr. Rhoads of the Water Management District agrees that monitoring the amount of phosphorus leaving each farm would be relatively cheap and easy. Farm owners could thus be held to their obligation to dump no more of the offending nutrient than the permits call for.
Outlining a system of trading pollution credits for the Everglades is one thing. Persuading the parties to the settlement to give a market-based solution a try is quite another.
In part, the reluctance to recast the agreement is based on issues of substance. Everyone agrees that phosphorus is only one source of damage to the Everglades. Other chemicals -- and probably more important, the timing and pattern of water flows -- may be responsible for much of the damage. And some environmentalists believe that filtration marshes would offer greater flexibility in curing the as-yet-undiagnosed malady.
A bigger problem is that the long battle over the farms' responsibility for damage to the wetlands has left environmentalists wary of dialogue that might only be an excuse for delay. "There's lots to talk about," said James Webb of the Wilderness Society's office in Miami. "I just don't feel like talking to those guys."
But this ill will is not likely to be a deal-stopper, if only because many environmental professionals think pollution-credit trading is just too good an idea to pass by. "No one in his right mind," said Zach Willey of the Environmental Defense Fund, should fight an approach that "would achieve environmental goals and save jobs and money at the same time."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Results Improve at Chrysler, But It Remains in the Red

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 30

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, in the midst of feverish efforts to improve consumer acceptance of its models and its financial stability, reported a sharply improved performance for the first quarter today. But unlike Ford and General Motors, which reported profits earlier in the week, the auto maker was unable to move into the black.
The No. 3 American car maker posted a loss of $13 million, on revenues of $8.19 billion, in contrast to a loss of $598 million, on revenues of $5.84 billion, in the comparable period last year. Both losses reflected large one-time gains from an accounting change relating to income taxes. 
 "The industry is starting to show some signs of recovery, but it's not coming back as fast as we'd like," said Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman and chief executive. "We couldn't overcome the cost of several new-product launches and other unusual events during the quarter."
Although analysts and investors are pleased at the progress Chrysler has made by introducing new models, cutting costs and raising more capital, the company still has major hurdles looming before it is out of danger.
"Chrysler still depends on the economy and auto sales improving, and they are very fragile, though improving," said Harvey Heinbach, the automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "The costs for product introduction are big, but they aren't going away."
Because of its large losses relative to its equity base, Chrysler has a far thinner financial cushion than the General Motors Corporation or the Ford Motor Company. Analysts remain concerned about Chrysler's financial subsidiary, the Chrysler Financial Corporation, which is negotiating new credit lines to replace financing that expires over two years.
Without revived sales and earnings, Chrysler could have trouble obtaining new credit from its bankers, which would jeopardize retail financing for its new models.
The Chrysler Financial Corporation posted a first-quarter profit of $111 million, including a one-time gain related to the new accounting standard for income taxes, up from a profit of $77 million last year.
 
Sells Mitsubishi Stake
 Also included in the quarter was a one-time net gain of $88 million from Chrysler's sale of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's common shares, reducing Chrysler's stake to 5.9 percent from 10.9 percent. Chrysler common shares fell 37.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today to finish at $19.25. And Chrysler recorded a one-time loss of $63 million in the first quarter, reflecting the loss on its investment in a Canadian real estate company, which it declined to name.
Last year's first-quarter loss was increased by a $257 million charge against earnings to reflect a change in accounting for sales incentives.
Like the rest of the domestic industry, Chrysler was able to improve financial performance mainly by increasing the sales volume of cars and trucks from factories to dealers. Last year, retail sales to individuals were only slightly lower, but dealers were liquidating inventories so they were not buying aggressively from the Big Three.
Chrysler's worldwide vehicle sales to dealers totaled 496,190 in the quarter, up 25.1 percent from 396,410.
The results were not surprising to Chrysler, which had predicted that its first-quarter results would be worse than those of the fourth quarter, when the car maker bested Ford and G.M. by posting a small profit as the others recorded losses.
On the positive side, the Chrysler's new Jeep Grand Cherokee model has received very favorable reviews since production began in January. Chrysler will soon begin promoting its L/H mid-sized sedans, three new car models aimed at the Ford Taurus, Honda Accord and others that some in the automotive industry have named "last hope."
Prototypes of the L/H models have received positive comments from indpendent testers, but Chrysler also needs a problem-free rollout of production vehicles from its plant in Bramalea, Ontario.

HEADLINE: Indicators Up by 0.2% In March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The Government index meant to forecast the economy posted its third straight gain in March, rising a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.
This latest reading of the index of leading indicators, combined with other statistics reported today on first-time jobless claims, factory orders and the rising activity of Chicago-area purchasing managers, was still further indication of an economic recovery that unlike last year's was very likely to be sustained. 
 "The risk of a triple-dip can almost be ignored," asserted Howard Keen, the chief economist for Conrail, the big freight carrier based in Philadelphia.
But while many analysts have been busy this week raising estimates for overall growth, with 3 percent for the year no longer regarded as unduly optimistic, most continued to point to relatively sluggish expansion in coming quarters.
 
A Cautious Outlook
 "No change to our slow-go outlook," C. J. Lawrence's team of economists told clients, adding that the first-quarter surge in consumer spending reported by the Government on Tuesday could not continue.
The March gain in the leading index was well under the nine-tenths of 1 percent average gain for January and February, with big gains for two components being largely offset by weakness elsewhere.
At the same time, a companion index gauging current economic activity was unchanged in March after a five-tenths of 1 percent February advance that broke a string of declines from October through January. The four components of the coincident index -- the non-farm payrolls, industrial production, manufacturing and trade sales and personal income excluding transfer payments -- were essentially the criteria used by the National Bureau of Economic Research to designate July 1990 as the start of the latest, and still officially unended, recession.
 
Confirmation of Trend
 Still another index, one that lags behind the economy at large and thus is seen as confirming a new direction, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, breaking a streak of 13 straight declines. The seven components of the index of lagging indicators are average duration of unemployment, the inventory-to-sales ratio, unit labor costs, the prime rate, bank loans, the ratio of consumer installment credit to income, and consumer prices.
The rise in the predictive index was paced by a big improvement in consumer expectations and a surge in the price of a group of materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle. Small positive contributions were made by a rise in contracts and orders for new plant and equipment and by an increase in the proportion of companies reporting slower deliveries from suppliers.
Six of the 11 components pulled the leading index down, the biggest drag being a drop in the M-2 money supply, which includes currency, checking accounts, savings accounts and money-market mutual funds.
Other negative forces were lower building permits, a fall in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods, lower unfilled orders for durable manufactured goods, a drop in stock prices and a rise in first-time claims, since reversed, for unemployment insurance.
The final component, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged in March.
 
'A Very Reliable Indicator'
 Mr. Keen of Conrail said one reason for his confidence that this year's economic pickup would not run out of steam was that April was the first month since the recession began in which there was both a rise in commodity prices and a decline in initial jobless claims. "This to me is a very reliable indicator," he added, citing what he called a nearly infallible record of moving with, though not ahead, of the economy.
Meanwhile, two predictive indicators compiled by private analysts also moved forward at latest reading. Safian Investment Research said its index had risen four-tenths of 1 percent, and Herzog Heine Geduld reported its Macro-Economic index had risen to plus 139 from 126 on a scale at which 50 signals recovery.
The ratio of the Government's coincident index to its lagging index -- regarded as a forecaster -- fell slightly after two straight gains.
The Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University, citing the strong correlation it has found between the length of a business expansion and the behavior of the prime rate at its outset, ventured today that the economy would grow for nearly three years from last year's trough, "or through early 1994."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Where Will East Find Foundations?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE euphoria that greeted the downfall of Communism in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union has given way to anxiety that it will take many years for these states to make the transition to effectively functioning market economies -- and some may not make it at all before dictatorship returns.
A major obstacle is the difficulty of supplying the enormous amount of capital that will be required for the capital stock of the countries in the East to reach the level of Western industrial nations. The requirements of the former East Germany alone, with a population of only 20 million, is expected to cost the German Government more than $50 billion a year for several years. 
 Nothing on that scale will be possible to meet the capital needs of the nearly 400 million people of Eastern Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States, which, by conservative estimate, will total $180 billion a year for 10 years.
The seven major industrial countries -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- this week endorsed a $24 billion aid package for Russia alone within the context of an agreed International Monetary Fund program for stabilizing the economy.
The problem of capital shortage is only one of the fundamental obstacles the former Communist states must overcome. They have to get rid of Stalinism's economic institutions if they are to move forward. In "Faulty Foundations: Soviet Economic Policies, 1928-1940," to be published next week by the Princeton University Press, Holland Hunter and Janusz M. Szyrmer describe that Stalinist legacy, which includes these shortcomings:
*An irrational structure of relative prices set by bureaucrats, which distorts the use of resources and breeds shortages and inefficiencies.
*A focus on physical output and an excessive emphasis on producer goods and monumental projects, to the neglect of intangible output, improvement in the quality of goods and services and environmental consequences.
*Obsolete plant and equipment, and poorly trained and motivated labor and mangement.
*Public suspicions of the old Communist leaders, agents, operatives and the "nomenklatura" -- the important officials and bureaucrats -- and public suspicions of the new capitalists, many of whom were drawn from the old order or from criminal elements of society.
"These new business efforts, surrounded as they are by graft, corruption and Mafia-like 'protection services,' need a legal system equipped to enforce a normal commercial code," Mr. Holland says. "At the same time the code should not be a cloak for maintaining the old planned-economy administrative controls over day-to-day business decisions. In the absence of a well-enforced commercial code, joint ventures with Western firms face discouraging prospects."
Conventional economic prescriptions for reforming the ex-Communist economies neglect the barriers to economic growth posed by the inadequate legal, moral and institutional foundations for an effective market economy, says Prof. Richard Rose of the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow, writing in the April issue of the Journal of Democracy, published by the Johns Hopkins University Press. The standard view taught in most American graduate economic departments that "a market is a market is a market, whether legal or not," may hold up tolerably well in Western economies, where illegality is the exception not the rule.
But in this transition period between Communism and capitalism, the systems are an inefficient and chaotic mixture of legal, nonlegal and parasiticial economies. Most households in Eastern Europe have people working in the official economy, subject to law, but with incomes insufficient to meet their basic needs. Mr. Rose quotes a Bulgarian saying of the day: "If you have to live from only one job, you will die." So most people turn to the illegal economies to make ends meet.
Achieving legitimacy and true civil societies, essential to the development of a market system in which domestic and international businesses can operate freely and effectively, must become the primary goal of countries in the former Soviet empire.
But how to achieve a more legitimate society? In an interview in New York yesterday, Anatoly A. Sobchak, the Mayor of St. Petersburg, who is a lawyer by profession, said: "Everyone thinks the answer is a quick fix -- greater coercion. But the best answer is to raise living standards."
A recent survey in Moscow, he said, found that 60 percent of female students were engaged in prostitution. In St. Petersburg, he said, the ratio is 30 percent. "You can't stop it by coercion," he added. "You've got to try something else. We have no proper legal framework. The problem is not having enough laws. Rather, as the German philospher Karl Jaspers said, 'It's not what we create on paper, but what we live by."

HEADLINE: Safety Net Savior

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 30

 BODY:
In his two-story house in one of Albany's most comfortable suburbs, Michael J. Dowling keeps a scale model of the thatch-roofed cottage that was his boyhood home in Limerick, Ireland. He built the model several years ago as a reminder of humble beginnings.
A large cooking fireplace provided the only heat in the three-room house, and a ditch in the yard served as the toilet. At night, rats would crawl out of the thatch to warm themselves by the embers. When it rained, water would seep through the thick mud walls, forming inch-deep puddles on the dirt floor. 
 It is a long way from that wee house in Limerick to Mr. Dowling's spacious office in the Capitol, where he is now Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services. In that job, he serves as the Governor's top adviser on everything from Medicaid to mental health and oversees agencies that spend almost two-thirds of the state's $30.8 billion budget.
But Mr. Dowling's journey out of poverty left him with both a personal compassion for the disadvantaged and a pragmatic approach to government. And that approach, which emphasizes self-help over dependency and incremental progress over grand vision, has left a lasting imprint on New York's social policy during the difficult days of the recession.
 
Fiscal Pressures
 "Nobody knows the poor better than Mike or feels for them more than Mike," Mr. Cuomo said in a recent interview. "But he's a person who knows life too, and knows that you can't always have all that you want at the moment."
That understanding has been critical to the 42-year-old Mr. Dowling's efforts to preserve New York's social safety net when there is increasing political pressure to shrink it.
In a nod to the fiscal constraints of the times, he has used a succession of tough budgets as a rationale for making the system more efficient. But he also has placed his linebacker's frame in the way of the kind of radical cuts in social-service programs being made in states from California to Massachusetts.
For a man whose greatest joy was once the creation of new programs, the sometimes frustrating mission of the last three years has been to protect what already exists.
"Given the bad budgets of the last couple of years, we've been able to maintain the core programs we feel are most important," Mr. Dowling said. "Nothing has been dismantled."
 
Expanding Portfolio
 But social-service advocates, while praising Mr. Dowling's commitment, said that the state's recurring budget problems had forced him to swallow hard over some decisions. "I think he's holding together what he can hold together," said Elie S. Ward, deputy director of Statewide Youth Advocacy. "In some cases he's being successful, and in other ways things are crumbling."
"The budget and the politics have put him in a position of having to defend things you can tell he doesn't want to defend," she added.
Many who work with Mr. Dowling, whose salary is $96,662, believe he is stretched too thin. As Mr. Cuomo has expanded Mr. Dowling's portfolio in the last year, it has fallen to Mr. Dowling to forge agreements between the Democratic-majority Assembly, which is highly protective of programs for the disadvantaged, and the Republican-led Senate, which sees the recession as an opportunity to cut social-service spending.
Last month, he brokered major components of the deal that produced $1.1 billion in savings from the state's Medicaid and welfare programs.
In the last year, Mr. Dowling directed the searches for the state's new health and social services commissioners. He worked with New York City officials to design new programs to move homeless people out of shelters and to fight outbreaks of tuberculosis and measles.
He helped design legislation to require Medicaid recipients to seek care from health maintenance organizations. He had a heavy influence on Mr. Cuomo's decision to keep private the names of health care workers who are infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. And Mr. Dowling successfully pushed to close underused mental hospitals in order to free money for community mental health programs.
"There's an understanding in Albany now that in the health and human services arena he is the most important policy-maker, more important than any commissioner," said Cesar A. Perales, the former state social-services commissioner who is now New York City's deputy mayor for health and human services.
 
Work at a Young Age
 When Mr. Dowling's father, a laborer "with big meathooks for hands," had to stop working at a young age because of a debilitating bout with arthritis, the family accepted disability payments from the Irish welfare system. But Mr. Dowling, the oldest of five siblings, helped support the family by working continuously through his childhood -- milking cows, toiling in factories and traveling to England for the summer because the wages there were higher.
"I basically developed the feeling that families who are struggling need assistance, and that the kind that is provided should recognize their struggle," Mr. Dowling said. "But I also developed a very strong sense that while the system should help you, it should never undercut the desire of people to help themselves."
Mr. Dowling first came to the United States to find summer jobs that would help him pay for his undergraduate education in Ireland. He worked on construction crews, on the New York City docks, and even in the engine room of a Circle Line cruise boat, where he often slept as well.
 
Bond With the Governor
 After moving to New York permanently in 1971, he earned a master's degree in social work from Fordham University, held a series of jobs as a consultant on anti-poverty issues and then returned to Fordham to teach and serve as an assistant dean. He joined the State Department of Social Services as a deputy commissioner in 1983 and moved to Mr. Cuomo's central staff five years later.
Those who know both Mr. Dowling and Mr. Cuomo see a special bond between the two men, largely because Mr. Dowling's story is so similar to that of Mr. Cuomo's parents, who were poor Italian immigrants.
"Mike is not some academician," Mr. Cuomo said, "not some elegantly educated elitist type who, with heart pure as gold, turns the pages of his texts with uncallused fingers and learns about life mostly by observing -- albeit with great compassion -- how poorer people live lives he's never experienced. That kind of person can become an intellectual zealot on a subject and be unbending.
"Mike knows what poverty is, knows what hard work is. Most of all he knows the give and take of life, the hard practicalities."
 
Lobbying Over a Beer
 On a staff that is known for being all work and no play, Mr. Dowling does much of his most persuasive lobbying over a pitcher of beer at pubs near the Capitol. Tall and burly, he wears a scruffy beard that perfectly complements his ready smile and a lilting accent that Mr. Cuomo describes as one-quarter prose and three-quarters music.
"With that disarming Irish brogue of his, he can tell people bad news and they will look at it and say thank you," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
But Mr. Dowling is also known as a no-nonsense negotiator whose face turns port-red when he grows impatient. His bouts of profanity, including those in the Governor's presence, are so common they are now dismissed as more endearing than intemperate.
"It's no big deal anymore when his cheeks turn red," said one colleague. "It's only when his neck starts to turn red that I get worried."
That side of Mr. Dowling's temperament may have been honed on the hurling field, where he was a championship player of the rugged Irish pastime that is part field hockey, part soccer. His philosophy on game day, Mr. Dowling said, was that "if your head gets in the way of my stick, that's your problem."
But for the most part, Mr. Dowling has become known as a conciliator who is forever seeking common ground. "I'm not a purist who identifies an ideal and says we can only accept success if we get what we've set in our dreams," he said. "The history of progress is taking continuous steps forward all the time."

HEADLINE: Dinkins to Visit Europe in June on Trade Mission

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Seeking foreign investments to pull the city out of its economic slump, Mayor David N. Dinkins will try to persuade European companies to place their American corporate headquarters in New York City when he visits Europe in June, city officials and business leaders said yesterday.
Mr. Dinkins formally announced yesterday that he will visit London, Paris and Frankfurt on a five-day trade mission beginning on June 1. The New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry will pay expenses for the Mayor and his aides, estimated at about $4,000 per person. A total figure could not be obtained last night because officials had not decided how many aides would go. 
 At least 20 executives from utilities, banks, insurance companies, accounting firms and real estate companies will accompany the Mayor, along with his recently appointed Deputy Mayor for Finance, Barry F. Sullivan. Representatives from the state Department of Economic Development and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey also plan to go.
The delegation will include Preston R. Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, Lance R. Primis, president and general manager of The New York Times, and Robert B. Catell, president of Brooklyn Union Gas.
The city will pay for the Mayor's security detail. The companies sending executives will pay for them.
 
'Not a Junket'
 Mr. Sullivan, who took over as the city's chief financial development official last month, said the trip to Europe would be all work.
"This is not a junket," Mr. Sullivan said yesterday. "For those of you who have done overseas travel, there is no fun in being in three cities in five days, working from breakfast through dinner."
Mr. Dinkins's travels stirred controversy last year. Last fall, good-government lobbyists raised questions about his use of a quasi-public corporation to solicit donations from companies doing business with the city for his journey to South Africa, which he billed as a trade mission. The Mayor also initially accepted an expense-paid trip to Munich, Germany, to see a tennis tournament, but canceled the trip after critics charged that it presented a conflict of interest.
Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said the trip in June did not pose the same ethical dilemmas that the South African trip did. The trip to Europe is not a vacation, he said, and the partnership asked the Mayor to head the delegation, not the other way around.
 
Normal Course of Duties
 "These kinds of trips are classic in the job resume of what the Mayor is supposed to do," Mr. Russianoff said.
The city will focus on attracting service-sector companies that wish to establish corporate headquarters in the United States, Mr. Sullivan said, though a few of the companies the group will court may have interest in light manufacturing plants.
The delegation will fly to London on June 1, where it will meet with the American ambassador, British concerns with New York offices and London financial institutions that may be interested in underwriting city projects.
On June 3, the Mayor plans to fly to Paris for a meeting with Mayor Jacques Chirac, the Chamber of Commerce and several financial institutions and the next day he is scheduled to meet with French business leaders. On June 5, Mr. Dinkins will meet in Frankfurt with its mayor and business leaders including executives of the Treuhandanstalt, the German privatization agency that is selling the businesses and property of the former East German state. The Mayor is also scheduled to visit a Holocaust memorial.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Up 1.6%, Biggest Gain in 5 Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories in March recorded their sharpest advance in five months, the Government said today in another sign the economic recovery is proceeding.
Manufacturers told the Commerce Department that they had received a seasonally adjusted $240.8 billion in new orders, a stronger-than-expected 1.6 percent increase over the previous month. 
 It was the third consecutive monthly rise, after advances of seven-tenths of 1 percent in February and five-tenths of 1 percent in January, and the largest since October.
"Cross your fingers," said Priscilla Trumbull of the WEFA Group, a forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "I think things are turning up, but it's going to be agonizingly slow."
Analysts had been anticipating a March rise of about 1 percent. But manufacturers continued to reduce their backlog of unfilled orders, an indication they can handle the rise in new orders without substantially expanding their payrolls.
The backlog fell six-tenths of 1 percent in March, the seventh drop in a row.
 
Layoffs Are Stemmed
 Ms. Trumbull said today's report suggested the manufacturing sector had rebounded enough to stem layoffs but not enough to generate a lot of new jobs.
"We are at a kind of delicate balance right now," she said. "Things are pointing up but they aren't pointing up so definitively and strongly that we're going to see employers rushing out to hire new people."
Despite recent gains in new orders, their level was still 5.6 percent below the $255 billion peak reached in December 1990, early in the recession.
Much of the strength in March came from a revised 2.1 percent gain in orders for durable goods, substantial items expected to last three or more years. They range from industrial turbines to computers to automobiles to washing machines.
Last week, in an advance estimate, the department said durable goods orders rose only 1.6 percent in March. They were up two-tenths of 1 percent in February and 2.4 percent in January.
Orders for nondurable goods, like food and clothing, rose 1.2 percent in March after a 1.3 percent gain in February.
Among the individual areas of strength in March were engines and turbines, up 14.3 percent; metalworking machinery, up 8.5 percent; communications equipment, up 14.5 percent; military goods, up 10.1 percent, and transportation equipment, up 6.4 percent.
Excluding the often-volatile transportation category, which in March included a 27.1 percent jump in aircraft, overall orders rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month after a six-tenths of 1 percent gain in February.
Leaving out orders for military goods, another category that swings widely from month to month, orders rose 1.4 percent, the same as in both February and January.
Shipments from factories, a measure of current production, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in March to $243.9 billion, the 11th increase in the last 12 months.
Inventories held steady at $372.85 billion, the first break after five consecutive declines. Economists are hoping for production gains in future months as manufacturers start to restock their inventories.

HEADLINE: New Claims By Jobless Hold Steady

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new applications for unemployment benefits held steady in mid-April, the Government said today, suggesting that the tentative recovery is starting to buoy the labor market.
 Initial claims were unchanged at 404,000 for the week ended April 18, after three weeks of decline in the number of applications for state benefits, the Labor Department said.
 
 Economists, who were expecting an increase of 5,000, viewed the figure as a sign that the recovery is taking hold.
 "It suggests we are not going to slip back into recession and that we will maintain a moderate growth pace," said Jean Sundrla, an analyst at the consulting firm Evans Economics Inc.
 Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said the report was "another indication of the potential for a sturdier recovery."
 "A strengthening of the labor market does seem to be occurring," she said.
 The labor market is usually the last sector of the economy to respond to recovery because companies prefer to delay rehiring until they are convinced that growth is firmly on track.
 Economists said four weeks of flat or declining jobless claims suggested the labor market was stabilizing.
 "These figures are consistent with a modestly recovering economy," said Samuel Kahan, economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago.
 The four-week moving average, which irons out the volatility of weekly reports, declined for the fourth week to reach 414,250, its lowest level since Oct. 25, when claims averaged 411,750.
 The apparent strengthening in the labor market was widespread. Forty-three states and United States territories reported declines in initial claims, led by a 9,032 drop in Pennsylvania.
 Michigan, hard-hit by the downturn, reported a 3,955 decline in first-time claims, with fewer layoffs in the automobile industry, the department said.
 Only two states, Texas and Virginia, reported gains of more than 1,000 new applications, with 2,489 and 1,225 additional claims, respectively. Virginia cited layoffs in the textile, food processing and trade industries for its rise.

HEADLINE: Earnings Up 7% at I.C.I.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, April 30

 BODY:
Britain's biggest industrial manufacturer, Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., said today that first-quarter 1992 pretax earnings edged up 7 percent, to 212 million, or $374.7 million.
Revenues were little changed at 3.06 billion, or $5.4 billion. 
 I.C.I.'s chairman, Denys Henderson, said there were tentative signs of an economic recovery in the United States and Britain, especially in housing, consumer products and textile markets. But he added, "It is still uncertain when the difficult trading conditions of the past 18 months will finally be behind us."
Pharmaceuticals profits rose by more than a third, to 122 million ($216 million), helped by continued sharp growth in sales of newer products such as the heart drug Zestril, the cancer drug Zoladex and the anaesthetic Diprivan.
Agrochemical profits, however, dipped below levels a year earlier, to 48 million ($85 million) because of lower volumes in January and February.
Analysts expect full-year profits for 1992 to be about 900 million ($1.6 billion), compared with 1991's 843 million ($1.5 billion).

HEADLINE: The Art Market;
Auction Houses Cutting Prices To Lure Buyers

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
TO judge this spring's contemporary-art auctions by their catalogue's covers, literally, is to conclude that times are good. And they are, for buyers. But for sellers and auction houses, the story is not so rosy.
Debt, death and divorce, the three D's of the auction business, keep the art market going. And the adage will be underscored by this season's two weeks of auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York, which begin on Tuesday. And starting this weekend, the works to be sold, over 3,000 paintings, drawings and sculptures by such artists as Picasso and Polke, Renoir and Warhol, valued at more than $325 million, will go on public view at the two houses. 
 With the economy still in a slump and the art market trying to recover from its shaky performance over the last 18 months, few sellers are willingly putting works on the block. As a result, auction house executives are stressing bargain prices and estate merchandise to rebuild buyer enthusiasm.
They are reluctant to predict the outcome, however. "It's in the lap of the gods for both houses," said Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York. "There's been a lot of polite interest, especially in the top lots, but until the actual event it's impossible to say what will really happen."
Another issue that neither house is willing to discuss is why much of the art is for sale in the first place. But the works on the covers of Sotheby's and Christie's contemporary catalogues tell the tale. Both are considered exceptional paintings by big-ticket artists, and both are being sold by men whose companies are in financial trouble.
In the case of Sotheby's, the catalogue cover shows Malcolm Morley's 1968 "Vermeer, Portrait of the Artist in His Studio." The work, which belongs to the advertising magnate Charles Saatchi, is a stunning re-creation of a poster of an Old Master painting and is expected to fetch $350,000 to $400,000.
Contemporary experts agree the work is priced to sell. One reason might be to raise money for Mr. Saatchi's London-based company, Saatchi & Saatchi, which reported losses of $103.3 million last year. The Morley is just one of 21 works from Mr. Saatchi's collection that are going on the block on Wednesday. Together, the Saatchi pictures constitute more than a third of the evening's offerings.
Much of Sotheby's contemporary-art sale in November was also from Mr. Saatchi's holdings. While the collector refused to talk about his art dealings, Lucy Mitchell-Innes, head of contemporary art for Sotheby's, said: "Mr. Saatchi is changing the nature of his collection. He is concentrating more on young British artists and blue-chip Americans." This collector's bulk-buying habit a decade ago was widely regarded as a factor in the soaring prices of contemporary art in the 1980's, and his vast unloading when the market peaked was thought to have made the value of many contemporary artists' works plummet.
On Christie's catalogue cover for the Tuesday sale is Andy Warhol's "210 Coca-Cola Bottles," which people in the art world say is still owned by Martin S. Blinder, the man credited with being the first to sell art in shopping malls a decade ago. But his company, Martin Lawrence Limited Editions of Van Nuys, Calif., recently reported a 50 percent decline in revenues between the first nine months of 1990 and the first nine months of 1991.
Mr. Blinder bought the Warhol for $1.43 million at Christie's four years ago. Painted in 1962, it is the largest and most complex of the artist's Coke bottle paintings. Christie's has optimistically estimated that it will bring $2.2 million to $2.8 million. Mr. Blinder did not return phone calls.
"This was the first Warhol to break a million dollars," said Diane Upright, who heads Christie's department of contemporary art. "After that there was a whole upward spiral of prices culminating in 1989, when a Marilyn Monroe sold for more than $4 million. In this context, our estimate really isn't too high." Although Mr. Blinder's name never appears in the catalogue, art experts say they think he is selling several other works that night, too.
Mr. Blinder and Mr. Saatchi are not alone in trying to raise quick cash by selling art. As a result, works are coming back on the market faster than in the years when the economy was stronger. Take the painting on the cover of Christie's May 12 catalogue of Impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculpture. It is "La Loge," Renoir's 1874 work of a woman sitting in a box at the opera. It was last at auction at the height of the market, in May 1989, when the German collector Hermann Schnabel bought it at Christie's in New York for $12.1 million.
Mr. Schnabel is selling the painting, along with 13 other works, but this time Christie's has shied away from putting a firm presale estimate on "La Loge." "We're figuring anywhere from $6 million to $8 million," Mr. Burge said. "But who knows."
Estate property is by far the freshest art on the market this spring. And Christie's has two of the season's most enticing estates. On Tuesday, the night of its contemporary auction, it will be selling 25 works from the estate of Frederick Roos, a Swedish businessman, collector and founder of the Rooseum Center for Contemporary Art in Malmo. He died last May at the age of 40, leaving 2,000 works of art and debts of about $20 million.
This spring Christie's is selling only a portion of his holdings. "It's the right estate at the right time," Ms. Upright said. "The sale is filled with artists of the 80's, such as Kiefer, Baselitz, Polke and Richter, German artists whose current price levels are viewed as attractive to collectors and who did stunningly well last spring."
Among the highlights of the sale are Anselm Kiefer's "Columns" (1983) and Georg Baselitz's "Franz in Bed" (1982). Each is estimated to bring $300,000 to $400,000. Another work receiving attention in this sale is Robert Gober's "Untitled (Sink)," estimated to sell for $90,000 to $120,000 and his "Untitled (Bed)," thought to bring $80,000 to $120,000.
"In this climate, Gober is one of the few artists either American or European whose prices continue to rise," Ms. Upright said.
The other big estate sale at Christie's focuses on the property of William A. McCarty-Cooper, the companion and adopted son of Douglas Cooper, a Cubist scholar and collector. The auction will take place on May 11 in a single-owner sale. Highlighting the evening are Braque's "Atelier VIII" (1952-55) and Picasso's "Compote Dish and Guitar" (1932). The auction house refused to commit itself to an estimate on either painting.
Other pre-Cubist and Cubist art from an estate is being offered at Sotheby's on May 13. The works belonged to Sidney E. Cohn, a labor-relations lawyer. Included in the auction are two 1907 drawings Picasso made as studies for the oil painting "Nude and Drapery." One is "Study of Head for Nude With Drapery," which depicts a masklike face and is estimated to sell for $500,000 to $700,000; the other is "Study for Nude With Drapery," estimated to fetch $600,000 to $800,000.
Another large estate in the sale that night belonged to Benjamin and Minna Reeves. Mr. Reeves, an importer, manufacturer and distributor of expensive foods, and his wife collected works by Pissarro, Renoir, Sisley and Fantin-Latour. The star picture in the group is Pissarro's "Parc aux Charrettes, Pontoise," a city scene painted in 1878. It is estimated to bring $1 million to $1.5 million.
Many of these Impressionist works once strongly appealed to Japanese buyers. Now that the Japanese have, for the most part, stopped buying, auction-house experts and gallery owners are hoping to lure collectors from Europe and America by putting low estimates on these works.
"There's a pent-up demand to buy across the board," maintained David Nash, who heads the Impressionist and modern departments at Sotheby's. "But the interest in 20th-century art is greater than in Impressionist right now."
Drawings by big name artists are also attracting buyers. And on May 13 Sotheby's is selling many outstanding ones by Matisse, Vuillard, Cezanne and Degas that were recently owned by the Manhattan dealer William Acquavella.
In the contemporary field, German artists are expected to fare particularly well. "There's no question there are good buys around," said Lawrence Rubin, director of M. Knoedler & Company in Manhattan. "If the auctions do well it will be a big step in the right direction. But at this point we can only hope."

HEADLINE: As Museum and Mall, A Seaport Lives On

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
IN a city of marvels, the escalator ride in the Pier 17 Pavilion at the South Street Seaport occupies a special category. The ascent begins next to a display of Nordic Track exercise equipment, and as the escalator rolls upward, a memorable scene unfolds before the dazzled spectator: a genuine middle-American mall, a spotless temple of T-shirt commerce, complete with functioning restrooms and telephones that work.
And food. Lots of food. For the full effect, one really has to leave the tasteful ground-floor restaurants behind and ascend to Level 3. There, in the infernal circle of fast food, the cholesterol transgressors circulate from Pizza on the Pier to Seaport Fries to Wok and Roll to Athenian Express and back to South Philly Steak and Fries, clutching oversize waxed cups stuffed with french fries, balancing pizza slices whose three-inch surface of goo is moving steadily toward the edges of the crust, already drooping under the weight. 
 For many, this is the South Street Seaport, an inviting stretch of shops and eating places with a breezy riverside promenade and a few ships for atmosphere. It is commercial, clean and safe.
Off to the side of the Seaport action, in a tiny workshop at Pier 15, Glenn Braun spends his days fashioning little ships and putting them in bottles. He also fields questions from curious visitors, 200 of them on a busy day. A lot of them ask, "Where's the museum?"
Good question. It's easy to forget, but the enormously popular "festival marketplace" created by the Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., is the outsize child of the South Street Seaport Museum, which celebrates its 25th anniversary this week with a retrospective exhibition titled "Of Sailing Ships and Sealing Wax: 25 Years of Collecting." The show, which opened on Tuesday, offers a selection from the museum's holdings, including maritime oil paintings, ship models, nautical fixtures and maps.
The exhibition could have been called "25 Years Up a Creek Without a Paddle." For a quarter of a century, the museum, founded on a wing and a prayer, has passed through one financial crisis after another, while experiencing more leadership turmoil than the Bounty. In 1985, it nearly voted itself out of existence. But it survives. Despite Government cutbacks and shrinking revenue sources for cultural institutions, it is showing surprising signs of vigor.
The museum and its excursion vessels have been averaging about half a million admissions in the last several years. A year and a half ago, the museum acquired, for $3.4 million, the large collection of maritime art and artifacts, 2,000 objects in all, that once belonged to the Seamen's Bank for Savings. And it has received grants totaling $750,000, the largest chunk of it from the state, to restore the Lettie G. Howard, the last Fredonia-type inshore fishing schooner, which will eventually set sail as an educational and sail-training vessel.
Of course, there is that nagging question. "The poor museum has been shunted off to the perimeter," says Peter Neill, who took over as its president in the summer of 1985. "It's a fact. My biggest problem is, physically, where's the museum?"
At the moment, it is many places. The museum includes administrative offices, a new visitors' center, exhibition galleries, a restored 19th-century stationer's shop, a library and a children's center.
At Bowne & Company, the stationers, visitors can operate a 19th-century hand press, order wedding invitations or talk over the fine points of the history and design of type with Julia Boltin, the shop's frighteningly well-informed printer. "Something Fishy," the exhibition at the children's center, tells youngsters ages 4 to 10 how fish get from the deep blue sea to their dinner plates.
Moored in the East River is a small fleet of historic vessels, dominated by the mammoth bark Peking. Like most of its fellows, the Peking serves as a floating museum, with photographs and text illustrating life on board the ship when it carried guano between South America and Europe. The Pioneer, a two-masted schooner, takes on passengers regularly and heads out for the open water of New York Harbor, racing past the Statue of Liberty and out as far as the Narrows.
"We now have a museum without walls," says Mr. Neill, interviewed in his office at 207 Front Street. "But the world needs to see a museum with walls. In typical Seaport fashion, we have worked backward, building what goes inside before we constructed the edifice."
 
Culture vs. Commerce
 The edifice arrives next. The museum is in the middle of an unannounced $20 million capital campaign, from which $8 million is to go toward turning the block of early 19th-century buildings on Schermerhorn Row, the architectural centerpiece of the Seaport, into a central exhibition space with two permanent displays. One will tell the story of New York as a port city; the other will present international maritime history as it bears on New York. As part of the project, to be completed in 1995, a historically accurate row house is to be built where the boat-building shop now stands, near the corner of Water Street and Burling Slip.
The Schermerhorn Row project is intended to create a physical focus for the museum and, Mr. Neill hopes, increase membership, which has held steady at about 7,000 for several years. Just as important, it will begin to restore the balance between commerce and culture, which, Mr. Neill admits, is badly out of whack.
Make no mistake: Mr. Neill has a high tolerance for commerce. A self-described "cultural entrepreneur," he sees it as part of the grand and glorious story of New York's waterfront. "They criticize the Seaport as real-estate speculation," he fumes. "Well, Schermerhorn Row began as a speculative real-estate deal. People talk about fast food. Well, look at old photographs of the area, and you'll see 'quick lunch' signs all over the place -- cheap food for the working man."
Passion and sophistry blend as Mr. Neill, a burly, bearded 50-year-old given to pounding the padded arm of his office chair with a fist, works up a righteous head of steam. In the bright, not too distant future, the milling throngs -- potential museumgoers, each and every one of them -- will enter Schermerhorn Row as consumers and emerge as savants, filled with a new understanding of the commerce that surrounds them. The buying and the selling will suddenly have a historical context. Past and present will seamlessly merge. Mr. Neill is firm on the notion that artifacts have to be used as metaphors to explain a way of life.
"A lot of museum people are snobs," he says, as though revealing a secret, "but we're populists because history is populist." A rogue thought intrudes: Would Melville have sprung for a jumbo cup of fries?
 
A Hard Bargain
 The South Street Seaport came into existence when a hardy band of preservationists decided that the decaying downtown waterfront district -- the original source of the city's wealth, the entry point for more immigrants than passed through Ellis Island -- had to be saved. From headquarters in a small storefront, the museum began acquiring historic properties and piers before they could be demolished. City landmark designation followed, and by agreement with the city, the museum became a kind of caretaker for the district.
The idea was to restore the neighborhood and create the museum along the way. Reality intervened. In the mid-1970's, the museum, financially prostrate, turned to the Rouse Company and begged it to work the magic that had made Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston and Harborplace in Baltimore artistic and commercial successes.
Seaport Marketplace, a Rouse subsidiary, would pay rent for its two retail coliseums, Fulton Market and Pier 17 Pavilion, to the museum, which, acting as agent for the city, would serve as landlord for the waterfront district, which includes the Fulton Fish Market and the commercial tenants.
The base rent from Rouse would insure a stable financial base for the museum. And if Rouse achieved excess profits, determined by a complicated formula, the extra money would be funneled directly into the museum. The Rouse deal has turned out to be a Faustian bargain. The city stepped in and rewrote the lease so that it would take 60 percent rather than 20 percent of total rents. And the extra profits never materialized.
 
Taking Back Control
 But the mall culture did. Chic boutiques appeared, like Ann Taylor and J. Crew. The Pier 17 Pavilion sprouted shops with funny names, like Hats in the Belfry. It got Foot Locker and Lady Foot Locker, and pushcarts selling everything from jewelry to computer-printed genealogical scrolls. Mass quantities of beer were consumed as thousands of Wall Streeters swept over the Seaport after work like a human tide. With an estimated 13 million to 15 million million visitors last year, the Seaport is now one of New York's leading tourist attractions.
In the late 1970's, John B. Hightower, the museum's president, defended the agreement with Rouse, saying, "The fact is that shopping is now the chief cultural activity in the United States." And how.
As Fulton Street and Pier 17 drew millions, the museum languished, offering few exhibitions and doing almost no restoration work on its ships. As it concentrated on its real-estate interests, membership and donations plummeted. A third of the staff was laid off.
Then came what Mr. Neill calls "the last great catharsis," a series of confrontations in early 1985 "when the museum people took back leadership from the real-estate people." The galvanizing moment came when John Ricker Jr., then the chairman, moved that the museum be dissolved. "The board said, 'Wait a minute, that's not the idea here,' " Mr. Neill says.
When the dust settled, both the chairman and the president of the museum resigned.
 
'A Fool or a Hero'
 Enter Mr. Neill. A St. Louis native, he had started out as a teacher and novelist, then drifted into maritime history and preservation while teaching writing and literature as an adjunct professsor at Yale University in the late 1970's. Already active in land-conservation groups, he became director of Schooner Inc. in New Haven, a nonprofit environmental group that offered educational programs aboard a working ship. In 1984, he was named director of the Office of Maritime Preservation of the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Washington, where he toiled happily until he was approached by the Seaport museum in 1985 about becoming its president.
The Seaport's offer was less than seductive. "The museum was intellectually and financially bankrupt," Mr. Neill recalls. "Every philanthropic relationship had been tainted. The job was considered by everyone to be a disastrous career move."
As Mr. Neill tells it, one look at the masts of the Peking against the towers of lower Manhattan sold him on the idea. "I decided I'd either be a fool or a hero to take the job," he says. Settling back into his chair with a broad smile, he adds, "I'm a hero." Mr. Neil recruited a solid board, as he puts it, "from the abyss." He beefed up the museum's education department, now the museum's largest. And he went to work on the financial problems, insisting that the museum rely more on philanthropy and earned income, less on Government aid. Since talking the helm, Mr. Neill has retired $1.5 million in debt and produced a surplus in the operating fund each year.
On this front, he has been relentless. Visitors to the museum gallery are pointedly encouraged by the guard to leave an extra dollar on the way out if they like the exhibition. Volunteers are eagerly recruited. (The museum has 400 of them.) "Are you a member?" Mr. Neill asks a reporter. Genuine alarm registers on his face when the answer is no. He jumps up and snatches a membership form from his desk.
"The arts have to compete for hearts and minds," he says. In a singsong voice, he ridicules "this idea of 'We need to be kept because we're this precious thing.' "
On the other hand, Mr. Neill makes it clear that he would like to see a little giveback from the city, which gives the museum no direct grants. "Do I want a city subsidy and do I think we deserve it?" he says. "Yes." The fist is pounding again. "We are one of the most imaginative purveyors of education to the city that there are. We served 40,000 students last year. That merits a public subsidy. Not charity, but a return for services rendered." Between fall and spring, the Pioneer roams the East Coast, offering educational programs to other cities.
 
A Touch of Rebellion
 If Mr. Neill is miffed at the city, that goes double forthe Rouse Company, the mere mention of which causes him to roll his eyes and sigh profoundly. The Pier 17 Pavilion he regards as a carbuncle on the face of his beloved. He will not pose for pictures with it in the background.
"There's real hostility there because, as you may have noticed, I don't shut up," he says, characterizing the relationship with Rouse. Mr. Neill has tried to explain to the company that a strong museum drawing more visitors will contribute to the Rouse bottom line. The company has thus far limited its enthusiasm to a single monetary pledge of $150,000, of which it has paid half.
Joseph E. Ochs, vice president and general manager of the Seaport Marketplace, says that the pledge, to help restore the Lettie G. Howard, was based on a more ambitious version of the project, and that as things now stand "$75,000 is more than fair." He also said the company has lent money to the museum from time to time, and takes a benefactor's table, at a cost of $50,000, at the museum's annual fund-raising dinner.
Rouse has resisted one of Mr. Neill's more daring proposals. In his quest for a permanent exhibition space, he suggested that Rouse sell the top two floors of the mammoth Fulton Market Building to the museum. The price? One dollar. The reasoning? "Up to now, that's been dead space for retailers," says Mr. Neill, who theorized that having fewer commercial tenants in Fulton Market will raise the profits in Pier 17. The museum once needed Rouse. Now, as Mr. Neill sees it, Rouse needs the museum.
Mr. Ochs says: "The marriage of the museum and the marketplace is what makes the seaport work. We salute the museum, but our whole basis is to lease space so we have the dollars to pay rent."
Mr. Neill says: "Rouse does what it does very well, but it's been done in many other places. What's different about this place is the architecture, the ships and the history, and the only way that can be articulated is through the museum."
Even with the expansion, it will remain a small museum in a city of powerhouse institutions. And Mr. Neill says he nourishes only modest territorial ambitions for it. The Schermerhorn Row complex and the piers seem about right to him.
"But on the program side, the sky's the limit," he says. "There's a population here that's the biggest intellectual sponge going, and I'll take the program anywhere, whether it's up to Harlem or floating off Sandy Hook."
 
Ships and Other Delights

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Selling in Japan, With Japan's Help

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
Takashi Tanji knows a thing or two about exports. As a child in Japan during the 1950's, he recalled, the essence of elementary-school economics was that Japan must export to survive. After graduating from college, he joined the Kanematsu Corporation, a big trading house, where he spent most of the next 25 years selling Japanese steel abroad.
For the foot soldiers in Japan's export-led economic miracle, like Mr. Tanji, the work was often hard and humbling. He remembers trying to sell steel pipe to oil-patch suppliers in Texas and Louisiana in the 1970's, staying in cheap hotels, scouring the Yellow Pages for prospective customers, and making cold calls with decidedly mixed results. 
 Today, the 49-year-old Mr. Tanji is back in America, working the other side of the trade ledger, as part of an unusual Japanese Government program to help smaller American companies sell to Japan. The program itself is a sign of the economic times: it is run by the Japan External Trade Organization, or Jetro, an arm of the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry established in 1958 to aid Japan's postwar export drive.
Yet given Japan's huge trade surpluses and trade conflicts with other nations, Tokyo no longer needs an export-promotion agency. So Jetro has reversed course, becoming an agency that helps Western companies sell in Japan. To the extent that it is successful, of course, Japanese exports are less likely to run into protectionist problems in the United States.
Mr. Tanji is one of 18 senior trade advisers stationed by Jetro across the United States, whose task is to find American companies -- typically with 300 or fewer employees -- with products that can be sold in Japan and help them do it. Most of the advisers, like Mr. Tanji, who arrived in Tampa in the fall of 1990, have been lent from trading companies and are veterans of Japan's export drive, not the country's recently acquired enthusiasm for imported goods.
"When I was assigned this job, I thought it would be difficult," Mr. Tanji said. "And it is difficult. To sell in Japan is not easy."
But the so-called Jetro experts program, begun less than two years ago, can now point to 35 companies it has helped makes sales in Japan. To be sure, many of these success stories fit into the tradition of Western niche-and-novelty suppliers that do well in Japan, so long as they operate on the periphery of Japan's industrial economy. Indeed, the products Jetro has ushered into the Japanese market include catfish, log cabins, fishing tackle, T-shirts, trendy hats and refurbished 50's-vintage American cars.
And the Jetro program will do little to narrow America's big trade deficit with Japan, $43 billion last year. But Japanese officials and American trade experts say its impact goes well beyond the handful of companies in the program so far. Advisers like Mr. Tanji have met with hundreds of American companies and thousands of individuals, getting out the word that Japan is a big market that can be cracked.
 
Developing Export Culture
 The Jetro program, American trade officials say, is a useful step in helping smaller American companies develop an export culture. And a more outward-looking mentality is already in evidence as technological and economic forces that began in the 1980's -- lower costs for international travel and phone calls, the worldwide proliferation of fax machines, a weaker dollar that makes American exports more competitive and soft markets at home -- made going abroad easier and necessary, according to David Birch, a Cambridge, Mass., consultant. In fact, 87 of 51,000 exporters surveyed by his firm, Cognetics Inc., had fewer than 500 employees.
Yet there is still plenty of room for growth. At present, just 15 percent of United States manufacturers account for 85 percent of American manufactured exports. "Smaller U.S. companies aren't beginning to meet their potential as exporters," said Susan Schwab, director general of the United States and Foreign Commercial Service, an export promotion arm of the Commerce Department. "And the real significance of the Jetro program is the spillover effect as other companies see some of their local peers exporting to Japan."
Across the country, there is now a solid core of companies that Jetro has helped sell in Japan. In many ways, the agency's representatives have played the time-honored role in Japan of the go-between, making introductions, trading on longstanding relationships and interpreting the local business culture for the Americans.
For example, Crane National Vendors of Bridgeton, Mo., which sold $4 million of its computerized vending machines in Japan last year, was coached in how to get the many health and product-standard approvals from government agencies required to sell its machines in Japan. Merlink Inc. of Rocky Mount, N.C., was introduced to a Japanese company that has begun to market its log-cabin homes aggressively , with estimated sales in Japan of $1.3 million this year. And Andermac Inc. of Yuba City, Calif., was scouted by Jetro representatives and, after its specialized hospital beds were tailored for the Japanese market, the company's sales in Japan reached $500,000 last year.
 
One Company's Story
 One of the intriguing small-company cases is here in Clearwater, Fla., CLI Systems Inc., across the causeway from Tampa. Founded by Donald Lewis and two partners, the company began five years ago with a stake of $500,000 and a catchy invention, a device for preventing rust by directing a low-voltage flow of electricity on the metal being protected. Cars and construction machinery were seen as the main markets.
The three local businessmen also started with an unusual marketing strategy. They decided to try to sell their product first in Japan, the Everest of export markets, a big and formidable challenge. They had read research reports saying Japanese companies were particularly receptive to new technology, and they figured that selling to Japanese industrial customers would give the company credibility worldwide.
After a couple of trips to Japan, CLI Systems had a few encouraging orders. But in early 1990, the company nearly went under when follow-up orders were slow in coming. Then, soon after an American trade official in Japan told Mr. Lewis of the new Jetro program, he got in touch with the Japanese agency, and in the fall of 1990 the company was listed in a Jetro journal as one of several imports that might be of interest to Japanese industrial buyers.
In the next two weeks, the little Florida company received 47 inquiries from Japanese trading companies and industrial companies. "The fax machine here was just humming," recalled Mr. Lewis, the company's president.
About the same time, Mr. Tanji arrived in Tampa. One of his first moves was to visit CLI Systems. He examined its rust arrestors, and immediately took samples to New York, where officials from the Tokyo Electric Power Company, a big utility, were on a buying trip. Soon afterward, Mr. Lewis was introduced to the right people at the Nissan Motor Company.
 
Opening Doors
 "The notion of my getting in to see the decision maker at Tokyo Electric and Nissan without the help of Jetro is pretty remote," Mr. Lewis said.
Getting in the door was one thing, but the company quickly learned that making goods to discriminating Japanese standards was quite another. The rust-proofing device that CLI Systems sells today looks entirely different from the one it offered a few years ago. The black plastic device is smaller and more stylish than the original design. Before, it was presented to customers plopped in a clear plastic case.
Now, it rests mounted in a cardboard box, set off by red velour paper. Metal anodes that attach to the metal surfaces being protected are similarly mounted, jewel-box style, in the presentation box, the wires neatly coiled. The packaging has pictures of planets, an atom icon and, in high-techese, declares its contents to be a "Solid State Electronic Rust Proofing System."
In Japan, the looks of an industrial product can mean as much as its utility. Mr. Lewis vividly recalls being told over drinks one evening with a Japanese trading company official that if a product was going to cost $400 to $1,500 apiece, as did the company's rust proofers, it should look like it's worth it.
A bit to his surprise, the Japanese wanted an American flag insignia and "Made in U.S.A." prominently displayed on the package. "Americans are perceived as innovators by the Japanese," Mr. Lewis explained. "But we're not seen as good manufacturers."
CLI Systems lived up to that national stereotype of sloppy manufacturing a few years ago, but by rigorous testing at each stage of production, it now says its systems are virtually free of defects.
The product modifications and hard work seem to have paid off. Its current customers include Nissan, Honda, Tokyo Electric, Japan Airlines, Sony and the Japan Highway Corporation, while several other major corporations are testing its devices. Its sales have jumped to the rate of a few million dollars a year. But Mr. Lewis conceded that because growth has accelerated so quickly recently "I'm really flying blind on volume, and if any of these big guys kick in, it could be astronomical."
CLI Systems currently employs 17 people and is hiring more, while some of the work is farmed out to three subcontractors. The Japan Import-Export Bank has just lent the company $250,000 to expand its production for the Japanese market, the first such loan to an American company to export to Japan. Mr. Lewis has shipped some of his rust proofers to other markets, including Australia, Malaysia, South Korea and Britain. The company is also looking to raise additional capital to begin selling in the United States.
For his part, Mr. Tanji runs through the litany of the Florida company's virtues -- patience, hard work, catering to customer demands and a willingness to spend money and time to develop a distinctive technology. "If other companies do the same, they will succeed in Japan," he said. "There's no mystery to it."
