HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: The Overview;
TOLL IS 38 IN LOS ANGELES RIOTS BUT VIOLENCE SEEMS TO ABATE; BUSH DISPATCHES FORCE OF 5,000

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 1

 BODY:
After witnessing two days of nearly unchecked rioting across vast swaths of the city, residents today began the excruciating process of getting on with life in ravaged neighborhoods, and the White House sent 5,000 Federal troops to help insure a growing but tenuous calm.
National Guard troops were sent to shopping centers that the police had cleared of looters. Children, their schools closed for the second day in a row, could be seen playing unsupervised. Families strolled along fire-scarred streets and gawked at the troops. 
 And Rodney G. King, in his first public appearance since just after police officers beat him 14 months ago, asked for the violence and lawlessness to end.
 
Cleanup Efforts Begin
 But as an uneasy peace took hold, sporadic violence flared in several other cities around the country, among them Atlanta, Seattle, Miami and San Francisco.
In South-Central Los Angeles there were scattered shootings and stabbings, but the widespread looting of Wednesday night and Thursday gave way to spontaneous cleanup efforts by residents of some of the areas worst hit by the rioting. The Los Angeles Fire Department said that by early evening all but one or two of the 3,767 building fires that had raged throughout the city since Wednesday were doused and that few new fires were breaking out.
Officials said the dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed on Thursday had generally succeeded in keeping people off the streets and would remain in effect for at least another day.
 
1,419 Injured
 By late afternoon the death toll from the violence stood at 38, surpassing the total of 34 who died during the seven days of the Watts riots here in August 1965. In addition, 1,419 people, along with two police officers this morning, had been reported injured and more than 4,000 arrested.
Of the 38 people known to have died in the unrest, 15 are black, 11 Hispanic, 5 white and 2 are Asian. The races of 5 had not been determined, the Los Angeles County Coroner's office said. And like the victims of the violence, those looting the stores across the city were of every race.
The coroner said 28 of the dead had been killed by gunfire, with 6 of them having been killed in gunfights with the police.
Five people were killed on Wednesday and most of the others were killed on Thursday, the coroner's office said. The coroner could not provide a figure for the number of people killed today.
Damage has been estimated at more than $500 million by the Mayor's office, although no one had begun a complete accounting of the losses.
After a request from Mayor Tom Bradley and Gov. Pete Wilson, President Bush dispatched almost 4,000 troops from the Army and the Marines to the area, as well as 1,000 Federal law-enforcement officers. The troops, 1,300 marines and more than 2,500 soldiers, began arriving in the Los Angeles area late today from bases around California.
Anton Calleia, Mayor Bradley's special assistant for emergency operations, said the Federal troops would take up positions on the streets this evening. The decision came as President Bush put control of the National Guard under the Federal military commanders on the scene.
Federal military commanders and local officials now have at their disposal close to 30,000 uniformed personnel in the Los Angeles area. That figure includes more than 8,000 members of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, almost 8,000 members of the Los Angeles Police Department, 6,000 members of the National Guard, almost 4,000 marines and Army infantry troops, 1,000 Federal law-enforcement officers and several thousand police officers from Long Beach and other municipalities in the region.
Mr. Calleia said policing decisions would be made by local officials and that local officials and the Federal military commanders would work together on how to deploy the troops. But he said that the ultimate power over how to use all the uniformed personnel would rest with the military commanders.
 
Tallying the Destruction
 Throughout Los Angeles, already battered by recession, residents began taking stock of the enormous economic toll to the city's poorest neighborhoods. Scores of small businesses were burned to the ground. Almost no grocery stores in the South-Central area were open, and many of those that were conducted business through locked gates.
With the violence apparently ebbing, the attention of city, state and Federal officials began shifting toward the underlying racial tensions that exploded on Wednesday after the acquittals of four white police officers in the videotaped beating of Mr. King.
Mr. King himself asked for the violence and lawlessness to end.
"People, I just want to say, you know, can we all get along?" Mr. King said today in a quavering voice as he faced scores of reporters and cameras outside his lawyer's office in Beverly Hills. "I mean, we're all stuck here for a while. Let's try to work it out."
Earlier in the day, Governor Wilson said at a news conference that the major goal once the rioting is quelled should be to provide more economic opportunity to the city's minorities and to give young people more reason to feel they have a stake in the community. But he offered no specific programs, and it was unclear what steps Federal, state and local officials would take to address the widespread feelings that the criminal justice system and the economy in Los Angeles remain segregated and inequitable.
Willie L. Williams, the Philadelphia Police Commissioner who has been chosen to replace Daryl F. Gates as the chief of police, said today that despite their acquittal on criminal charges, the four policemen who were videotaped beating Mr. King will still have to answer to him when he takes the helm.
"I cannot tell you if I'm going to fire anybody because that administrative process will most likely have just begun or not even have been completed prior to my arrival in Los Angeles," he said. "But clearly, the burden of proof and the burden of evidence in an administrative trial is far less in terms of a violation of departmental policy than it is in a criminal court, so the decisions that will and can be made are significantly different."
Today, the city slowed to a near halt. Because the looting and arson had spread on Wednesday across a wide area of the city, including more affluent neighborhoods, many residents stayed home.
Many businesses remained closed, as did most schools and universities throughout the city. Concerts, sporting events and other activities were canceled. Some flights in and out of Los Angeles International Airport were delayed or canceled because of the lingering concern about smoke billowing from the burning buildings.
Unlike Wednesday night and early Thursday -- when the rioters roamed the streets at will -- the police were out in force throughout much of South-Central Los Angeles. Chief Gates has been widely criticized for not responding more aggressively to quell the unrest.
And as of mid-afternoon, 4,393 people had been arrested in connection with the disturbances throughout Los Angeles County since Wednesday afternoon, said Deputy Hal Grant, a spokesman for the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. The arrests were made by the Los Angeles Police Department, the Sheriff's Department and law-enforcement agencies in nearby cities, including Long Beach, where more than 500 arrests were made Thursday night and this morning.
About 1,300 of the arrests were made by the Los Angeles Police Department. Officer Anita McKeon of the department's Emergency Operations Center said the pace of arrests in the city today had declined as the looting had subsided.
Deputy Grant said jails in the area were in danger of becoming overcrowded if arrests continued in large numbers. He said officials were developing plans for dealing with the problem, but said he did not have details.
 
Flash Points Cool
 Some of the flash points cooled as police officers, the California Highway Patrol and the National Guard took up visible positions. In Koreatown, where Korean-American merchants had banded together on Thursday into armed vigilante groups that occasionally fired on what they considered menacing youths, there were no reports of further incidents.
National Guard troops were sent to several shopping centers that had been cleared of looters by the police.
Several hundred Korean-Americans gathered along Wilshire Boulevard in mid-afternoon in an apparently spontaneous demonstration calling for interracial unity and an end to the violence.
Two hours of criss-crossing South- Central Los Angeles and adjacent neighborhoods today found scenes of war-like destruction interspersed with scenes of near-normalcy.
Entire blocks of businesses were totally destroyed by fire. At some stores, looters were still carrying out merchandise. At Martin Luther King Boulevard and Normandie Avenue, a Mobil gasoline station on one corner had been burned down. A Shell station across the street, the words "black owned" scrawled across its windows, remained intact.
 
Thousands Go for Mail
 With mail deliveries canceled, thousands of people lined up at post offices, many of them to pick up county welfare and Social Security checks, even as it dawned on them that they might be unable to cash the checks because most banks and check-cashing services were closed.
In some of the worst-hit areas, residents and other people from around the region appeared this morning with brooms and shovels to begin a cleanup effort and, they said, send a signal that they are determined to recapture control of the streets from looters and arsonists.
"We can't say we're going to control the violence," said Juan Guinto, a 22-year-old Angeleno as he shoveled debris from a looted and burned building. "But if our leaders, Jesse Jackson and our councilmen, can help by getting us to work together, then this community can rise again."
Officials here said they had requested that Federal troops be sent here in case looting and arson erupted again tonight.
The 1,300 marines, almost all of them veterans of the war in the Persian Gulf, were from Camp Pendleton, north of San Diego. They were dispatched to the Los Alamitos Naval Air Station, where they were to wait for further orders.
The Army troops sent to Los Angeles are based at Fort Ord, on the central California coast near Monterey. They are units of the 7th Infantry Light, which was sent to Panama City during the invasion of Panama in 1989, and include military police and some units with training in urban warfare.
The 1,000 Federal law-enforcement officers sent here by President Bush include units from the United States Marshal Service, the Border Patrol and the Bureau of Prisons.

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: The President;
Bush Says Verdict 'Stunned' Him; He Vows to Put an End to Rioting

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
President Bush said tonight that he had been "stunned" by the verdict in the Los Angeles police beating case, promised that the state court trial that touched off rioting and looting "was not the end of the process" and sent Federal troops into the ravaged city to restore order.
Seeking to diminish tensions and demonstrate that Mr. Bush is taking action, the Justice Department disclosed that a grand jury in Los Angeles has been reviewing evidence and issuing subpoenas to determine whether the four police officers acquitted of beating a black motorist should now be charged under Federal civil rights laws. 
 Mr. Bush, while expressing sympathy for the outrage of civil rights leaders over the acquittal, said he would use "whatever force is necessary" to stop the violence in Los Angeles. The President sent 1,000 marines and between 2,500 and 3,000 soldiers into the streets. They werearmed with light weapons and ordered to return fire if fired upon. Mr. Bush also put the California National Guard under Pentagon command and dispatched 1,000 riot-trained Federal law officers to reinforce the local police.
 
Troops on City Streets
 His orders, issued at 9:20 P.M., put a total of between 6,500 and 7,000 soldiers, marines and National Guard troops into the streets of Los Angeles during the night.
Mr. Bush addressed an anguished nation from the Oval Office, surrounded by the symbols of the Presidential power that he has brought to bear in war and diplomacy and is now being forced to turn to in the biggest domestic crisis of his political career. [Excerpts, page 8.]
By mixing forceful calls for order with expressions of sympathy, he seemed to be moving to stabilize the situation before the violence that has touched Los Angeles and a number of other cities developed into a national pattern of civil unrest.
He condemned the riot in Los Angeles as producing television pictures that were "horrifying almost beyond belief."
"What we saw last night and the night before in Los Angeles is not about civil rights," Mr. Bush said, his expression grim and determined. "It's not about the great cause of equality that all Americans must uphold. It's not a message of protest. It's been the brutality of the mob, pure and simple. And let me assure you I will use whatever force is ncessary to restore order."
Under pressure from civil rights leaders who met with Mr. Bush today in the White House and from some of his own advisers, the President broke with his refusal to comment on the verdict in the police officers' trial.
 
'Hard to Understand'
 "Viewed from outside the trial," the President said, "it was hard to understand how the verdict could possibly square with the video" of the beating of Rodney G. King. "Those civil rights leaders with whom I met were stunned, and so was I, and so was Barbara and so were my kids," he said. "But the verdict Wednesday was not the end of the process."
Mr. Bush said he had immediately ordered Federal authorities to pursue the possibility of filing criminal charges against the four acquitted men and other police officers under Federal civil rights laws, an investigation being conducted in a political climate that seems to demand an indictment. Today's announcement that a grand jury is reviewing the case seemed likely to increase the pressure to bring charges against the officers.
During a day of urgent meetings and rapid decisions that threw the White House into a state of emergency of a kind not seen since the war in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bush sent 1,500 marines from the First Marine Expeditonary Force and 3,000 members of the Army's Seventh Infantry to Los Angeles to help keep order.
Mr. Bush signed the deployment order after speaking to Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles. Though they told him that the situation was improving, Mr. Bush wanted a strong show of force on the streets through the night, a senior Administration official said.
Mr. Bush's orders were to equip the troops with loaded handguns and M-16 rifles and to have them shoot back if fired upon, the official said.
 
New Test for Bush
 Although Federal troops were used to prevent rioting in the Virgin Islands after Hurricane Hugo in 1989, today's action was more in keeping with the deployment of soldiers in the 1960's and 1970's to control race riots and disturbances during the Vietnam War. The decision, reached early at the White House meeting by Mr. Bush and his top military and legal advisers, was a major escalation in Mr. Bush's response to the rioting.
The violence thrust a dizzying new test on Mr. Bush in already stormy political days, and the President sought to reassure outraged minorities by meeting with civil rights leaders in the White House. The guest list was drawn from the old guard of the 1960's with whom he is more comfortable rather than from prominent young politicians, intellectuals or artists.
The session forced him to confront questions about what had become of the more tolerant America he promised at his inauguration more than three years ago, just as his public stance immediately after the verdicts aroused criticism that he is not sensitive to racial issues.
Before tonight's televised address, Mr. Bush had been walking a fine political line: While he focused on issues of law and order in public, his aides behind the scenes sought to convey the impression that he was as upset and confused as anyone else.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush had felt constrained in his public statements out of concern that he not prejudge any new Federal proceeding or appear to undercut his own arguments in favor of law and order by denouncing the original jury verdict.
There is precedent on both sides of the question. Lyndon B. Johnson used the arrest of four Ku Klux Klansmen on charges of murdering a civil rights worker in March 1965 to declare war on the racist organization, which he said was responsible for the slaying. But Richard M. Nixon was embarrassed into making a public retraction of his pronouncement that Charles Manson was "guilty, directly or indirectly, of eight murders" before the Sharon Tate murder case went to trial in 1970.
After the White House meeting, the civil rights leaders continued to assail the President's policies and demanded that he exert "moral leadership." In doing so, they openly confronted Mr. Bush with an accusation that had simmered unspoken since Wednesday's acquittal of the four police officers: that 12 years of Republican leadership had created a climate of economic inequity and racial injustice.
"He's been very vociferous about violence in the streets, but very silent about violence in the economic and in the criminal justice suites, which are the breeding grounds for violence in the streets," said the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
Mr. Lowery and the others applauded Mr. Bush's decision to send Federal reinforcements to Los Angeles and his announcement that the Justice Department had revived its inquiry into whether the police officers should be charged under Federal civil rights statutes.
But they demanded that Mr. Bush address the broad range of economic, social and racial issues that they said were behind the violence in Los Angeles and have gone unattended during the Bush Administration.
 
System 'Failed Us'
 "We reminded the President that for 14 months the black community has been very patient, waiting on the American justice system to act, and it failed us miserably," said Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Mr. Bush echoed those words tonight in his speech and said, "We owe it to all Americans who put their faith in the law to see that justice is served."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 35; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 530 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The Administration has quietly tested Congressional reaction on a possible free-trade agreement with Chile, but is deeply divided over whether to proceed with negotiations. The pact would be the next step in Bush's vision of a free-trade zone spanning the Western Hemisphere. But some lawmakers are concerned about more competition for American companies and workers. [35.] 
 A scandal is unfolding in southern China involving a company that two years ago became the first foreign concern to be listed on a Chinese stock exchange. [35.]
Lonrho shares fell sharply in London after reports that the U.S. Treasury was looking into the company's sale of a one-third stake in Metropole Hotels to Libya. [38.]
 
The Economy
The growth of manufacturing slowed in April, a result of more modest growth in production and new orders, according to a report by purchasing managers. Economists said the figures demonstrated that the nation's emergence from recession would be gradual. The index fell to 51.3 percent, from 54.1 percent in March. [35.]
Construction spending rose 1.6 percent in March, to its highest level in 15 months, the Commerce Dept. said, pushed by gains in single-family housing activity. [36.]
Organic fertilizers and pesticides are being bought by more and more gardeners worried about harsh synthetic chemicals leaching into drinking water or causing children to fall ill. [35.]
 
Companies
N. J. Nicholas Jr. is getting a parting deal from Time Warner that almost makes losing one's job an enviable proposition: $15.8 million in severance, plus he stays on the payroll. [35.]

Markets

Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates moved lower after the release of the purchasing managers' report. [38.] Standard & Poor's affirmed New York City's single-A-minus credit rating. [27.]
Grain and soybean futures prices rose sharply after predictions of hot, dry weather in the Corn Belt. [45.]
The dollar fell in thin trading, mostly because of the disappointing purchasing managers' report. Gold prices rose. [45.]

HEADLINE: Chile Test On Broader Free Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The Bush Administration quietly tested Congressional reaction this week to a possible free-trade agreement with Chile, but is deeply divided over whether to proceed with negotiations, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
The pact would be the next step in President Bush's vision of a free-trade zone spanning the Western Hemisphere. Negotiations are now taking place to broaden an existing free-trade agreement with Canada to include Mexico. 
 But Congressional reaction has been mixed, with some members concerned that American companies and workers already face the prospect of more acute competition with Mexico and should not be rushed into facing South American competition as well.
 
Pollution and Other Concerns
 The Administration is also struggling with concerns that more trade and industry in Mexico would worsen pollution there and in border states, and some members of Congress want those issues resolved before new talks begin.
Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's Subcommittee on International Trade, said, "I would be far more comfortable if we worked out the details" of a free-trade agreement with Mexico, "including the environmental and worker-adjustment components, before beginning formal negotiations with Chile."
President Patricio Aylwin of Chile is scheduled to meet President Bush here on May 13 and will seek the opening of negotiations then, Chilean and American officials said. The Treasury and State Departments are enthusiastic about the idea as a way to reward Chile for opening its economy, making regular payments on its foreign debt and moving to democracy after more than a decade of military rule.
 
 
Already Cut Tariffs
 Chile has been singled out because it has already reduced tariffs and adopted laws protecting foreign investments, so that a free-trade agreement would be easier to negotiate with it than with virtually any other Latin American nation right now.
But Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has been reluctant to open talks now for several reasons, Administration officials said. She worries that Congress might vent its frustration over the negotiations with Mexico by blocking the Chilean talks. And she has been concerned about how her 162-employee agency could handle another significant project when it is already swamped with not only the Mexico negotiations but also the deadlocked global trade talks in Geneva.
Kathleen A. Lydon, a spokeswoman for the trade office, said, however, that Mrs. Hills wanted to negotiate an agreement and only wanted to wait so as to allow time for consultations with Congress, businesses and unions. "We very much want to go forward quickly," she said. "The only question is when."
 
A Busy Office
 Mrs. Hills expressed reservations to colleagues last year about her agency's ability to start talks with Mexico if the negotiations in Geneva continued. But while a shortage of lawyers skilled in drafting trade agreements did delay a few meetings with Mexico late last fall, the extra burden has so far not had a significant effect on either set of talks, Mrs. Hills has said.
The United States has a widening trade surplus with Chile. Last year the United States sent Chile $1.84 billion worth of aircraft, computers, cars and other mostly manufactured goods, while importing from Chile only $1.3 billion worth of fruit, copper, fish and other raw materials.
Under the fast-track rules that now govern Congressional consideration of important trade agreements, the Administration must notify Congress before beginning negotiations. The talks cannot then begin until after at least 60 days have passed during which Congress has been in session, and once an agreement has been reached, Congress must vote on it without amendments.
Because of the political conventions this summer and various recesses, these 60 days would be spread over four or five months, so actual negotiations probably would not begin until December, after the American elections, said Andres Velasco, the international economics coordinator at Chile's Finance Ministry.
Alejandro Foxley, Chile's Finance Minister, met here on Wednesday with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to discuss the timing of free-trade talks, a Treasury official said. No decision was reached.
 
A Possible Snag
 Either the House Ways and Means Committee or the Senate Finance Committee could stop the opening of negotiations by passing a resolution of disapproval. Both committees have traditionally defended free trade in Congress.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who is a strong free-trade proponent on the Ways and Means Committee, said such a resolution might pass. While few members have taken a position on the issue, lobbying by unions could sway a majority against talks, he said.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. does not oppose trade talks with Chile but would want them to address labor and environmental issues that the negotiations with Mexico have not resolved, said Candice M. Johnson, a spokeswoman.
Gary R. Edson, the general counsel at the White House trade office, and William E. Barreda, the Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for trade and investment, held a closed-door meeting on Monday with Congressional aides to discuss a possible deal with Chile.
But even though the two men came together, along with more junior officials from the trade office and the State Department, Mr. Edson expressed noticeably less enthusiasm for immediate negotiations than did Mr. Barreda, said a Congressional aide who insisted on anonymity.
"There did not appear to be a unanimous Administration position," the aide said.
Mr. Edson and Mr. Barreda declined to comment.
David Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, has been Chile's strongest supporter. He said in a speech on April 24 that if negotiations were held, the Administration should start the process by early June so as to allow time to draw up an agreement before the Administration's fast-track negotiating authority comes up for renewal next spring.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 23.03 as Traders Leave Early

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices closed lower yesterday as computerized sell programs kicked in gear and many Wall Street traders trekked home early, anxious about the possibility of street demonstrations.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,336.09, off 23.03 points for the day but up 11.63 for the week. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advances on the New York Stock Exchange by 922 to 794.
Prices were narrowly mixed in the morning session after traders took profits from the market's recent rise and responded to a report showing slow growth in manufacturing.
 
Computer-Driven Selling
 But computer-driven selling hit stocks shortly after noon. Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody, said the selling started after rumors of rioting related to the Rodney King verdict circulated in Chicago and New York.
The rumors affected stock futures trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which brought down stock prices in New York, he said.
Trading dropped off in the afternoon session, as many investors and stock dealers went home early. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 177.4 million shares, down from 223.2 million in the previous session.
Other indexes were also lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.42 points, to 412.53; the New York Stock Exchange index, 1.10 points, to 227.20; the Nasdaq composite, 0.54 point, to 578.14, and the Amex composite, 0.83 point, to 389.78.
 
Effect of Early Exit
 Merrill Lynch, Salomon, Chemical Banking, Chase Manhattan and First Boston were among the large brokerage houses that allowed employees to go home early.
"People are leaving early, so you don't have full participation in the securities market," said Steven Van Brunt, assistant vice president for equities trading at Nikko Securities International. The early exit of traders posed "a liquidity problem," he said, with a scarcity of buyers with cash to steady the market.
Hildegard Zagorski, vice president at Prudential Securities, said many large investors were selling as a precaution. "The market hates uncertainty," she added. "They don't know what's going to happen over a long, hot weekend."
 
UAL Off 1 5/8
 UAL fell 1 7/8, to 122 5/8, after it told securities analysts it expected a loss in the second quarter. Constar International was up 2 3/4, to 43 1/4, but the Tennessee-based plastics concern said it had no explanation for the sudden rise.
Oil-service companies did well in the session, as oil prices reached their highs for the year. Schlumberger was up 2 1/8, at 64 1/4; Kerr-McGee, 3/8, at 39 3/8, and Haliburton, 1 3/8, at 26 5/8.
One bit of economic data released in the session was the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly index on manufacturing activity. The index was 51.3 percent in April, down from 54.1 percent in March, an indication of slow growth ahead for the nation's industries.

HEADLINE: Purchasers Say Pace of Gains Slid in April

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The growth of the nation's manufacturing economy slowed in April, as a result of more modest growth in production and new orders, according to a report released yesterday by the nation's purchasing managers. Economists said the figures demonstrated that the nation's emergence from recession would be gradual.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity fell in April to 51.3 percent from 54.1 percent in March. The March reading had been the highest since last summer. 
 The April numbers seem to indicate that the economy has lost some of the steam it developed in the previous few months. Since the beginning of the year, the index has climbed steadily. But the April reading represented the first monthly decline since December.
"The numbers indicate that the recovery is pretty spotty and there is not much confidence in a widespread economic advance," said Wayne C. Stevens, chief economist with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. "The economic recovery seems to be concentrated in certain regions and in certain industries. The recovery is fragile."
The monthly index, compiled from a survey of more than 300 purchasing managers representing a wide range of industries, is the first significant indicator of the previous month's activity. A reading below 50 indicates that the economy is contracting, while a reading above 50 shows expansion.
A more upbeat reading on the economy came yesterday from the Commerce Department, which reported that construction spending rose 1.6 percent in March, to its highest level in 15 months. [Page 36.]
"The growth rate of the economy slowed in April from the rapid pace of the previous two months," said Robert J. Bretz, director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. and chairman of the association's survey committee. "Nevertheless, the growth in new orders continues at a relatively high rate and should sustain a healthy growth in production."
The purchasing managers' report came a day after the Government's index of leading indicators posted its third straight gain in March, rising a modest two-tenths of 1 percent. Also, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for April increased to 77.2 from 76 in March, according to people with access to the report.
The association's index of new orders for everything from hydraulic pumps and photographic film to polyester coatings and lumber fell to 56.7 percent in April from 62.4 percent in March. The association said that despite the decline, the rate of new orders was strong enough to fuel growth in production in coming months.
The rate of production was significantly weaker in April, the association said, stating that its production index fell to 56.6 percent, from 60.1 percent in March. But the association said strong new orders, coupled with a low level of inventories, would keep production growing. The association's index of inventories dropped to 42.4 percent in April from 43.8 percent in March.
New orders for exports took a slight drop, the association said, stating that its index of exports slid to 52.3 percent in April from 52.9 percent in March. That is a sharp drop from the February level of 55.9 percent. Meanwhile, the association's index of imports increased to 53 percent in April from 51 percent in March.
The association's employment index increased to 43.9 percent in April from 42.8 percent in March. The industries with the greatest growth in employment in April were in apparel, textiles and wood products. The association said an employment index under 48 percent was generally consistent with a decline in the Bureau of Labor Statistics' data on manufacturing employment.
The price index increased in April, to 49.6 percent, from 46.6 percent in March. That reading was the highest in a year. The association said that purchasers reported that they resisted sellers' attempts to raise prices for a number of basic products like steel, paper and plastic resins.

HEADLINE: Compromise Offered at U.N. on Greenhouse Gas Emissions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 1

 BODY:
The chairman of a United Nations negotiating committee today offered a proposal that officials from several countries said could provide the basis for an agreement to curb emissions of atmospheric gases that scientists fear will cause global warming.
The proposal was offered by Jean Ripert of France, who heads a multi-national negotiating effort aimed at producing a global warming treaty, to be signed next month at the world environmental conference in Rio de Janeiro. However, its wording was seen by many delegates as unclear, and was interpreted in various ways. 
 A common interpretation among European and American officials was that it provided the elements of an agreement by which industrial nations would set a goal of reducing emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide and methane to 1990 levels by the year 2000.
Progress toward that goal would be periodically reviewed by the treaty signers, and they could strengthen its provisions if need be, according to this interpretation.
Scientists predict that if the greenhouse gases continue to be poured into the atmosphere at current rates, earth temperatures will warm 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century, with possibly catastrophic effects. These might include sea-level rise, increased droughts and storms, severe damage to natural ecosystems and damage to agriculture.
 
Environmentalists Unhappy
 A global warming treaty would be the centerpiece of the Rio conference, and failure to achieve it would be considered a big blow to the success of the conference, which is to be attended by many heads of state and government.
Some environmental advocates said the proposal was meaningless because it did not require advanced nations to abide by a firm target for reducing emissions.
"It's a text that commits no one to doing anything, ever," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, an atmospheric scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, a research and advocacy group.
Until now, European Community countries have insisted that a target be adopted, limiting greenhouse-gas emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000. The United States has argued that actions it is already taking will bring it close to that goal by 2000, but that it cannot promise to meet it without harming its economy.
While it is "not obvious" what Mr. Ripert's proposal means, "our reaction is positive," said Robert A. Reinstein, the head of the American delegation. He said it would become evident in the next few days whether the proposal could be a "vehicle for bridging the gap" between the Americans and the Europeans in time to meet a deadline of next Friday.
This disagreement has been the chief obstacle to settling on a proposed treaty. Mr. Reinstein said he was "encouraged that the process was moving in the right direction."
James Cameron, who represents the Alliance of Small Island States, countries that could be inundated by rising seas if global warming becomes a reality, said that while the proposal displays some "bad drafting," the "grist for a settlement is there."
A somewhat similar view was expressed by Bert Metz, head of the Dutch delegation, who said that although the proposal was not acceptable as it stands, "it could be made acceptable." The Netherlands has been one of the strongest advocates of firm targets and timetables for reducing emissions.
Mr. Ripert said he formulated his proposal after consultating with a number of European governments and with the Bush Administration. "It is my perception," he said, "that the United States could live with it."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Resume Contacts With Peru's Leader

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The first high-level talks between the Bush Administration and President Alberto K. Fujimori since the Peruvian leader suspended democratic institutions nearly a month ago will be held on Saturday in Lima, the State Department said today.
Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, left today for weekend meetings with President Fujimori and other Peruvian officials. A State Department official said today that Mr. Aronson's goal in the talks was to persuade Mr. Fujimori to cooperate with mediators from the Organization of American States in efforts to restore democracy promptly. 
 The Peruvian President, who dissolved the national legislature and dismissed much of the judiciary on April 5 in order to give himself and the army more power to deal with leftist guerrillas and narcotics producers and traffickers, has proposed a one-year plan to revive democratic institutions in phases. Bush Administration officials say that Washington would like to see the process speeded up.
Diplomats from the region say that there is apprehension that Mr. Fujimori's action, while popular with many Peruvians, set an unwelcome precedent for other Latin American nations, where recent moves toward democracy and free enterprise are also threatened by economic problems and social unrest, if not guerrilla war. Venezuela, a democracy of long standing, suppressed a military coup only with great difficulty earlier this year.
Mr. Aronson and a large interagency aid team were in Lima on April 5 when Mr. Fujimori dissolved the national legislature and suspended judges, saying that politicians were corrupt and the courts inefficient in meeting a national crisis. The Assistant Secretary canceled a meeting with the President and returned instead to Washington. The Bush Administration suspended most nonhumanitarian assistance.
Relations with Peru were further strained when on April 24, Peruvian fighter planes fired on an American C-130 transport aircraft 60 miles off the coast of Peru. The attack on the plane, which had just completed an anti-narcotics surveillance mission, killed one airman. Four other crew members were wounded.
Peruvian officials later described the attack as accidental and apologized.

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: On the Streets;
Getting Back to Daily Life: Searching for a Place to Shop Amid Destruction

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 1

 BODY:
Having torn itself apart in an agony of looting and burning, South-Central Los Angeles was a place of anger, sadness and futility today.
Convoys of screeching fire trucks and police cars sped back and forth through the smoky streets as residents searched in vain for a loaf of bread or a tank of gas or a pack of cigarettes. 
 "When are we ever going to recover from all this?" asked Al Johnson, who left his house today for the first time in two days to search for food. "Not in my time. Not in your time."
The crumbling streets of Los Angeles's inner city were still dangerous today after two nights of anarchy and violence. From among its blackened and still smoking buildings, and its smashed storefronts with their twisted security bars, men were still firing occasional shots at each other and at the police.
 
'Only Going to Get Worse'
 From one block to the next, new fires continued to break out, pursued by clusters of three, four or five fire trucks, always escorted for protection by several police cars with shotguns poking from the windows.
And with the war brought home, National Guard troops with their helmets and flak jackets and their military transport vehicles from the Persian Gulf war stood guard against an unknown enemy.
"The sad thing," said William Hicks, a Superior Court bailiff who was walking the streets in search of food, "is that it's only going to get worse from here. There's going to be added frustration because of something that we caused ourselves."
Mr. Hicks was waiting in line outside Echo Video and Mini Market, which had been looted but not burned and was admitting just one or two customers at a time to prevent further looting.
"I've spent two days trying to find a place to shop," Mr. Hicks said. "Thank God this guy's still open. I'm all right for people being angry. I'm angry, too. But I don't believe we should do it this way. Twenty-seven years ago we burned the place down when we had the Watts riot and things have only gotten worse."
 
'Hard Times Ahead'
 James Hill, a drug counselor who was also waiting, said he saw "hard times ahead."
"What happens when the food runs out?" he said. "It's going to be soup lines. Look at all the people who have been put out of work. Look at the medical center down there that burned up. That's 15 or 20 people out of work."
Los Angeles is such a racially divided city that people like these do not even consider driving a few blocks north to the other side of the freeway for a tank of gas or a bag of groceries.
"There's no markets left around here," said Kiris Coburn, an usher at a sports arena. "We're going to have to drive 15 or 20 minutes to get food, and when we get there, they're going to look at us worried."
William Dorsey, a retired gardener, added: "You take every freeway in Los Angeles, it's a dividing line. That's the way they corral you, keep you 'where you belong.' "
South-Central Los Angeles is a largely black and Hispanic area, and most of the destruction over the last two days has been concentrated there. One of the most stunning developments has been the movement of some of the violence into other parts of the city.
But in an area still suffering from the destruction of the 1965 riots, with a minimal economic base and continuing gang and drug violence, recovery is likely to take many years longer here than elsewhere.
 
Protective Graffiti
 Amid the destruction in the already-crumbling neighborhoods, new graffiti have appeared on the sides of shops: "Black Owned." On some streets, the effects of this strategy can be striking, with individual black-owned storefronts standing undamaged amid the charred ruins of their neighbors.
Other, more ominous graffiti have appeared on a broad white wall on Slauson Avenue. They read, in large, neat letters: "Crips Bloods Mexicans together forever tonite 4/30/92."
Others on the same wall read, "Now what you going to do honkey," "L.A.P.D. killa" and "Black thang/ brown thang."
More plaintively, some shopfronts with living quarters above them, carry hand-lettered signs in their windows reading, "People live here."
 
Like a War Zone
 On the corner of Jefferson and Western, National Guard troops had set up a strong point at a burned and looted mall.
They stood with raised weapons before a panorama of the economic destruction the rioting has brought: Duds 'n' Suds Coin Wash, Midcity Discount Records, Ar-Ex Pharmacy, Wigs Shoes Century Fashion, Checks Cashed Money Orders, J J's Burgers, Chuck's Beauty Supply, Shelton's Barber Shop, Fashions for the Foxy Lady.
"Why did they wait three days to send the National Guard when everything is already torn up and burned?" said Renee Harrell, staring at the Guard members, who stared back at her.
"The white people knew what was going to happen," she said. "They wanted it to happen. Now they're here protecting things that are already burned up."
Ms. Harrell's companion, Sandra Smith, said, "This is a modern-day plantation and they are the supervisors."
 
Crowded Gun Shops
 Everyone in this city was talking about the trial and the riots, but a few wanted to register their feelings publicly. The letters column of The Los Angeles Times, always a vibrant sounding board, today published emotional, often eloquent words from 19 readers, nearly all of whom disagreed with the verdict.
"Myself and two of my friends could have taken King down and hogtied him in less than 60 seconds," wrote Dan Jensen of San Clemente. "If 24 trained police could not do it without a number of them first teeing off on King's head 30 or 40 times, it is because they were not properly trained."
Another writer, Marc Norman, said: "As a third-generation, Afro-American Angeleno, I can definitely say I don't want my family's fourth generation here."
In more affluent areas of the city and its suburbs, it was the violence, not the verdict, that was uppermost in the minds of many.
At the loading dock of National Gun Sales in Northridge, a San Fernando Valley suburb within the city limits, workers stacked cartons with 3,000 rounds of 9-millimeter ammunition and 1,000 rounds of 12-guage hollow-point rifle slugs.
Under the terms of the state of emergency and curfew imposed by Mayor Tom Bradley, ammunition and weapon sales have been suspended here, but a steady parade of customers trooped into the store today, buying accessories for guns normally kept at home but these days being carried. The ammunition being unloaded would be ready for another day, when the curfew was lifted.
Joe G., a maintenance man who lives in Saugus, 10 miles north of Simi Valley, came to buy a holster for his .380-caliber semiautomatic handgun. "When they're coming up to the car and pulling people out, you have to protect yourself," he said. "I got my gun with me right now and I'm going to keep it with me til things settle down."
Mr. G., who said he was afraid to have his full name published, said that the dimension of the uprising in Los Angeles exceeded his wildest imagination and was the work of opportunistic thugs who "have absolutely no feelings about Rodney King" and were "just out to get stuff for free," while "the police watched and didn't do anything."
"If there'd been a show of force from the start, this wouldn't have happened," he said.
Another customer at the gun store, Dave Burkman, a contractor from nearby San Fernando, had a theory about why the police responded so slowly, blaming Police Chief Darryl F. Gates. The outgoing police chief, defensive about the behavior of his officers in the King beating and reluctant to cede the reins of his department to Willie L. Williams, the Philadelphia Police Commissioner who will become the chief of police in Los Angeles, set out to send the city a message, Mr. Burkman said.
"He was teaching people a lesson," Mr. Burkman said. "If you don't want police intervention, here's what you get. And it was the ultimate goodbye: Here Willie, it's your town now. I wouldn't put it past Gates to do that in a heartbeat."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1561 words

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: The Campaign;
Riots and Ballots

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
In the 1960's, pictures of Southern police beating black demonstrators helped propel civil rights to the top of the national agenda. A few years later, pictures of black rioters burning American cities helped Republicans push "law and order" to the fore.
If history is any guide, television coverage of Rodney G. King's beating and the protests it inspired have introduced a powerful new force that could reshape an already unpredictable political year. 
 But the question is, in what way would it do so: by focusing public attention on issues that the Democrats consider central to their cause -- civil rights, homelessness, education and economic opportunity for the poor? Or by promoting the law-and-order politics that have long been a hot button for Republicans?
The impact of the verdict and riots on the fate of American politicians and political parties may not seem like a major consideration when weighed against the tragedies of death, arson and mayhem and the heightened awareness of how far from solution the nation's worst social problem remains. But race and crime have opened sores in American politics and changed its direction before, and there is little reason to doubt they will again this year.
 
Possible Advantage for Clinton
 Turmoil in California could change the terms of the Presidential debate to the advantage of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic nominee. As a Southerner who has emphasized racial unity since his campaign began, he might be seen as a healer.
But the lurid television images of looting and burning could provoke deep resentment among middle-class whites. Responding to such resentments helped send Richard M. Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George Bush to the White House and helped relegate the needs of the inner cities to a secondary position in the politics of the last decade.
Taken as a whole, the riots also present a golden opportunity for Ross Perot, the potential third-party candidate. He might well argue that an entirely new approach is needed because the Democrats had their chances to solve the problems of race and poverty in the 1960's and failed, and the Republicans achieved no more in the last two decades.
"Most people considered the verdict unfair, and that seemed to shift the focus decisively towards injustice," said Prof. Larry M. Bartels of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University. "The rioting may have moved it back towards fear. The way national leaders frame the question now will prove significant."
 
Riots of 1960's
 The events of the last 72 hours have stirred memories of the 1960's, whose early years were marked by the civil rights movement and widespread sympathy for the aspirations of blacks in the white middle class. But the Great Society lost momentum, urban riots broke out in 1965, 1966, 1967 and 1968, and significant segments of the white middle class turned to the Republicans, with their emphasis on crime rather than aid programs.
A New York Times/CBS News poll last month showed that blacks and whites in equal numbers, about two-thirds of each group, rejected the notion that it is sometimes "better for the people to take the law into their own hands." The figures might be different today; in this era of instant communication, popular sympathies can swing from one side of an issue to the other in a matter of hours.
But a national poll taken for USA Today on Thursday, after the first night of rioting, showed that 86 percent of white people still considered the King verdict wrong, and 47 percent considered the rioting "wrong but understandable," as opposed to 51 percent who said they considered the disturbances "completely unjustified." That suggests considerable residual sympathy for the plight of urban blacks.
Although such polls often fail to grasp the subtleties of a situation, they can provide valuable first reactions. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Former Representative William H. Gray 3d, now the head of the United Negro College Fund, said on Friday that black people "have not made a lot of progress in this country" in the last 25 years, citing infant mortality, unemployment and education statistics. With his usual flair for the dramatic, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said more young black men were in American prisons than in American colleges.
"The fire next time is going to engulf all of us," said Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, in what could well become his party's clarion call this fall.
Clearly, the Democrats would like to use the rage and despair in Los Angeles to buttress their case that by neglecting domestic problems, President Bush has worsened racial tensions. Mr. Clinton spoke on Thursday of "more than a decade of urban decay" caused by lower Federal spending in cities.
Critics also argue that through devices like the Willie Horton commercial in the 1988 campaign and the description of Democratic civil-rights proposals as "quota bills," Mr. Bush had deliberately tried to play on the fears of the white middle class, particularly rural voters in the South and members of ethnic groups in the Northern cities and suburbs. Those have been the most important swing voters in Presidential politics for 25 years.
 
A 'Racial Firecracker'
 Christopher Arterton, dean of the Graduate School of Political Management in Washington, said, "The Republicans have been playing with this racial firecracker for a long time, and it has gone off in their hands." The riots, he said, could give "a political punch and vigor to a whole constellation of urban issues that they have lacked for many years," but he warned of the kind of white backlash that President Nixon capitalized upon.
Although Mr. Nixon advocated welfare reform and sought to create more jobs in the ghetto by inducing businesses to invest money there, he put the greatest emphasis, at last in his public utterances, on "more police and better pay and training for law officers." Making the political point explicit, Mr. Nixon once said, "Far from being a Great Society, ours is becoming a lawless society."
Republican strategy this time, it appears, will have several dimensions. Mr. Bush has so far tried to balance veiled criticisms of the acquittal of the four policemen who attacked Mr. King with condemnation of the rioters.
But the emphasis has increasingly been on law and order, with the dispatch of Federal marshals and troops to Los Angeles; he spoke at first of his "frustration" at the verdict, but he did not explicitly criticize it. He has not pledged any new programs and has met only with traditional civil-rights leaders, not with outspoken black politicians of the new generation, like Representative Maxine Waters, whose district includes the main riot area.
Although his nomination is assured, the President, always fretful about his party's conservative wing, might be pushed to the right by Patrick J. Buchanan, who is still a primary candidate in North Carolina next Tuesday and California on June 2. In television interviews yesterday, Mr. Buchanan defended the King verdict and attacked the Administration's continuing consideration of a civil-rights prosecution of the four policemen.
Mr. Clinton's mild criticisms brought instant dismissal from Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, who called him "Slippery Bill" and accused him of politicizing the issue. That suggests that the White House thinks it can counter Democratic criticism not only on substantive grounds but also by exploiting the vulnerability of Mr. Clinton as the message-bearer.
Peter Hart, a leading Democratic poll-taker, sees the California turmoil as a plus for the Democrats, on balance, because it feeds into a pervasive public sense that fundamental issues in American society are not being successfully addressed.
"Jobs, education, now the criminal justice system -- people are looking for an alternative because they have the feeling the country is on the wrong track," he said. "That's never good news for an incumbent President. If it lasts, it has to help Bill Clinton, maybe Ross Perot even more."
Looking back three decades, Kevin Phillips, who predicted Republican dominance of the Presidency when others thought the party would never win again, also saw the dramatic events on the West Coast as an opportunity for the Democrats and for Mr. Perot, but doubted the Democrats' ability to exploit the opening before them.
 
G.O.P.'s Hold on Presidency
 "In the 1960's, the liberals were widely seen as having failed to deal with major questions of law enforcement, taxation, fiscal management and the role of government, as well as race," he said. "They were repudiated, and the Republicans moved into a 25-year period of executive hegemony.
"Twelve years of Reagan and Bush has not cured the problems, either. It hasn't given us morning in America. It's produced more columns of smoke rising from our inner cities."
The Democrats' problem, Mr. Phillips asserted, is that most Americans do not care deeply about big cities, and if that is the focus of the debate, they will lose. What they need to do, he said, is to make the cities part of a larger discussion of the Republicans' failure to address things most voters do care deeply about, like education and health care for everyone.

HEADLINE: Regional Update

 BODY:

FUNDS FOR ROADS: A bill that would increase the New Jersey Transportation Trust Fund's spending limit by $200 million to help road construction projects has won final approval in the Assembly. The bill, passed on Thursday, would raise the trust fund cap to $565 million. The fund is backed by state gasoline taxes. The measure was first proposed by Gov. Jim Florio as a way to help the state recover from the recession.
 
MURDER-SCHEME INDICTMENTS: Five people have been indicted in a conspiracy that ended with the shooting death of a New Jersey Institute of Technology campus police officer.
The indictments, returned on Thursday, stem from the Nov. 23 slaying of Revell Quince, 43 years old, as he returned home from work. Prosecutors say Mr. Quince's stepdaughter, Cynthia Gregory, 22, said she engineered the plot because Mr. Quince had sexually abused her. 

NO NEW TRIAL FOR McCANN: A Federal judge has denied a new trial for the ousted Mayor of Jersey City, Gerald McCann, who was convicted of bank fraud and tax charges. The decision Thursday by Judge John C. Lif land of Federal District Court in Newark paves the way for the sentencing of Mr. McCann, who faces up to 71 years in prison and $1 million in fines. No sentencing date was set.
 
NO SIGN OF OFFICIAL: An intensive search continued yesterday today for the president of Exxon International, ho has been missing since Wednesday morning, when his car was found in his driveway in Morris Township, N.J., with the engine running.
"At this point, we don't have anything," Lois Ferguson, a spokeswoman for the Morris County Prosecutor's Office, said about the disappearance of Sidney J. Reso, 57 years old.
 
CONNECTICUT BUDGET STALLS: The $8.08 billion budget that sailed through the Connecticut House on Thursday stalled in the Senate yesterday.
Some House members charged that the Senate was holding the budget hostage to prod the House into passing a bill legalizing slot machines by a veto-proof margin. But Senate leaders denied the charge and said their caucus was grappling with House changes to the budget, especially in the teachers pension fund, welfare and local school aid.

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: Political Memo;
Clinton's Reaction to Rioters Evolves

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 1

 BODY:
Bill Clinton has talked about race relations throughout the campaign. To white audiences in New Hampshire and Michigan and to black audiences in Chicago and Jackson, Miss., he issued pleas for an end to racial division, usually evoking warm applause that would suggest a unanimity of spirit on the issue.
But in the wake of the deadly riots that engulfed Los Angeles this week, Mr. Clinton found himself searching for the right moral and political tone to apply to some knotty and painful issues. Just as President Bush worked throughout the day on Thursday to devise an appropriate response to the Los Angeles violence, so too did Mr. Clinton. 
 After talking in the morning with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Representative Maxine Waters of California and Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton began the day by condemning the acquittal of four white police officers in the beating of Rodney G. King and expressing sympathy for the outrage that fed the riots.
In Chapel Hill, N.C., where he taped radio interviews on Thursday, the Arkansas Governor said he understood the rioters' behavior. "To them, it sort of stands for all the neglect, all the economic decline, all the insecurity of the streets, and not being able to walk safely on the streets," he said.
 
Calls Rioters 'Lawless'
 But immediately afterward, aides said, Mr. Clinton watched the latest news reports from Los Angeles of looting, fires and innocent motorists being beaten by marauders. "There is a great deal of difference between being disappointed, angered and befuddled by the verdict, and taking the law into your own hands," he said today.
At the next stop, Birmingham, Ala., Mr. Clinton scrapped his standard rally speech and told a racially integrated gathering of supporters that the Los Angeles rioters were "lawless vandals." But he also characterized the unrest in Los Angeles as proof that the nation's leaders have allowed "the very fabric of our society to rot out from under us."
He continued: "It does not have to be that these children die in the streets of our cities. It does not have to be that their lives are lost to crime and drugs and gangs. It does not have to be that our schools fail just because the children who attend them come from families who are troubled. Let us resolve in this election, yes, to have a new economic direction; yes, to reorganize America to compete and win; but first to bind up the wounds of this nation."
Evoking memories of the racial strife that wracked his native South during the 1960's, Mr. Clinton told the Birmingham gathering: "We never got anywhere in this part of the country shouting at one another. When we started talking to one another, we found out that we were a lot more alike than we thought."
The evolution continued today, as Mr. Clinton called for a national day of prayer on Sunday. He also made plans to address the issue again when he speaks before the centrist Democratic Leadership Council meeting in New Orleans on Saturday.
"Racism and violence only beget more racism and more violence," Mr. Clinton said today.
Some political experts believe that Democrats will never triumph in a debate about law and order. Republicans seized that high ground years ago, the reasoning goes, and President Bush possesses an advantage of incumbency: He can order Federal troops into riot-torn neighborhoods.
The Clinton camp is hoping it can counter such political wisdom by focusing the debate on underlying causes of the violence. At a news conference in Chapel Hill, for example, Mr. Clinton said, "It is time for the President once again to be involved in sharing the pain as well as the promise of America."
After the Bush campaign accused him of politicizing the riots, Mr. Clinton resisted invitations at a news conference today to criticize the President as he had on Thursday, when he attributed the urban unrest to an "absence of action" on urban issues by successive Republican Administrations. "I don't think today is the day for us to be casting stones and placing blame," he said in a news conference at the State Capitol.
But Gov. Ann Richards of Texas, who endorsed Mr. Clinton at a news conference in Port Arthur, Tex., tonight, did not hesitate to lambaste the President.
"The people of Los Angeles are living through a nightmare that I think has been caused by years of manipulation," she said. "They've been manipulated politically on the issues about race, about economic equality. We've seen a lot of hypocrisy, we've seen a lot of indifference, and we've seen a lot of indecision that's brought us to a place where Willie Horton and Rodney King symbolize the polar opposites of the very same fear that the law cannot protect us and our Government won't do it."
"These young hoodlums who burn and batter and turn our streets into killing fields were once our children," Governor Richards said.

LENGTH: 567 words

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues Rise on Purchasing Report

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates moved lower yesterday, as traders bought notes and bonds after an important barometer of manufacturing activity showed that conditions were less healthy than expected.
Although results of a survey of the nation's purchasing managers showed that manufacturing activity rose for the third straight month in April, the rate of the expansion was down, an indication that credit is unlikely to be tightened soon. 
 Most traders and analysts had expected the survey's composite index to rise from March's 54.1 percent reading, the highest since last summer. Instead, it fell back to 51.3 percent. A reading below 50 percent means economic contraction; above 50 shows expansion.
The survey "showed some erosion in the pace of production and new orders," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Bond prices also got a lift from an article in The New York Times reporting that Brazilian officials had agreed to use some of their $14 billion in foreign-exchange reserves to buy Treasury securities, as part of the country's debt restructuring with commercial bank creditors.
Earlier this week, bond prices rose on rumors that Argentina would be buying zero-coupon Treasury bonds as part of its restructuring efforts.
"The story created expectations that the Brazilians will have demand for zero-coupon bonds as well," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
Trading tailed off in the early afternoon as a number of brokers sent employees home early because of fears that tumult might erupt in New York City, as it had in Los Angeles and some other cities.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100, up 3/8 point, to yield 8.00 percent, compared with 8.03 percent late Thursday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year securities were offered late yesterday at 9925/32 , up 9/32 , to yield 7.53 percent. The 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 1006/32 up 6/32 , to yield 5.30 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell.
Three-month bills were offered in late trading at a discount rate of 3.61 percent, down 7 basis points, or seven one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.73 percent. And one-year bill rates slid by 10 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.09 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Ford Credit offered $700 million of securities backed by auto loan receivables through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 7 3/8 percent notes, which mature on April 15, 1997, were priced at $99.687 to yield 7.454 percent, 65 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
Triple-A ratings are expected from both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead underwriter for an offering of $150 million worth of noncallable three-year notes for Albertson's Inc.
The 6 3/8 percent notes were priced at $99.93 to yield 6.40 percent, 45 basis points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: A Scandal On China's Exchange

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 1

 BODY:
A scandal is unfolding in southern China involving a company that two years ago became the first foreign concern to be listed on a Chinese stock exchange. The garment and real estate company is now embroiled in a battle with regulators over its survival, and the Government has detained two employees and even refused to allow family visits.
The company suggests that it got into trouble because it refused to sell shares to the Chinese Government at a cut-rate price, while the Government hints that it intervened because of financial irregularities. 
 At the heart of the dispute is the Champaign Industrial Company, a joint venture between China and a group of American, Australian and Malaysian investors. In 1990 it sold shares to the public and was listed on the stock exchange in the city of Shenzhen, a special economic zone on the border with Hong Kong.
 
Spreading to Others
 While news of the scandal has generally been confined to the investment community in Shenzhen and Hong Kong, it is slowly spreading to other investors interested in China. The Shenzhen stock exchange recently began offering special shares to foreign institutional investors, and these shares are regulated by the same officials who govern Champaign's domestically traded stock.
The United States Consulate in Guangzhou has begun to investigate the scandal, but would not comment.
Whatever the real story, the battle illustrates the complexities of the Chinese market. Equities are new here, the country's securities regulations all fit into a tiny pamphlet and annual reports may run to eight pages.
"We obviously don't know quite where the truth lies," said Archibald W. F. Hart, director of research at Crosby Securities (Hongkong) Ltd. "The authorities suspect there might be some irregularities in the company and so they're quite keen to crack down on those irregularities and put a stop to them."
After the 1990 offering, the company's stock price soared, from about $2 a share to nearly $40, and the Chinese partner sold out at an enormous profit. But then various Chinese Government branches began paying visits to Champaign, inspecting it and interrupting its activities.
 
Stake Reportedly Sought
 According to a Hong Kong businessman close to the company, the Chinese officials made clear what they were after: a 22 percent stake in the company, at an insider price one-third the market level. Champaign refused, and the problems got worse.
On April 6, five officials in Shenzhen confiscated the official seal of the company and shut down its financial operations. Then the next day, regulators summoned Champaign's deputy general manager and the deputy chief accountant, who are both Chinese nationals.
The authorities later confirmed that the two were being detained but refused to explain just why they were being jailed or to allow anyone to see them.
The People's Bank of China, which regulates the market, refused to comment. However, the official Chinese press has quoted the regulators as saying that Champaign's directors have mismanaged and defrauded the company. The bank is conducting a thorough investigation, the Chinese press reports said.
A public security official in Shenzhen confirmed that the employees had been "temporarily detained," which means there is no need for an arrest warrant, but would not say where they were being held.
 
They 'Try to be Fair'
 Most analysts in Hong Kong are enthusiastic about Chinese stocks and express a measure of sympathy for the Shenzhen regulators.
"They didn't handle this very well," said Xu Yanping, research manager at Hoare Govett Asia Ltd. "But they really try to be fair with all the companies and they really care about their image."
The exchange's image may be tarnished, however, by a lawsuit that Champaign filed on April 18 against the People's Bank of China. The suit charges that the regulators overstepped their powers and illegally detained the two employees.
Shenzhen authorities, concerned that negative publicity could hurt their prospects for attracting overseas investors, have publicly emphasized their responsibility to take action against corrupt practices of listed companies.
American fund managers have been visiting China to survey the investment opportunities and several have already begun purchasing China's special shares for foreigners, called B shares, from Hong Kong brokerage houses. Champaign's shares are A shares, and can be purchased only by Chinese nationals.
 
Real Estate Potential
 One factor in Champaign's favor, if the company ever resolves its problems with Chinese officials, is that it is one of the few joint ventures that have purchased Chinese property development companies. The Chinese real estate market has been growing rapidly, and some analysts say the potential for profits is tremendous.
According to Champaign's annual report, audited by a Chinese accounting firm, revenues jumped from the equivalent of $14.8 million in 1990 to about $54.7 million last year. Profits, however, rose from $5.8 million in 1990 to only $8.4 million last year, in part because of higher administrative expenses and losses from overseas operations.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Weak Purchasers' Report Leads to Drop in the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell in thin trading yesterday, mostly because of a disappointing report from the nation's purchasing executives.
Gold prices rose. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fetched $339 an ounce, up $1.40 from Thursday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold sold for $338.25, up $1.35. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report on business that manufacturing growth slowed in April.
"It was further incentive for the market to sell off the dollar," said Mike Faust, senior currency strategist at MMS International. "The dollar hadn't responded well to as-expected economic data released this week."
Reports showing an improving economy often strengthen the dollar, but on Thursday the dollar fell despite positive economic data. Traders said that numbers showing only sluggish recovery were no longer sufficient to lift the dollar and that the market would need strong data to move upward.
The dollar was not supported by another report yesterday that showed an improving economy. The Government said construction spending jumped 1.6 percent in March to the highest level in 15 months, the third straight increase.
In addition, trading was thin. Most of Europe observed a May Day holiday; only London markets were open.
And in New York many banks decided to close earlier than usual yesterday afternoon. There were fears that the two nights of racial unrest in Los Angeles and protests in other cities might spread to New York.
In New York, the dollar fell to 132.65 Japanese yen, from 133.25 late Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 133.13 yen, from 133.38 yen Thursday. Later, in London, it fell to 132.75 yen.
Also in New York, the British pound rose to $1.7865, from $1.7780 Thursday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7840, from $1.7755.

HEADLINE: New York City Maintains Its Credit Rating

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A major Wall Street credit-rating service expressed increased confidence yesterday in Mayor David N. Dinkins's fiscal plans by maintaining New York City's current credit rating.
"The city's single-A-minus rating on $17 billion in general obligation debt is affirmed," the Standard & Poor's Corporation rating service announced in a press release. 
 The affirmation is significant because Standard & Poor's had threatened to lower the city's rating. The agency had consistently objected to city plans for borrowing hundreds of millions of dollars to close a gap in its operating budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1. A lowered rating would have raised the interest rate the city pays to bond holders, and it would have discouraged some institutional lenders, particularly pension funds, from buying city bonds.
 
Creating a Surplus
 The Dinkins administration allayed the rating agency's concerns this week when it released a proposed $29.5 billion budget that did not include any borrowing for operating expenses. The Mayor said he had managed to create a $455 million surplus in the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, allowing the city to avoid borrowing next year for operating expenses.
Mr. Dinkins's proposed 1993 budget "is the third in a series of improving financial plans since November 1991 to address the substantial budget gaps facing New York City over the next several years," the Standard & Poor's statement said.
"The initial plan, proposed in November 1991, relied on $1 billion of debt proceeds to fund spending," the statement continued. "In addition, the plan was connected to a loosely structured effort to reduce the size of city government, and it relied heavily on uncertain state and Federal revenues, or spending relief."
In January and February, the city "provided more specific information on how and when government 'downsizing' would occur, and with each plan revision, the city demonstrated an ability to reduce its need for deficit financing," Standard & Poor's said.
Mr. Dinkins's spokesman, Leland T. Jones, said last night: "The Mayor was very pleased when he heard the news. The rating agency's decision reflects the very hard choices and the hard work the Mayor had to do to propose his third straight balanced budget. But, obviously, there's a lot more hard work to do in the months ahead."
The A- rating -- on a scale ranging from AAA+ to D, which means payment in default -- means the city remains safely within what Standard & Poor's calls its "investment grade" category. Any rating below BBB is considered "speculative grade."
While expressing renewed confidence, the agency warned that the city still must deal with difficulties. "The city's planned use of its projected $455 million surplus to fund 1993 spending is, of course, a one-shot budget gap closer," it said. "But it is much more preferable than earlier plans to finance the gap with deficit financing."
"Certainly, the current projected surplus cannot be viewed as a panacea to the city's financial stress," the statement continued. "It is more like a down payment toward additional budget actions that continue to be necessary for the city to live within its means over the next few years, without the need for major tax increases."
