HEADLINE: Libyan Deal Has Complications for Lonrho

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, May 1

 BODY:
Shares of the British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. fell sharply in London today after a newspaper reported that the United States Treasury was looking into the company's sale of a one-third stake in Metropole Hotels to Libya.
The company's stock tumbled more than 10 percent -- down 11 pence (19 cents) to close at 95 pence ($1.69) -- after The Financial Times said the Treasury's Office of Foreign Asset Control was interested in the Libyan deal. 
 The newspaper quoted a senior official of the office as having said that Lonrho could be placed on Washington's list of banned companies, if Libya acquired shares that would give that country a significant interest in running a Lonrho company.
 
Treasury's Response
 In Washington today, a Treasury spokesman, Scott Dykema, cited the department's policy of not confirming or denying the existence of investigations. But he repeated a comment he had made on March 30 about the Metropole deal: "That transaction is the kind of thing that we would be interested in taking a look at."
Lonrho said last month that it would sell the stake for 177.5 million ($306 million) to the Libyan Arab Foreign Investment Company.
Lonrho's deputy chairman, Paul Spicer, said The Financial Times article had no new information. "There is not a single new fact, and it was an uneccessary article," he said in an interview.
In recent weeks, the Treasury Department has been cracking down on violations of Washington's 1986 sanctions against Libya. It has sent warning letters to 80 Americans working in Libya and has updated a list of companies and individuals that it said were violating the sanctions.

HEADLINE: Susan Brewster, 41; Helped to Stabilize Yonkers's Finances

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Susan N. Brewster, the executive director of the State Financial Control Board for the City of Yonkers for the last six years, died on Tuesday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. She was 41 years old and lived in Ossining.
She died of complications of leukemia, her husband, Charles Eisenmann, said. 
 Mrs. Brewster helped stabilize Yonkers's municipal finances during a period of budgetary strain and turbulence over millions of dollars in fines that a Federal judge threatened to impose on the city to pressure compliance on housing desegregation.
She outlined what was called a doomsday budget, which warned that if the case was not resolved, the city would be forced to dismantle services to pay the fines. After some fines were collected, officials reached a settlement with the court.
Born in London, Mrs. Brewster grew up in Ossining. After graduating from Brown University, she earned a master's degree in business administration at Columbia.
She started as a financial aide in the Ossining urban renewal agency, then worked for the New York City Office of Management and Budget. She became director of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act program in Fairfield County, Conn., then was appointed the Private Industry Council's deputy director for southern Connecticut. She joined the Yonkers control board as deputy director.
Mrs. Brewster helped found Job's Refuge, a homeless shelter in Ossining. She served on the board of the Open Door Family Health Clinic in Ossining, was a deacon for Briarcliff Congregational Church and was president of the Inter-Faith Council for Action, a housing preservation organization.
Surviving are her husband of eight years; their daughter, Catherine Eisenmann; her mother, Barbara Brewster of Ossining; and three sisters, Deborah Ferrenz of Silver Spring, Md., Abigail McGahey of Tyngsboro, Mass., and Alison Henderson of North Andover, Mass.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
For Draft Pick, Prosperity Is Just Around the Corner

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 1

 BODY:
As a football player at Arizona State, Phillippi Sparks was a sophisticated cornerback. He covered receivers tightly. He hit them hard. He supported the run.
As a world traveler, he was not sophisticated. Until today, he said, he had never been in the East or anywhere near it. But as the Giants' second choice in the 1992 National Football League draft, he flew here today for a weekend minicamp for rookies. 
 "I was shocked by the stadium," he said at a news conference there. "It's beautiful. I didn't know the Giants, Jets and Knights all played here. I guess it keeps the economy going."
The Giants will keep his economy going. And his economy, Sparks said, is in good shape, thanks to Jim Wiedmann of Phoenix, his father-in-law, who manufactures fiberglass tops for tractors.
"He took care of us until I could play pro ball," Sparks said. "Jodi and I have a 2-year-old daughter, Jordin, and a baby due in June. He helped us financially. He bought us a Jeep Renegade, and that would have been illegal if an agent gave it to us. He said as long as you take care of my daughter, I'm happy to do it. I think I would do it for my daughter."
Sparks was full of stories. He told how he had met his future wife when he was a student at Glendale Community College in Arizona.
"I went to an Arizona State squad game," he said. "When you see a pretty girl, you want to talk to her. I said, 'You have pretty eyes.' What a line, huh? I didn't see her again for a year. She was going to Arizona State and taking one course at Glendale, and I saw her again at Glendale. I said, 'You have pretty eyes.' She said, 'Are you the guy I met at Arizona State last year?' "
Then there is the matter of his first name.
"I've been called everything," he said, "Filly-pie, Fillip-ee, things like that. It's Fill-EE-pee. My mother was one of 10 children. Her younger brother, Phillippi, died in a house fire, and she said she would name her first son after him."
Sparks is 23 years old, 6 feet and 195 pounds. He said his right shoulder, which popped out last season, forcing him to miss two games, was sound, and he cited his performance at February's scouting combine, where he bench-pressed 225 pounds 18 times.
He is solidly built, and his scouting report says he is a mean player. He has been compared with Mark Collins, the Giants' left cornerback. Coincidentally, they have the same agent: Frank Bauer of Stockton, Calif.
Sparks was a 24-foot long jumper in high school and a strong safety in junior college. At Arizona State, he also played free safety at times and returned punts and kickoffs.
The Giants, with Greg Jackson and Myron Guyton, are relatively sound at safety. But they hope a younger player can move ahead of Everson Walls, 32 years old, and Perry Williams, almost 32, at right cornerback. Sparks will get the chance.
"He'll work as a corner initially," Coach Ray Handley said. "If he can't play corner, we'll move him to safety. If he can play corner, and we think he can, he'll have a good opportunity to start. In any case, he'll be a kickoff returner and perhaps back up Dave Meggett as a punt returner."
Off the field, Sparks is well-spoken and quick to laugh. He sounds serious about doing the right thing. For example, he did not declare for the draft as a junior, he said, because he wanted a degree. He has four classes left for a degree in social work, which he expects to earn this summer or next spring.
The mild-mannered student changes personalities when he plays football.
"There's a big difference on the field," he said. "Off the field, I feel like any normal person. On the field, I'm totally different. There aren't words to describe how you change. Some players have to be that way to be motivated. I'm self-motivated. When I step across the line, it's business. I hate my opponent. Sometimes, I get carried away a little in practice. Sometimes, defensive players don't always get along with teammates."
Last Sunday's draft, he said, tested his nerves. He said the Giants called him early in the first round and asked about the shoulder. He said a reporter from Buffalo called later in the round and said the Bills were interested in him. When the Giants took him in the second round, he said, his main feeling was satisfaction.
"Three million men would like to be in that spot," he said. "I know the Giants need a little help in the secondary, and I hope and pray I can fill those shoes. I'll play safety or corner or return kickoffs, whatever they want me to do. I just want to make the team."
One question about Sparks concerns his tackling.
"I guess I have a lot to prove," he said. "I thought I was able to do fairly well in my collegiate career. It doesn't matter what other people think, it's what the Giants think."

HEADLINE: Banks Expand Their Range of Services

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Walk into many banks or savings institutions these days and most likely there will be experts on hand to offer mutual funds, annuities and other investment or insurance products.
The traditional services, including checking and savings accounts and certificates of deposit, are still there, of course, but today about half of the nation's 1,600 savings and loan associations and many banks, both large and small, are also selling an array of securities and the like. 
 "There's a major movement in the industry now to market a broad range of investment services," said James Shelton, executive director of the Bank Securities Association, a trade organization for banks based in San Francisco. "It is a natural distribution system."
 
Interest-Rate Help
 Fred DeBussey, senior vice president of Fitch Investors Service, a major rating agency, said: "People feel comfortable with folks they know and a lot of people feel comfortable dealing with banks. Nationwide, this is a trend that is going to grow all through this decade."
Spurring this growth is the current low interest-rate environment, which has forced six-month bank C.D. rates down to an average of less than 4 percent. Many individuals who for a long time became accustomed to high C.D. rates, which as recently as a year ago averaged about 6 percent, are searching for alternative investment possibilities with larger yields; among the choices are common-stock mutual funds and long-term Government bonds.
Retail bankers are seeking ways to provide these and other options to keep their customers from taking their certificate of deposit dollars to brokerage or mutual fund concerns, or to insurance companies.
"If they have to go elsewhere to buy an investment option, maybe they will go elsewhere with their other business as well," said Anthony Ronda, a vice president of Apple Bank for Savings in New York. "And then we might lose them as a customer."
Richard Davies, president of First Chicago Investment Corporation, a subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation, said: "There's nothing we can't offer. Early in the 80's, investment products were a little sideline. We really view this now as a key strategic product line."
As banks expand the range of their services and move more aggressively into investments, and as regulators continue to interpret the laws separating banking and securities more liberally, consumers are becoming more accustomed to a separate area in their branch devoted solely to these kinds of products.
Some banks have even developed their own group of proprietary funds available only in their branches to sell along with the nationally known funds from groups like Fidelity, Dreyfus and Nuveen. In buying nontraditional products from banks, cost is rarely a factor. Many banks give their customers a discounted rate, just as many brokerage firms do. Instead, banks emphasize intangibles like convenience, access and trust.
"Our average client is more risk-averse than the average client of a brokerage firm," said J. Edward Diamond, president of the Dime Agency, a subsidiary of the Dime Savings Bank in New York. "So there is a lower-pressure atmosphere and completely unbiased investment advice."
Gregory J. Weber, a senior vice president of INB Financial Corporation in Indianapolis, noted that securities buyers at banks "deal with one person and can develop a lasting relationship; the customers that we sell these products to trust us."
Even though savings and checking accounts are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, investment and insurance products are not. Therefore, banks try to separate the two categories in their branches as much as possible to avoid some inevitable confusion. In fact, Federal and state laws and regulations force banks to establish distinct subsidiaries or affiliates for their brokerage activities.
As a result, even though there may be one-stop shopping, customers must still deal with different people in a different part of the bank when discussing deposits and loans on the one hand and stocks and insurance on the other.
Sometimes the sellers of nontraditional products are employees of the bank or one of its subsidiaries. Other times they are employed by outside companies hired by the bank to sell and promote stocks, bonds, funds and similar products on the bank premises. In either case, the securities sales representatives must have the licenses necessary to handle those more complex items.
"We intentionally separate people who can sell bank products, which are insured, and investment products, which are not insured," said Loren Smith, a managing director of Citibank. "We bend over backward to make that clear to people."
 
Integrating Services
 According to Roger R. Ludemann, a senior vice president of American Charter Federal Savings and Loan Association in Lincoln, Neb.: "For the most part, customers going into these products typically didn't go into these kinds of products in the past. So we have separate signage to make sure they understand that the products are not F.D.I.C. insured."
Although bankers generally keep the marketing of nonbanking products in a different niche from their banking products, they are developing ways to integrate customers' various financial transactions within the bank. For example, at Bank One in Milwaukee, money received by customers from securities sales is automatically credited to their checking accounts. And at Citibank, bank statements will soon include information about securities transactions along with the standard banking data.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Instead of dealing with a bank teller, a customer at Citibank in Manhattan consults with an investment adviser, Dustin Chase. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Yes, Environmentalists Have Answers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Malcom Wallop notes in his commentary on our energy problems, excerpted in an advertisement by the Mobil Corporation (Op-Ed, April 9), that the North Atlantic and mid-Atlantic offshore areas may contain natural gas reserves equivalent to 450 million and 900 million barrels of oil, respectively. Since United States oil consumption is about 16 million barrels of oil a day, these postulated reserves are equivalent to less than 90 days of consumption. 
 Moreover, natural gas is in great oversupply from domestic wells; according to news accounts many small producers are being driven out of business. We do not need more natural-gas production, especially from expensive offshore platforms in environmentally fragile areas.
According to Senator Wallop, the environmental community, which is against war, coal, nuclear power, hydroelectricity and drilling offshore and in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, must come forward with something positive. Indeed the environmental community has done so.
First among its suggestions is efficient use of available resources. An increase in automobile fuel economy standards from 28 to 40 miles a gallon could save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day, more than 10 times what might be produced from the Arctic refuge. Electric utilities in California and New York have found it is much easier and as profitable to sell energy efficiency as to build generating stations. Environmental organizations have produced energy strategies to save money and reduce pollution and our dependence on imported oil.
Despite massive cuts in renewable energy research funds by the Reagan-Bush Administration, there has been impressive progress in solar electric technologies: the California Energy Commission has stated that wind turbines, among all renewable and fossil fuel technologies, now produce electricity at the lowest cost, a monumental accomplishment.
Senator Wallop may be forgiven. However, if the people at Mobil agree with his statements, we are truly in great difficulty.
 
ALFRED CAVALLO
Princeton, N.J., April 18, 1992
 
The writer is a research physicist at Princeton University's Center for Energy and Environmental Studies.

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
Spring Cleaning for Profit

 BODY:
Tag sales can raise cash in a tight economy, remove clutter, reduce moving costs and help the environment by promoting recycling and re-use. Here are some tips on how to organize a tag sale to achieve the best results.
 
PREPARATION
Use a porch, garage or driveway to prevent strangers from wandering through the house. The sale price should be about a third of the current purchase price of a similar new item. Group sales with neighbors mean more things to sell. Hot sellers this year include LP's, vintage linens, and Victoriana. 

PROMOTION
Advertise at least one week in advance in the classified sections of community and regional papers. Don't overlook local weekly giveaway papers. Use tempting words or phrases like "antiques," "collectibles," "estate sale" or "must sell." But make sure your ad is accurate. Say "no early birds" if you want to avoid bargain hunters at 6 A.M.
 
WHEN TO SCHEDULE
Saturdays and Sundays draw the best traffic. Try Friday and Saturday if you have items that might attract serious antique dealers. Two days is usually sufficient.
 
WATCH FOR THIEVES
Theft is common. Professionals use oversize shopping bags, rolled umbrellas and big inside pockets. To increase security, use only one area for the entrance and exit and ask two or three people to act as monitors. Another person should be posted full time at the checkout table. It is best to accept only cash, but if more costly items require checks, take a cash deposit until the buyer's check clears.
 
USING PROFESSIONALS
The whole job can be turned over to tag-sale professionals (listed under "T" in the Yellow Pages). They charge a commission that averages around 25 percent of total receipts, with a minimium amount as protection should sales be slow.
Sources: The Treasure Hunters of White Plains, which handles tag sales; and Lock, Stock and Barrel Estate Sales of Westport, Conn.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
TURTLE MOON, by Alice Hoffman. (Putnam, $21.95.) Ms. Hoffman's lovely novel insists that there is magic in our lives; its chief characters, two damaged adults and a troubled child, not only believe in happy endings, they are willing to work for them.
HEAD TO HEAD: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe, and America, by Lester Thurow. (Morrow, $25.) A professor and cogent analyst of economics argues that other societies, operating by other rules, are likely to leave the United States behind; his probable winner is Europe.
A COMPLICATED WAR: The Harrowing of Mozambique, by William Finnegan. (University of California, $25.) A brilliant, sometimes devastating eyewitness report of the civil war, sponsored by South Africa, that has killed a million Mozambicans.
LIFE FORCE, by Fay Weldon. (Viking, $21.) The author, a generous satirist and feminist student of modern mores, delivers a sex comedy that is also a parable about the act of creativity itself.
ONLY MAN IS VILE: The Tragedy of Sri Lanka, by William McGowan. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) How the people of a terrestrial paradise (still remembered as Ceylon) turned it, with the assistance of India, into a hell on earth in barely a decade.
ON MOZART: A Paean for Wolfgang, by Anthony Burgess. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) Mr. Burgess, himself a skilled composer when not novelizing, sets his homage in heaven, where the departed utter truths about music that are not easily available on earth.
BEGINNING WITH MY STREETS: Essays and Recollections, by Czeslaw Milosz. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) The 1980 Nobel laureate discusses a variety of themes: time and ephemerality, nationalism and religion, the cardinal sins, his literary friends.

CORRECTION-DATE: CORRECTION-DATE: May 2, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:

CORRECTION:

The nonfiction best seller list on page 32 of The Times Book Review today omits "Brother Eagle, Sister Sky: A Message From Chief Seattle," which was carried for 17 weeks in the nonfiction category.
The change was made because of evidence, reported in a news article on April 21, that the contents of the book do not reflect words spoken by Chief Seattle, but have as their source a speech written for a 1971 movie by Ted Perry, a screenwriter.
 "Brother Eagle, Sister Sky" has been reclassified under "Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous." Because that category lists only five entries a week and the book is not among the top five, it does not appear.

LENGTH: 780 words

HEADLINE: Marilyn in Fantasy

BYLINE: By Robert F. Moss; Robert F. Moss teaches film at Brooklyn College. His most recent book is "The Films of Carol Reed."

 BODY:

QUEEN OF DESIRE
By Sam Toperoff.
276 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $20. 
 A GRECIAN urn may have sufficed as an eternal home for Keats's anonymous Attic maiden, but it would never do for Marilyn Monroe. She'll be spending eternity not only on our movie screens but on our T-shirts, coffee mugs and pizza parlor walls.
In the publishing industry, Monroe's story appears to be both recession-proof and quintessentially American, a tawdry passion play of glittering triumph and early demise that can be retold season after season. In the 80-odd books she has inspired, her life has been pawed over by big-star biographers, archeologists of scandal, conspiracy theorists, semioticians, brand-name authors (Norman Mailer, Gloria Steinem and, of course, Arthur Miller) and every self-proclaimed "friend" with a memoir to peddle.
And now we have Sam Toperoff's "Queen of Desire," a novel based on Monroe's life, modishly blending truth and invention, real people and fictional characters. Mr. Toperoff's publisher invokes E. L. Doctorow and Don DeLillo as antecedents, but this is no jumbo jet of a book like "Ragtime" or "Libra," only a little two-seater that puddle-hops from period to period in its subject's spectacular history.
Mr. Toperoff, who is primarily known as a journalist, though he has published fiction as well, clearly covets the special laurel wreath of the novelist. Unfortunately, in harnessing his imagination to a tale that's been in reruns for 30 years, he has too severely limited his artistic boundaries.
But to give him his due, Mr. Toperoff gets some modest creative fire going intermittently; one effective strategy is to preface each phase of Monroe's life with an adroitly counterfeited magazine interview. Thus, the reader is properly cued for the mixture of imaginary and biographically accurate episodes that follows. The early chapters include graphic accounts of sexual abuse at age 9 by her mother's boyfriend and of her best friend's abortion in a seedy motel during World War II. A subsequent scene from Monroe's stint as a nightclub singer is rather programmatic, however.
A few chapters later, she is an ambitious starlet being coaxed into making minor adjustments to her face by Hollywood's leading plastic surgeon, who is presented to us as a Pygmalion-like genius. But with his secluded hilltop mansion and faint resemblance to a James Bond villain, the doctor arouses more mirth than awe (especially since his name is Goldfedder).
The remainder of the book teeters along this same erratic course. Mr. Toperoff, who has a good deal of sportswriting on his resume, is at his best in depicting Monroe's visit to Yankee Stadium with her second husband, Joe DiMaggio. Invading the press box, Monroe draws on a combination of ingenuousness, guile and glamour to neutralize two male chauvinist columnists, Red Smith and Jimmy Cannon.
IN later chapters, though, the story again turns dramatically inert. A mournful poker game including Monroe, Clark Gable, John Huston and Montgomery Clift, during the shooting of "The Misfits" (Monroe's last film), is intended to bang the drum slowly -- for the star's failing marriage to Arthur Miller, for her lost chances to have a baby, for Gable, who died soon afterward. Instead, the elegiac music is dim and muffled. Also, a defect that sabotages Mr. Toperoff's work throughout is particularly in evidence here: his real-life characters tend to be pallid facsimiles of the vibrant originals.
And yet Mr. Toperoff ends in bravura style, offering a surprisingly taut imagining of Monroe's final hours, during which the actress, groggy from drink and drugs, valiantly debates the overbearing atheist Madalyn Murray O'Hair (of all people) on a call-in radio show. With the unctuous host falling under her spell, the great movie queen sinks into oblivion.
In essence, then, this Monroe is the tragic heroine we know so well -- pathologically insecure, a tender spirit bruised by life, a brilliant natural talent manipulated by men for their own ends, a born victim. But while Mr. Toperoff has the same right to his fictionalized celebrities as, say, Gore Vidal has to his Lincoln and Burr, the reader also has a right to decide that these concoctions suffer by comparison to their historical prototypes.
Still, in this instance enough of Monroe's extraordinary personality survives in Mr. Toperoff's rendering to keep us turning the pages. Dying young, Marilyn Monroe, famous for her eternally famished heart, got the most ironic present the world could give her: endless love. "Queen of Desire" is the latest wreath to be laid on her tomb. It certainly won't be the last.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 918 words

HEADLINE: Flash, Trash and Genius

BYLINE: By Martin Gottlieb; Martin Gottlieb, projects editor for The New York Times, has covered development in New York.

 BODY:

INVENTING TIMES SQUARE
Commerce and Culture at the Crossroads of the World.
Edited by William R. Taylor.
Illustrated. 467 pp. New York:
Russell Sage Foundation. $39.95. 
 ONE evening in 1919, a short, shy fellow named Irving Caesar, who was just short of his 25th birthday, sat close to the stage of one of the cavernous theaters on Times Square and took in a performance of the song "Swanee," which he had written with George Gershwin. The song was a great early triumph for Gershwin, of course, and became the signature piece for the man who performed it that night, Al Jolson. As Jolson sang, Mr. Caesar recalled in a conversation in his Broadway office a full seven decades later, the young man felt bombarded by the excitement and spectacle. It had something to do with Jolson's presence, he thought, and the howl of applause, and the 60 showgirls stretched in a line with light bulbs beaming through their transparent high heels.
Mr. Caesar is not mentioned in the 23 essays that make up "Inventing Times Square," a volume culled from two years of seminars by urban studies scholars meeting at New York University. But noted and amply analyzed is just about every major cultural force that could have contributed to putting him in the middle of this place in the first half of the century, when to be there was to be at the center of a world of flash, trash and pop genius unlike anything before.
The lyricist of "Tea for Two" and "I Want to Be Happy" may be surprised to learn in this book of his debt to late 19th-century liberal Protestant theology, to say nothing of the establishment of tourism as an industry, the transformation of New York City zoning regulations or the pre-Depression accumulation of capital on Wall Street -- forces cited here as contributing to making Times Square the nation's cultural and commercial powerhouse. Together, the essays present a portrait of pre-World War II America in good-natured upheaval, shaking off convention and inventing and reinventing an unpredictable "commercial culture" that thrived in Times Square until, in recent decades, it was pre-empted by what the book's editor, William R. Taylor, a historian at the State University of New York, Stony Brook, defines as a standardized mass culture.
As one contributor, William Leach, who is now writing a history of American consumer culture, says: "Qualities once seen as subversive and immoral and as existing on the margins of American culture gradually moved to the heart of that culture -- carnival color and light, wishing, desiring, dreaming, spending and speculation, theatricality, luxury and unmitigated pursuit of personal pleasure and gain. These qualities were 'consumerist' and are today thought of by many Americans (and by people wanting to come to this country) as the most seductive features of American life and as somehow intrinsic to what it means to be an American."
None of the essays -- which cover topics as diverse as Irving Berlin and Times Square's gay underground -- are without interest, but those that are most intriguing deal with a breaking down of walls between classes, cultures, neighborhoods, pools of money, egos. The result, at its best, was a sort of hyperegalitarianism that still characterizes the city at its most exuberant.
Missing from the book is what others in words, song and spectacle have captured so well: the flavor of this world and what it was like to taste it. This shortcoming notwithstanding, if there is a latent point to the book, it is just how seemingly ignorant and disrespectful of the area is the huge city and state plan to replace Times Square with an office park duded up with lights and with some restored theaters that will fail to mask the plan's monolithic blandness.
This emerges full blast in an elegant and biting afterword by Ada Louise Huxtable, for many years the architecture critic of The New York Times. "From the start, the premises of the development project were wrong," she writes. "This was a back-from-the-dead example of the thoroughly discredited bulldozer urban renewal of the 1960's. It was predicated solely on the aims and principles of private development, even though it was a publicly sponsored and assisted project which used substantial amounts of public money." In Mrs. Huxtable's eyes, the "cleanup" promised by these buildings "was a convenient cover for conventional development." Lighting, building setbacks and other zoning features mandated around Times Square by the city are "a kind of splendid wallpaper, or light show for a performance that isn't there."
If the city chose to, it could try to reinvent Times Square in a way that, despite the physical realities of the development project, is truer to the ethnic, economic and cultural mix that percolates through these pages. Many of the new buildings in the Times Square area stand empty or nearly so, and there's no reason that eventually they should have to be filled entirely with lawyers, accountants and executives from companies looking for skyscraper fire sales. With some government inducements, they might be filled with the back offices that large corporations are moving out of the city in droves and that provide whatever 90's equivalents there are to the entry-level jobs that New York boasted in Times Square's heyday. The work force would no doubt be more varied in every way, and on payday it would no doubt be looking for some new forms of popular entertainment.
What better place than Times Square?

PUB-DATE: May 3, 1992,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 34; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
CHASING THE MONSOON: A Modern Pilgrimage Through India, by Alexander Frater. (Owl/Holt, $12.95.) When the author was a boy, he had over his bed a print of a landscape in India entitled "Cherrapunji, Assam: The Wettest Place on Earth." This book chronicles Mr. Frater's 1987 journey to that site. Last year our reviewer, Raleigh Trevelyan, called it "delightful, witty and unusual . . . full of humorous perceptions."
BRIEF LIVES, by Anita Brookner. (Vintage Contemporaries, $11.) This novel is narrated by Fay Langdon, who has reached old age with the somber realization that she has never really been loved. She looks back on her relationships with her husband and lover, both now dead, and her lover's wife, a woman who seems to embrace life with all the verve and daring Fay lacks. But in the end her story is a courageous one, Joyce Reiser Kornblatt said in The Book Review last year: "[Fay] 'felt a grief that was not merely personalized but general, and an unwilling solidarity with all female destinies.' That empathy, which Fay comes to late, informs all of Anita Brookner's novels. 'Brief Lives' is yet another instance of her large and knowing heart." 
 SOMEDAY, by Andrew H. Malcolm. (Harper Perennial, $11.) Mr. Malcolm, national affairs correspondent of The New York Times, had written extensively on death and dying before he had to confront the final illness of his mother. Last year our reviewer, Perri Klass, called his book "a noble salute to the many layers of family involvement, the specificity of illness and death and the complexity of love."
TO KNOW A WOMAN, by Amos Oz. Translated by Nicholas de Lange. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $8.95.) An Israeli author writes about a retired secret service officer who is surrounded by women he struggles to know: his mother, mother-in-law, teen-age daughter and, in spirit, his dead wife. Last year our reviewer, William H. Pritchard, said that this is a novel in which "the human condition is observed -- kept watch over -- with scrupulous exactitude."
FREE SPACES: The Sources of Democratic Change in America, by Sara M. Evans and Harry C. Boyte. (University of Chicago, $12.95.) "Free spaces" are organizations that bridge the gap between citizens and the state, including church groups, labor unions and farmers' alliances. Although our reviewer, Benjamin R. Barber, did not always see such institutions as salutary (a new introduction addresses his and others' criticisms), he praised the book in 1986 for reminding us "how crucial it is to root democracy in the free space of local human communities."
OBJECT LESSONS, by Anna Quindlen. (Ivy, $5.99.) The intergenerational battle of wills within a large Irish Catholic family in the 1960's is at the heart of this first novel by Ms. Quindlen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for The New York Times. In 1991 our reviewer, Anne Tyler, characterized the book as "intelligent, highly entertaining and laced with acute perceptions about the nature of day-to-day family life."
BELLE MOSKOWITZ: Feminine Politics and the Exercise of Power in the Age of Alfred E. Smith, by Elisabeth Israels Perry. (Routledge, $15.95.) Belle Moskowitz, the largely unsung heroine of Al Smith's political career, was arguably the most powerful woman in American politics in the 1920's. This biography by her granddaughter is "compact" and "compassionate," David Seidman said here in 1987.
NOW YOU SEE IT, by Cornelia Nixon. (Harper Perennial, $9.) This novel consists of a series of intertwined stories about a romantic and impractical California professor, his rigid German wife and their children. Last year our reviewer, Rand Richards Cooper, found "more than a touch of magic in these graceful pages."
THE END OF LAISSEZ-FAIRE: National Purpose and the Global Economy After the Cold War, by Robert Kuttner. (University of Pennsylvania, $16.95.) While laissez-faire policies had a renaissance during the Reagan years, Mr. Kuttner believes that now that the Soviet threat has disappeared, the United States' allies will be less likely than ever to favor the extremes of free trade. The author's "richly detailed evidence . . . will have to be taken into account by anyone assessing the present state of the world economy," Dennis H. Wrong said in The Book Review in 1991.
THE M.D.: A Horror Story, by Thomas M. Disch. (Berkley, $5.99.) William Michaels is not the first doctor to sell his soul to the devil, and in this contemporary Faustian fable the workings of his magical caduceus are grisly indeed. Last year our reviewer, Gahan Wilson, said he was "highly entertained and constantly surprised by Mr. Disch's marvelous imagination."
MAKING SEX: Body and Gender From the Greeks to Freud, by Thomas Laqueur. (Harvard University, $12.95.) The author argues that our assumptions about gender are determined more by cultural bias than scientific fact. " 'Making Sex' is an impressive history of a particularly treacherous set of ideas -- those that relate biology to our concepts of male-female differences," Melvin Konner said here in 1990.
THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING, by Lisa Grunwald. (Warner, $9.99.) Science collides head-on with mysticism when Alexander Simon, a physicist, faces his long-absent mother. Last year our reviewer, Greg Johnson, found the novelist's characterization sometimes superficial, but praised her "gift for irony and her storytelling energy."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2432 words

HEADLINE: It Wasn't Such a Wonderful Life

BYLINE: By Barry Gewen; Barry Gewen is an editor of The Book Review.

 BODY:

FRANK CAPRA
The Catastrophe of Success.
By Joseph McBride.
Illustrated. 768 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $27.50. 
 PROBABLY no film maker ever dominated an era the way Frank Capra dominated his. During the 1930's, at the peak of his powers and his success, he won three Academy Awards and was Hollywood's most highly paid director. He also served as president of both the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the Screen Directors Guild. Time magazine put him on its cover. The Philip Morris Company used him to peddle cigarettes. ("I smoke quite a lot when directing a picture," he was paid to say. "I like to smoke Philip Morris because of their throat ease, so noticeable when one's voice is important.") The film critic for London's Daily Express thought that Capra's political influence was potentially as great as Franklin D. Roosevelt's. And Capra was one of those rare Americans whose name became not only a household word but an adjective as well.
Audiences flocked to see "Capraesque" movies like "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" and "Meet John Doe" -- parables of ordinary people forced to stand up against the greed and corruption of the rich and powerful. Those dramatic comedies, with their depictions of hardship, their "common man" heroes (usually Jimmy Stewart or Gary Cooper) and their celebrations of small-town virtues, gave expression to a country struggling to climb out of the Depression; they have, ever since their release, been identified with Roosevelt and the New Deal. Yet it is one of the great surprises of Joseph McBride's masterly, comprehensive and frequently surprising biography, "Frank Capra: The Catastrophe of Success," that the man who seemed to put the spirit of the New Deal on the screen was, in reality, a closet reactionary and a dogged Roosevelt hater.
Frank Capra managed to fool just about everyone; even his wife was unsure of his political affiliations. Longtime co-workers who were Democrats assumed he shared their political convictions. Katharine Hepburn, who starred in his 1948 picture "State of the Union," thought him "quite liberal"; others applied the term "radical" to him. And why shouldn't they have, when Variety was calling a sympathetic character in "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" "quasi-communistic" and The Saturday Evening Post was reporting that in the Soviet Union Capra was "hailed as a comrade"? But as Mr. McBride, the author of previous books on Howard Hawks, John Ford and Orson Welles, tells us, Capra was a lifelong Republican who never once voted for Roosevelt. He was an admirer of Franco and Mussolini. In later years, during the McCarthy period, he served as a secret F.B.I. informer.
In part, the misperception was due to Capra's writers, who generally ranged from New Deal Democrats to card-carrying Communists. One of Capra's great strengths as a director in the 1930's was his ability to work with anyone who had something to contribute to his pictures, even those who were far to his left. He was also enough of a popular entertainer to cater to his audiences; he understood that during the Depression the most hissable villains were grasping bankers and businessmen.
But ultimately the misunderstanding over Capra's politics seems to be a case of people seeing what they wanted to see. In his analysis of "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," Mr. McBride points out that the Gary Cooper character, far from being some sort of socialist or New Deal liberal, was, if anything, an "enlightened plutocrat" whose philosophy of voluntary giving was little different from that of Republican businessmen opposed to the New Deal; and he shrewdly notes that while Deeds got into trouble for trying to distribute most of the $20 million he inherited to desperate farmers, he was still planning to keep $2 million for himself.
A plutocrat less enlightened than Deeds, Capra derived his conservative politics from his battles to reach the top. His was a Horatio Alger story, full of pluck and luck, but in the end, as Mr. McBride vividly demonstrates, more chilling than inspiring. Capra was born in Sicily in 1897 and came to the United States with his family in 1903. He was raised in Los Angeles, where his father was a laborer and farmhand, and he spent a lifetime escaping from his background and family. While still in grammar school, Capra changed his middle name from Rosario to Russell -- a name that he said "didn't smell of the ghetto." He was determined to go to college despite his family's peasant distrust of learning ("Those people with education can't make a living," his brother-in-law, a fruit peddler, told him). Through a combination of loans, odd jobs and some help from home, he succeeded in graduating in 1918 from the Throop College of Technology (later the California Institute of Technology).
THE movie business was an obvious avenue for an ambitious young Californian, and within a few years Capra was writing gags for the Our Gang series and the comedian Harry Langdon. In 1926 he directed his first feature, "The Strong Man," starring Langdon. A year later he moved to up-and-coming Columbia Pictures, beginning a productive 12-year association with the studio's equally ambitious head, the feared and fearsome Harry Cohn. By the early 1930's Capra was Columbia's most successful director, earning huge salaries from the Depression-resistant movie industry for action-adventure films with names like "Submarine," "Flight" and "Dirigible." As the economy collapsed around his countrymen, the self-made Capra, Mr. McBride says, "could see in himself the living proof of . . . faith in the American system."
Still, his greatest triumphs were ahead of him. In 1931 he met the playwright Robert Riskin and started a collaboration that ran through nine screenplays and included the bulk of his most memorable movies. With Riskin, a Roosevelt Democrat, giving edge to Capra's natural sentimentality, the director hammered out a formula that took his films to another level, turning him from a successful studio hack into the kind of person Time puts on its cover and The New Yorker writes profiles of. His peers recognized his transformation by voting his picture "It Happened One Night" the best film of 1934 and awarding him his first Oscar for direction. (Riskin also won for best screenplay, and the two leads, Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert, won for best actor and best actress, a sweep of the five top prizes that would not be duplicated until "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" in 1976.) Capra won another Oscar two years later for "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," directed from another Riskin script, and yet again in 1939 for Riskin's adaptation of the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart play "You Can't Take It With You." Even without Riskin, Capra stayed with the formula to make "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" in 1939 and "It's a Wonderful Life" in 1946.
IT is hard to believe that anyone who reads "Frank Capra" will ever be able to watch these movies in quite the same way again. Instead of lively, socially conscious entertainments, one is apt to see the idealized fancies of an insecure immigrant parading his Americanism across the screen, or the contradictions of a parvenu who was contemptuous of the masses yet eager to please them. The platitudes in the films -- their persistent prating about human kindness and loving thy neighbor -- are likely to be more annoying than before, the melodrama at their heart more obtrusive. Isn't "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" really about the conflict between an overaged Boy Scout and an ogre who beats up little children? Does it have anything to do with politics at all?
Yet among the elements that make this book so rich is its intertwining of the bad and the good, so that while we may be appalled at the way Capra turned his back on his parents, we can at the same time admire his sheer determination to make something of himself in the face of huge obstacles. Similarly, if the themes that once provided Capra's films with their resonance no longer hold up, other qualities in them emerge clearer than ever: Capra's narrative strengths, his skill with ensembles, his facility for wringing every bit of juice out of a scene, his attention to (and joy in) his secondary characters. By filling his pictures with an assortment of kooks and clowns, Capra looked forward a few years to Preston Sturges, and backward to Charles Dickens. Although Mr. McBride does not say enough about these particular virtues, he makes certain that we will never forget another of Capra's special talents: his extraordinary ability to bring out the best in his actors.
Mr. McBride shows that Capra almost singlehandedly created a pantheon of screen idols. He established Jean Harlow as a star. He turned Clark Gable into a sex symbol. He highlighted Barbara Stanwyck's special combination of grittiness and vulnerability, making her an overnight sensation. He coaxed Gary Cooper into two of his finest performances, as Longfellow Deeds and John Doe. He changed Jean Arthur from an anxiety-ridden contract player into a feisty leading lady. He molded Jimmy Stewart into Jimmy Stewart. His actors understood what he did for them. "I just had complete confidence in Frank Capra," Mr. Stewart said. "I always had, from the very first day I worked with him. . . . I just hung on every word Frank Capra said."
Jimmy Stewart had cause to be doubly grateful to Capra. Following his military service as a pilot in World War II, the actor's future was in doubt, and he was thinking of quitting Hollywood. Capra, just back from the Army, where he had produced a celebrated series of propaganda films called "Why We Fight," revived Mr. Stewart's career by casting him in "It's a Wonderful Life." It was Capra's first postwar movie. It was also the last significant picture he directed -- and while it may now be Capra's most popular movie, television's very own Christmas chestnut, it was, Mr. McBride tells us, a box-office disappointment at the time of its release.
Though Capra's film making stretched into the 1960's, the remainder of his work consisted of formulaic exercises and remakes of earlier films, banal star vehicles and clinkers pure and simple. His was, says Mr. McBride, "the most precipitous decline of any American film maker since D. W. Griffith."
One can glean a host of reasons for the collapse from the last 150 pages of Mr. McBride's text. Capra himself blamed Hollywood's lower budgets and standards. Jimmy Stewart thought the problem was the change in the industry after the big studios lost power. Another co-worker noted that Capra seemed more anxious after World War II. Certainly he was more closed-minded, no longer the sounding board for his colleagues' ideas that he had been in the 30's. Instead of collaborating with his writers, now he was interested in grabbing most of the credit for himself.
One critic, William S. Pechter, believed that Capra had nothing more to say in his films. "It's a Wonderful Life," he argued, should logically have ended with the hero's suicide; the intervention of a guardian angel was a mask for Capra's deep pessimism about his fellow Americans, and revealed his intellectual bankruptcy. Mr. McBride talks about a lack of courage, especially after the Red scare of the late 40's and early 50's took hold. Any and all of these explanations can serve, but together they add up to the fact that Capra was very much a man of his time and the times had passed him by.
Mr. McBride's account of the last years is grueling and terribly sad. Capra found it increasingly difficult to secure work. He managed to direct only three features in the 1950's, and his last film was the egregious "Pocketful of Miracles" in 1961, a remake of his 1933 success "Lady for a Day." One sign of Capra's desperation in these years was his offer to direct an episode of the television show "The Addams Family." Another was his idea for a movie on the life of St. Paul -- starring Frank Sinatra. He suffered from debilitating headaches and was often suicidal. Though his first wife and many of his closest collaborators, including Harry Cohn and Robert Riskin, were Jewish, he now began blaming the Jews for his troubles. He finally retired from film making in 1966 and devoted the next several years to writing his autobiography. "The Name Above the Title" was published in 1971, and appears to have been a lie practically from beginning to end. "Frank Capra" is in one sense a 768-page corrective to the false impressions it gave.
Amazingly, Capra hung on for another two decades. When he died last year at the age of 94, he had been out of the movie business for 25 years. He had not made a major motion picture for 45 years. No doubt many people who saw his obituary were taken aback, believing he had died long before. The truth is, he had.
 
 
 
BETWEEN THE IMAGE AND THE MAN
 Joseph McBride was on an assignment for Variety when he first met Frank Capra in 1975 at a country club near Palm Springs, Calif. The director, he recalled, "was telling me how he hated rich people. And right in the middle a man from the country club came over and said, 'Frank, here are the pictures of you playing golf with President Ford,' and Capra said, 'Ah, wonderful.' "
Capra looked at the photographs for a moment and then asked, "Where was I? Oh yeah, I was telling you that I've always had a hatred of rich people," Mr. McBride said by telephone from his home in Los Angeles. "Then he just continued, without losing a beat. That illuminated something for me about Capra: there was a contradiction between the image and the man."
In 1982, Mr. McBride wrote a celebration of that image, the television script for "The American Film Institute Salute to Frank Capra." During that assignment, he discovered more contradictions in the Capra myth. In 1984 he started working on "Frank Capra," his 11th book.
Capra was happy to help, the 44-year-old Mr. McBride said. "I'm very grateful to him." But the director's stroke in 1985 made further cooperation impossible.
Some members of Capra's family and film crew also cooperated. They "clearly felt very hurt by his autobiography," Mr. McBride recounted, "and they were more than willing to open up and tell me anything that I needed to know. If he had only given people more credit, they would have been better disposed toward him."
Nonetheless, Mr. McBride said, "I still think he's a great director, and I still respond to the same things in his films -- the energy and the idealism mixed with disillusionment." -- JOSEPH A. CINCOTTI

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Capra directing his last movie, "Pocketful of Miracles," in 1961. (The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences/United Artists/From "Frank Capra")

PUB-DATE: May 3, 1992,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 27; Column 1; Magazine Desk
