HEADLINE: The Curse of the Statehouse

BYLINE: By Robert Reinhold; Robert Reinhold is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
It is not unusual for Pete Wilson, the Governor of California, to stay up half the night writing speeches at the Governor's residence in Sacramento while state workers sleep. And according to his wife, Gayle, he toiled until 4 in the morning before his address to Stanford University's centennial convocation last Oct. 1. This was no routine speech, because it was his first major public appearance after vetoing a bill giving homosexuals state protection against discrimination in the work place.
Feeling betrayed that the centrist Republican Governor had vetoed the bill after signaling he would sign it, enraged gay protesters in San Francisco had smashed up a state building a day earlier. The Governor's security people urged him to cancel, but he went to Stanford anyway, scarcely looking up while delivering his 15-minute speech against a thunderous barrage of shouts from 300 demonstrators straining against police lines. At one point, an orange flew out of the crowd toward the podium. Wilson reached up, caught it and threw it back. Tense bodyguards hustled Gayle Wilson out of the area. When it was over, George Raine, a political correspondent for The San Francisco Examiner, sought out the Governor and found him shaken, his pale-blue eyes moist with tears. 
 It was a rare moment of public emotion for the Governor, a man of measured actions and methodical habits who spends his entire 12-hour days at the state Capitol without taking off the jacket of his gray pin-striped suit. It was also yet another sign that all had not gone according to plan for Wilson, who had abandoned a safe seat in the United States Senate two years ago to run for Governor of the nation's largest state.
Wilson came to office 16 months ago amid high hopes and expectations -- with a reputation as a pragmatic conciliator and consensus builder who could bring changes to a troubled state and a virtually paralyzed state government. National Republican leaders had their own agenda for the new Wilson administration: to prevent California's Democrats from controlling reapportionment in the state, which, after the November elections, will hold roughly one of every eight seats in Congress.
Now it might be said that at age 58, after more than a quarter of a century in public life, Pete Wilson has the job he always wanted -- but at the wrong time.
Through most of his career, Wilson was seen as the quintessential Republican moderate, a fiscal conservative who favored "choice" on abortion, while keeping lines open to environmental, Jewish, women's, gay and other groups often at odds with traditional Republican thinking. He himself prefers to be called a conservative, though a "compassionate" one. Either way, after just a few months in office last year, he was widely touted by national publications as a top Presidential contender in 1996.
But the question, for now at least, is not whether Pete Wilson will run for President of the United States but whether he can survive more than one term as Governor of California.
Economic and political realities have blunted his goals. The combined forces of recession and cutbacks in military spending have plunged California into its worst economic slump since the Depression. Wilson himself opened a large fissure within his own party last year when he allied himself with the Democrats in the State Assembly to raise $7.3 billion in new taxes to help close a staggering $14.3 billion budget gap -- more than a third of the state's entire budget and the largest in the history of any American state. He has since alienated the Democrats also, already unhappy about his backing of a voter initiative that limited the terms of state legislators, by besting them on reapportionment.
By mid-March of this year, according to the California Poll, Wilson's job-performance rating had slid to the lowest point of any Governor in 30 years, with only 22 percent giving him excellent or good marks. This contrasted with 43 percent for his Republican predecessor, George Deukmejian Jr.; 53 percent for the last Democrat, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., and 42 percent for Ronald Reagan, at comparable points in their administrations. "He's dodging grenades from left and right," says Dan Walters, the veteran political columnist for The Sacramento Bee. "This illustrates how difficult it is for a centrist to govern when dealing with polarized elements. People in the middle have no natural base."
WILSON'S TRAVAILS demonstrate how difficult it has become to govern the states, where the domestic problems that have taken second billing in Washington for more than a decade have come home to roost. Probably nowhere does this take more dramatic form than California, where vast immigration has swelled the population to more than 30 million. Since August 1990, the once-booming state has lost 690,000 jobs (or 1 in every 20), many of them high-paying positions in the stricken aerospace and defense industries. Over the last year, unemployment has run well above the national average, standing at 8.5 percent in March. The Los Angeles Aerospace Task Force recently estimated that 210,000 more jobs will be lost in the Los Angeles area by 1995 as a result of defense cutbacks. Commercial construction fell by 37 percent in 1991, and retail sales dropped by 3.4 percent from last year during the crucial November-December period.
This slump has unmasked severe fiscal problems that have been building in California since 1978. That was the year a tax revolt led to the passage of Proposition 13, which limited local governments' taxing authority and thereby shifted the main burden of providing services to the state. Later ballot measures further handcuffed the Governor and Legislature by guaranteeing minimum funds for public schools and other programs. Also, Congress has repeatedly imposed responsibilities on the states -- for Medicaid, welfare and other programs -- without necessarily financing them; in all, $1.4 billion of California's current general fund of $43.8 billion goes for such Federal mandates. The problems created by all this were disguised by the unrelenting economic growth of the 1980's, when it seemed as if the state were immune to national ups and downs, and revenues grew regularly by as much as 8 percent a year.
But now the Governor and the Legislature face fiscal problems of terrifying proportions. Wilson's proposed $60.2 billion budget for 1993 looked hopeless by late last month. The Commission on State Finance estimates that revenues will fall short of proposed spending by as much as $11 billion.
The prolonged drought, the San Francisco earthquake, the Oakland fire, the crop freeze, the whitefly infestation and other natural calamities have added to the state's burdens, not to mention such chronic ailments as traffic congestion, poor schools, high crime and smog. The major bond-rating agencies have downgraded California's credit rating, and some economists argue that California has begun a long decline from which recovery will be difficult. Economic stagnation, however, appears to have done little to slow population growth. Last year, the population increased by 670,000, nearly half of it from migration from other states and foreign countries. This increase further strained schools, welfare, public health and other entitlement programs. California has 12 percent of the American population, but bears 26 percent of the welfare burden.
"California was supposedly the bellwether for the nation, a model for others," says Mervin D. Field, director of the California Poll. "But now its problems are as large as the promise once was. The constraints on the Governor and Legislature are greater now than they've ever been."
ON A GLORIOUS SUNNY LATE-WINTER day in Sacramento, the grounds around the state Capitol are lush with vegetation that speaks to California's great diversity and wealth: towering ponderosa pines, Mexican fan palms, rows of elegantly manicured Irish yews, leafy citrus trees dripping with Valencia oranges. In a first-floor corner office behind a wall of bright red camellia blossoms, Peter Barton Wilson, 36th Governor of California, greets a visitor in the room from which Ronald Reagan, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr. and George Deukmejian ran the state. After 24 years of leadership under these men, during which many festering problems went neglected, the time would seem to have come for a pragmatic "hands on" technician of government like Wilson, a former Mayor of San Diego.
Wilson says he has always preferred the executive role to the legislative. "I have held both," he says. "The executive is much more challenging, much more demanding, much more satisfying. I came back to this job, if not knowing the full dimensions, at least knowing that it was not an easy job."
A close friend of Wilson's, Stuart Spencer, a Republican strategist, had strongly urged him not to run for Governor. "Stu sat down with me and said, 'Go ahead, you hard head,' " Wilson recalls. " 'You will do what you want to do, but I think being Governor of any major state is a terrible responsibility. The states have become ungovernable, and California may be the most of all.'
"Well, I don't buy the fact that it's ungovernable, that you cannot make change. I didn't come back here to wear a boutonniere or to cap off a resume. I came back intending to make change. I made the decision some years ago not to practice law and not to make money. This is a job I wanted for some time. In terms of challenges, it offers a great deal more now than it has to any of my predecessors."
Wilson is not alone as a Governor facing fiscal problems. Like many Republicans, Wilson attributes many of the states' ills to the "built-in autopilot spending" of Congress, of which he was a member for eight years and which he contends "distorts and reorders state priorities and state spending." He makes no mention of the fact that another Republican Governor of California, Ronald Reagan, was the architect of the new federalism, which shifted much of the load onto the states.
Still, Wilson is the most active Governor the Capitol has seen in years, and he has brought to the table the most ambitious set of programs since the heyday of California's great builder, Gov. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown.
At the top of his agenda is a "preventive" government program meant to redirect some of the money being spent on "remedial programs" like welfare toward prenatal and early childhood care, to address what he calls "the default" of parental responsibility. He speaks often of infants born with crack addiction and the effects of fetal alcohol syndrome.
Another top priority is to reverse what he sees as a drastic deterioration of California's economic competitiveness and business climate, by lowering such barriers as a costly, fraud-ridden workers' compensation system for injuries. ("Most of the disabilities under which employers labor in this state have been imposed either by acts of the Legislature or local government," he says. "And there has been an attitude of arrogance, that we were irresistible to business.")
Wilson has also called for a revamping of the state's welfare system, whose caseloads have been growing at four times the rate of population growth and which he says is crowding out crucial health and educational programs. He would cut welfare grants by 10 percent overall, and add incentives to get families off welfare, like a 15 percent reduction after six months, except when the adult is disabled or too old to work, and a $50 monthly increase for teen-age parents who remain in school.
He has coupled these changes with a proposal to give the Governor sweeping new budget powers, a proposal he hopes to steer around the Legislature by placing it on the November ballot as a voter initiative. If passed, it would give the Governor the power to reduce government salaries and spending if the Legislature does not pass a budget acceptable to him by July 1, and then later declare fiscal emergencies if the budget becomes unbalanced, allowing him again to reduce spending unless the Legislature enacts its own plan within 30 days.
Wilson has also offered the outlines of a new long-range water policy, meant to alleviate shortages in some areas and repair environmental damage by various means, including the politically controversial concept of creating a freer market in water so that it can be transferred to cities and other areas of need.
And he has opened an emotionally charged debate by contending California is caught in "a population squeeze," its coffers drained by growth in school-age children, welfare recipients and other tax "receivers," caused in part by huge immigration, while older, working-age residents who pay the taxes are increasingly leaving the state. Critics argue, and Wilson vigorously denies, he is trying to scapegoat the poor and foreign for the state's ills.
Whatever the merits of Wilson's proposals, budget constraints have made it all but impossible to do much for now, and it is difficult to discern a consistent Wilson ideology. "I know Jack Kemp's views, I know Dick Cheney's," says one leading California Republican who has supported Wilson for 25 years and spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But I don't know Pete Wilson's. He is pro-choice on abortion, but if the majority of the public became pro-life, would he become pro-life? I don't know."
Almost from the beginning of his political career as an assemblyman, then later as a mayor and senator, Wilson has been called by political observers the consummate politician, paddling left, then right, just enough to keep his political canoe closest to both sides of the stream. "His recent rightward tilt is explained by the fact that he's in serious trouble with the people who elected him," says the Republican.
Wilson maintains that such accusations are "flatly contradicted" by his record in politics. "I have very consistently been a fiscal conservative," he says. "I have been recognized for good stewardship, for being tight with the taxpayers' dollars. The sole dereliction in that respect was the tax increase last year, and it was compelled by the Constitution and the inability of the Legislature to come to grips with deeper cuts."
When Wilson came to Sacramento as Governor last year, he was welcomed by both Republicans and Democrats, many of whom had become frustrated after eight years of the dour Governor Deukmejian. At the outset, Wilson seemed to do all the right things. Reaching out for bipartisan support, he did the unthinkable, for a Republican: he met with the Democratic caucuses of the Democratic-controlled Legislature, went to Assembly Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr.'s parties and showed up at Brown's office without staff. Senator David A. Roberti of Hollywood, the President pro tem of the State Senate, recalls getting a call from the Governor last summer amid the budget frenzy. Wilson did not want to discuss the fiscal crisis, Roberti says, slapping his forehead in amazement, but rather Norplant, the implanted birth-control device. The Governor wanted government family-planning programs to make it available to impoverished women of childbearing age.
Aided by the Democrats, Wilson finally got a budget last summer, with a painful mix of new taxes, fees and spending cuts. In the fractious Assembly, Speaker Brown delivered nearly every Democrat for Wilson, while the Governor, who had alienated his party's own right wing, could muster only 9 of the 31 Republicans on the crucial tax votes. The national news media portrayed Wilson as a hero; in California, his popularity nose-dived.
That was just the beginning of Wilson's ordeal. Many in Sacramento trace the Governor's troubles in large measure to the loss of Otto Bos. A former newspaper reporter who had joined Wilson when he was Mayor of San Diego, the Dutch-born Bos was not only his director of public affairs but one of his closest advisers and friends. The tall, jovial Bos, well liked and admired for his political savvy by both Republicans and Democrats, was a master at image building, and had a gift for anticipating the public relations consequences of political acts. For Wilson, he was also a keen set of eyes and ears on the world. While playing soccer on a fine Sunday afternoon in San Diego last June 2, Bos collapsed and died of a heart attack at the age of 47.
It is impossible to say for sure if Bos could have prevented his old friend's current plight, but after his death Wilson inflicted a number of wounds on himself. His handling of the gay-rights-bill veto illustrates this. Wilson had told a group of newspaper editors that he would "very likely" sign the bill, similar to one vetoed by Deukmejian. But instead he surprised everyone, including many of his own staff, by issuing a detailed, lawyerly veto message that said the state Constitution and various existing state laws and regulations already conferred adequate protection on homosexuals. Critics said he was pandering to the right wing still seething over his new taxes. The Governor was shocked by the furious reaction. In the end, his stand lost him many of the liberals and moderates who had voted for him, while doing little to shore up his right flank.
Then came the embarrassing episode following his State of the State Address in January. In an apparent effort to counter suggestions he was out of touch with people, he inserted into the speech three unnamed Californians he said he had met who were suffering from the recession. Wilson found himself ridiculed nationally when reporters asked for the names of the men, only to be told they were "allegorical" by his press office.
Wilson may have also misjudged the Sacramento he returned to after a two-dec ade absence. (He had been an Assemblyman from San Diego for six years.) Some say he took a myopic Washington view when he brought in most of his Senate staff, who tended to look down on the Legislature and the Sacramento press corps. To rectify this, he recently added three top deputies familiar with Sacramento politics: Bill Hauck, George Dunn and Joe Shumate.
But Wilson now faces an antagonistic Legislature. Many members resent him for supporting the successful 1990 voter initiative that imposed tight term limits on both houses (a measure that would sweep out the current Senate within eight years, the Assembly in six) and has already cut staff budgets by 40 percent. Wilson made even fewer friends when he vetoed three Democratic-drawn plans for reapportionment as gerrymandering, and asked the California Supreme Court to take over the process. A panel of retired judges appointed by the court ignored existing districts, forcing incumbents into a mad scramble. Even the powerful Senator Roberti found himself redrawn out of his seat in Hollywood and forced to take a second residence in the less-liberal San Fernando Valley to survive. "Things went south with the leadership on reapportionment," says Bob White, the Governor's chief of staff, warning that his boss is a "dogged" fighter who will not easily by beaten. "Pete Wilson has always been underestimated."
 IN ALL THIS, WILSON HAS remained, as Ronald Brownstein of The Los Angeles Times once put it, "smooth and cool and opaque, like a stone in a river." The Governor views the collapse of his popularity with a mixture of resignation and determination. "It obviously does not please me, nor does it surprise me," he says, adding that he found the public "schizophrenic" about the dire budget situation, at once outraged over the new taxes but unwilling to accept deep cuts in social programs. He waves off questions about Presidential ambitions with a standard answer that he is more concerned now with being a good Governor.
Throughout his career, Wilson has brought less the passion of an ideologue than the relentlessness of a workaholic, the obsessiveness of a perfectionist. Born in Illinois, Wilson, the son of an advertising salesman, grew up in St. Louis, attended the fashionable St. Louis Country Day School and then Yale, where he majored in English literature and graduated in 1955. He came to California as a Marine infantry officer, stationed at Coronado, near San Diego.
After discharge, he attended law school at Boalt Hall at the University of California at Berkeley, graduating in 1962, then got involved in Republican politics, working as an advance man for the failed gubernatorial campaign of Richard Nixon that year. He then gravitated to San Diego and, finally passing the bar exam after three failed attempts, practiced law there for a couple of years before running for State Assembly, winning a seat in 1966 at age 33. He rose quickly into the Republican leadership in the Assembly, but left to run successfully for Mayor of San Diego in 1971 and again in 1975. In 1978, he made a stab at the Republican gubernatorial nomination, but ran fourth in a field of five in the primary -- rejected as too liberal, by California Republican standards, for having backed Gerald Ford over Ronald Reagan in the 1976 Presidential race and for opposing the tax-cutting Proposition 13 that year.
He did not give up. After winning a third term as Mayor in 1979, he won the Republican nomination for United States Senator in 1982, and ploddingly outdistanced his Democratic rival, Jerry Brown. He won re-election in 1988, with the largest vote in California history, and then two years later beat out the flashy Democratic nominee for Governor, former Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco, in a whisker-thin victory.
If friends and foes agree on anything, it is that Pete Wilson is the hardest-working, most diligent and tenacious Governor that California has seen in modern memory. Wilson's aides run ragged late into most nights, as well as most weekends. "Whether one agrees with him or not, he has brought to the job more sheer energy and tenacity than I've ever seen in a public official," says Steven A. Merksamer, Deukmejian's former chief of staff. "He's a bulldog and a workhorse. He may be down, but he can never be written off."
Thomas W. Hayes, the Governor's director of finance, recalls Wilson's presentation of his first budget last year. Normally, the Governor presents an overview, then leaves, allowing the experts to explain the details to the press. As the briefing progressed, Hayes remembers, "I got a bruise on my arm, and the Governor knocked me off the podium." Wilson remained for an hour and a half, answering the most complicated questions. Another high-ranking official recalls trying to brief Wilson on the welfare issue. "I was supposed to be explaining the program to him," he says. "But here he was explaining it to me."
Wilson typically comes home late, has a cocktail (Scotch and water or gin and tonic) before dinner and then stays up late reading briefing papers. Even his leisure reading tends to be laden with policy content. Among the titles on his bed stand recently were "We Must Take Charge: The Schools and Our Future," by Chester E. Finn Jr., the neoconservative critic of teachers and schools; "The Content of Our Character: A New Vision of Race in America," by Shelby Steele, the conservative black scholar who argues that it is time for blacks to cease thinking of themselves as victims, and, in apparent preparation for California's first scheduled execution since 1967, "Public Justice, Private Mercy: A Governor's Education on Death Row," former Governor Edmund G. (Pat) Brown's 1989 book (with Dick Adler) on the dilemmas he faced in granting clemency appeals.
Indeed, according to the Governor's staff, the appeal on behalf of the condemned murderer Robert Alton Harris produced one of the most wrenching episodes of the Wilson administration. Though long an advocate of the death penalty, Wilson was presented with a difficult predicament in Harris's case. In 1978, while Wilson was Mayor of San Diego, Harris had committed the most heinous of crimes, shooting two teen-age boys to death in cold blood to cover up a robbery, then calmly eating the hamburgers the two boys had just bought. Yet Harris was also a victim of fetal alcohol syndrome and had a vicious father who beat him -- the very forms of prenatal and childhood abuse that Wilson has been combating. On the evening of April 16, Wilson rejected Harris's clemency appeal, saying he had compassion for Harris the child but that Harris the man was still responsible for his conduct. Even critics of capital punishment agreed that Wilson had diligently studied the case, as well as the scientific evidence about fetal alcohol syndrome. Harris went to his death in the gas chamber at San Quentin on April 21.
Despite the pace he sets for himself, friends say Wilson can relax. A dry wit, he invents limericks and is a superb impressionist, particularly of his former colleague in the Senate, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. Though his voice is not great, he is not shy about performing at roasts and functions, delighting a high-powered audience last month at a dinner at the Beverly Hilton Hotel celebrating his 25th year in politics with a song-and-dance routine in a straw hat. He rises early for workouts on the Stairmaster Gravitron or on the treadmill at the Governor's residence, where he lives with his second wife, Gayle Wilson, and one of her two sons from a previous marriage. "This is a guy who gets up ready to go to work," says Gayle. "He's happy."
But Wilson cannot be entirely happy about the turn of events in Sacramento this year. Not least is the very personal and poisonous feud that has broken out with Speaker Brown.
FROM THE GOVERNOR'S ground-floor corner office, the axis of power runs to the opposite corner of the domed Capitol, upstairs on the second floor. There, amid the splendor of Victorian furniture and massive floral displays, presides Willie Brown, the second most powerful man in California, nearly 28 years in the Assembly, the last 11 as Speaker. He is determined to destroy Wilson politically.
One of the shrewdest politicians in America, Brown could hardly offer a sharper contrast to the blond, button-down Yalie Governor. Born in 1934, just seven months after Wilson, Brown, the son of a black Pullman porter in rural Mineola, Tex., came to California as a youth and worked his way through college and law school as a doorman, janitor and shoe salesman; unlike Wilson, he passed the bar exam on his first try. While the Governor's favorite pastime is barbecuing chicken for friends, Brown is an aficionado of fast cars and $1,500 Italian double-breasted suits.
After initially playing ball with Wilson, Brown has already this year opposed the creation of a new Office of Child Development and Education -- one of the Governor's top priorities -- dueled him on the budget, stalled key appointments and snubbed the the Governor's party after the State of the State Address in January. "I certainly wouldn't want to use whatever free time I might have to be with him," Brown told reporters.
"I think he hopes ultimately to get elected to the Presidency," says Brown. "But the first step is to get rid of Willie Brown, David Roberti, the Democratic majority in both houses, the influence the Legislature has on public-policy making in California. Period. And I think those five things constitute his menu, his recipe, ultimately propelling himself into the national spotlight as the Governor from the biggest state in the union who controlled welfare, changed the face of California politically on a partisan basis. That's his goal.
"I feel betrayed," Brown continues. "I agreed to cut my constituency for the solution to the budget problem last year. I cut welfare. I have a history of working closer with governors than probably any other Speaker ever. Wilson has been the only one I've worked with who is totally political in every one of his decisions. Reagan was not, Jerry Brown was not, Deukmejian wasn't in any of his decisions. None of the other three had such an overriding ambition for themselves personally and for their party. If this guy were up for election today, he'd be defeated. Get-even time will be November 1994, when he's retired, when his term is limited to one."
Senator Roberti, while less strident, is no fan of Wilson's either. "To win back the right wing, the Governor has sharpened his political attack on Democrats," he says. "The net effect now is that the Democrats are mad at him, and he has not won over the right." To support his point, he cites the words of Patrick J. Buchanan, who had just brought his Republican Presidential campaign to the steps of the State Capitol with a blast at Wilson. "Your party has been abandoned by Mr. Wilson," Buchanan, campaigning for the June 2 primary, told the crowd,
To all this, Wilson responds that he is determined to remake the Legislature. "If the only way to make change around here is to change the composition of the Legislature, I'm prepared to see that happen," he says. "The only real grounds they have for unhappiness is reapportionment. They had experienced the bonanza that had flowed from the flagrant gerrymander 10 years before. I am not going to pay tribute."
Wilson will say only that he wants a Republican majority. But as Roberti says, "If he believes a Republican majority will be helpful, he's hallucinating." The key, according to Wilson's political operatives, is to bring in more centrist Republicans, and redistricting has created more marginal districts likely to produce moderate candidates from both parties. In addition, three of the most conservative Republicans in the Assembly, William Baker, Tom McClintock and Phillip Wyman (part of a group of 15 or so "cavemen," as they are called in Sacramento), are running for Congress this year. With about two dozen of the 80 Assembly members leaving and others struggling in new districts, the November election is destined to bring about the biggest legislative turnover in years.
Fortunately for Wilson, he will not have to run for re-election until 1994. But he faces what may be a bigger hurdle within the next few months -- getting a new state budget. All sides agree there can be no more taxes this year, so still-deeper cuts in spending must be made -- cuts that are sure to hasten the decline of California's fine universities, public schools, parks, freeways and other "infrastructure" essential to economic recovery. Wilson and the Assembly are heading for a possibly calamitous shutdown of state services if no agreement is reached within a few weeks after the new fiscal year begins on July 1. The Democrats say this is exactly what Wilson wants, so that he can blame the Legislature for the resulting disarray and help push incumbents out in November. But the gamble is, the public is apt to hold Wilson accountable too.
Against this backdrop, Wilson faces another high-stakes political gamble over the welfare-cutting initiative he has mounted for the November ballot. Of every dollar spent under the California budget, 45 cents goes to primary and secondary education and 32 cents to health and welfare. Education should not touched, Wilson argues, because it is essential to rebuilding economic competitiveness, and he has targeted welfare. These proposed welfare cuts are called cruel by such opponents as California's two top Roman Catholic clergy, Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles and Archbishop John R. Quinn of San Francisco, as well as Jewish, Lutheran and other religious leaders.
Besides cutting welfare payments, the Taxpayer Protection Act, as Wilson dubs it, would endow the Governor with major new budgetary powers. It would authorize him to declare an emergency if no budget is approved by July 1, under which he could cut by up to 5 percent the salaries of state workers not covered by union agreements. It would also empower him to declare fiscal emergencies and cut spending whenever spending and revenues are more than 3 percent out of whack.
This bid for increased budget authority has enraged many legislators as a "power grab," and the Democratic leadership has sought to undermine it by passing its own welfare cuts. This would strip the initiative of its welfare component, turning it solely into a vote on whether to shift the balance of power in Sacramento to the Governor -- in effect, a public referendum on Wilson's performance.
"It is a big gamble," says one top Wilson aide. "He either wins it or serves only one term."

GRAPHIC: Photos: California's - and Gov. Pete Wilson's - problems loom as large as their promise once did. From left, Wilson surveying fire damage in Oakland, October 1991 (Scott Sommerdorf/The San Francisco Chronicle/Sipa)(pg. 26); a Sacramento protest against education cuts, April 1991 (Michael Schumann/Saba); flooding in Ventura County, February 1992 (Phillipe Aimar/Sipa); a gay-rights demonstration at Stanford University, October 1991 (Paul Sakuma/Associated Press); the San Francisco earthquake, 1989. (Ed Kashi/Gamma-Liaison)(pg. 27); Assembly Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr., the second most powerful man in California and Wilson's sworn political enemy. (John Harding for The New York Times); Wilson lost his most savvy adviser when Otto Bos, pictured in 1988 behind Wilson and his wife, Gayle, died last year at the age of 47. HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Muti: Arrivederci, Not Addio

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
When Riccardo Muti takes the stage of Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening to conduct works by Cherubini and Rossini, it will be the latest in a long series of goodbyes. The concert marks his last performance in the United States as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra. And after leading a tour through Europe and Israel later this month, the 50-year-old maestro will turn his energies toward guest conducting and his duties as head of La Scala Opera in Milan, a two-hour trip (at the breakneck speed he drives) from his home in Ravenna, Italy.
For a dozen years he has held the Philadelphia post, which he inherited from Eugene Ormandy and will relinquish to Wolfgang Sawallisch. For eight years before that, he was a guest conductor of the orchestra. He suffered occasional barbs that his approach, particularly in vocal music, was rigid and dogmatic, and some complained that he did away with the plush "Philadelphia sound" made famous under Ormandy. Mr. Muti leaves with one of his major goals frustratingly unfulfilled, the realization of a new concert hall in which the orchestra could perform and record. 
 Yet his tenure has in almost every other respect been a resounding success. An exacting and sometimes withering commander on the podium, he earned the respect and admiration of his orchestra, almost half of which he appointed. He also won the affection of most of a Philadelphia public notoriously slow to embrace change. And the change from the staid Ormandy, whose personality mirrored the city's own, to Mr. Muti could hardly have been more radical.
Philadelphia was Ormandy's home. In a real sense, it never became Mr. Muti's, even though he spent more weeks conducting here than many music directors of major orchestras spend with their ensembles. He lived in a furnished apartment next to the Academy of Music, the orchestra's longtime hall, ate nearby and made no bones about the fact that his heart was in Italy.
But as his English improved and he accustomed himself to American ways, he tempered the severe image he had crafted for the role of music director, which masked personal warmth and a wicked sense of humor (aimed in private at critics and other musical hangers-on). Nowadays Mr. Muti seems cheerful and contented, and not at all the dour, unsmiling young autocrat that skeptics called him when he arrived. He has become an impassioned and eloquent spokesman for music and for the musical health of the city.
"I feel loved by the people here -- not by everybody -- but in general," he said recently after a performance of Shostakovich and Martucci, having been stopped several times to sign autographs at dinner and on the street. "The enthusiasm of Philadelphians is very important to me."
Especially against the backdrop of the erratic New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta, the cultivated, prismatic sound and precise ensemble playing that Mr. Muti fostered in his players also won over New York audiences during the Philadelphians' frequent visits to Carnegie and Avery Fisher Hall. The orchestra had grown shoddy in the waning years of Ormandy's tenure. Mr. Muti instilled discipline and fostered versatility. He insisted there should be no such thing as a single Philadelphia sound.
In the last years of Ormandy's reign, the orchestra served up week in and week out Romantic standards to a complacent Philadelphia public. Under Mr. Muti it regularly stretched out into contemporary music, increasingly by American composers, into early music and to the distant corners of the Italian repertory that is especially dear to the conductor.
He has recorded some of the central German repertory, like the Brahms symphonies. But this was never his strength, and he has wisely concentrated much of his energy both in concert and in the studio on material that accentuates his ability to elicit color and virtuosic excitement from the players. He leaves behind outstanding recordings not only of Italian music but also of the works of Shostakovich, Tchaikovsky, Prokofiev and other Russian composers. As he himself points out, the orchestra "does not impress through loudness, but it has a human, distinctive sound that I don't think has been conveyed through records, because we record on a basketball court."
Perhaps most significant, Mr. Muti has converted the Philadelphians to opera, and the orchestra's annual operas in concert became high points of the musical seasons both here and in New York. He conducted Gluck and Verdi, Wagner, Puccini and Leoncavallo. Particularly in the hothouse environment of an opera in concert, Mr. Muti's firm grip on the singers and orchestra stood out in relief. He has heard countless times the complaints that he dominates the singers, but at their frequent best his performances had a combination of refinement and coherence and overarching shape that was the strongest rebuttal.
"I believe in a stylistic unity for a performance," he said. "At the same time I of course realize that the conductor must not kill the individuality of the performer. But in Italy the perception is just the opposite -- that I should be praised for exercising control."
Mr. Muti is understandably proud of what opera has done for the orchestra. "It can now perform brilliantly an opera of Puccini, when 15 years ago it didn't know what an opera was," he said. Mr. Ormandy disdained opera, and his attitude spread among Philadelphians. "I remember the resistance of some people, even on the board, who didn't think opera was first-class music," Mr. Muti recalled. "But now the attitude is completely different."
Mr. Muti is a man accustomed to getting his way, whether it involves players, audiences or recording companies. Aghast that latecomers treated concerts as social events and regularly delayed the start of orchestra performances, he started precisely on schedule, and audiences learned to adjust.
But about one key issue, Mr. Muti failed to sway the public. He insists that his departure has nothing to do with the striking failure of the orchestra, the city's most glamorous cultural institution, to muster support for a new hall, a design for which has already been completed by the architect Robert Venturi for a site a block south of the Academy.
Since announcing his departure in 1990, Mr. Muti has become an even more outspoken advocate for the project, pleading with the city and the orchestra's board to "wake up" to the need for modern performing facilities. He points out that the Vienna Philharmonic, which he will lead on an American tour in 1994, refuses to play in the Academy because of its acoustics. His case was further buoyed recently by a study that ranked Philadelphia 15th out of 15 cities in terms of the number of performances, tickets sold and seats available for performing-arts events. Numerous local and visiting organizations must jostle for what little time is not taken up in the Academy by the orchestra.
"I am concerned that the future of the orchestra is based very much on its competition with other great orchestras through modern media," Mr. Muti explained. "Concerts will be a part of the future, of course, but already you have the possibility to see orchestras from all over the world by pushing a button on your television. Orchestras like Berlin and Vienna are working hard on high technology, and laser disks are a reality. If Philadelphia is not part of this group, the musicians will certainly start to feel frustrated. And it is possible that at some point the quality of their playing will suffer."
Complaints about the brutally dry acoustics of the 135-year-old hall date back to the days of Leopold Stokowski. But Ormandy did not complain, and Mr. Muti has had to fight against a local myth that this hall is an acoustic wonder. In a tradition-bound city, the Philadelphia Orchestra in the beautiful and ornate Academy of Music is one of the proudest traditions.
It has not helped Mr. Muti's cause that the orchestra was perceived as arrogant by local donors in its expectation of contributions and its domination of a plan that is supposed to benefit many local performing-arts groups. Nor has it helped that the city, like much of the country, is in an economic slump, although the Philadelphia Art Museum managed to raise tens of millions of dollars for its endowment at the same time that the orchestra raised less than $24 million toward its goal of $90 million. Now that the orchestra has agreed to share responsibility for a new hall with a civic group that is planning a large-scale arts complex, there is renewed hope that the project may yet be realized.
Mr. Muti becomes conductor laureate of the orchestra and will return next season for four weeks, including two concerts in New York. He says he does not seek to become music director elsewhere. "Philadelphia will forever be my orchestra in my heart," he insisted. "I feel I have done a lot here, but now it's time to do more for my own country."

PUB-DATE: May 3, 1992,

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1908 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Images of Catastrophe as Corporate Ballyhoo

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg; Vicki Goldberg is the author of "The Power of Photography: How Photographs Changed Our Lives."

 BODY:
As everyone over 5 must know by now, Benetton has been appropriating the news for its ads. In March, Vogue rudely slapped six pages of the company's ads between beauty creams and luxe: three double-page spreads of a bombed-out car ablaze in the street, Albanian refugees climbing desperately onto a packed ship, and a young man dying of AIDS in his father's arms.
In last month's issue of Interview, an Indian couple waded through a flood for Benetton; in Vanity Fair and Details, refugees scrambled into a boxcar and an armed soldier held a large bone behind his back. (In Italian publications only, a murdered Mafia victim lay in a pool of blood.) 
 Each picture is stamped with a small green logo saying "United Colors of Benetton." Subjects and locations are not identified, though the world is awash with different varieties of refugees, terrorism and illness. But the images do have tiny captions -- announcing that the latest issue of the company's magazine is available.
Opinion is noisily divided over the propriety of all this, with older age groups reported to be much more opposed than younger ones. Since Albanians, terrorists and bombing victims have no organized constituencies to argue their causes, the chief source of contention is the alleged exploitation of AIDS. Several European and British magazines refused to print the AIDS picture; the British Act Up, like its American counterpart, an AIDS advocacy and protest group, tried to organize an international boycott, but American Act Up was divided on the issue and decided this was not the place to take a stand. No American periodical has censored any of the new campaign, though some balked at earlier Benetton ads with photographs of colored condoms and of a newborn baby still attached to its umbilical cord.
No one fumed when the AIDS photograph was published in an article in Life a year and a half ago; the shock came when Benetton claimed ownership of today's most desperate news by branding it with the company name. The company, which sells clothing in 93 countries, swears that it is only trying to encourage awareness of social problems and of its own cutting-edge, concerned position. Yes, it contributes to charities, including some money for AIDS education in New York. But however pure or impure its motives (and though advertising keeps capitalism perking along, it has seldom been accused of purity), Benetton has given us what we should have expected and probably deserve: images of catastrophe as corporate ballyhoo.
In fact, news and advertising have been inching into each other's territory for years. Political advisers who set up photo ops already understand how photojournalism can be made to serve political ends amounting to unacknowledged public relations. All Benetton has done is to carry several current trends in image reproduction to their logical conclusions.
News photographs wander loose from their moorings all the time. This is partly because they really belong to everyone, copyright notwithstanding. This century's history is encoded in a set of photographic images filed in the mind: Jack Ruby shooting Lee Harvey Oswald, a Chinese dissident holding a hand up to stop a line of tanks. Whole populations have the same mental-image files, which constitute a large part of the common culture. Flashing the key images guarantees instant connection and social commentary; witness Andy Warhol's paintings from photographs of civil rights protests or of Jackie Kennedy mourning.
News imagery is so strong it does not entirely lose its meaning when radically displaced. Journalistic photographs have long been snatched out of journals to hang in museums. Some of James Nachtwey's war reportage from El Salvador at the International Center of Photography in 1989 was too bloody for most publications, but not for art audiences.
If art feels free to borrow news, so does entertainment. Billy Joel's music video "We Didn't Start the Fire" ran through a series of landmark news images. In the movie "Naked Gun 2 1/2," a nightclub that catered to miserable losers was decorated with pictures of events like the Hindenburg explosion and the execution of a Vietcong suspect on a Saigon street. Art, music, film -- Benetton asks, in effect, why not ads?
And indeed, advertising does feed on news photography. Political contests take to it like catnip. In 1964, Lyndon Johnson's Presidential campaign ran a television commercial with a little girl plucking flower petals and counting backwards -- to the image of a nuclear explosion. (Anti-nuclear groups like the explosion film, too.) Bad news also sells insurance and protective organizations like labor unions, which before the current recession used Depression-era pictures to indicate how things had improved.
Manufacturers can turn the familiarity of dire images to their advantage by spoofing them. Kenneth Cole, the shoe company, ran a picture of Gen. Manuel Noriega with the tag line "One heel you definitely won't see at our semi-annual sale." And good news sells anything. At Sherman Grinberg, a New York stock film company, the story is told about a drug manufacturer that ran a film of George Bush shaking hands with Mikhail Gorbachev; the pitch was about the end of the cold war. The White House snuffled a bit and said it was not amused; the drug company pulled the commercial. In December 1989, Pepsi showed video clips of the Berlin wall as it came tumbling down, with no text but "Peace on Earth" and the company logo.
Bad news might not seem like the ideal atmosphere for selling casual clothes of the sort Benetton produces, but fashion has long known how to cohabit with real-world horrors. Vogue published Lee Miller's devastating pictures of concentration camp victims at the end of World War II and, more recently, photographs on subjects like homelessness.
And for a period in the 70's, couturier-designed tragedies became high-fashion chic. Charles Jourdan advertised shoes with Guy Bourdin's photograph of the chalked outline of a body on the highway; a lone shoe lay forlornly beside the drawing. Helmut Newton's photographs of women murdering men illustrated a Oui magazine feature on men's suits -- the last word in drop-dead fashions.
Real news, fashion and advertising live in unnerving proximity anyway. A Benetton calamity is on a page by itself, but a page in a newspaper will have a headline like "Serbs Intensify Sarejevo Attacks; 'Pure Terrorism,' Bosnia Charges" next to a photograph of a sultry model asking you to admire her brassiere and panties. On the evening news, the anchor promises, in a sprightly voice, more information on the Lockerbie plane crash and nuclear dumps, followed by music fit for the Second Coming and a commercial for a miraculously responsive sports car.
More than 20 years ago, the photographer Robert Heinecken montaged opposites like these to make a political point. He superimposed upon ads for stockings and women's razors a picture of a Vietnamese soldier holding up two severed heads, then inserted the new images surreptitiously into fashion magazines on the newsstands. One aspect of Heinecken's message was similar to Benetton's: something terrible is going on out there while you're wondering whether your legs are sufficiently silky. But then he wasn't selling silk.
Most of our news is commercially sponsored; the alternative is government, which most Americans trust even less than advertisers. Unwritten laws decree there should be some separation, however thin, between current history and commerce. But reporting and advertising are becoming increasingly porous categories -- witness that new staple, infotainment -- and the independent identity of the news grows fragile. Sometimes, now, local newscasts include interviews with the condemned criminal whose crimes provided a plot for that evening's docudrama -- a public relations campaign masquerading as news.
Commercials, on the other hand, may camouflage themselves as investigative journalism. Last year, Joan Lunden, co-host of ABC's "Good Morning America," appeared in a Vaseline commercial masquerading as a news program. Behind what looked like an anchor's desk, she delivered what sounded like a soft-news report on skin care. The only meaningful difference between the Benetton campaign and such an attempt to fuse news and advertising is that Benetton is not pretending (except perhaps in its disclaimers). The bombed-out car, the ship and the illness are undeniably news, the logo indisputably an ad.
The photographs do not hawk sweaters, but consumers are quite accustomed to fashion ads that haven't much to do with clothes. In the promotional mini-magazine that Calvin Klein sent out with an issue of Vanity Fair last year, the models seemed much happier when they weren't wearing their Calvins at all. Supposedly the consumer aspires to the life styles: Klein's pouty, pumped-up rock-and-roll; Ralph Lauren's ersatz pukka British; Georges Marciano's bimbo western. Benetton abandons any pretense. This is it, kids: you really live like this, in the middle of an epidemic, with the news coming at you from all sides. Will people now think Benetton the proper apparel to wear to a terrorist bombing?
Many companies today link their products to controversial causes, counting on a newly active group of (mostly younger) consumers who prefer their corporations socially concerned. Their ads ask for money or say whom to call; Benetton merely plunks down its logo atop flood and fire. Abrupt and uncomfortable as this is, it is not really a departure, just a jamming together of goodwill-seeking and new sponsorship. News and brand identification are already only minimally separated every day on public TV when logos like Pepsi's and A.T.& T.'s round off accounts of scandals and collapsing republics on shows like the MacNeil/Lehrer report.
America is already afflicted with what might be called logolalia. Never mind the ads and packaging; people are also walking logos. Some years ago, women of a certain economic stratum stopped wearing their own monograms and started wearing other peoples' -- Chanel, Yves St. Laurent -- in large letters. The advent of the T-shirt as sportswear for the millions transferred a lot of brand-name product ads from the working man's back to others'. How many people have you seen lately whose chests hype the Hard Rock Cafe?
Now images also carry logos. A good number of newspaper photographs of the Persian Gulf war or the William Kennedy Smith trial were marked CNN in the lower right corner. On television, movie scenes suddenly and briefly sprout the letters TNT or TBS, and news clips occasionally bloom with a network trademark: name-brand clothes, entertainment and news.
Whatever its sales potential, the new Benetton campaign has sparked intense discussion about AIDS and about the company itself. The company estimates that with its ads running worldwide and the media covering the controversy, between 500 million and a billion people have seen the AIDS image, far more than ever saw it when it came out in Life. Conceivably, Benetton has created the most up-to-date news venue of all. A public that is reading fewer newspapers and believing fewer broadcasts might begin to swallow tiny doses of information between the ads for liquor and lingerie.
Name recognition counts. Luciano Benetton, founder of the company, ran for senator in last month's election in Italy, and won.

(Benetton)(pg. 33); An Indian couple wade through a flood for Benetton -- News photographs wander loose from their moorings all the time. (Benetton)(pg. 35)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Rail and More In Europe

 BODY:
Passes that combine European rail travel with other forms of transportation are becoming increasingly popular.
One new pass, for travel in Norway, Sweden and Denmark, is called the Scanrail 'n' Drive pass. The pass provides 4 days of unlimited train travel and 3 days' rental of a Hertz car to be used within 15 days; the cost ranges from $225 a person, based on two people traveling together, for second-class rail travel and an economy car, to $295 for first-class rail and intermediate-size car. A pass for 9 days of rail travel and 3 car rental days to be used in 21 days is $319 to $419 a person. A Scanrail Pass, good for unlimited rail travel in the three countries, costs $145 in second class and $179 in first class for four days' use out of 15; $299 and $239 for 9 days out of 21, and $359 for 14 days out of a month. 
 Similar programs are now being offered for Portugal. Three days of rail travel can be combined with three days of car rental from Avis, to be used within one month, for $129 with first-class rail travel (no pass is available for second class) and economy car, up to $189 for a small car with automatic shift; extra days of rail are $20 a person, based on two traveling together. Additional car days are $85 for a small automatic or $40 for economy. Portugal also offers a Flexiplan rail pass, with 4 days' first-class travel out of 15 days costing $89, and 7 out of 21, $139.
The Scandinavian and Portuguese passes are available through Rail Europe, 230 Westchester Avenue, White Plains, N.Y. 10604; (800) 438-7245.
In Austria, a new pass called Bicycle Card for a Day entitles travelers to take their bicycles on some trains and hang them on special fixtures in the car in which they ride. The pass, which costs $3, is good for an unlimited number of uses during the day it is issued and can be used (along with a passenger ticket or rail pass) on regional trains marked in the schedule with a bicycle symbol. Bicycles can be rented for $4.50 a day at about 160 train stations in Austria and can be returned at any station. For schedules: Austrian National Tourist Office, 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10151, (212) 944-6880.

HEADLINE: Grand Central Owner Seeks Broader Use Of Air Rights

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
WHILE travelers can no longer reach far-away points from Grand Central Terminal, the owners of the mid-Manhattan landmark envision some distant destinations for its unused development rights.
As the latest step in a real estate struggle that has lasted a quarter of a century, the Penn Central Corporation, which owns the terminal, has proposed a zoning subdistrict from Third to Fifth Avenue, 38th to 48th Street, within which Grand Central's air rights could be transferred to development sites. 
 Penn Central would expand by 29 blocks a smaller Grand Central subdistrict that was proposed last year by the staff of the City Planning Department. The official version is to be considered May 20 by the City Planning Commission.
Meanwhile, in the most obvious sign that the days of long-distance travel have ended at Grand Central, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which leases the terminal, is looking for a restaurateur, grocer or other retailer to take over the newly renovated 12,000-square-foot waiting room on 42d Street.
Separate as they may seem, the zoning and renovation questions are related. The M.T.A., which uses the terminal for its Metro-North Commuter Railroad division, has already spent $71.9 million on repairing and restoring the building and plans to spend $113 million more.
Because the value of these improvements currently accrues to Penn Central, the authority is also pursuing strategies to purchase the building, including possible condemnation. But a deal would depend on what happens to the air rights, which Penn Central calculates at 1.966 million square feet (the equivalent of two Chrysler Buildings). "If the air-rights issue were settled tomorrow, we'd probably be talking with Penn Central on Monday," said Donald N. Nelson, the president of Metro-North.
Penn Central is not satisfied with the city planners' proposal, which it says is too limited and cumbersome. The corporation said that if it cannot disperse the air rights more widely and easily, it will use them to build a tower directly over the terminal "as promptly as possible." The architectural and legal groundwork is already being laid for a tower that would be "in harmony" with the existing Beaux-Arts facade.
"The city and community should not misunderstand Penn Central's resolve," the Cincinnati-based corporation said, "and that is to realize the value of the air rights, which value has been denied it for so long." Given the magnitude of its holdings, and the desirability -- in a better market -- of office space around Grand Central Terminal, that value could be in the many millions of dollars.
IN 1968, Penn Central proposed a 53-story skyscraper over the terminal. That was rejected by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, leading to a 10-year legal battle that ended when the United States Supreme Court upheld the city's action and, indeed, the constitutionality of the landmarks law itself.
The court noted that Grand Central's transferable development rights "undoubtedly mitigate whatever financial burdens the law has imposed" on Penn Central and that Penn Central's "ability to use these rights has not been abrogated; they are made transferable to at least eight parcels in the vicinity of the terminal."
In the intervening years, however, a consensus has grown that the current arrangement, under which the air rights can move only to sites directly across from Grand Central or along a chain of lots in common ownership, does not afford Penn Central enough opportunities to sell these rights.
It also does not make any planning sense, in that it directs development by patterns of ownership, rather than patterns of existing land use, density and transportation.
(In 1989, the Planning Commission rejected Penn Central's attempt to transfer air rights along a chain of subsurface lots to a development site at 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets.)
The City Planning Department has proposed a new zoning subdistrict from Madison to Lexington Avenue, 41st to 48th Street. Within the core of this subdistrict, air rights could be used to develop structures 21.6 times the size of their lots -- as high a floor-area ratio as the city has permitted anywhere in recent decades. Such dense buildings would only be allowed by special permit, however. On the edges of the subdistrict, the air rights could be used to raise the floor-area ratio from 15 to 16, as a matter of right.
"What's indisputable," said the chairman of the commission, Richard L. Schaffer, "is that right now you have a limited, arbitrary way of determining receiving sites. We have increased the number of opportunities to transfer these development rights. And we have done so with a strong planning nexus."
And with the survival of the landmark terminal itself at stake, Laurie Beckelman, the chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said, "We wholeheartedly embrace the city planning proposal."
However, both Penn Central and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority believe that city planners have not gone far enough.
"We fear that the special-permit requirement for significant transfers could discourage developers from attempting such transfers," said Peter E. Stangl, the chairman of the M.T.A., in a letter to Mr. Schaffer. "The requirement increases the time and cost to accomplish a transfer and decreases the predictability of outcomes -- in terms of both timing and success."
"Second," Mr. Stangl wrote, "we question whether there are sufficient receiving sites within the proposed boundaries of the subdistrict. Our review of the inventory indicates that it may be inadequate."
Now, Penn Central has come forward with what amounts to a counter-proposal, devised by the planning firm of Buckhurst Fish Hutton Katz & Jacquemart and the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, both of Manhattan.
Penn Central would create a much larger subdistrict within which air rights could be transferred. As importantly, buildings with floor-area ratios of 21.6 would be allowed automatically in the core of the subdistrict, without need of a special permit. On three sides of that core would be areas in which buildings with floor-area ratios of 18 would be allowed, even in mid-blocks. At the edges of the subdistrict, the ratio would be 16.
Mr. Schaffer dismissed the Penn Central effort. "It's clear that this is a real estate proposal, not a planning proposal," he said. "There is only one subdistrict before the City Planning Commission. The document that Penn Central has produced is extremely short on planning analysis."
BUT the subdistrict proposed by the city has also come in for criticism on planning grounds. Community Board 5, for example, has unanimously called on the city to suspend its efforts to adopt the measure until further environmental analysis, according to Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the board's land-use committee.
"We're sympathetic to the creation of a special district," Mr. Rose said. "But what such a plan would look like has to be determined from considering environmental factors as well as economic ones."
City planners say that an environmental analysis of the Grand Central area -- particularly from the standpoint of traffic volume and air pollution -- would be virtually meaningless, except on a case-by-case basis through the special-permit process.
"Even if we were able to do a credible environmental review now," said Robert E. Flahive, director of the Manhattan office, "we'd be hard pressed in five years to point to a generic environmental impact statement and say, 'We analyzed this in 1992.' The background conditions may be very different."
At a public forum tomorrow, Mr. Flahive is scheduled to discuss the subdistrict with Frank S. Fish, a principal in Buckhurst Fish. The session begins at 6 P.M. in the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 50th Street. A hearing by the planning commission is scheduled May 20, with a vote expected in June. The matter then goes to the City Council.
While the zoning saga plays out invisibly to the traveling public, another facet of Grand Central's unfolding future is far easier to notice: the restoration of the former main waiting room.
Although the room has not yet reopened to the public, it is possible to see through the enormous interior windows that the chamber is glowing as it has not since Grand Central opened in 1913. The luster seems to emanate from the Caen stone walls themselves.
The M.T.A. has spent $4.3 million to strip architectural accretions from the waiting room, remove and store the great oak benches, and restore the five 17-foot gold-and-nickel-plated chandeliers. It also has restored the sumptuous Bottocino marble wainscoting and the richly embellished ceilings more than 50 feet above the Tennessee Pink marble floor.
"We're plowing public money into the infrastructure simply because it must be done to maintain it for transportation purposes," Mr. Nelson said. "The waiting room was the location of most of the severe leaks, the most discolored marble and Caen stone and, we suspected, steel problems."
Metro-North's chief architect, Wayne D. Ehmann, said: "The waiting room has been an excellent way to find out how to restore the rest of the terminal. We saw this as an area we could use as a test bed without affecting ridership."
The architects for the restoration are Beyer Blinder Belle of Manhattan and the general contractor is George Campbell Associates of Flushing, Queens.
Originally designed for the comfort of long-distance passengers who sometimes had to wait hours for trains, the waiting room had become the "most altered, deteriorated and redundant space in the terminal," in the words of the architect John Belle.
It was closed to the public in the summer of 1989. A plywood tunnel was built through it to keep a passage open from 42d Street to the main concourse. Restoration work began in 1991 and is scheduled to be finished in July.
A new waiting area was created on the west balcony, overlooking the concourse. Accommodating about 60 people, the area has about one-tenth the capacity of the old waiting room. But with the disappearance of long-distance trains from Grand Central Terminal (the last ones rolled out in April 1991), travelers now spend minutes -- rather than hours -- in the building. "A small waiting room is more than enough for our customers," Mr. Ehmann said.
SO a search has begun for tenants to take over the space on a 10-year lease. Restaurants top the agenda because existing food services in the terminal, "while generally profitable, are both geographically and conceptually unfocused," stated the request for proposals by the M.T.A. "The goal of the waiting-room project is to provide station users and visitors with a variety of high quality meal options within a unified space and theme."
Ideally, the authority said, there would be a restaurant with table-service, a cafe and a specialty food store.
"Customers would be able to purchase food, either to eat while seated at tables, without service or to go," the document said. "The addition of ancillary retail sales, such as cookbooks, house or kitchen wares, single-item food stands or other complementary items is encouraged."
The room could logically be divided along the 25-foot-wide passageway that must be maintained between the concourse and 42d Street. Terms of the lease depend a great deal on who the tenant is, what the tenant needs and when the tenant signs.
Not yet resolved is the question of what will happen to the freestanding benches. That depends in part on who takes the space. In approving the restoration plan in 1991, the landmarks commission asked for the "replacement of, if not all, some of the benches" in "their original locations." And Ms. Beckelman said the commission still expects that "some of the benches will be re-used." In that way, the memory of the long-distance era at Grand Central will not be lost entirely.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: For Directors and Managers;
Co-op/Condo Seminar

 BODY:
With taxes and operating costs on the rise, the job of maintaining the financial health of co-ops and condominiums has never been more of a challenge for their boards of directors and managers.
For those charged with the task, help is available in the form of a daylong seminar on financial planning next Saturday at the Hotel Macklowe, 144 West 44th Street. The forum is being sponsored by the Council of New York Cooperatives, the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives and N.Y. Habitat, a magazine covering co-op and condominium management issues. 
 Among the topics to be discussed will be how to get the most out of management companies, tax-planning strategies, raising revenue and avoiding unnecessary repairs. In addition to the sessions for board members there will be a special workshop for managing agents on how to assist client buildings with their economic strategies.
The conference will begin at 8:30 A.M. and is expected to last until about 4:30 P.M. The cost of participation will be $95 for a single board member, $150 for two participants from the same co-op or condominium and $215 for three board members. Members of the council and the federation are entitled to a 5 percent discount. For further information call (212) 983-6700.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: $100 Million Rebuilding;
Ferry Terminal Contest

 BODY:
The fire that damaged the Staten Island ferry terminal last year provided what the stagnant economy could not: a spur to reconstruction.
Known formally as the Whitehall Ferry Terminal, the structure was supposed to have been renovated as part of the South Ferry Plaza commercial development, forming the base of a 60-story office tower. But that project fell through in January 1991. 
 Now, seeing an opportunity "to create a major civic statement" at the tip of Manhattan, the city's Economic Development Corporation will hold an architectural competition for the $100 million project to rebuild the terminal and its plaza, which is to begin in 1994.
The city is asking interested firms to submit their qualifications by May 29. Five firms will be asked to prepare designs, for which the city expects to provide a $30,000 stipend. These submissions will then go to a jury of city officials, community leaders, civic groups and architects.
Inquiries should be addressed to the Whitehall Ferry Terminal Competition, Economic Development Corporation, 110 William Street, New York, N.Y. 10038.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: New Housing in Chicago;
Where Bargains for Renters are 'Terrific'

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THE good news, says Christine Williams, is that Chicago's residential developers appear to be holding their fire. None of the projected market-rate high-rise developments are moving into construction for the moment. The market neeeds time to absorb what is already built, she says.
Ms. Williams, vice president of the Real Estate Research Corporation, a consulting firm based here, has figures that show that new "luxury" residential construction has marched along at an average rate of 1,600 units a year over the last four years, recession notwithstanding. Five new projects with a total of 2,600 apartments have come on the market since the start of last year alone. 
 With few exceptions, these new buildings are rentals, not condominiums. And as they lease up steadily, with a nudge from a month or two of free rent, they demonstrate how a city with a fundamentally positive attitude toward new development has continued to sustain housing prices that are remarkably low by the standards of comparable cities.
Right now they are even low in relation to the cost of development. Too low, some specialists say, to sustain the mortgages that some have received.
"Chicago is a terrific housing bargain for the renter, relative to development costs and land costs, whether you're talking about San Franciso, New York, Los Angeles or Boston," said Jared Shlaes, a real-estate consultant and former developer himself. And in contrast with New York, no tax abatement program has beeen necessary to keep market-rate housing flowing.
What New Yorkers would define as middle- to upper-middle-income luxury high-rise apartments are on the market in new buildings for about $1.35 to $1.55 a square foot a month, Ms. Williams said. At $1.35 a square foot, or $16.20 a foot a year, an 800-square-foot one-bedroom apartment would rent for $1,080; at $1.55 a foot, or $18.60 a foot a year, it would rent for $1,240 a month.
Also at $1.55 a square foot, an 1,100-square-foot, two-bedroom, for example, would rent for $1,700 a month. In New York City, comparable new housing would rent for $27 to $30 a square foot a year; the 1,100-square-foot apartment would cost $2,000 to $2,500 a month.
How can the developers here do it?
One reason is that land costs are much lower than in New York City. Chicago is well endowed with well-situated vacant or nearly vacant land intended for residential or mixed-use developments. The bitter and lengthy New York battles over emptying old buildings of residential tenants with statutory rights to stay in place are unknown. The absence of rent regulation leads builders to hope that they will be able to take advantage of an eventually stronger market, whatever the level of initial rents.
In a word, development incentives are far stronger. But the competitive risks are greater.
In the mid-80's, Chicago developers were paying $12 to $20 a developable square foot for building sites. Even at the higher figure, the land cost embedded in an 800-square-foot one-bedroom apartment is only $16,000. In New York, rentals in new West Side buildings have a land cost of about $40,000 for a one-bedroom apartment. The developers paid roughly $50 a developable foot for ready-to-build land.
In addition, Chicago builders get a higher-density use of the land. Land is typically developed to a density of about 20 square feet of building for each square foot of site, a floor-area ratio of 20, under a "planned unit development" ordinance. Builders present a specific site plan for a project to the Department of Planning and Development. It is eventually voted upon by the Chicago Plan Commission and the City Council.
In the downtown area, at least, Chicago welcomes new development and favors density and height, as opposed to bulk, according to Jack Guthman, a lawyer with the firm of Sidley & Austin who represents many developers. With high-rise buildings appearing on broad swaths of vacant land, often near the Lake Michigan waterfront, residential towers 40 and 50 stories high, occupying about half their 40,000-square-foot sites, are not uncommon.
"They are generous on F.A.R. but strict about other things -- like loading docks and parking spaces," said Mr. Guthman.
For all these factors, the supply-demand situation appears to be the principal one holding prices down. Some experienced developers say that major new projects cannot even break even at current market rents. They need rents of $1.65 to $1.75 a square foot a month for that, or about $20 a square foot a year. Accordingly, the projects may be renting at figures that in the present market are "uneconomic." Time and an upward swing in the market may change that.
But default rates on post-1980 projects that were insured by the Federal Government show that a price has already been paid for overambitiousness. At the Chicago office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Developmeent, 17 projects out of 27 built since 1980 with Government mortgage insurance have been taken back with an outlay of $510 million from the mortgage insurance fund. The largest is the $160 million mortgage on the 2,500-unit Presidential Towers project, which is four years old and 92 percent occupied.
With mortgage rates down, some of the projects may be candidates for refinancing at more favorable rates, said Joseph Garaffa, deputy regional administrator of the Chicago office of H.U.D. Meanwhile, the owners remain in possession, hoping that with time the value of the real estate will recover.
The Government insured about 9,800 housing units in Chicago during the period, but none after 1987. About 20,000 units have been built between 1980 and the present. Residential construction since 1987 has proceeded with uninsured financing.
In the Streeterville-Michigan Avenue corridor, just north of the Chicago River, major new projects include the 904-unit Cityfront Place, two midrise and one high-rise building on two-and-a-half acres of land owned by the Chicago Dock and Canal Trust. The Habitat Company, headed by Daniel Levin, is the developer. The trust owns the two 200-unit midrises for the trust, and Habitat with Northwest Mutual Life Insurance as equity partner owns the 39-story high-rise.
Cityfront Place has been offering two-bedroom apartments with cherrywood doors, Italian marble baths, built-in microwave ovens and garbage disposals for $1,650 a month, with two months' free rent. The building has a health club, a pool, a sun deck on each building, a party room and a parking garage for 600 cars. James Watts, the project manager, said the project is over 70 percent leased.
Closer to the Loop, at 440 North Wabash Avenue, the John Buck Company is on the market with the 50-story Plaza 440, consisting of 457 apartments in a mixed-use building with a 336-room Marriott hotel and a 400-car garage. Deluxe two-bedroom apartments can be rented for $1,400 to $2,000 a month. One-bedrooms are available for $1,200 to $1,300.
The John Buck Company is known mainly as a real-estate services company for corporate users -- it has taken over management of the 4.5-million-square-foot Sears Towers and will lease out 2.8 million square feet in it as Sears's merchants group moves to the suburbs -- but it took on the mixed-use project when it bought the 40,000-square-foot North Wabash Avenue parking lot four years ago.
"We're the last of the new stuff," said Bill Moody, the project manager. "There will be a pause in new investment now. Real estate is battered and everyone is cautious."
For the long term, the land is still available for substantial new high-rise growth near the glamorous Chicago waterfront and inland as well. But Chicagoans themeselves are unlikely to abandon the low-rise neighborhood housing that principally characterizes the city to the north, south and west of the central business district.
"Many people from Chicago want older-style properties," said John Supera, whose father, Michael, runs a company that manages 2,000 apartments in the Lincoln Park and DePaul University area. "They like to walk around the neighborhood, go to the cleaners, that sort of thing." His buildings are 99 percent leased, he said.
