HEADLINE: Groundwater

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on Feb. 23 entitled "Protecting Groundwater and Open Space" about efforts to protect the region's groundwater while resurrecting the economy failed to address a critical point. 
 It will remain the responsibility of locally elected officials to recognize that the region is in economic crisis and that they, not Washington nor Albany, hold the key to how best create an environment for economic growth that protects the quality of life.
Those who call for the purchase of these properties instead have failed to see that there are no longer tax revenues available from a sagging economy and a growing unemployed work force to make the sale.
Against these realities and a state budget deficit that threatens to collapse our Long Island education system, there is a current proposal that would see state taxpayers spend $20 million to acquire a wish list of property throughout Nassau and Suffolk.
This plan does not include the dollars already gathered from a destitute Suffolk County for the purchase of Hampton Hills in Southampton for $17.8 million, Froelich Farm in Huntington for $12.4 million and Robins Island for $9 million.
At a time when we are fighting to preserve our schools, our police and our homes, we need to find radically innovative programs that will protect our environment and the people who live on the Island, without fleecing the taxpayers.
The answer is to create clustered development so that the public gains open space in perpetuity without having to pay a dime. Clustering, whereby developers are only permitted to use a portion of their property, is a device that sophisticated planners and astute community leaders can embrace that will allow economic pump priming to go forward under very strict guidelines.
Clustering has already been used successfully by the Tilles Organization, owners of the Underhill site in Jericho. At their Crossways International Plaza in neighboring Woodbury, they dedicated 87 acres to the Town for a park and a police station and they put 52 buildings on the remaining 224 acre site.
But Tilles, and Canon, need to operate under very specific guidelines set down by government that would allow clustering to proceed at Underhill and DeSeversky respectively. They would need to agree to covenants and restrictions that would guarantee the preservation and protection of existing natural resources on the site.
Can Oyster Bay Town, Brookville Village, or the people of New York State come up the tens of millions of dollars needed to purchase both sites? Or will we choose to allow the courts to dictate the ultimate use of our open space?
 
STEPHEN HESS
 
The writer is president of the Association for a Better Long Island in Woodbury, L.I.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Irvington Offices;
Converted Warehouses Offer 'SoHo in Westchester'

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
WHEN Joseph M. Kessler was thinking about moving his management consulting business from midtown Manhattan to waterfront offices in the Village of Irvington in Westchester County, everyone advised him against it.
"The so-called experts said my clients would balk about my being out of Manhattan, but it never happened," Mr. Kessler said. "Nobody seemed to care and the move helped us out enormously with lower overhead. I also improved my life style by cutting my commute by two-thirds." 
 For Mr. Kessler and other tenants who moved from Manhattan to warehouse buildings in Irvington, their initial fears proved unfounded.
"I know I was attracted by the fact that it's a quaint old river town," said Mr. Kessler, "and as it turns out, the address seems to add a certain mystique that, I think, has actually helped business."
That kind of thinking is helping to turn Irvington's old industrial waterfront into a trendy relocation spot for small- to medium-sized businesses from Manhattan.
"It's kind of like SoHo in Westchester," said Terry Talley, who moved her advertising agency, Talley, Tabatch, from midtown Manhattan two years ago. "I mean with the loft atmoshpere and creatively minded people, it seems like the place to be."
For the last four years, Noble Van & Storage, a property management company, has been converting two turn-of-the-century warehouses into loft-like offices and light industrial space, attracting 40 tenants ranging from graphic arts and advertising agencies to laser research firms and clothing designers.
"We hope to eventually create a community of businesses that can complement and cooperate with each other," said Michael K. Lyons, a co-owner of Noble.
The project's biggest selling point, Mr. Lyons believes, is the Village of Irvington itself, which was named for the writer Washington Irving, who built his home there.
"I think the history and atmosphere here attract the kind of artistic and creative people we want," said Mr. Lyons, who sports a ponytail as well as a business suit.
To date, Noble has converted 140,000 square feet of warehouse space. The first building worked on, One Bridge Street, is now 90 percent occupied. And half of Two Bridge Street has been converted and leased.
"We'll convert the rest once we get a tenant," said William J. Thompson, Noble's other owner.
Last week, Eileen Fisher, a clothing designer, leased 12,000 square feet in Two Bridge Street, a building with a pitched roof, skylights and catwalks.
"We'll custom-build practically any kind of office space a tenant wants," said Mr. Lyons. The company will lease space as small as 250 square feet or as large as 40,000.
Mr. Lyons's own office, at One Bridge Street, is perched atop an old elevator shaft. Surrounded by windows, it has views of the Hudson River and the Tappan Zee Bridge. To the left of Mr Lyons's desk, on the ceiling, are the original elevator pulleys, now purely decorative and painted a bright red.
WHEN Steel Swift, co-owner of Tangram, designer and builder of trade-show exhibits, first looked at One Bridge Street four years ago "it was very raw," he said, adding that there were "dead pigeons on the floor."
His company now occupies a 1,500-square-foot corner office, with original brick walls and river views. It also has a 7,000-square-foot workshop and 3,000 square feet of storage space.
"When we were in Manhattan, our offices were on lower Broadway and the shop was in Fort Greene in Brooklyn," Mr. Steel said. "Consolidating everything was a big plus."
Tangram was unable to finance that much space in Manhattan. By contrast, riverfront leasing in Irvington costs $8 to $18 a square foot, depending on the location in the buildings.
Irvington isn't the only Westchester community developing office space on the river. About 20 miles upriver, in Peeksill, some old factories once owned by the Fleischmann distillers now house offices for artists, accountants and mortgage brokers. And on a much smaller scale, a 5,000-square-foot building in Cold Spring in Putman County was converted for use by artists and small business owners.
But Irvington is the only southern Westchester community that has successfully made use of its old warehouses. That is partly due to the fact that they were never really abandoned.
IN other communites, such as Hastings-on-Hudson, the riverfront has been vacant for almost two decades.
As a result, the buildings fell into desrepair and, in some cases, toxic waste has leached into the soil, forestalling any new development.
In Irvington, Lord and Burnham Company, a greenhouse manufacturer, occupied the waterfront from 1870 until 1986, when it disbanded the operation. Then Noble leased 220,000 square feet in the two main warehouse buildings and several auxiliary structures.
"We're now leasing with the intention to buy, and will probably own the properties within two years," said Mr. Lyons.
Noble still uses part of the property for its warehousing operation, but intends eventually to convert the entire space for tenancy.
In 1989, Irvington changed the zoning along the riverfront from heavy to light industrial use.
"The village wanted to gain control over the future of the waterfront," said Mr. Thompson. "And what we're doing fits right into their plans."
Also working in Noble's favor is the good relationship that Lord and Burnham developed over the years with the village government.
"Lord and Burnham was always good to the village," said Reginald Marra, who was Mayor from 1979 to 1989. "Whenever we needed something fixed, they would try to take care of it."
That beneficence has extended to Noble and the Bridge Street properties.
"With this project," Mr. Marra said, "they're proving that you don't have to tear down some of these old buildings. People in the village are used to seeing them, are not offended by them and like them being used in this way."
The properties are cut off from downtown by the Metro-North train tracks, which are only a few hundred feet from the office buildings.
Aidan Corish, a partner in Tangram, likes the proximity to the train into Manhattan.
"I can leave my office at 10 A.M. and be sitting in a client's office in Manhattan at 11," he said.
The disadvantage is that the rumble from the trains can be clearly heard, especially in the offices on the east side of the buildings, although nobody there seems to mind.
What some of the tenants who moved from Manhattan do complain about the lack of a social life in Irvington. "There's really no great restaurants where you can entertain clients and no health club I can go to during the day," said Joseph Kessler.
The developers are hoping to change that soon by building a restaurant and health club on the waterfront property.
Whether or not that comes to pass, Mr. Kessler is still happy he made the move. With the 20-minute commute from his home in Ossining, "I can now drop my son off at preschool and be back in time for work," he said. "I can even go home for lunch."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Warehouses, top, left, on the Hudson in Irvington, N.Y.; office space in a converted warehouse, above, and William J. Thompson, left, with Michael K. Lyons, owners of Noble Van & Storage. (Photographs by Allen Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 'The Kid' in Charge at Town Hall

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
WHEN Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas visited Clinton, Conn., during the state's Democratic presidential primary campaign, he was forced to improvise on one of his standard talks to young people. He was at Morgan High School, saying to the students that everyone in government was middle-aged, when he glanced over at his chief host in the community. "Except your First Selectman," he added quickly.
The exception was 25-year-old Paul W. Austin, the youngest person now serving as head of a Connecticut municipality, and probably the youngest ever. During his own campaign last fall Mr. Austin was commonly referred to as "the kid" or "Doogie," for the adolescent doctor in the television show "Doogie Howser, M.D." 
 With his unlined face and shock of blond hair, Mr. Austin appears even younger than he is. At his desk in town hall, he looks as if he should be planning the senior prom, not running a town of some 14,000 people.
"I can understand some people coming in and see me sitting here, 25 years old, and have trouble dealing with that," Mr. Austin said. "But it means that I have to be well prepared to deal with them. I have to do my homework."
He does not mind the homework, or the long hours he puts in for the full-time, $45,000-a-year job, he said. "I'm here at 7:30 in the morning and go to about 8 at night. Sometimes, I bring dinner in." In addition to attending many evening meetings, Mr. Austin is at Town Hall on Saturday afternoons, for anyone who cares to drop in and talk.
Until 1988 Mr. Austin was more accustomed to spending his Saturday hours in the library at Connecticut College in New London, where he was studying for a degree in economics and political science. But his interest in politics goes back to his childhood, said Mr. Austin, the son of a Presbyterian minister "who moved around a lot."
 
The Boy Who Would Be President
 One of Mr. Austin's favorite stories is about one of his early motivators, a great-uncle, who told him that he would be President of the United States some day. "Then I found out later he said the same thing to my two brothers," Mr. Austin said. No matter. The germ had been planted.
After graduating from college Mr. Austin dove right into politics, as an aide to Richard J. Balducci, Speaker of the State House; as director of the Taxpayers Alliance to Serve Connecticut, a group that supported the state income tax, and as chairman of the Democratic Town Committee in Clinton.
He had selected the shore town very deliberately as his home in 1988, he said. "It's a town with an interesting mix of young and old," he said, "and from blue-collar workers to people who own big cottages on the beaches." With what appears to be an inexhaustible supply of energy, coupled with an inclination to talk to everyone, he quickly became well known in town.
"I never felt I was a real part of a community before," he said. "But here I am. This town has a work aspect, but it has a social aspect, too."
When Mr. Austin decided to run for First Selectman, he was very much a long shot. Despite his affability and his party post, he had only been in town three years. He was one of four candidates for the job, including a Republican twice his age, who had served more than Mr. Austin's entire lifetime on the Board of Finance or the Board of Selectmen. Nevertheless, at a time of general political discontent in Connecticut, Mr. Austin won the election, squeaking in by a margin of 42 votes out of 3,031 cast.
Since the victory he has been as much an inescapable presence as the stately brick Town Hall on Route 1. Unlike many first selectmen, who shy away from school affairs, Mr. Austin often wanders into that sacred territory, talking to teachers, administrators and students. One of his latest ventures is promoting a basketball game, pitting male and female high school students against people who work in town government, to benefit literacy volunteers. At the high school he seems to be about as well known as most teachers but regarded by students as more of a peer. The First Selectman, who is not married, gets a lot of giggles from some of the young women.
He also appears to get the respect from the older people who run neighboring towns. At a recent meeting to talk over his idea of buying municipal supplies jointly to save money, the older municipal leaders listened politely and seemed receptive. One of them, Paula C. Ferrara, the Republican First Selectman of neighboring Westbrook, later described Mr. Austin as full of energy and with some innovative ideas. She confessed to being old enough to be his mother and said meetings with him are like talking to her own children. "I think it's cute," she said.
 
Talking About His Plans
 Mr. Austin's chief booster is a local Democratic Selectman, James M. McCusker Jr. "He's a breath of fresh air to the community," Mr. McCusker said. "He's out and about. He makes himself available."
The most serious complaint about the young First Selectman is that in his exuberance he is likely to discourse too much about his plans, especially with reporters, without first informing other officials who might be involved. Mr. Austin's plan for making better use of town buildings was one that brought some criticism.
He makes no apologizes for thinking aloud, he said. He was talking about an idea for possibly using schools and other buildings for children's day care, he said, and the objections did not come until he suggested a committee to research it.
"This town has 880 single-parent families, with little day care before or after school," he said. "There's no recreational facilities for teens or seniors. I want to set up a program to address these needs."
When he ran for election, he promised to talk about his ideas openly, he said, and that is what he has done.
One of the questions about Mr. Austin has been whether the Clinton job is just a first, and very temporary, step on a political career.
"You never can tell when an opportunity comes up," he said. "So you've got to be flexible."
But he is that he is enjoying his first elected job so much, he said, that he is beginning to think it would be fun, and gratifying, to stay on to see how all the plans work out in 20 years or so. He said, he definitely planned to run again when his first term is completed.
And this spring he has found one group in town does not regard him as a youngster. The First Selectman is now an assistant coach of a Little League baseball team. Among these players he is a real elder, he said, adding, "All the guys on the Little League team call me Mr. Austin."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul W. Austin, Clinton's First Selectman, is the youngest person heading a Connecticut municipality. (Bruce Johnson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Guard Fears Impact of Cuts

BYLINE: >By ALBERT J. PARISI

 BODY:
FOR 38-year-old Daniel T. Mahon of Warren Township, a technical supervisor at a Federal installation, the loss of his National Guard income, he says, would force him to sell the house he and his wife bought two and a half years ago.
For Donald Hartfield, 28, of Newark, who was laid off from his job as a maintenance man at Giants Stadium seven months ago, it would leave him broke, he says. State Guard officials say about 30 percent of their members are otherwise unemployed. 
 Throughout the state, members of the National Guard -- and, to a lesser extent, the Reserves -- are nervously awaiting the outcome of a Congressional debate over the Pentagon's plan to do away with some 140,000 positions nationwide, out of a total of 1.2 million, over a two-year period. The expected saving: $20 billion.
 
10 Armory Closings Seen
 The New Jersey cuts, if approved by Congress, could mean the loss of up to 6,300 full- and part-time jobs, officials say, and the elimination of 9 State Guard, 16 Army Reserve and 2 Naval Reserve units as early as June 1993. In addition, 10 of the state's 40 Army National Guard armories in 20 counties would be forced to close. (Only Passaic County has no armory.)
For Guard officials, the proposed reductions represent a threat to their mission. "We're talking about cutbacks here which will seriously hamper our ability to carry out the job we're assigned to do," said Maj. Gen. Vito Morgano, commander of the New Jersey Army and Air National Guard.
The missions of the Guard and the Reserves are different, and the impact of the cutbacks on the two would be different as well.
While both groups require members to attend a two-or-three-day weekend drill once a month and an annual two-week stint, and the pay is comparable, the Reserve units train to provide active military forces with medical, transportation and other support services in time of war or national emergency. The Guard's primary role is to help communities cope with floods or other natural disasters.
Under the proposed elimination of Reserve units, said Steven Stromvall, a spokesman for the Army Reserve Command headquarters in Atlanta, "we expect to lose very, very few people."
 
Cuts Through Attrition
 Attrition would cover most job reductions, he said, and most of the other reservists affected would be absorbed into units that had not been cut.
For example, there are no cutbacks planned for the 514th Airlift Wing of the Air Force Reserve, based at McGuire Air Force Base in Wrightstown, in Burlington County, said Art Covello, a spokesman for the unit. The 514th was responsible for ferrying troops and supplies during the war in the Persian Gulf.
In the case of the Guard, in which units are not expected to be combined, the cutbacks could reduce the New Jersey ranks to about 7,400 from today's 10,800 by 1993.
Units slated for elimination, General Morgano said, represent talents and skills not easily replaced. One such is the 104th Army National Guard Engineer Battalion, based in Teaneck, which, he said, is the state's only Guard engineering unit. It has aided communities damaged by floods in Wayne and along the Passaic River Basin.
Even limited reductions, he said, would produce a domino effect. They would end some $28 million in salaries for the 600 full-time employees and 2,750 part-time Guard members who would lose their jobs, which would trim tax revenue. In addition, businesses in the towns where Guard units are based would lose revenue.
 
Legislators Pledge to Help
 The impact of the announced cuts has led such legislators as United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and Representatives Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, and H. James Saxton, Republican of Mount Holly, to pledge the Guard their help in minimizing the cutbacks.
Especially in New Jersey's cities, officials say, the curtailment of the Guard and the closing of armories would have a major impact. There the Guard pay is often a member's only source of income, and the armory itself is a community gathering place.
The Newark Armory, at 120 Roseville Avenue, is a case in point.
Maj. Paul H. Rutt of Hasbrouck Heights, who supervises the armory, said its closing would have devastating results both on the neighborhood economy and on those who view it as a "community anchor."
"For some of the people here, this place is the difference between a straight and narrow path and the mean streets," said Major Rutt, who also supervises Guard sites in Jersey City, Riverdale and Woodbridge.
Of the 290 Guard members assigned to the Second Battalion of the 113th Infantry Division, an armored unit, at the armory, nearly one-third are unemployed in civilian life, Major Rutt said. Guard officials in New Jersey say that some 30 percent of their members statewide fall into the same category.
While the 113th Infantry is not slated for cutting, the armory is, and the unit would be transferred elsewhere. For the many unit members without cars, demanding that they fulfill their Guard obligation elsewhere "is like asking them to travel to the moon," Major Rutt said.
"Asking someone who makes a couple of hundred dollars for the weekend to pay for bus fare out of their own pocket to, say, Fort Dix isn't exactly being realistic," he said.
 
Loss of Pension Benefits
 Those forced to leave the Guard, he said, face not only the loss of pay but also loss of pension benefits built up over many years as well as discounted privileges at the post exchange and commissary, which many Guard members rely on to feed and clothe their families, Major Rutt said.
For Douglas Zeigler, 29, a guardsman who lives four blocks from the Newark Armory in an apartment he shares with his mother, grandmother and sister, his $3,000 annual income as a sergeant "helps to pay our bills and is time away from the streets."
Mr. Zeigler, a former full-time security guard, said that he had lost his job 18 months ago and that he had filled out countless job applications. "Nobody calls back," he said. "Just too many people out there looking for work, and every place has a waiting list."
While Mr. Zeigler is paid only for scheduled weekend Guard drills, he spends most days at the armory, he said, "helping out where I can because in a way it gives me a feeling of belonging." He spends some evenings there, too -- he is the scoutmaster for a troop that uses the armory.
The armory is also the home of the Newark Drum and Bugle Corps and provides a staging area for food and clothing drives for local charities.
 
Guard- Sponsored Program
 Mr. Zeigler earned a high school equivalency diploma through a Guard-sponsored program and said he planned to take advantage of college courses at state schools -- up to 12 credits a semester -- available to him without charge through the Guard.
Mr. Hartfield said his yearly pay of some $1,800 as a Newark guardsman went directly toward "my half of the rent" of an apartment he shares with his sister. After losing his job at Giants Stadium, he said, he has been unable to find another.
"I don't know what I'd do if it wasn't for the Guard work," he said, adding that he cannot file for unemployment compenstation because his service constitutes earned income and disqualifies him by state law.
"I've got friends out there who are making money by selling drugs -- not because they want to, because they have to to make ends meet," said Mr. Hartfield, a high school dropout. "I don't say nothing to them, but I know that I'm not going to wind up in jail or dead somewhere."
He also earned a high school equivalency diploma through the Guard.
 
A Difference in Impact
 For those Guard members with full-time jobs, the impact of the proposed cutbacks tends to be very different.
Tony A. Howard, 30, of Parsippany is a captain and company commander of a State National Guard unit based at the Newark Armory. "With the way things are, I've come to count on that extra income," said Mr. Howard, a production supervisor for a tax preparation service based in Cedar Grove.
His Guard pay helps him keep up his monthly car payments and buy clothing for his 14-year-old son, who, he said, "gets bigger with each and every day."
Mr. Mahon, a Guard captain and personnel officer at the armory in Washington Township, said he subsisted on the $7,000 he earned with the Guard. His regular salary goes right back into the home that he and his wife, Debra, bought at a high interest rate.
"My mortgage every month is $1,600, and between that and all my bills, my whole paycheck is gone," he said. Without such extra income, he said, he would be forced to sell the house. What's more, he added, "if we were to put the house on the market tomorrow, it's a sure bet that I'd wind up losing a lot of money."
 
Relocation Termed a Hardship
 Aldwin Olivera, 37, of North Bergen is a full-time guardsman and the Newark Armory's supply sergeant. His Guard connection provided him with a safety net four years ago when the company he had worked for went bankrupt, and he was able to switch from part-time Guard duty to a $30,000 full-time post. The closing of the armory, he said, would create a hardship for him and his family if he were assigned to a distant unit.
"By the time my wife gets ready for work, and by the time we get my daughter ready for day care, we'd have to rearrange everything," he said. "My daughter's got to be picked up on time, otherwise that's more money I've got to pay, that and maybe tolls and upkeep on my car."
Staff Sergeant Olivera said the threat of the armory's closing had filled him with anxiety. "Like lots of people around here, there was a time that you joined up because Government service meant job security," he said. "But not any more. Forget the assurances."

Aldwin Olivera with his wife, Aida, and 3-year-old daughter, Danielle, at their Newark home. The Newark Armory, where he works, may be closed in National Guard cutbacks. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

 
 
'EVITA' IN YORKTOWN
 A production of "Evita" by the nonprofit Yorktown Regional Theater Company opens at the Yorktown Performing Arts Theater Friday for seven performances. The musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber traces the rags-to-riches story of Eva Duarte, the low-born Argentine dancer-actress-radio personality who became the First Lady of her country. 
 Manipulative and ambitious, she was a force to reckon with, engineering the rise of her husband, Juan Peron, to the position of dictator. The two ruled together for six years, adored by the public because of their apparent compassion for the poor, but by the time Eva died of cancer at the age of 33 the Perons had stripped the country of its economic and moral resources. Juan Peron was soon overthrown and exiled. Thirty years later Eva is still regarded by many as a saint.
Craig Schulman, who had the leading role in "Les Miserables" on Broadway, plays Che, the revolutionary; Angela DeCicco portrays Evita, and Jeff Scott is Juan Peron.
Performances are scheduled for Friday and Saturday and from May 14 through 16 at 8 P.M., May 13 at 1 P.M. and May 17 at 3 P.M. The theater is at 1974 Commerce Street in Yorktown heights. Tickets at $15 and $18 can be reserved by calling 962-6665. Tickets for children through 12 years old and adults 65 and older are $13.
 
MEDIA AND THE CAMPAIGN
 Tom Post, general editor of Newsweek Magazine; Kyle Crichton, an editor on The New York Times Magazine handling politics and foreign affairs, and J. R. Brandstrader, a financial writer for Barron's, The Wall Street Journal and The New York Daily News, will participate in a panel discussion about the media and its reporting on the current presidential campaign.
"Campaign '92: How the Media Shape the Issues" will follow a dinner at Guidas Restaurant in Ossining today at 5 P.M., organized by the League of Women Voters of Briarcliff, Ossining, Croton and Cortlandt. Questions from the audience will be fielded by the panelists following their discussion. The numbers to call for information and reservations are 941-6674 or 941-2662.
 
'RUN FOR YOUR WIFE'
 "Run for Your Wife," a British comedy by Ray Cooney, which ran in London from 1982 to 1991 and on Broadway in 1989, will be performed by the Company Players of Throgs Neck, the Bronx, in New Rochelle. Presented by Fate Productions, performances are on Friday, Saturday and May 16 at 8 P.M., and next Sunday and May 17 at 3 P.M. in Romita Auditorium of the College of New Rochelle, at Elm Street and Castle Place.
The show is a fund-raising event for Fate Productions, a community theater founded last year by alumnae of the college. Tickets at $8, $6 for children, students and people 65 and older are available by calling 636-7450.
 
BENEFIT AT RIVERCLIFF
 Rivercliff, a 25-room Georgian manor house built in 1910 in Upper Nyack, was once the estate of Anton H. G. Fokker, designer of the synchronized propeller-machine gun aircraft of World War I.
The current owner, Dr. William D. Hardy Jr., has lent the house for use as a designer showhouse for the benefit of the Nyack Hospital and the Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern. It will be open for viewing today through May 31 from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and on Thursdays until 8 P.M.
Mario Buatta, the honorary chairman, will give a talk tomorrow at noon on "Decorating for Today With You in Mind," for which admission will be $50, including lunch, catalogue and a tour of the house.
Other noted interior designers who have redecorated rooms for the show are Jamie Gibbs, who will talk about window treatments on May 11 at 10 A.M., and Vicente Wolf, whose topic will be "Inspirations" on May 18 at 10 A.M. Admission to each lecture will be $25.
More than 35 interior designers, landscape designers and decorative painters have contributed their talents to transforming Rivercliff into the last word in the decorative arts.
A silent auction and raffle will produce prizes that include a trans-Atlantic cruise on the Queen Elizabeth 2, designer rugs, antiques and Oriental art objects. A gift shop will be open daily, and lunches prepared by restaurant chefs will be available for $10.
Admission is $15, or $12 for people 65 years older. The house is at 649 North Broadway, and the phone number for more information is 368-5151.
 
LONDONER IN RECITAL
 John Scott, organist and director of music at St. Paul's Cathedral in London, will give a free organ recital at the Reformed Church at Pondfield Road and Midland Avenue in Bronxville today at 4 P.M. Mr. Scott, who is in his late 30's, is also professor of organ at the Royal Academy of Music and assistant conductor to Sir David Willcocks of the Bach Choir in London.
In 1984 he won the international J. S. Bach Organ Competition in Leipzig. He was the youngest soloist to appear at the Proms (similar to the Boston Pops) concerts in Albert Hall, and in 1981 he performed at the wedding of the Prince and Princess of Wales. His American tours are booked two years in advance.
Among the works he will perform are two pieces composed by Mozart for musical clocks, transcribed for organ. Musical clocks were mechanisms that were pre-programmed and set off by clockworks. They produced a light, toylike sound. "The few that may still be in existence are probably in European museums," said Rodney Schuller, music director at the Bronxville church.
Also on the program are Bach's "Toccata and Fugue in F major," Mozart's "Fantasia in F minor," Franck's "Prelude, Fugue and Variations," an orchestral transcription for organ of Wagner's "Meistersinger" and the first movement of Widor's Fifth Symphony.
 
GARDENING WITH ROSES
 Everything will be coming up roses and rosarians when the Caramoor Garden Guild presents a symposium titled "Gardening With Roses" Friday from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. The event will be held at the Caramoor Center for the Arts in Katonah.
The session, a mixture of rose history and how-to expertise, will reveal how to find and recover old varieties of roses, how to incorporate roses into any size or style of garden and how to overcome fear of roses as an intimidating plant to cultivate.
Stephen Scanniello, head of the rose department at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden; Michael Shoup, author and owner of the Antique Rose Emporium in Texas, and Lily Shohan, an accredited American Rose Society judge will speak on the various aspects of rose culture.
Tickets, which include lunch, are $65. The number to call for reservations or more information is 232-1253.
 
COURSE IN GARDENING
 The fundamentals of gardening will be taught in a six-session course at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx by Ralph Snodsmith, host of "The Garden Hot Line" on WOR radio and garden editor for ABC television's "Good Morning America."
The classes, which will cover many facets of gardening from planting to the relationship of plants to the environment, will be held in two sections, from 10:15 A.M. to 12:15 P.M. or from 6:15 to 8:15 P.M. on Mondays beginning tomorrow. The fee is $143. The number to call to reserve a place is (212) 220-8747.

HEADLINE: Coming to Aid of a Homeless Shelter

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo offered to buy and renovate the once-proud hostelry that has become the rundown homeless shelter known as the Coachman Hotel in downtown White Plains. But Mr. Cuomo set a condition: the White Plains Common Council had to allow Westhelp, his nonprofit housing agency, to build 36 units of transitional housing as temporary quarters for families on welfare on city-owned land on Mamaroneck Avenue.
That, Mr. Cuomo discovered, was the end of that. 
 The plan ignited community opposition, and last September Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio and two supporters on the Council defeated it, sending the Governor's son back to his New York office amid a shower of angry words and raised fists in the Common Council chambers.
Now the County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, has stepped in, proposing a plan to renovate the Coachman that seems likely to please White Plains residents. Many want better management for the shelter but oppose additional housing for the homeless in their city.
 
Westhab to Replace Westhelp
 Noting the many problems at the Coachman, including drug sales and other crimes, Mr. O'Rourke said, "The county's intention has always been to clean up the Coachman and to make a reasonable place for people to live temporarily."
Westhelp will be replaced by Westhab, another nonprofit housing agency, which will completely renovate the shelter and manage it as a Tier II complete-service operation. Westhab, like Westhelp, redirects the allocations of Federal, state and county money used to house homeless families in motels to temporary housing and comprehensive care for families.
Housing Enterprises for the Less Privileged, a statewide agency, is the largest private provider of housing for the homeless in the nation. Help, as the agency is known, and its Westchester division, Westhelp, uses available funds to build emergency apartments for homeless families in several locations, including a 108-unit complex in Greenburgh and 46 units in Mount Vernon. The now-defunct Mamaroneck Avenue project proposed in White Plains was intended to complete the Help plan for Westchester.
People in Tier II programs operated by Westhab and Westhelp stay in the temporary housing an average of six months before finding permanent housing, said Commissioner Mary Glass of the Department of Social Services, while motel residents need an average of 30 months to find permanent housing.
 
$20 Million Loan Expected
 The Westhab program, based in Elmsford, has used public money to renovate more than 400 substandard housing units in the county in the last decade.
Under the program Mr. O'Rourke has proposed for the Coachman, Westhab, with a $20 million loan from the New York State Housing Finance Agency, will lease the hotel and an adjacent parking lot from the owners, Universal Hotels, for $8.9 million and provide housing, special counseling and employment for tenants while helping them find permanent housing. The parking lot is to become a playground.
Under the plan, which must be approved by the County Board of Legislators and by the Board of Acquisition and Contract, the county will buy the hotel for $1.18 million.
"The Coachman Hotel has symbolized everything that was wrong with homeless care," Mr. Cuomo said at a news briefing. "To finally do what was set out to do, to clean up the hotel and to get families into mainstream society is a phenomenal achievement."
Westhab will use plans drawn up by Westhelp for the renovation, Mr. Cuomo said, adding: "Westhelp is not an operator. We develop and come up with model programs."
Community opposition to housing for the homeless recently flared in the Fulton Park section of Greenburgh, only a few miles from the Westhelp complex. Neighborhood residents and town officials are opposing a county plan to double the capacity of the 58-bed Kings Inn, a former motel converted to a men's shelter, which has been operated since February by Westhab.
Although Greenburgh officials have asked the county to comply with its building and zoning codes, the county has refused. Negotiations to reduce the size of the men's shelter are continuing, said Frederick Turner, the Greenburgh Town Attorney.
Mr. Cuomo will be the keynote speaker at the seventh yearly Hope for the Homeless Dinner scheduled for Tuesday, May 19, at the Rye Town Hilton. The dinner, which begins with a 6 P.M. reception, is the largest source of nonprofit funds for the homeless in the county, raising $95,000 last year. Tickets are $55. The number to call for reservations and more information is 949-3043.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
After the Riots, Washington May Be Helpless

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As Los Angeles burned last week, it appeared that the nation might once again be prepared to look at the issues of economic growth and fairness and at the reality that the 1980's boom did not spread to the growing underclass of American cities.
There is no simple relationship between economic growth and inner-city rage. From 1963 through 1965, the year of the Watts riot, there was significantly better growth than in any similar period for almost a decade before. Now, the situation is reversed. Through the first three-plus years of his term, George Bush has presided over less economic growth than any President since World War II, even with last week's report of a mild revival in this year's first quarter. 
 Nonetheless, the sense of frustration and of hopelessness about escaping from inner-city poverty probably is similar now to what it was when Watts exploded. The statistics on such things as black teen-age unemployment are as horrifying as ever, and, to hear employers talk, many high school graduates now are less capable than their parents were three decades ago.
The market reaction to the riots in Los Angeles and some other cities was muted. The dollar weakened and a flight to safety pushed up prices of Treasury securities. But the stock market blissfully ignored the rioting on Thursday, and while selling increased on Friday, there was no panic exit. The Dow Jones industrial average finished the week up 11.63 points, at 3,336.09.
Whether that calm reaction was warranted remains to be seen. Conceivably, the specter of anarchy, and all that seems to say about this society, could deal a blow to consumer confidence, which had begun to rise because people have been feeling better about the future, not because they thought the present situation had improved very much.
The rising gap between rich and poor in this country has probably served as an aid to securities prices in the last few years, if only because it is the better-off who buy most of the stocks and bonds. Now it may serve to remind those who are well-off of the fragility of a modern society and of uncertainties much more fundamental than worries over next quarter's profits.
A generation ago, inner-city riots spurred the Government to huge efforts to address inequalities, with some positive effects. A similar effort seems impossible now. With the huge deficits that accompanied the Reagan boom and the Bush bust, a war on poverty will be difficult.
That the current economic slowdown has lasted so long has been due in part to the fact that fiscal policy was paralyzed. Investors, however, have been more than willing to believe that monetary policy, by itself, would eventually get the economy growing again, and have bid share prices up on that assumption.
It is hard, however, to see how Fed policy can do much for the problems now thrown into sharp perspective by the flames of Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
M.B.A. in Reality

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
B MINUS. That's the mark that B. Joseph White, dean of the University of Michigan Business School, gives other business schools for their efforts in preparing what he calls competent business leaders for tomorrow's challenges.
Dean White, a business school teacher and business executive who has been in his current post since July, sees some serious gaps in the education of M.B.A.'s. They may learn corporate strategy and finance, he says, but they don't learn operational effectiveness -- how to achieve world-class quality, for example. 
 That is where his new M.A.P. program comes in. It may have a dull name -- Multidisciplinary Action Project -- but it aims to corral all those new concepts about managing to regain competitiveness from the Japanese and others and teach managers how to act on the ideas.
"Business is not just an intellectual game, it's an action game," Mr. White said in a telephone interview last week.
The M.A.P. program is a business residency that places all Michigan M.B.A. students in companies like Xerox, Federal Express and Motorola for a period of real-world training. The first program began in March and ran through April.
The second part of Mr. White's thesis about M.B.A.'s is that they don't care enough about the nonbusiness systems of society -- education, health care, the justice system. He wants the executive mindset to include leadership on social, racial and environmental problems. To foster that ideal, the 420 students who entered the Michigan school at Ann Arbor for the current class were assigned to decaying neighborhoods and community service organizations for two days, an experience that led to year-long involvement for many.
The third part to Mr. White's thinking is to get students interested in helping to fill the economic void in the former Soviet bloc. The school has just set up the William Davidson Institute with a $30 million grant to assist emerging economies in eastern and central Europe. William Davidson heads Guardian Industries of Northville, Mich., a glass manufacturer with operations in Hungary. The grant came from Guardian.
Dean White, 45, says his value system was forged in a stint as a vice president at Cummins Engine, a company that he says stresses issues of corporate responsibility. He had been a Michigan faculty member in the 1970's before going to Cummins and returned to the faculty five years ago.

LENGTH: 1712 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 5-10

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Paying the Price for Violence in South-Central Los Angeles 

The riots in Los Angeles and elsewhere around the country are a profound human tragedy, with dozens killed and thousands injured. But they are also a business nightmare falling disproportionately on hundreds of small companies. "It's a mess. I can't believe they've done this," said Sonia Garcia, manager of a local food market in Los Angeles that had its windows smashed. County authorities estimate roughly that more than $200 million has been lost. "The only way to assess loss is to go in there and look at the damage, and it's not in the interest of our adjusters to go out there at this point," said Jerry Parsons, a spokesman for State Farm Insurance in Bloomington, Ill. Though more businesses are insured than during the Watts riots in 1965, "small businesses don't have the ability to make up lost time, lost money, lost production," said Ronald J. Lenney, president of a company that employs 75 people.
 
A Joint Step Toward Interactivity
 
Linking computers to television sets has long been a futurist's dream. It would enable customers to download customized entertainment from vast, centralized libraries. Last week that dream moved a step nearer to reality when the International Business Machines Corporation and Time Warner Inc., the nation's largest media company and No. 2 cable television operator, said they would join forces on an interactive TV project. The new system would allow cable subscribers to call up programs from libraries. Though it won't be ready for a decade, the companies have high hopes for the plan. "We see four industries converging: computers, consumer electronics, telecommunications and media and entertainment," said Lucie J. Fjeldstad, the vice president in charge of multimedia at I.B.M. Those industries will "form a new industry that will deliver a wide spectrum of digital goods and services to businesses and homes," she said.

Citibank's Perception Problems
 
Citicorp is like "Rashomon," the classic Japanese film. Deciphering its true nature depends upon whom you ask. For some, it is banking's biggest weakling. But for the analysts at Fidelity Investments, the nations largest family of mutual funds, it is banking's comeback kid. Last week, Fidelity disclosed that it had taken a 10 percent stake in Citicorp that it will spread among its various funds. That investment was worth about $645 million. "We're impressed with Citicorp's turnaround," said Bruce Herring, portfolio manger for Fidelity's Select Financial Services fund. Citicorp said last week it had earned $183 million or 37 cent a share, up 96.8 percent from 93 million or 17 cents a share in the first quarter last week.

No to Tarzan the Hunk Man?
 
Though Tarzan gallivants around the jungle clad in a loin cloth, the heirs of Edgar Rice Burroughs, his creator, say the ape man is really a very modest and moral character at heart. For that reason, they filed a $1 million suit against Conde Nast Publications for its 14-page "Tarzan, Meet Jane," spread in Vogue. The suit was filed in a Federal court in Manhattan. Even though the character's copyright expired long ago (he is 70 years old, after all), the suit charges that the layouts, which show a rock-ribbed, skimpily-clad Tarzan posing with a series of Janes, were too "sexually charged," and were "inconsistent with the good, wholesome and attractive images of Tarzan and Jane." In a statement, Conde Nast argued that the work was "an appropriate editorial use of public domain characters." Now it's up to the courts.

Nowhere to Run or Hide
 
A new telephone system, announced last week by A.T.& T., guarantees you can be bothered wherever you go. The new program, called Easy Reach, will assign subscribers their own "700" number. Call the number and you'll get the subscriber no matter where they are. The system, which makes use of A.T.& T.'s massive computer power, can route calls everywhere, including onto cellular networks. A "700" number will cost $7 a month with a one set-up charge of $25. But they are not intended for widespread use. Subscribers must approve would-be callers and put them on a list and can strike callers from their list whenever they wish.

Spared in the Nick of Time
 
The 990-foot luxury liner United States started its life in 1952. Its white-shoe crew set the record for crossing the Atlantic. The ship made 400 Atlantic crossings before it was retired in 1969. Last week, the United States escaped being turned into razor blades, but barely. The ship, which cost $78 million to build, was sold for $2.6 million to Marmara Investments, a Turkish shipping firm. A spokesman for the firm, said the new owners would invest $145 million, refitting it as a cruise ship.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Yeltsin Seeks No-Pain Gain
 
What the budding capitalists in Moscow don't realize is that a gift from the tooth fairy first of all requires the pain of losing the tooth. That much was evident last week when after joining the International Monetary Fund as a prelude to receiving up to $24 billion in Western aid, Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, said his country would not go along with the conditions the I.M.F. is famous for setting down. Some of those conditions -- reducing the budget deficit, reforming the farming and energy sectors and others -- can be downright painful as well as slow. "We do not intend to work under the direct orders of the I.M.F. We do not agree completely with this organization's viewpoint and we will stick to our point of view," Mr. Yeltsin said.

Olympia & York's Bad Times
 
It hasn't been the best of years for cash-strapped Olympia & York, North America's largest real estate developer. Not only has it missed payments on its $18.5 billion in outstanding loans, but last week its creditors threatened to seize the company's Toronto headquarters, the Exchange Tower. The trustees for Olympia's creditors set May 20 to discuss whether or not to take over the tower.

In Germany, Labor Awakens
 
Labor relations in Germany have been placid for years. In part, that is because Germany's labor unions, which often have representatives on the boards of the companies where their members work, have gotten a pretty good deal for their volk. Not only do they earn world-class wages, but their work week is the industrial world's shortest and their vacations are among the world's longest. But last week, that tranquility began unraveling. First the civil servants went on strike. They demanded a 9.5 percent pay increase; the Government offered 4.8 percent. Then IG Metall, the powerful metal workers union, staged a "demonstration" strike. About 130,000 of its 3.6 million members put down their tools. The metal workers want a 9.5 percent increase. Their employers offered 3.3 percent.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A Little Economic Necromancy
 
Slow growth in the winter, getting stronger in the spring, might as well be a sentence in the fortune-telling book, the I Ching. But that is how the Government sees the economy. It is also how Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company saw it. So far his forecast -- 2 percent growth in the gross domestic product in the first quarter -- is exactly in line with the figures released last week by the Commerce Department. But Mr. Roach believes this recovery will be different from those that went before it. "It will be a productivity-led recovery," Mr. Roach said. "It will be built on a more solid foundation than what's gone before it when recoveries were led by consumption," he said. Solid foundation, yes. But the problem with that kind of recovery is that it doesn't create jobs since the gains come from increased efficiency. "I see growth at 4.25 percent over the final three quarters," he said.
 
Broadway Bounce Back? Can Do
 
Tinseltown may be in the doldrums, but unlike Hollywood, Broadway is golden right now. Last week, 27 productions attracted 222,000 theatergoers. Those kind of numbers haven't been seen since 1981. Last week closed out a month which attracted 830,000 people to the shows and with box-office receipts the highest of any four-week period in New York history with a take of $30,108,322. "Guys and Dolls," which opened last month, was a major hit but "Miss Saigon," with sales of $705,154, led the pack. "The Phantom of the Opera" had $645,103 in sales. And theatergoers don't just go to see plays, they eat too. "The telephone hasn't stopped ringing for reservations," said Joe Allen, owner of Joe Allen and Orso, two theater district restaurants. "Our business is up 20 percent."

A Little More Necromancy
 
The Government's main forecasting tool the index of leading economic indicators, increased by 0.2 percent in March, the Commerce Department said last week. The indicator charts growth six to nine months hence, and those figures suggest it won't exactly be robust. But while everyone is looking ahead, Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago, is looking in the rearview mirror. "The Commerce Department's lagging indicators were up 0.4 percent for March after declining for eight months," Mr. Kahan said. When those indicators -- which include exotica like the ratio of business inventories to sales -- are up, they signal that inflation may be in the offing. "The numbers sound a cautionary note on prices," he said.

New Homes Sales Drop Off a Cliff
 
Sales of new homes fell an astonishing 14.8 percent in March, the Commerce Department said last week. That was the steepest monthly decline in more than 10 years. Analysts said the drop was caused by rising mortgage rates and uncertainty over the attempt by Congress to enact a tax credit for some home buyers (it failed). They also said good weather in January and February lured people into making their purchases earlier. Even with those explanations -- or excuses -- analysts were worried. "It's a caution sign," said David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.

The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index jumped 8.3 points in April to 65.8, the highest reading in eight months.

HEADLINE: America -- Environmental Dictator?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: CUMANA, Venezuela

 BODY:
Down by the docks here, where Caribbean accents mingle with a sharp scent of fish, more and more tuna boats are tied up, and more and more sailors and canners are out of work.
With American consumers inspecting tuna cans for "Dolphin Safe" labels, the United States has imposed a series of embargoes on imports of yellowfin tuna from Venezuela and Mexico. Boats from these countries kill dolphins at twice the rate of American tuna fishers. Sealed off from the world's largest tuna market since August 1990, Venezuela's tuna fleet has shrunk to 34 boats, from a high of 118 just four years ago. 
 "We are paying for the dolphins with a crime wave," Ramon Martinez, a leftwing congressman, said of the economic depression that hangs over this city, Venezuela's biggest fishing port.
Besides being responsible for Cumana's leaping jobless rate, the tuna trade embargoes have set off an international debate over an issue destined to bedevil commerce in the 1990's -- clashes between free traders and environmentalists.
"A country may not restrict imports of a product solely because it originates in a country whose environmental policies are different," it was argued recently by the world's trade umpire, the Secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Echoing this view, Laura Rojas, Director General of Venezuela's Institute of Foreign Trade, said in an interview: "The U.S. has passed domestic legislation that has jurisdiction outside of the U.S. Environmental protection can't be had at the cost of another country."
In February, Venezuela joined members of the European Community and 23 other nations in urging the United States to abide by a GATT ruling that the unilateral American ban on tuna imports from Mexico and Venezuela is illegal.
Resistance was the response from environmentalists, including Earth Island Institute, a nonprofit group based in San Francisco that initiated court action leading to the tuna ban.
"They are kidding themselves if they think that GATT can force the U.S. to abandon laws to protect the global environment," said David C. Phillips, Earth Island's executive director. "In the 1990's, free trade and efforts to protect the global environment are on a collision course."
He predicted that other conflicts lie ahead, citing plans by several industrialized nations to ban imports of ozone-depleting chemicals, plans by several European nations to ban imports of tropical hardwoods that are not cut from sustainably managed forests and a threat by Japan to submit to GATT mediation unilateral embargoes on trade in whale products and bluefin tuna, a staple for sushi cuisine.
According to GATT, such problems concerning "the global commons" should be solved through "international environmental agreements."
But with little progress being made on preparing global agreements in advance of next month's United Nations conference on the environment and development in Rio de Janeiro, many analysts believe that unilateral environmental protectionism by the world's wealthy nations may be a wave of the future.
"Tuna is the debut for a great debate between environmentalists and traders," said Oliver Belisario, a Caracas-based consultant for Venezuela's tuna industry.
Not only has the United States ignored the GATT ruling of last fall, but, in January, a Federal judge in San Francisco issued a secondary embargo against 20 nations thought to be engaged in "tuna laundering."
Suspected of purchasing Venezuelan and Mexican tuna for repackaging and marketing abroad, these nations are prohibited from selling tuna to the United States. Since February, five nations have been dropped from the list after formally pledging not to buy Venezuelan or Mexican tuna.
With Venezuelan and Mexican tuna now shut out of the United States, Australia and most of Europe, tuna landed here sells at a steep discount from world prices -- about $600 a ton, compared with about $1,000 elsewhere if it qualifies as "Dolphin Safe." A ship's tuna catch is rated "Dolphin Safe" under American consumer law only if an international on-board observer certifies that no dolphins were killed during netting operations.
"The canners used the embargo as a tool to play with prices," complained Giovanni Ombra, the owner of several tuna boats here. "Several Venezuelan ship owners had to give their boats to the bank."
Safeway Stores Inc., the largest American supermarket chain, and Star-Kist, Chicken of the Sea and Bumble Bee, the United States's top three tuna companies, only sell tuna certified "Dolphin Safe." Cans labeled "Dolphin Safe" account for up to 95 percent of the tuna sold in the United States, a nation which accounts for about half of world consumption.
"We don't even can tuna in Venezuela for Venezuelan consumption any more," said John M. Werner, president of the local subsidiary of the H. J. Heinz Company. Heinz owns Star-Kist, the world's largest tuna canner. "Heinz has a worldwide 'dolphin safe' tuna policy," he said.
Under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, Venezuela and Mexico cannot export tuna products to the United States because their boats last year had a dolphin kill rate higher than the law's trigger point, which is 1.25 times the United States fleet average. Last year, American boats killed an average of 2.5 dolphins every time a mile-long purse seine net was set for a tuna shoal.
Venezuela contends that the United States has set standards that are impossibly high for third world fleets in order to protect the American fleet at a time, say the Venezuelans, when tuna demand is flat.
But demand is growing at an annual rate of 2 percent in the United States and 5 percent worldwide, according to Richard C. Atchison, executive director of the American Tunaboat Association, a trade group based in San Diego. The price of tuna has increased by an average of 6 percent worldwide since the secondary embargo was put in place earlier this year, he added.
Venezuelans claim they have reduced their dolphin kill by 75 percent in the last three years. According to varying estimates, Venezuelan boats accounted for one-quarter to one-third of the 25,000 dolphins killed last year in tuna nets in the main mortality area, the eastern tropical part of the Pacific Ocean.
To reduce the dolphin kill, Venezuela has banned drift nets, placed international observers on all tuna boats over 400 tons and required that all tuna boat captains take courses on new techniques in minimizing dolphin kills.
This month, Venezuela is scheduled to become a full member of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, a multilateral regulatory body. It has pledged $500,000 to the commission for research to find better ways to protect dolphins.
Venezuelans say that the Americans halved their dolphin kill ratios over the last decade by shifting their boats from the eastern Pacific to the western Pacific. In the eastern Pacific fishing grounds, in latitudes between California and Peru, dolphins congregate above schools of adult yellowfin tuna, a biological association which occurs less frequently in other waters of the world for reasons that are not clear to scientists.
Claiming to be prisoners of geography, the Venezuelans say it is too distant for them to fish in the western Pacific.
In addition, fishing in the eastern Pacific is largely in international waters. In the west, tuna captains have to pay royalties and access fees to governments of Polynesian island nations that control local marine resources.
"Under Venezuelan law, it is illegal to kill dolphins," said Eduardo Szeplaki, general coordinator of Fundatropicos, a Venezuelan environmental group. "Unfortunately, the profit motive leads them to violate the law."

HEADLINE: At Work;
When a White Collar Unravels

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Most middle-class Americans -- and most Americans define themselves as middle class -- find it difficult to see the poor as anything other than objects of charity, pity or contempt. That sentiment makes all the more arresting the ramifications of a new historical study of poverty, "The Dispossessed: America's Underclasses From the Civil War to the Present."
Like the labor economists who argued in this space last week that white-collar workers should attend to the fate of their unionized blue-collar counterparts, Dr. Jacqueline Jones, Harry S. Truman Professor of American Civilization at Brandeis University, contends that the middle class has much to learn from the former slaves, migrants and sharecroppers who people her research. 
 The Civil War, she argues, so fundamentally altered social and economic relations in the United States that the changes continue to reverberate today, explaining much that goes on with respect to work, from unemployment to layoffs to affirmative action.
"The Dispossessed" traces the experience of people for whom "mobility" -- the term that when coupled with "upward" is the resonant image of the American dream -- had a literal meaning: movement from, say, one farm in rural Georgia to another, in search of another barely-living wage. The slaves and poor whites who worked the land of the antebellum South became in succession over the generations the sharecroppers, tenant farmers and migrant laborers at the heart of agriculture in the South. And when, after World War II, mechanization administered the coup de grace to a dying way of subsistence, many migrated North to become the driving force of America's postwar industrial expansion.
Today, as industry itself migrates, whether offshore or out of state, the descendants of sharecroppers might well be laid-off auto workers or waitresses at malls, either chronically under- or unemployed.
The destiny of these workers, generation in and out, was determined by economic forces far beyond their control -- dropping demand for cotton, say -- and therein, Dr. Jones says, lies the cautionary tale for today's white-collar workers, who tend to believe firmly that success or failure is a private matter between an individual and his or her will.
Second of two articles
on structural changes in work.

 "Several points," she said, summoning contrasting images of tractors and computers, link the 19th-century cotton field with the 20th-century office.
"One: The impulse to streamline and consolidate in all kinds of businesses is characteristic of American enterprise," she said. For years, "it displaced blue-collar workers. Now similar forces are affecting white-collar workers."

SHE compares the hard-bargaining attitude of Southern landowners toward the rural proletariat after the Civil War to the company consolidations, downsizing and cost-cutting measures endemic now. "Combined with computerization, they eliminate managerial positions," she said. "The banking industry is a good example. All businesses want to be more competitive. Whether they are or not, workers lose their jobs."
"Two: The fate of individual workers often rests on the sector of the economy they are in, not on how productive or hard-working they are," Dr. Jones said. "Americans must come to grips with the fact that unemployment is not a reflection of one's character. It's pegged to international transformations. This country has embraced the myth over the generations that if you're out of work, something is wrong with you."
Being in the right place at the right time -- namely, in a expanding sector of the economy -- is more important than being hardworking, she argues, chucking a poison dart at American beliefs about achievement.
"Three: No matter how secure white-collar workers are, they will be affected by the unemployment in their region," she said. Massive layoffs eventually will be felt in a deterioration in schools and police and fire services as the tax base erodes. Dr. Jones points to central Ohio, a once-robust industrial region now in decline.
The final counsel Dr. Jones offers is that historically most poor people have demonstrated a nimbleness at exploiting their meager resources that the more secure should admire: "The poor don't always do the kind of work that gets recorded, but their coping strategies belie the image of them as shiftless and lazy. They deserve credit."
 
 
 
THE CENTRAL ROLE OF RACE
 "The Dispossessed" is a history of poverty, but its central issue is race. Dr. Jacqueline Jones's elegant opening sentence -- "Poverty abides no line drawn by color or culture" -- challenges the widespread perception that poverty is a problem of urban blacks. That perception, Dr. Jones believes, is a function of the objectification of blacks by whites.
"Americans have always singled out a 'dangerous class,' especially in the cities," she said. "My work tries to point out that blacks want the same thing for themselves and their children as whites do."
Her research demonstrates that since the Civil War, whites, especially white men, have been successful at constricting black opportunity. Early in this century, inexperienced whites applying for factory work were given preference over blacks, creating an economic foothold denied to blacks. Discrimination continued to preserve opportunities for white men by protecting them from competition.
Dr. Jones is critical of the "capture" of poverty studies by social scientists obsessed with the "pathology" of urban black street culture, which, she says, represents only a small segment of the poor. "There's a notion that all whites are middle class and all blacks are poor," she said. She points out that many cities have a solid black middle class. "Nobody wants to hear about them," she said.

HEADLINE: Simplistic Formulas, Broad Generalizations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Janine Wedel makes numerous and largely unsubstantiated critical comments regarding American assistance efforts in Eastern Europe, especially our aid to Poland ("Getting It Right in Aid to Russia," Forum, April 5). She takes highly complex issues, reduces them to simplistic formulas, then makes broad generalizations which do not stand up to closer scrutiny. 
 For example, she totally ignores the Polish-American Enterprise Fund, which has injected over $90 million into the Polish economy in the form of loans (more than 700 to small and medium-sized businesses) and equity investments. In fact, when questioned on this point during Congressional testimony, Ms. Wedel admitted she was incapable of even discussing the fund, the second-largest element of our aid to Poland. (The largest is the United States contribution of $200 million to the Polish Stabilization Fund, which Ms. Wedel admits is a success.) Similar investment funds have been formed for Hungary, Bulgaria and the Czech and Slovak Republic.
One of Ms. Wedel's many false allegations is that "United States policy insists on aiding the private sector and avoiding governments almost entirely." In Poland, the United States Government is providing assistance to government bodies dealing with finance, privatization, agriculture, energy and the environment, to name a few. The major emphasis of our program is on the private sector, but we do not shy away from assisting government institutions when it fits in with our overall strategy.
 
STEPHEN D. HAYES
Washington, April 14
 
The writer is director of the office of external affairs, United States Agency for International Development.

HEADLINE: The On-Time Record For PATH Trains

 BODY:
I would like to respond to several areas concerning PATH in a letter by Janet L. Grosso to the New Jersey editor on April 5.
PATH's on-time performance for 1991 was 90.4 percent. In December of that year and during the first two months of 1992, we did experience enroute delays in both our Journal Square-33d and Hoboken-33d services. These delays were caused by track conditions in several tunnel areas that required us to institute slow-speed orders in those tunnel areas. These problems did adversely affect PATH's on-time performance for this period. 
 During this period, every effort was made to minimize delays and inconvenience to our passengers. Public-address announcements and messages on our MetroVision monitors advised passengers to allow extra time for the daily commute. N.J. Transit was also advised of the problems and requested to hold connections whenever possible.
Temporary repairs have been performed to eliminate most of the track conditions that caused these problems. The slow-speed orders have been lifted, and our on-time performance levels have steadily climbed back to prior levels.
Another point raised by Ms. Grosso is incorrect. The 55 m.p.h. speed limit she refers to is the maximum attainable speed of the equipment, and PATH trains attain these speeds in the nontunnel area between Journal Square and Newark. The maximum speed for trains traveling in the tunnel areas is 40 m.p.h.
Further, PATH does have an agreement with N.J. Transit to guarantee connections. We notify N.J. Transit of all service delays and disruptions and request them to hold for connections wherever possible. N.J. Transit will hold trains upon request when operationally feasible and its schedule allows.
I want to assure Ms. Grosso and all our passengers of my personal commitment to providing consistent levels of quality services. PATH is a vital link in the total trans-Hudson network, which is essential to the economic growth of the metropolitan area. The Port Authority's mission is to improve on the levels of service and strengthen the region as a whole.
 
RICHARD R. KELLY
Vice President
and General Manager
PATH
New York

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Russians Set Out Under Capitalists' Rules for Change

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
No other nation today seems to have Russia's natural potential to burst forth as a great economic power. It's got oil reserves, vast forests and mineral deposits, proud and capable people, rich culture and traditions. It could become a mighty producer and consumer of goods of the 21st century.
The problem -- the eternal Russian problem -- is how to get to there from here. Russia's centuries-old pursuit of wealth is a history of dead ends. In the Middle Ages, trade routes from the East that had brought prosperity shifted to the Mediterranean, and Russian towns withered. Peter the Great brought an 18th century revival by importing Western ways, but at the price of allowing an even more pernicious system of serfdom. And Communism in this century achieved huge breakthroughs in heavy industry and space technology -- until the Soviet economy collapsed. 
 Now the United States and the other industrial powers, through their agent the International Monetary Fund, are enthusiastically pushing Russia down a new road. As a condition for billions of dollars in loans, they are insisting upon a regime that drastically cuts back many of the enterprises and jobs that gave most Russians an income until the Soviet Union collapsed. It is part of a complex economic formula often applied in the West -- with so-so success, by the way -- but never attempted in a nation without a market economy. A hint of the difficulties that may lie ahead is that no one has any idea how much Russian money is worth.
"This is uncharted territory for the I.M.F.," said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who participated in talks last week with Russian officials at the I.M.F.'s semi-annual meeting in Washington. "In the end, the Russians will have to manage the transition to capitalism by themselves, and the question for us is, 'Can we play a role?' "
While the Russian Government announced last week that it will make the ruble freely convertible into dollars and other hard currencies by early summer, presumably opening the gate for trade and foreign investment, convertibility assumes prior steps that could mean upheaval and painful setbacks for what is now the Commonwealth of Independent States. "The I.M.F. formula could easily go wrong; in fact it is hard to make it go right," said Robert Heilbroner, an economics historian. "It is very hard to write a scenario in which magic happens."
First, inflation must be reduced from its present rate of more than 20 percent a month. Otherwise the ruble will keep losing value, prompting a run on dollars and quickly using up the $6 billion that the West is to make available.
But controlling inflation may be impossible now. For one thing, President Boris N. Yeltsin will have to keep reducing his Government's budget deficit so that the central bank no longer has to print new rubles to pay Government debts. This, in turn, means cutting subsidies and credits to state enterprises -- something that Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, who is Mr. Yeltsin's economics chief, promised last week to achieve.
The state-owned enterprises losing Government subsidies and credits have three choices. The one preferred by the I.M.F. and Mr. Gaidar is to make ends meet by selling, at fire-sale discounts, goods stored up in anticipation of more inflation. The more likely response, many economists say, will be widespread layoffs. And if layoffs and wage concessions don't work, the third choice, unhappily, is bankruptcy.
 
Puzzle: The Value of a Ruble
 Many problems are ingrained in decades of central planning. To figure out the ruble's value, for example, the Yeltsin Government and the I.M.F. have to determine how many rubles are in circulation -- a sum that has so far escaped calculation in a system that carries out many transactions without using money. A stable exchange rate, promised last week by July 1, also implies that products in Russia can be realistically priced. If similar shoes sell in Russia for 1,000 rubles and in the United States for $100, then an exchange rate reflecting the value would be 10 rubles for each dollar. But what price will a state-owned shoe manufacturer have to charge to cover costs once the company loses its Government subsidy? No one knows, but if the price rises to 10,000 rubles in the coming months, then the ruble's value will sink to 100 to the dollar, disrupting the I.M.F.'s efforts at stabilization.
Finally, the I.M.F. prescription assumes that the Russian economy will respond as a free market would. With price ceilings lifted for most foods, for example, Russian farmers should get enough new income to offset rising costs for fertilizer, tractors and fuel, says Russell Cheetham, who directs World Bank operations for the Commonwealth republics. But numerous monopolies, most state-owned, control the transportation, processing and retailing of food and keep the new income for themselves. "In fact, there is evidence that prices to farmers are deteriorating," Mr. Cheetham said. And the Russian Central Bank is advancing 200 billion rubles in special credits for the farm sector -- printing more money -- to finance spring planting.
Such complications made some Bush Administration officials reluctant to lift foreign exchange restrictions and declare the ruble convertible. Indeed, a convertible currency encourages giant corporations like Ford or Honda to sell cars in Russia, confident of payment in dollars or yen. Such competition could drive Russian auto makers out of business before they had time to adjust to capitalism and open markets.
Such misgivings gave way, however, largely because Mr. Yeltsin made currency convertibility a political goal, staking popularity on its early achievement. Mr. Heilbroner would prefer a Russia less locked into Western ways. "What we are watching is the birth of a new social order," he said. "It is not going to be capitalism or socialism but some combination of many elements. That takes patience and help on our part to alleviate the pain, and a willingness not to meddle while this new order is coming into being."
That is more like the Russia imagined by the novelist Nikolai Gogol at the end of "Dead Souls": "You Russia -- aren't you racing headlong like the fastest troika imaginable? The road smokes under you, bridges rattle, and everything falls behind." But, he wrote, "She doesn't answer . . . the air is torn to shreds and turns into wind; everything on earth flashes past, and, casting worried, sidelong glances, other nations and countries step out of her way."
That may have been just a touch hyperbolic when it was written, in 1842. Today, the Western diffidence is definitely missing.
