HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
New, Virulent Strains of Hatred in the Balkans, and Beyond

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
When the battle for Bosnia and Herzegovina reached Sarajevo last month, one of the first buildings damaged was the old block on the embankment of the Miljacka River beside which a 19-year-old Bosnian Serb nationalist stood on June 28, 1914, when he fired the shots that killed Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Sophie. In those days, nobody doubted that events in the Balkans crucially affected the stability of Europe, and it was Gavrilo Princip's shots, prompting war between Serbia and Austria-Hungary, that led directly to World War I.
Now, with European security anchored in the diplomatic and military alliances that grew from World War II, the consequences of Balkan conflicts are less obviously dire, to all except those who suffer and die in them. Still, the artillery and mortar fire that Serb paramilitaries have rained down on Sarajevo, and the communal fighting that has killed at least 10,000 people and made 1.2 million others homeless elsewhere across Croatia and Bosnia, have broad implications for the stability of the modern world. The ghost of Princip is abroad, and those it threatens may include millions who know nothing of the historic grievances of Bosnian Serbs. 
 What is happening in Bosnia, with Serbs and Croats and Muslim Slavs killing one another with a ferocity not seen in Europe since 1945, is a measure of the potential conflicts that lie latent across Eastern Europe and the republics of the former Soviet Union now that the forces of ethnicity, religion and culture are no longer buried under the concrete of Communism. Farther afield, the events of last week in Afghanistan, with a coalition of guerrilla groups taking power from the disintegrated Communist regime, could prove to be just a pause before civil war breaks out again, this time between the various guerrilla groups and the rival ethnic, geographic and religious factions they represent.
 
'Only One Step Behind'
 Earlier this year, the belief that events in Yugoslavia were a contagion, not only within the republics of the old Communist federation but beyond them, helped to persuade Cyrus R. Vance, the United Nations' special envoy on Yugoslavia, that a United Nations peacekeeping force should be sent to Croatia. At a critical moment in the discussions in New York, Yuli M. Vorontsov, who once represented the Soviet Union and now speaks for Russia, intervened to urge that the plan proceed. "You must do this, for our sake," he said. "We are only one step behind Yugoslavia." His words apply as well to Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Romania, to cite only some of the former Communist countries that face challenges in accommodating large, restive ethnic groups. In Asia, though its Government would be the last to say so, China too is a powder keg of ethnic discontent.
Part of what doomed Communism was, of course, the Marxist-Leninist fallacy that ethnic, nationalist and religious hatreds were a product of capitalism, and that crushing the old ruling class would forge a brotherhood blind to distinctions of blood and religion. In fact, by trying to break the bonds that tied communities together, Communist repression forged the mutant strains that have now burst forth, most catastrophically in Yugoslavia. In Serbia and Croatia, what hope there was that old scores would be resolved peacefully vanished when leaders formed by the old regime rode to power in the first post-Communist elections by appealing to the most narrow-minded and vengeful instincts among peoples who had, in many cases, learned to live side by side with old enemies in a striking degree of harmony. Now, even the belated acknowledgement last week by the Government in Belgrade that Yugoslavia consists only of Serbia and Montenegro cannot stop the slaughter.
But to blame Communism for the malevolent resurgence of ancient currents is too comfortable a conclusion. While the Communists were brutal in their attempts to wipe the chalkboard of history, there was a nobility to the ideal of uniting peoples across the divides of culture and faith. In Afghanistan, what gave momentum to the small, conspiratorial Marxist party that seized power in 1978 were the country's woeful standards in education, economic development, health care, nutrition and the status of women. Now that the Kabul Government is in the hands of men who are committed to reinforcing the power of Islam, and whose political power rests in the country's maze of tribe and language, many Afghans fear that they will once more be denied the rewards of progress.
Nor is the challenge confined to countries that have thrown off the Marxist shackles. Vaclav Havel, the Czechoslovak President, has spoken of the shocks of the post-Communist era as "a long-forgotten history coming back to haunt us, a history full of thousands of economic, social, ethical, territorial, cultural and political problems that remained latent and unnoticed under the surface of totalitarian boredom." But he also says these shocks have had disturbing echoes in the West, ones that may eventually force the established democracies to examine whether their own universalist answers to the problems of human history -- political democracy, free economic markets, human rights, the elaboration of supranational accords -- respond adequately to human needs. "We must see the pluralism of the world, and not bind it by seeking common denominators or reducing everything to a single common equation," Mr. Havel has said.
Already, Western Europe has been shaken by visions out of its own past. The ethnic clashes in the old East Germany between neo-fascist groups and African and Asian immigrants, and the rising support for Jean-Marie Le Pen's anti-immigrant party in France, are only two pressing examples. And polls suggest that only a minority of Canadians believe any longer that the extension of French-language rights across all 10 provinces is an adequate response to the strivings of French-speaking Quebec for its own special degree of autonomy. In Britain, many politicians accept that something will have to be done to assuage the strength of nationalists in Scotland, and to a lesser extent in Wales.
And as soon as rioting in Los Angeles began last week, it renewed the debate in the United States about how minority rights and aspirations can best be secured, and whether there may be merit in approaches that give more leeway to the sense of a common fate among minority groups. Yugoslavia's most powerful lesson lies in the bloodshed and destruction that await when communities like the Bosnian Serbs are encouraged to believe that sectional rights rank above all others, and that in securing them no measures can be spared, not even those that inflict miseries on rival groups. But if there is another lesson here, it may be, as in Los Angeles, that no nation can rest easy as long as any community feels that it lacks guarantees of an equal spot in the sun.

Yugoslavia was born after World War I as a kingdom of the diverse south Slavs that was ruled from Belgrade, Serbia's capital. It was reconstituted after World War II as a federation of six republics. In the recent turmoil four have seceded, and Yugoslavia encompasses just two of the six, Serbia and Montenegro.

HEADLINE: CITY OF NIGHTMARES;
A Terrible Chain of Events Reveals Los Angeles Without Its Makeup

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Among the myriad layers of conflicting images that the City of Los Angeles conjures worldwide, none has been more cherished by its leaders than that of the vibrant fast-growing metropolis, the premiere world model of a harmonious and economically vigorous multi-cultural mix, a place built by optimists who came from other places to make a new life.
Last week that image turned into a different one, the kind offered up in the most terrifying of movies produced by the Los Angeles studios, a deadly mixture of "Blade Runner," "Die Hard" and "Grand Canyon." National Guard troops in full battle dress with loaded M-16 rifles stood sentinel in Pershing Square in front of a boarded-up Biltmore Hotel, Korean merchants with Uzi semi-automatic machine guns paced watchfully on the roofs of their stores, mobs of all races looted and burned not only in the heart of mostly black South-Central Los Angeles but also as far away as Koreatown, Hollywood and Beverly Hills. 
 White residents who had long thought they were remote and safe from the gang-ridden neighborhoods they knew only from television and movies cowered in their homes obeying a dusk-to-dawn curfew, bringing out hunting rifles and baseball bats for protection under a menacing pall of smoke that drifted out to the Pacific Ocean. President Bush sent in Federal police and troops. Foreign consulates issued travel warnings to their citizens. By yesterday afternoon, there were 44 dead, more than 1,765 injured -- 198 critically, some 3,767 fires in Los Angeles alone, more than 6,345 arrests and property damage in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
It was the worst possible outcome of the series of painful events that began on the night of March 3, 1991, when Los Angeles police officers were videotaped inflicting a prolonged beating on a prone black motorist, and that culminated Wednesday afternoon when an all- white jury in the conservative suburb of Simi Valley stunned the city and nation by acquitting all four officers charged.
The rage, pillaging and terror that followed the verdict brought home to Angelenos a realization that their city, with its superficial sheen of citrus trees, movie-star glitter and with-it restaurants and shops, had become a dangerous urban village where two decades of boom and growth appear to have widened the gap between rich and poor. Those looting last week were the children of blacks who rioted in Watts in 1965 or recent immigrants from Latin America for whom the Southern California dream has meant something other than pale blue swimming pools and big-fin convertibles. "We are experiencing the ugly reality of what Los Angeles has become," said John A. Arguellas, a former justice of the California Supreme Court who was vice chairman of the independent commission that investigated the police beating. "Everybody saw the videotape of the beating, but now everybody has been watching the reality of Los Angeles. It is a very, very ugly picture."
 
More Bad News for the Economy
 The events added to feelings of pessimism over the economically stricken Southern California region, already reeling from the combined effects of recession and massive cutbacks in defense spending. Tourism alone, which accounts for 360,000 jobs and generates $7 billion in economic activity annually, was devastated as hotels found themselves awash in cancellations from Japan and elsewhere. The ripples are expected to widen over the entire state, which has suffered a net loss of 690,000 jobs since the recession began in 1990 and whose government is struggling to overcome a budget shortfall that could reach $11 billion this year.
To fully comprehend the week's events was to feel a terrifying distance from those whose live out their lives on the economic and social margins of Southern California.
But the reality of the riots was much more complex than rich versus poor. South-Central Los Angeles and other minority communities from which the disorders sprang were badly divided. "There are those who feel a sense of attachment, living next door to people for whom the social contract does not exist, who are aware of how the privileged live," said Richard S. Weinstein, dean of the school of architecture and urban planning at the University of California at Los Angeles. "There is a point at which the coherence of the community is broken and anything is possible, at which those who have been marginalized act that way."
It was not the first time that the Los Angeles black community had rebelled against the police. In August 1965, years of frustration and resentment erupted into five days of rioting when a white policeman arrested a black man for drunk driving. Those disorders left 34 dead, more than 1,000 injured and a legacy of ill will so potent that the word Watts remains synonymous with black anger.
Eight years later, in 1973, voters in this predominantly white city elected their first black mayor, a former policeman named Tom Bradley. He was backed by a coalition that included the downtown white business establishment, affluent West Side Jewish voters and the black political leadership -- a diverse group united in the conviction that the city's future depended on putting aside its racist past. Mr. Bradley won wide admiration as a healer and conciliator, and under him the city truly came of age, its ports surpassing New York in volume, its downtown office space doubling over the last decade. Its proudest moment came when it flawlessly hosted the 1984 Olympic games.
The peace and harmony were only apparent. Over the last decade, powerful demographic forces began to change the urban complexion. Enormous waves of foreign immigrants arrived and began to push blacks out of Watts. Between the 1980 and 1990 censuses, the black population of Los Angeles County dropped from 13 percent to 11 percent of the population, while both the Hispanic population and the Asian population swelled. One of the most disturbing aspects of the disorders last week was the raw hostility between blacks and Koreans.
Meanwhile, older "Anglo" residents were moving farther out, to places like Simi Valley, just over the county line in Ventura County, where Los Angeles seems like a foreign country. Even the remaining Anglos mostly live in the San Fernando Valley, separated from central Los Angeles by a mountain range.
"We've got to come to grips with the fact that L.A. is segregated," said Dan Garcia, former president of the Police Commission who is now a vice president at Warner Brothers. "The distribution of power is uneven. We've got to figure out a new mechanism to talk to one another. In the San Fernando Valley the notion of the job of the police department is to protect the property and wealth of white people."
"This is a city with neighborhoods that are very distant," said Michael Woo, the city councilman who represents Hollywood, which was heavily burned and looted. "Below the cosmopolitan sheen on the surface, there is a lot of racial tension. It does not take much to lift the lid on the rules the city depends on. This is a city built by the dreams of optimists who left other places to make a better life. This is still a dream. My worst fear is that the middle class leaves and ethnic groups are pitted against each other."
 
Thoughts Turn to Rebuilding
 Yesterday, Craig Sasser, second vice president of the Los Angeles National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said profound change is possible only if black people look primarily to themselves. "We can't depend on white people to rebuild the community or wait for some handout from the government or the Los Angeles business association to make things right," he said in a telephone interview from his office in the South-Central section of the city. Mr. Sasser said he and a growing number of blacks are advocating that working blacks begin to pool their money to set up a fund to spur the return of businesses to the hardest hit areas of the city. Long before the unrest, he said, white-controlled banks demonstrated that they will not support blacks.
The question now is how Los Angeles responds to rebuilding. Many say the city needs more vigorous leadership than can be provided by the 74-year-old Mayor, whose office is so weak that he has not been able to remove Police Chief Daryl F. Gates, or by the rudderless, parochial 15-member City Council. "This is the alarm bell that if we did not respond in 1965, we certainly would be blind if we do not respond now," said Warren Christopher, the lawyer who headed the independent inquiry into the police beating. "With all our wealth and success we'd better take this second chance."
And as the events and their implications deepened, and disorder spread to San Francisco, Atlanta, New York and other cities, it was sobering to know that all this was not something confined to Los Angeles, or something that could easily be solved by local leadership. "We are the future," said Dean Weinstein. "What is happening to us here is already happening to other major cities. It is hard to imagine how these kinds of questions can be addressed without Federal attention. It means a whole reordering of domestic priorities."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Cars and VCR's Aren't Necessarily the First Domino

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Must commerce among nations always be a dog eat dog fight for absolute advantage? Economic Darwinians fear that America's loss of leadership in a few key industries is the beginning of an irreversible decline in competitiveness. A more sanguine school, which holds that industrialized economies will ultimately converge, maintains that Japan and Germany will catch up with the United States, but not surpass it.
As it turns out, reality isn't unfolding quite according to either script, some economists say. While the level of output per employee in Japan and Germany and the United States has converged since the 1950's, productivity in individual industries has begun to diverge. 
 Instead of catching up across the board, countries seem to be specializing in the things they do best. While Japan and Germany have surged ahead in some industries, the United States has widened its lead in others and stayed ahead, if by a narrower margin, in still others.
"If you lose one industry, there's no sign you'll lose them all," said Edward N. Wolff, an economist at New York University. "Just because Japan has taken over consumer electronics does not mean that Japan will triumph in mainframe computers or medical instruments."
A book by Professor Wolff and David Dollar, a colleague at the World Bank, called "Competitiveness, Convergence and International Specialization" will be published by M.I.T. Press this fall.
That pattern of specialization, which started to emerge after the early 1970's, said Dale W. Jorgenson, an economist at Harvard University, suggests that the United States still stands to gain from expanded world trade, but that it continues to face the possibility that trade conflicts will develop too.
"We can take some of their markets and they can take ours," said Professor Jorgenson. "So we will have to stamp out little moves toward protectionism and make sure our trading partners do too."
Productivity is a handy measure of an industry's competitive muscle. Industries with high levels of labor productivity tend to export a lot. "If you're the most efficient country in the world in making planes, you tend to dominate world aircraft trade," Professor Wolff said. "High productivity reflects how much investment you've poured into an industry as well as how sophisticated the technology you have."
 
'First Among Equals'

 For 25 years after World War II, the overall level of productivity among industrialized countries did converge. Productivity grew faster in Germany and Japan than in the United States during the 1950's, 1960's and early 1970's. "The U.S. was once the dominant economy," said Professor Wolff. "Now it's the first among equals."
Using output per worker as a yardstick for productivity, the United States is about 45 percent more efficient than either Germany or Japan, which are roughly equal.
Of course, using that measure instead of output per hour understates Germany's efficiency and overstates Japan's because German workers put in fewer hours on the job than Americans while their Japanese counterparts put in more.
"Many parts of Japanese businesses operate below United States standards," said Mr. Jorgenson. "Japan has world class factories in many industries, but getting things to and out of the factory is incredibly inefficient." Wholesaling, retailing and company departments like transportation and billing use methods that in the United States are considered archaic, he said. "The best example is Narita Airport -- logistically speaking, it's Idlewild 30 years ago."
But ever since the early 1970's, the gap in overall productivity has narrowed far more slowly. Why? After the first oil shock in 1973, Japan's overall productivity growth rate fell from 10 to 3 percent a year. United States productivity growth fell also, but only by 1 percentage point.
The fact that Japan was no longer catching up in overall productivity was masked, said Professor Jorgenson, by the vast appreciation of the dollar in the early 1980's. Even as Japan's domestic economy slowed, its exports exploded and the United States lost overseas markets and saw a flood of imports.
In any case, the United States and its main rivals have specialized in different industries. German bankers, it seems, are the world's most efficient. Small wonder. The United States has more than 12,000 banks, the Germans a dozen or two. Meanwhile, America's high-tech farms boast productivity 4 times as high as Japan's and 2.5 times as high as Germany's. Japan's electronics industry is twice as productive as Germany's and slightly ahead of United States electronics companies.
America's lead is actually growing in perhaps one-third of its industries including agriculture, wood products and food processing, which is really a clutch of industries that churn out everything from cigarettes to cereal to Coca-Cola.
Japan surged ahead in cars and trucks and, despite resurgent American competitiveness in steel and semiconductors, in metals and consumer electronics.
And in lots of industries, the United States is hanging on to its lead. That includes building materials, heavy machinery, computers.
Germany Slowing Down Suprisingly, the United States widened its lead over Germany during the 1980's, not only in overall productivity but in most manufacturing industries. Mr. Wolff attributes that reversal from earlier decades to the fact that German industry didn't face the same cold blast of world competition spurred by a too-strong dollar that woke American manufacturers to the need to boost efficiency.
A second reason, perhaps more unexpected, is that the United States invested more in manufacturing than Germany did in the 1980's.
Mr. Wolff is convinced that countries specialize and achieve leadership in those industries where they invest heavily in new plant and equipment. Investment not only gives each worker more equipment to work with but it also puts the latest technology in his or her hands.
And research and development is just as important.
"The U.S. is still the leader in aircraft because of heavy R. & D. spending, some of which came via the Pentagon," said Professor Wolff. "Likewise, medical equipment research is heavily subsidized by the National Institutes of Health."
In the 1950's and 1960's Japan and Germany mainly caught up by imitating United States technology. But Americans should take note that, since the 1970's, new investment has played the primary role.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Nostalgia and Need Conjure Up Thoughts of the W. P. A.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
Works Progress Administration: Its bland, ungainly name was strictly Government-issue, but perhaps no other social program has left Americans so misty-eyed with nostalgic recollection. Speak the initials W. P. A., and the mind's eye turns to the bold posters of brawny workers and the grainy photographs of the things they built -- the bridges, schools, airports, culverts and courthouses that still line the American landscape.
But this is also the program that catapulted the word boondoggle into common political usage. It inspired two Congressional investigations, set off riots in New York City and brought accusations of Communist infiltration. 
 Now, 50 years after its demise, the W. P. A. is back in the news. Last month a handful of Congressional Democrats led by Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma introduced legislation to create a new W. P. A. for people on welfare. Critics again cry boondoggle, but supporters say the poor would get the dignity of real work and the public, the tangible products of their labor.
The Boren plan would retain the current welfare system for mothers with young children and those enrolled in training programs. Others would have to take public works jobs for up to 32 hours a week.
The legislators acknowledged that with today's budgets, a pilot program might be all they can expect. But with welfare rolls setting new records every month -- more than 4.6 million families now rely on the system -- politicians from President Bush on down are seeking election-year advantage by calling, without specifics, for fundamental change. That, says Mr. Boren, is what his plan offers.
The trade-offs today are, in some respects, similar to the ones that Franklin D. Roosevelt faced: creating jobs has civic virtues, but mailing checks is cheaper.
Roosevelt tried it both ways. He mailed relief checks in 1933, then started and canceled a jobs program after recoiling from its costs. In 1935, concerned about the dole's demoralizing effects, Roosevelt gave jobs a second try, issuing his famous admonition that welfare not become "a narcotic." The phrase has been quoted often since -- most recently by President Bush -- but rarely in its original context of expanding government aid.
Harry Hopkins, the program's administrator, turned the W. P. A. into an undertaking of unparalleled proportions. It came to employ 3.3 million people nationwide. There were 200,000 in New York City alone, a work force larger than the national payroll of any private corporation.
Takeoff, not surprisingly, was bumpy. Work crews were said to spend the days moving leaf piles from one side of a street to the other. Unions struck over the program's refusal to pay wages equal to those of the private sector.
 
'Boondoggling'

 Exasperated after just four months, New York City's first program director sent Mr. Hopkins a confidential memo, calling the jobs strategy a "boondoggling" approach.
But in the view of Barbara Blumberg, a historian at Pace University and the author of "The New Deal and the Unemployed: The View from New York City," (Bucknell University Press, 1979), the surprising thing about the W. P. A. wasn't its initial difficulties, but the breadth of projects it bestowed. Nationwide about three quarters of its money was spent on construction, as workers built or improved 651,000 miles of roads, 39,000 schools and 464 new airfields, including New York's La Guardia. The program sent housekeepers to the sick, teachers to prisons. Ms. Blumberg calculates that by 1940 its dentists filled 1,000,000 New York City cavities.
The W. P. A.'s arts programs consumed only about 5 percent of its budget. But the guidebooks, poster art and theater productions contribute disproportionately to its elan. Here is a welfare program that claims among its alumni Saul Bellow, Richard Wright, Jackson Pollock, Orson Welles, John Cheever and Ralph Ellison.
Was it efficient? Ms. Blumberg said construction projects could run three to four times the cost of private work, in part by design, since they avoided cost-saving machinery in order to hire more workers. But, she noted, no number of welfare checks ever patched roads or fixed teeth.
Among the program's problems was its start-and-stop funding, with Roosevelt repeatedly having to seek appropriations supplements. It created jobs for only about a third of those who wanted them, and pay scales, which varied by skill level, were often meager. When 1936 cuts laid off 20 percent of the work force, New York City workers rioted.
 
Best and Worst
 In 1938, the House Un-American Activities Committee began looking for Communists, and indeed it found some. When the Gallup group asked Americans in 1939 what they liked best and least about the New Deal, the answer in both cases was the W. P. A. Congress then placed strict new limits on the scope of its work, and the program shrank for several years more. It died in 1943, rendered inessential by the war that had roused the American economy.
At its peak the W. P. A. spent $2.2 billion in a year. Ballpark estimates of what a similar program would cost today top $30 billion.
Could it work today?
The W. P. A. had at least one great advantage: a labor force vastly more skilled than most people now on welfare. A more relevant comparison might be the public employment effort undertaken by the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act of the 1970's. Public employee unions, wary of low-paid competition, sharply limited the projects C. E. T. A. could undertake, and it foundered on familiar charges of make-work. Defenders say it raised skills, but it has left no romantic aura.
Not so the W. P. A., which brought rhapsodic tones, though no subsequent action, from none other a Big Government critic than Ronald Reagan in a radio interview a month before his election as President. "W. P. A. -- some people have called it boondoggle and everything else. But having lived through that era and seen it, no, it was probably one of the social programs that was most practical in those New Deal days."
And if someone were to propose a set of similar projects today? "I think it could be most helpful," Mr. Reagan told his radio audience.

HEADLINE: RIOT IN LOS ANGLES: Pocket of Tension;
A Target of Rioters, Koreatown Is Bitter, Armed and Determined

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2

 BODY:
The nation's largest Korean-American community is grim, armed and determined to repel racial violence in its riot-scarred corner of the city.
A vigilante Korean security force, wearing white scarves, is patrolling the burned and looted shops of Koreatown, the economically vibrant enclave just north of the sad streets of South-Central Los Angeles, where black and Hispanic residents struggle with poverty and crime. 
 Today, with an uneasy peace settling over the city after hundreds of their businesses were destroyed, the Koreans stood armed inside their shattered store windows.
The shopkeepers voiced outrage at the slow response of the police when their community came under attack Wednesday night and Thursday. And they expressed despair over the sudden destruction of American success stories that had taken lifetimes to build.
"Why did it happen?" said Carl Rhyu, a member of the community's security force. "That's a good question."
He was among a group of armed Koreans on the rooftop of Lucky Electronics who, in a sign of the general tension and confusion in the area, held a brief standoff Friday night with crouching National Guardsmen that ended when the two sides figured out who the other was.
 
Lightning Rod for Anger
 "I think the black people are jealous of the Koreans," he said, voicing a gut feeling that many Korean residents express privately but are too careful to state in public. "They're lazy; we are working hard. They're not making money; we are making money."
In the South-Central area, where Korean shops have become the object of resentment even as they provide what is often the only retail service to residents, some shopkeepers climbed ladders to remove the Korean lettering from their signboards. At the Korean consulate, where National Guardsmen stood watch, an identifying plaque had been covered up by tape.
Yumi Park, the former director of the Korean American Grocers Association, said about 600 Korean-owned retail outlets had been damaged in the South-Central area and about 200 in Koreatown.
Lawrence Aubry, a member of the Los Angeles County Human Relations Commission, said Korean merchants had become a lightning rod for the discontent of some black residents. Many blacks in Los Angeles have remained poor as, one after another, immigrant groups have arrived and climbed past them to prosperity.
"It's illogical, but it's convenient to target the Koreans," he said. "Why were they burning the businesses that serve them? Why has that anger not been vented at the educational system that has failed them? Why weren't the employment offices burned to the ground?"
In place of the scenes of rioting and burning today, more than 5,000 people, most of them Koreans, gathered in Koreatown for a demonstration and march protesting the violence.
 
On the Defensive
 Defending the armed response of the Koreans, Mr. Rhyu said, "If it was your own business and your own property, would you be willing to trust it to someone else? We are glad the National Guard is here. They're good backup. But when our shops were burning we called the police every five minutes; no response."
One of the most gripping and, increasingly, controversial television images of the violence was a scene of two Korean merchants firing pistols repeatedly from a military stance. The image seemed to speak of race war, and of vigilantes taking the law into their own hands.
But this morning, amid the empty shelves of the Western Gun Shop, the two men spoke in anger and despair of the failure of the police to protect them, of the collapse of their American dream, and of a sister and sister-in-law who are now hospitalized with gunshot wounds fired from a crowd of looters.
"I want to make it clear that we didn't open fire first," said David Joo, manager of the gun shop. "At that time, four police cars were there. Somebody started to shoot at us. The L.A.P.D. ran away in half a second. I never saw such a fast escape. I was pretty disappointed."
 
'Please Call Ambulance'
 The incident occurred outside Park's Wilshire Jewelry, which is owned by Richard Park, who also owns the gunshop.
More than 200 people had converged on the mall where the jewelry shop is situated, Mr. Park said, and the shots came just as his sister and sister-in-law were trying to flee. His sister was wounded in the leg and his sister-in-law in the kidney and stomach, he said.
"I scream: 'Please call ambulance. Please, somebody hurt. Somebody crying. Please call ambulance. Ambulance,' " Mr. Park recalled. "But when a lot of shots were fired, everybody left.
"I don't know if I am wrong or not. People say I am wrong. What am I going to do? Just sit down and die? I am going to protect my store and my family and myself."
Mrs. Park, the former director of the Korean American Grocers Association, estimated that there were about 6,000 Korean retail outlets in Los Angeles County, a main source of livelihood for the 300,000 to 400,000 Korean-Americans who live here. There are more than a million Korean-Americans in the nation.
When Jewish shop owners left the South-Central area after the Watts riots of 1965, Asian businesses began to move in, and over the last decade the Koreans have become overwhelmingly dominant there, while also developing the Koreatown enclave.
Across much of the poorest area of the city, the only shops to buy groceries or liquor or gasoline, or to have clothes cleaned or a car repaired, are owned by Korean immigrants.
The Koreans have become the focus of black resentment since the videotaped fatal shooting by a Korean grocer of a 15-year-old black girl, Latasha Harlins, last year. The resentment boiled over last November when a judge declined to send the grocer, Soon Ja Du, to prison after she was convicted of manslaughter.
 
Few Choices for Koreans
 Since then, some black groups have led boycotts of Korean shops. The owner of one of those shops, John's Liquor Store, closed the business and sought a black buyer as part of an agreement with the boycotters. The business remains unsold six months later, Mrs. Park said, leaving local residents with one less place to shop.
Bong Hwan Kim, co-chairman of the Korean American Alliance, which was formed to ease tensions in the community, said most Korean shop owners will have little choice but to try to reopen their businesses.
Without the English language or the resources to compete for business in more affluent areas, and with too much pride to return in failure to Korea, he said, they will go back to face the dangers of doing business in the South-Central neighborhood.
Cosmos Appliance was one of the first Korean stores to be smashed and looted on Wednesday night when angry demonstrators burst northward from the South-Central area after the acquittal of four white police officers who had been shown on videotape clubbing and kicking a black motorist, Rodney G. King.
The owner and a group of friends and relatives took up arms and barricaded themselves inside amid the shattered televisions and video machines. As the looters approached again in the morning, they followed their progress on a Korean language radio station, much as Los Angeles residents follow traffic reports on the crowded freeways.
 
'Nobody Showed Up'
 "We called the police and nobody showed up," Michael Kim, one of the armed defenders, said this morning. "There was a fire burning across the street for three hours and nobody came."
At mid-afternoon Thursday, with the store barricaded and guarded, several cars drove back and forth outside, firing at the windows, Mr. Kim said, "and we shot back at them."
Nobody was hurt, but Mr. Kim and his wife, J. Kim, remained angry this morning at the failure of their new country to protect them. "We took 15 years to build this up, and in two days it is gone," Mrs. Kim said.
At Western Gun Shop, Mr. Park said 20 years of struggle in America had crumbled around him.
"Why did they do it? Everything in my store is gone, even the ball pens. They've broken the empty showcases. Why? They burned all my papers. Why? Even the empty checkbooks, they threw into the street. Why?"
Mr. Park said he had come to America as a student and had since brought seven brothers and sisters to join him. "I love this country," he said. "America is a dream."
For 20 years, he said, "I am working, working, working. I work 10, 12, 15 hours a day, hard, hard working. My whole family is working," he said. "But that day that happened, nobody helped me. Everybody ran away. Now everything is gone."

HEADLINE: Sarajevo's Center Erupts in War, Weakening Yugoslav Truce Effort

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 2

 BODY:
A fierce battle involving tanks, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades erupted today in the center of Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, raising fears that efforts at achieving peace there may be swept away by Serbs fighting to consolidate gains made in a monthlong offensive for Bosnian territory.
For weeks, the center of Sarajevo, a city where Muslim Slavs outnumber Serbs, has been the scene of sporadic sniper exchanges and mortar and artillery attacks from the surrounding hills. But at lunchtime today, the cobbled streets and alleys erupted into what a Yugoslav Army spokesman in the city described as "all-out war." 
 The fighting pitted army tanks and armored personnel carriers backing the Serbs against heavily armed militiamen fighting for the Muslim Slav and Croat populations.
 
Vista of Destruction
 At dusk, with the fighting continuing, reporters on the scene described a vista of blazing government buildings, bodies of fighters and civilians lying in the street for hours after the fighting began, artillery and mortar shells pouring down from the hills used for the 1984 Olympic winter games, and of close-range fighting in the narrow alleys of the Bascarsija district, heart of the old Muslim city.
The European Community's 12 nations and the United States granted Bosnia and Herzegovina recognition as a state independent from Yugoslavia early last month, continuing the dismemberment of the nation.
Bosnia, home to an ethnic mix in which Serbs are heavily outnumbered, thus followed Croatia and Slovenia, two other former Yugoslav republics, out of the union despite efforts by Serbia and the remnants of the Yugoslav power structure in Belgrade to fight in Croatia and elsewhere to keep as much territory as possible.
Tonight, the Yugoslav press agency Tanyug reported that Alija Izetbegovic, the Bosnian President, who is a Muslim Slav, had been arrested by the Yugoslav Army at the Sarajevo airport when he returned from the Lisbon talks aboard a European Community jet. The report said Mr. Izetbegovic had been taken to the Lukavica army barracks outside the city, and it quoted him as having told a Yugoslav radio reporter: "I was brought to Lukavica by force. The army waited for me at the airport. I am virtually a prisoner."
Army commanders gave conflicting accounts of the incident, some saying that Mr. Izetbegovic was offered protection when it became clear that there was no safe way for him to enter the city, and others saying that he would be released when a cease-fire made it possible for the army to collect its dead and wounded.
In the confusion today in Sarajevo, there were conflicting accounts of which side started the battle, and each side blamed the other. There was also confusion late in the day, when a cease-fire was reported and the fighting abated somewhat. But shellfire and machine-gun fire continued into the night.
The political trigger for the battles came 12 hours earlier, with the collapse of peace negotiations in Portugal under European Community sponsorship.
The chief negotiator, Jose Cutileiro of Portugal, blamed the collapse on Serbian leaders' failure to honor important commitments that they gave under a cease-fire agreement reached in Sarajevo on April 23, including pledges to dismantle barricades around Sarajevo and to withdraw artillery trained on the city.
 
Sarajevo's Worst Nightmare
 European Community attempts to still the fighting received a further blow today, when a Belgian officer posted in Bosnia as an observer died from stomach wounds inflicted by an exploding shell near the town of Mostar, 50 miles southwest of Sarajevo. The officer, who was not named in the European Community announcement of his death, was the sixth community observer to be killed here this year. Five Italians died in January when their helicopter was shot down by the Yugoslav Air Force.
The battle in Sarajevo fulfilled many of the worst nightmares of those who have sought a peaceful settlement in Bosnia. The fighting from street to street, with few parallels in any European city since the 1956 uprising in Budapest against Hungary's Communist rulers, sent thousands of people who had been out shopping and relaxing in the spring sunshine scurrying for cover in doorways, hotels and basements. One major downtown hotel was hit by at least four artillery shells.
A BBC reporter said in a broadcast received in Belgrade that the fighting was the worst he had seen in nearly a year of civil war in Bosnia and Croatia, which broke away from Yugoslavia last year.
No reliable estimate of the number killed and wounded was available, but a spokesman for the Yugoslav Army said its units had suffered "terrible casualties" in fighting around an officers' club and the army headquarters, both in the center city district that lies a few blocks back from the Miljacka River.
The area is only a short walk from the site of the most renowned incident in Sarajevo's 500-year history, the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria along the river embankment in 1914. The assassination led directly to the outbreak of World War I.
The fighting involving forces of the Serb-led Yugoslav Army and Serbian irregulars has scarred Croatia as well as Bosnia and Herzegovina. A fourth republic, Macedonia, has declared its sovereignty but has not won international recognition because of a dispute with Greece over its name, and the two remaining republics, Serbia and Montenegro, joined in establishing a new, truncated Yugoslav federation earlier this week.
 
Seizing Bosnian Land
 In Bosnia, Western diplomatic efforts have sought to persuade the three principal groups in the population of 4.3 million, Muslims Slavs, Serbs and Croats, to accept a Swiss-style constitution giving each group extensive autonomy within ethnic cantons.
Serbian leaders, backed by Serbian-based paramilitary groups and by the Serb-led Yugoslav Army, say that they will accept that, but their military offensive of the last month appears to have been aimed at seizing as much as 70 percent of the republic for the 31 percent of the population who are Serb.
The offensives, which have been accompanied by counteroffensives by Muslim Slav and Croatian fighters, have killed at least 300 people and created a tide of refugees not seen in Europe since World War II. According to United Nations figures, nearly 450,000 Bosnians, a 10th of the population, are already homeless.
Among Muslim Slav and Croatian leaders, the Serbian offensives have been seen as an attempt to consolidate Serb territories in the republic for later annexation to Serbia. After today's fighting broke out, those leaders asserted that the Serbs, emboldened by the failure of the United States and the European Community to follow through on threats of diplomatic and economic sanctions against Serbia if it did not halt the Bosnian fighting, have decided to make a final push for control of the Bosnian capital.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Europe Backs Greece on Name
 GUIMARAES, Portugal, May 2 (Reuters) -- The European Community yielded to pressure from Greece today and agreed to recognize the breakaway Yugoslav republic of Macedonia only if it changed its name.
 The community is "willing to recognize that state as a sovereign and independent state, within its existing borders, and under a name that can be accepted by all parties concerned," community foreign ministers said in a statement.
Greece, a member of the European Community, has strenuously opposed recognition of an independent state called Macedonia, saying that only the Macedonia region of northern Greece is entitled to the name.

HEADLINE: RIOT IN LOS ANGLES: At the Epicenter;
Decades of Rage Created Crucible of Violence

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2

 BODY:
Large flakes of ash drifted to the ground as the basement of a church in the city's South-Central section began filling up Thursday evening with refugees from the fear and the fire sweeping through the streets.
Michael Ming, a 23-year-old college student, stood outside in the falling dusk and watched a building burn to the ground a block and a half away. It had been burning for 12 hours. Gunshots echoed through the dimness, and a little girl asked her mother if they could go home. Their home, her mother said, was in flames. 
 Mr. Ming had gone to the church that desperate and dangerous night to answer its call for aid, a call written on a banner draped across the face of its modern building: "Brothers, come help us stop the madness."
 
Ambivalence About Rioters
 "Yeah, it's madness," Mr. Ming said of the riots, touched off by the acquittal of four white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of a black motorist. "But it's also understandable. And if the social conditions don't change, it will happen again and again and not just in L.A."
Like most people here, Mr. Ming condemned the violence and mourned the dead and the newly homeless. But he and a broad range of others, from solidly middle-class blacks like Al Myles to young Hispanic residents like James Garcia, also expressed ambivalence and guarded admiration for the rioters' rage at "the system."
The explosive violence here had been smoldering for 27 years, said scholars, ministers, advocates and residents of the city's arson-scarred and riot-torn neighborhoods in more than two dozen interviews.
Many said the acquittal of the four police officers charged with using excessive force in the beating of the black motorist, Rodney G. King, was only a spark put to a tinderbox of anger constructed from years of deep poverty, governmental neglect, racism, charges of police abuse and high unemployment.
Warren M. Christopher, a Deputy Attorney General under President Lyndon B. Johnson who headed a commission that investigated the beating, said the acquittal "uncorked" the same resentment and frustration that burned through Watts in 1965 and this time spread its flames and death across a much larger swath of the city.
In an interview Friday, he said the city had made a crucial mistake after Watts, a mistake that has returned to haunt Los Angeles and other cities: when the fires were put out and the troops were gone, the problems and people of Watts received only half-hearted assistance in rebuilding their neighborhood and lives.
"This is a second opportunity to get at some of the underlying causes," Mr. Christopher said. "You don't get very many second chances."
 
Rainbow of Rage
 But unlike the Watts riot, which was largely within the predominantly black neighborhood, this week's violence and arsons were spread out, and the rioters included black, Hispanic and white residents, displaying a growing sense of despair.
The riot was a rainbow of anger.
"The police treat us very bad, too," said Mr. Garcia, a 17-year-old Hispanic high school student. "People want justice. They hit Rodney King; we hit them. It cost them money to do us wrong this time."
Although residents were quick to assail Chief Daryl F. Gates as part of the problem, they did not volunteer criticism or praise for the longtime black Mayor of this city, Tom Bradley, a former police officer.
On the surface, the history of tension and trouble between the police and black and Hispanic residents was at the heart of what happened here. For many, the riot was a simple message to the authorities and the larger society: Treat us right. We've been pushed too close to the edge.
"Almost everybody I know has been harassed and much worse by the police," said Ervin Mitchell Jr., 31, a design engineer from South-Central who was standing with Mr. Ming. "Young blacks and Hispanics have been persecuted, beaten and pulled out of our cars because of stereotypes. We're tired of being treated like garbage. We're tired of living in a society that denies us the right to be considered as a human being."
 
Disgust All Round
 Mr. Ming added: "But it goes way beyond that. The way the whole entire system is structured, the rich get richer, the poor get poorer. It provides almost no hope for most folks, especially black folks."
Not far away, and several hours later, Walter Thompson, 19, stood on a sun-soaked street corner with his friend Cindy Edwards, 16. Ms. Edwards said she was disgusted with the verdict, and with the looting. Which was worse was a tossup, she said.
"Now I don't have a store to go to," she said. "We had two. They burned one down. The other, they looted."
Mr. Thompson cut in and said the looting should have occurred in Simi Valley, the predominantly white suburb where the trial of the four officers was moved.
"That's where the enemy is," he said.
Then, like many others, he bitterly cited the slaying last year of a 15-year-old black girl, Latasha Harlins, as evidence that blacks are treated unfairly by what he called "the prejudiced criminal justice system."
 
Bullet in the Rubbish
 Miss Harlins was shot in the back of the head by a Korean merchant after a dispute in a grocery store. That shooting, like the beating of Mr. King, was captured by a video camera. The merchant was convicted of manslaughter and given five years probation.
"We're mad for a whole lot of reasons," Mr. Thompson said, raising his voice and stepping closer. "First that 15-year-old girl was killed and they got away with it. Then they beat Rodney King like a dog and the jury sets them free. The black people don't get no justice, nowhere, no time."
Telling him to be calm, Ms. Edwards gently pulled Mr. Thompson away. "This has really hurt us," she explained.
Across the street, a growing band of young people was led by the actor Edward James Olmos in cleaning up the riot-ravaged street. They swept up large piles of broken class, charred beer cans, green olives and even a bullet or two.
 
Joblessness and Anger
 The lack of decent jobs in the inner city, especially for teen-agers, was another reason given for the days of rage.
"I don't think it's very difficult to figure out" why the riots happened so intensely, said Ramona Ripston, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. "As far as I can see," she said, "we have a lot of young people, 15, 16 years old, no programs to keep them in school, no jobs, no health care, no stake in society. It's a form of civil war. America had better wake up."
South-Central residents said that while outrage about the verdict and lack of meaningful opportunity motivated many rioters, plain lawlessness pushed many more into stores for looting.
"Some people say this is because of Rodney King," said Yolanda Gnat, 33, as she searched for an open store in the area to buy milk for her baby. "Others are doing it just to be doing it. A lot of people probably never even heard of Rodney King. They're doing it because it's like Christmas in the springtime."
 
Refuge in a Church
 Steve D. Valdivia and his staff at the Community Youth Gang Services have been on the violent streets since the rioting began.
"The first-night reports from my staff were scary," he said. "They said they had never seen such hatred and despair in people's faces. We've seen this coming. Everything was building up to this. There have been a number of shootings of minority kids. And now everybody is upset about the verdict. Young people always act out the frustrations of a community."
The Rev. Cecil Murray has turned his church, the First African Methodist Episcopal Church, which Mayor Bradley attends, into a shelter from the riots and the fires burning in almost every direction nearby.
Thursday night, 100 men, women and children, mostly black and Hispanic, crowded into the basement, sleeping and talking on a forest of green cots set up inches apart by the Red Cross.
"Earthquakes is what we're trained for," a Red Cross volunteer said.
Many people watched the riots on two television sets, one tuned to a Spanish-language station.
"That's my house," a woman said, pointing to a building engulfed in flames on the television screen.
One television stayed on throughout the night. So did several babies.
Mr. Murray swept through the room, talking with the children and praying with an 80-year-old woman who had to be carried from her apartment building in a blanket.
 
Gang Cooperation
 That night, David Madise, 30, stood on a dark sidewalk, watching over First A.M.E. and its basement of scared strangers.
"I came out to help," he said. "I'm just making sure everything is cool."
He spent the worst nights of the riot in front of the church and saw two men struggling up the hilly street, pushing a big screen television set in the middle of the night.
They asked him to help but he refused.
"Since this started, I've seen Bloods and Crips working together like crazy, looting and carrying away everything they could get their hands on" he said, referring to the city's infamous and usually rival street gangs. "They didn't care about colors. That was a big change."
 
'Land of Crazy Folks'
 The next day, Mr. Murray said sending in the National Guard was "only a Band-Aid" approach to deep-seated problems.
"The War on Poverty became the war on the poor because it was poorly managed," he said. "America is creating a land of crazy folks. Crazy situations create crazy people."
The situation has been extremely crazy for Eddy Zapata and his family. They were burned out of their home on Wednesday and spent two days living with his sister-in-law in a small and overcrowded apartment.
On Friday, the 39-year-old freelance auto mechanic took his wife and two children, 6 years and 1 month old, to Mr. Murray's church. The riot took everything from the struggling family -- their house, clothes, tools and maybe their hope.
Holding his baby daughter in his lap, Mr. Zapata said he had no idea what the family would do now.
 
Everyone Lost Something
 "We lost everything," he said. "For the last three years I have been trying to make it on my own with my shop. Now it is gone."
The entire city has lost something during these days of violence: businesses, homes, sons and daughters and trust.
Al Myles, a 38-year-old businessman, lost another fragile piece of his faith in "people of color ever really winning our equal rights."
"To me, this feels like a complete duplication of the Watts riot," Mr. Myles said. "The verdict sent a clear message: that there's only one kind of justice and it doesn't apply to people of color in any way.
"I don't condone what's happening, but how else are you going to get the idea across that we're tired of this abuse?" he said. "They haven't listened to us in courts or the ballot. But this time it's not just blacks who are upset. I think everybody is upset with injustice, with the lawlessness of the law."
With that, he took a deep breath and looked sad.

HEADLINE: Medicad Plan Promotes Nursing-Home Insurance

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
In an innovative move affecting long-term care for the elderly, New York State plans to encourage middle-income residents to buy nursing-home insurance in a program that would exempt them from onerous Medicaid limits on personal wealth.
Those who buy the insurance, which would also cover care at home, would no longer be forced to impoverish themselves to qualify for state-financed care. State officials hope the program will help slow steep growth in New York's $6 billion-a-year Medicaid budget for long-term care. 
 Under the plan, people worried about Alzheimer's disease and other debilitating illnesses could buy insurance from private companies that would pay for up to three years of nursing-home care or six years of home care. If they required additional care, those who bought the policies would automatically be entitled to Medicaid without having to "spend down" their assets, said Mildred Shapiro, associate commissioner of the medical assistance division of the State Department of Social Services.
"Spending down" is the practice, common among older people, of transferring securities, real estate and other assets to trusts and relatives to qualify for Medicaid.
 
Dumping Assets
 Insurance companies have offered long-term care policies nationally for at least a decade, but only about two million have been sold, according to the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group. Most people resist buying them until they are in their late 60's, when only the most expensive policies guarantee lifetime coverage. Those who buy less-costly policies still risk having to spend down to go on Medicaid when coverage runs out.
Federal Medicaid officials approved New York's plan in February. The State Legislature authorized the program in 1989 and is expected to approve "technical changes" that have been made since then, Ms. Shapiro said. Insurance industry executives said they were confident that the State Insurance Department would allow them to sell the long-term care policies by fall.
 
Who Qualifies Now
 Connecticut and Indiana recently started similar state-approved insurance programs, and California is awaiting Federal approval. Participants in those three states could keep a dollar in assets for each dollar of long-term care insurance they bought. New York residents would be allowed to keep all their assets if they bought a state-approved three-year policy.
Insurance executives predicted that thousands of New Yorkers would buy the policies. But several consumer advocates criticized the plan, saying that few elderly people could afford the insurance and that the Federal Government should develop a national program for long-term care.
To qualify for Medicaid now, a single person in New York must have no more than $3,050 in assets. The spouse of a nursing home patient is allowed to keep $68,700 in assets and the family home, under a Federal law that was passed at the urging middle-income people to protect the spouse. The plan would continue limits on income: $6,100 a year for a single person getting home care and $8,900 a year for couples on Medicaid. A nursing home patient would be allowed only $50 a month in income, but the spouse could have $20,616 in income.
Nursing homes in New York State charge private patients, on average, $62,000 a year, and in the New York metropolitan region, $69,000. The average stay in a nursing home is 32 months, Ms. Shapiro said.
The policies would provide at least $100 a day for nursing home care and $50 for home care, she said.
Ms. Shapiro estimated that annual premiums would be from $1,500 to $2,000 for people who buy the insurance at age 65 and $400 to $600 for those who do so at age 40. Insurers would need state approval to raise premiums, but benefits would increase by 5 percent compounded annually to protect against inflation.
 
Plan Has Its Skeptics
 Robert Freedman, a Manhattan lawyer who is vice chairman of the elder law section of the New York State Bar Association, said the program would allow middle-income residents to purchase the kind of insurance that only the wealthy can now afford. "If you have $8 million, you get insurance," he said. "If you have $100,000, you can't afford it unless you have a high pension."
Ms. Shapiro said the new long-term care policies were expected to appeal most to people 65 and older. They would need at least $20,000 in annual income to afford them, she said, adding that there are about 700,000 such New Yorkers.
But Mae Hall, an 80-year-old widow who is president of Seniors Helping Seniors, a Manhattan advocacy group, was skeptical. "I can't afford that," Mrs. Hall said of the new insurance, although she said her income was around $20,000 a year.
And Rose Zirolnik, 74, a registered nurse in New Rochelle, said she would have to see the fine print. "I would have to do some homework to see if what the state is going to do makes sense and fits my pocket," she said.
 
Savings Seen for State
 The program could eventually generate substantial savings in New York's $6 billion annual Medicaid budget for long-term care -- nearly one-fourth the national total of $25 billion, proponents said. Without it, the $6 billion is expected to more than triple, to $23.5 billion, by 2010 because of inflation of medical costs and growth in the number of elderly people who require long-term care, they said.
Medicaid now covers 85,000 nursing home patients in New York and 150,000 receiving home care. Half of the state's nursing home patients use up their savings and qualify for Medicaid within nine months of admission, she said. Many others "spend down" assets more than 30 months before they enter nursing homes so they can qualify for Medicaid as soon as they arrive.
At least six insurance companies -- Metropolitan Life, Travelers, John Hancock, Amex Life Assurance, CNA and Finger Lakes -- have told state officials that they are interested in selling the new policies in New York.
A vice president of Metropolitan Life, James B. Weil, said several large employers and labor unions in New York State hoped to buy the policies once they were approved.
An executive of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, Linda Berg Maney, noted that New York State's "seal of approval will give a lot of people peace of mind."
But Gail Shearer, a policy analyst with the Consumers Union in Washington, maintained that the plan was not fair to poor people who could not afford the insurance and would still have to spend down their meager assets to qualify for Medicaid.
And Diane Archer, executive director of the Medicare Beneficiaries Defense Fund, a nonprofit advocacy group in New York, said, "What we need is a national health-care program available to all people."

HEADLINE: April 26-May 2: Red-Tape Agenda;
Ban on New Rules Renewed, Angering Conservationists

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

 BODY:
Sometimes those wounded in the Bush Administration's war on red tape wonder whether the red tape was ever the target. The Administration announced last week that it would extend a 90-day freeze on new Federal regulations for several months, saying it had done wonders for the economy. But conservation groups argue that most of the rules being held up are the ones that restrict strip miners, oil refiners, automobile makers, property developers and others that threaten the environment. Other rules get changed if the Administration feels like it, they say.
As an example, they cite an 85-year-old rule that lets anyone object to the sale of a stand of National Forest trees. The rule gives the public 45 days to object, and shuts off the chainsaws for another 115 days while the Forest Service responds. The Forest Service wants to make objectors go to court to stop any sales, but local conservation groups say that would break them financially. 
 The Forest Service and the timber industry say slowed-down sales are raising home lumber prices. Environmentalists reply that ancient trees on public lands are sold far too cheaply and that private tree farms can supply the lumber and preserve jobs.

HEADLINE: Planner Offers Russia as Open Market

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
In his five days of meetings here, Yegor T. Gaidar, Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister, sketched a sweeping yet detailed vision of Russia's economic future, including plans to make the ruble convertible by July 1 and to speed up privatization.
Mr. Gaidar, who is chief architect of Russia's economic reforms, said he would put an emphasis on increasing oil and agricultural production. 
 He said the transition to a market economy would last through most of the 1990's and would be "socially depressing," but he talked of Russia as a land of go-go capitalism, with huge opportunities for foreign investors.
"It is the country of the big possibilities," he said. "It is probably the most important market for risk and venture capital."
 
Polls Bring Confidence
 At news conferences and at meetings with American, European and International Monetary Fund officials, Mr. Gaidar vowed to speed reforms, although he said the Government would continue to face hostility from the Russian Parliament over its program.
The Cabinet sees a window of opportunity to press ahead, he said, because recent opinion polls have given higher ratings to the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin despite the pain brought about by removing price controls and adopting other reforms. Countering predictions, labor unions have for the most part backed the shift toward a market economy, he noted.
The 36-year-old economist made it clear that July 1 would be a pivotal date for Russia. He said he hoped that Russia would sign a reform agreement with the International Monetary Fund by then that would make billions of dollars in I.M.F. and World Bank loans available.
Echoing recent remarks by Mr. Yel tsin, Mr. Gaidar said Russia would not allow the I.M.F. to dictate its policy but that he hoped that his country's plans would easily gain the organization's approval. He and Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, agreed that there would be disputes over some issues, like how many new credits can be allocated to sinking enterprises.
 
A Single Ruble Rate
 In a speech to the United States Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Gaidar outlined plans to create a single exchange rate for the ruble by July 1 to replace the varying and confusing rates that exist now. Different rates are currently in place for tourist and for business transactions.
Mr. Gaidar said that creating a single rate would essentially make the ruble convertible and would be a crucial step toward setting up the $6 billion ruble stabilization fund promised by 11 industrialized nations.
He said he would like to peg the ruble to the dollar, but allow the Russian currency's value to fluctuate within a range of 7.5 percent. Economists say that stabilizing the ruble against foreign currencies will help create an anchor for Russia's often-arbitrary pricing structure, by linking its prices to those elsewhere in the world.
Georgi Matyukhin, president of Russia's central bank, said in Washington this week that he expected the stabilization fund to take effect in the last three months of 1992. American, European and I.M.F. officials say that not only Russia, but other republics that use the ruble as well, will have to do more to reduce their budget deficits and money supply growth before the fund can be set up.
Mr. Gaidar said Russia was working closely with the former Soviet republics of Belarus and Kazakhstan to rein in their money supply, and the I.M.F. is expected to press the republics to do the same. He complained about Ukraine, which seems undecided on whether to create its own currency or stick with the ruble.
He seemed to be pressing Ukraine to keep using the ruble, saying republics that establish their own currencies would probably have to import Russian oil, not in rubles, but at world prices and in hard currency.
 
Quiet Pressure on Republics
 The Group of Seven leading industrialized nations and the I.M.F. are quietly urging republics to stick with the ruble. They worry that the establishment of new currencies in different republics will cause trade to plunge, just as Soviet trade with Eastern Europe declined after the countries stopped dealing on a ruble basis.
Impressing questioners with his knowledge of every nook of the Russian economy, Mr. Gaidar outlined a plan to begin privatizing big state-owned enterprises this fall.
He said privatization would at first be focused on several sectors, including building materials, construction, food processing, farming and light industry. The Government hopes to establish a voucher system enabling the cash-poor public to acquire shares in the companies, he said.
Most economists say privatization is vital because it forces management to care more about profits, efficiency and competition, and thereby helps hold down inflation.
Mr. Gaidar said the Russian Government privatized 20 times as many enterprises in April as in all of 1991, collecting 3 billion rubles in April compared with 200 million for all of 1991.
"The most important thing," he said, "is to try to privatize as rapidly as possible and to try to create a property structure that would be regarded by society as more or less just, that will not create a terrible redistributionary conflict that will undermine political stablity."
 
Workers Get a Stake
 Workers in many state-owned companies asked that ownership be turned over to them for free; to placate them, the Government plans to give workers 25 percent of a company's shares for free, but without voting rights, in major privatizations.
Workers will be able to buy an additional 10 percent of their company's shares, with voting rights.
Managers also often wanted to be given outright ownership of the enterprise, but Mr. Gaidar said managers would be able to buy 5 percent of the shares on a preferential basis.
The Government is also auctioning off stores, and workers are given a 30 percent discount in buying their shops.
In Mr. Gaidar's view, the decline in oil production is one of Russia's most critical problems because it has reduced oil exports, a crucial source of hard currency. He said the Government plans a vast increase in domestic oil prices to encourage conservation at home, to provide more money for the domestic industry and increase the amount available for export.
He said Russia was opening up the gold and oil industries to foreign investment, a move that should bring in new equipment and thereby help increase exports.
 
Lassitude on the Farm
 He said Russia had created 60,000 smaller units from huge collective farms but that much more must be done to privatize the farm sector and make it more efficient. One factor hurting farm production, Russian officials say, is that many of the brightest, most energetic young people from the countryside moved to the cities during the Communist era.
Mr. Gaidar said Russia would impose an import tax, not to protect its industries but to raise revenue and reduce the nation's trade deficit. He said that an export tax was also needed to raise revenue, though he admitted it might discourage some foreign companies from investing in Russia's natural resources.
