HEADLINE: How Dinkins Strove to Keep the Peace

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
At 6:30 Wednesday night, Mayor David N. Dinkins received a telephone call in his private quarters at Gracie Mansion, his official residence. The message was urgent. A jury had just acquitted four white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of Rodney G. King, a black motorist.
The danger was obvious, recalled Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary. The King case had been a well-publicized symbol of police brutality to many, whites as well as blacks. The acquittal of policemen, often a flashpoint for violence in urban communities, had brought Los Angeles to the brink. Could New York be next? 
 For the next three days, Mr. Dinkins and his aides would struggle to prevent that. They cajoled, pleaded with and warned community leaders who were likely to lead demonstrations -- like the Rev. Al Sharpton and the Rev. Herbert Daughtry -- to keep them from turning violent. They also urged television news directors to use caution in their broadcasts, given the racially charged nature of what they were showing.
At the same time, Mr. Dinkins, elected as a conciliator at a time of racial tension, made numerous appearances in which he condemned the verdict. He urged restraint but also sent a message to those tempted to respond with rage: Violence would not be tolerated. He told Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown to prepare for the worst.
So far the Mayor's approach appears to be working, with only a few scattered incidents of violence Friday night, including a stabbing in Harlem. "I'm pleased that things are relatively calm in the city," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday after a walk along 125th Street in Harlem. During the walk, he said he had come to thank people, "especially the young people in our city, for the restraint they showed."
Administration officials, recalling their actions over these crucial days, said the Mayor's response had been refined by the experience gained in handling racial clashes last summer in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, after a car driven by a Hasidic Jew struck and killed a black child.
What follows is an account of the 72 hours after Mayor Dinkins heard of the verdict in Los Angeles.
 
Wednesday
 6:30 P.M.: After receiving the call at Gracie Mansion -- and despite his general practice of not criticizing jury verdicts -- Mr. Dinkins instructs his aides to draft a strong statement, expressing his outrage but appealing for calm.
Mr. Dinkins immediately calls Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch Jr., his chief political strategist, who handled racial conflicts in Crown Heights and Bensonhurst. They decide that the best way to stave off violence in New York City is with the help of religious and community leaders.
Despite his dislike for unplanned television interviews, the Mayor and his aides agree that he will make regular appearances on the evening news programs until the potential for violence is over. As he leaves a banquet for city education awards at the Equitable Center in midtown Manhattan, the Mayor holds brief on-camera interviews with reporters for the late television news programs on WCBS and WABC. His message is the same: The verdict in Los Angeles was unfair, he says, but there is no need for violence.
 
Thursday
 10:45 A.M.: The Mayor receives a call at City Hall from Vice President Dan Quayle, who is planning to visit New York later in the day. Mr. Quayle informs the Mayor that the President is planning to have the Justice Department and the F.B.I. review the King case with the possibility of bringing Federal civil-rights charges.
11:00 A.M.: The Mayor meets with his aides to discuss the rioting in Los Angeles and its impact on New York. It is decided that he will meet with clergy and community leaders at Gracie Mansion the next day to solicit support in keeping the peace.
11:30 A.M.: At a news conference to announce an economic development trip to Europe, Mr. Dinkins denounces the violence in Los Angeles. But says he understands the anger and frustation at the verdict. The Mayor also relates his conversation with Vice President Quayle and says he is encouraged by the promise of Federal action.
Noon:: Bill Lynch and Fritz Alexander, Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, arrange meetings with community leaders and law enforcement officials and monitor activities throughout the city.
5 P.M.: Mayor appears on each of the local evening news programs. His message is unchanged from the day before: He appeals for calm and expresses dissatisfaction with the Los Angeles verdict.
 
Friday
 8:30 A.M.: As the bloodshed, looting and destruction mount in Los Angeles, the Mayor holds a meeting at Gracie Mansion with 125 community and religious leaders to discuss how best to keep the peace. "Don't let this turn into another Crown Heights," says Mordechai Levy of the Jewish Defense Organization. Mr. Dinkins seeks to allay his concerns.
The leaders, including Mr. Sharpton, express their concerns about possible violence and how the police will respond. But they also agree to use their influence to calm the situation. Mr. Dinkins and the others then hold a news conference.
9 A.M.: The Police Department opens a telephone line that residents can call to get accurate information on trouble in the city. Later, the concerns of the police are borne out when a host of rumors, most unfounded, sweep the city, leading many businesses to close and thousands of commuters to head home early.
11 A.M.: The Mayor holds a meeting with law-enforcement officials to discuss the city's response. He relays the fears of community leaders that the police could overreact or use excessive force in handling disturbances -- thus worsening a tense situation. He also commends Mr. Sharpton for his cooperation in keeping the peace.
1 P.M.: The Mayor calls news directors at television stations to praise them for being responsible in their coverage of the Los Angeles riots.
3 P.M.: Panic begins to spread throughout the city that there will be rioting. A television station invites the Mayor to interrupt programs to issue another appeal for calm. Mr. Dinkins declines the offer, saying he will wait for evening news programs to avoid the appearance of a crisis.
5:30 P.M.: Mayor Dinkins goes on the evening news programs once again, commending New Yorkers.
6:15 P.M.: Mayor Dinkins holds a cabinet meeting at Gracie Mansion to discuss his strategy for the weekend. At the Mayor's invitation, community leaders are also there.
7:30 P.M.: Reports begin to circulate of scattered violence, and the Mayor stops by the command center at Police Headquarters.
10 P.M.: The Mayor appears on the late night news programs.
 
Saturday
 1 P.M.: Mr. Dinkins, accompanied by a police bodyguard, walked into the All Seasons Shoes store on 125th Street. "He was just talking about, 'Keep the peace, and no rioting,' " said Kang Lee, who works there. "He was checking on all of the businesses to see if they were O.K."
Mary Baker, owner of Mary's Hair Gallery, felt Mr. Dinkins "should have been doing this a long time ago, not waiting for something to happen."
"All the people shook his hand and spoke to him," Ms. Baker said. "I don't think they gave him a chance to discuss nothing, they were so busy shaking his hand, they were so pleased to see him."
As Mr. Dinkins walked through Harlem yesterday he could not help but remind many New Yorkers of another Mayor, John V. Lindsay, who at a very different but also difficult time had walked the streets of the ghetto and urged calm.
But this time the voice was of the city's first black mayor, who had some claim to understanding the pent-up frustration he had been trying so hard to contain. "Remember," the Mayor said, "no matter how frustrated and distressed we all are over what has occurred, violence and destruction are not the answer."

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief's First 4 Months: Red Tape Cut, Feathers Ruffled, Funds Exhausted

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 2

 BODY:
After four months on the job as the United Nations' sixth Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt has acquired a reputation as an active and formidable diplomat not afraid of ruffling feathers in an organization with a legendary resistance to change.
He moved swiftly in his first eight weeks to overhaul the senior levels of the secretariat in New York. And he helped push the Security Council into new, high-risk peacekeeping operations in Somalia and Yugoslavia in addition to the demanding and expensive missions it had already taken on in the Western Sahara and Cambodia. 
 At the same time, he promoted peace efforts in Afghanistan and boldly threatened to pull the 28-year-old peacekeeping force out of Cyprus if feuding Greeks and Turks do not patch up their differences this year.
But the paradoxical consequence of all that activity is that Mr. Boutros-Ghali now finds himself presiding over an organization that seems exhausted. It has run out of money to pay for new peacekeeping operations just as demand is soaring for what many see as its most useful functions in the post-cold-war world. It even lacks staff to mediate fresh disputes.
With the United Nations peacekeeping bill expected to quadruple this year, from more than $700 million to about $3 billion, and the Bush Administration unwilling to ask a reluctant Congress for more funds in an election year, Mr. Boutros-Ghali has been forced to call a halt to new operations.
"It is not realistic for us to accept any new peacekeeping operations this year," the Secretary General said in a recent interview. "We haven't got the money, so they would be at the expense of other operations. Also our own staff is overloaded."
 
U.N.'s Full Plate And a Tight Budget
 The issue came to the fore during United Nations efforts to halt the civil wars in Somalia and the former Yugoslav federation. Before he took office, Mr. Boutros-Ghali called it "a disgrace" that the United Nations had watched Somalia disintegrate into bloody anarchy without lifting a finger and vowed to intervene.
Similarly, he pushed the Security Council into intervening in the Yugoslav civil war, saying it was necessary to risk a peacekeeping operation in Croatia even though the factions might go on fighting.
But in Paris this week, Mr. Boutros-Ghali told President Francois Mitterrand that France's request for a second Yugoslav peacekeeping operation, to stop the latest civil strife in Bosnia and Herzegovina, was unrealistic unless the Europeans find a way to pay for it.
At the same time, he is also backing America's demand that oil-producing Persian Gulf states pay for most of the proposed Somali operation because the Bush Administration is unwilling to ask Congress for extra money.
The United Nations is not even seeking to play the role of mediator in those conflicts. It is ceding the task in Somalia to the Organization of African Unity and the Arab and Islamic organizations it belongs to. In Yugoslavia the European Community has taken on the job.
"Our plate is full," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said. "The United Nations Charter specifically gives regional organizations first responsibility for mediating disputes. They may not have our experience but they have more resources and they can learn."
 
Personal Liberation And Decisive Moves
 The fast initial pace the new Secretary General set himself generally has drawn plaudits in the northern industrial world, though the reaction among third-world countries has been more mixed.
"His early actions have been received very positively, though we still haven't seen his long-term vision for the organization," said Edward C. Luck, head of the American United Nations Association.
Sir Brian Urquhart, former Under Secretary General in charge of peacekeeping and now at the Ford Foundation, said, "It has been rather an impressive start."
A fast start also distinguishes him from his more cautious predecessor, Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former Peruvian diplomat who stepped down and retired at the age of 70, the age at which Mr. Boutros-Ghali took over the post.
The Secretary General says he has acted decisively because the changing world climate gave him the chance to do so and "decisiveness is the best way to get things done".
He insists his administrative reforms reflect a belief that such changes are unavoidable if the organization is to take advantage of the opportunities the cold war's demise has given it.
But some of those who know him well suspect his surprising outburst of energy also reflects the sense of personal liberation the top United Nations job has finally given him.
 
France's Choice Has Rocky Start
 A small man with immense charm as well as a keen and irreverent wit, Mr. Boutros-Ghali comes from one of Egypt's most prominent Coptic Christian families with a long tradition of public service. His grandfather was Prime Minister and his father Minister of Finance.
Fluent in English, French and Arabic, he also represents that fading strata of cosmopolitan Egyptian society, equally at home in Cairo and Alexandria or the capitals of Europe, that was immortalized in the four novels of Lawrence Durrell's Alexandria Quartet.
Educated at universities in Paris and New York, Mr. Boutros-Ghali enjoyed a highly successful career in the Egyptian foreign service, playing a key role at the Camp David negotiations that led to Egypt's recognition of Israel and eventually reaching the No. 2 spot in the Foreign Ministry before becoming Deputy Prime Minister.
But Egyptians say his Christianity and his Jewish wife have always denied him the very top posts -- until now.
"Tariq Aziz, another Christian Arab, could became Iraq's Foreign Minister, but that's not the Egyptian way," said Richard E. Murphy, a former Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs who is now with the Council on Foreign Relations.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali was far from being the Security Council's unanimous choice as Secretary General. France, which had backed him from the outset, engineered his selection, in the process outwitting the United States and Britain, which had shown only lukewarm support.
And although the choice satisfied the third world's demand that an African get the job, the light-skinned Egyptian was not quite what Sub-Saharan Africa had in mind.
Neither was his arrival at the United Nations entirely smooth. A close Egyptian aide he brought with him had to flee the country almost the next day after being charged with sexual harassment by a maid at a New York hotel.
 
Posts Are Filled, Bureaucracy Yields
 Nevertheless, the new Secretary General set himself a 60-day deadline to streamline the upper ranks of the Secretariat along lines largely recommended by the United States and a group of other countries.
Defying those who said the organization's intractable bureaucracy would never yield, he ended a chaotic system under which some 28 Under Secretaries General reported directly to him, dividing the United Nations work into eight departments, each headed by an Under Secretary General, with two more in charge of its offices in Geneva and Vienna.
But he also left many veterans of the organization gasping with disbelief by ignoring the usual careful regional sharing of top jobs.
Half the No. 2 posts went to citizens of the five powers with permanent Security Council seats and another four to citizens of other European countries. As a result, James O. Jonah, a respected long-serving staff member from Sierra Leone, ended up as the third world's sole representative among the organization's second-ranking officers.
The Secretary General even invited President Bush to nominate an American of his choice to the organization's top budget and management post in deference to Washington's complaints about inefficentcy.
Not surprisingly, many third-world governments were irritated by the job allotments and the apparent diminishing of United Nations economic and social activities in favor of its peacemaking role.
 
Putting Emphasis On Prevention
 But there was little they could do about it, since the author was a third-worlder member whose candidacy they had supported.
The new appointments are only for a year, so early 1992 is likely to see further streamlining at the top of the Secretariat as well as compressions at lower levels.
In the meantime, Mr. Boutros-Ghali is pushing for another administrative reform of considerable potential significance.
He wants to start consolidating the separate information and other offices the United Nations and its agencies maintain across the world into single units that he calls "United Nations Embassies."
Not only would that cut wasteful duplication, but such offices could serve as his "eyes and ears" in sensitive areas, he said, reporting to him on emerging disputes before they erupt into conflicts and helping him resolve them.
But not everything has gone well for Mr. Boutros-Ghali since taking office. His first news conference, delayed until March, was a disaster.
With nothing new to announce, he was ignored by the Western press but still managed to infuriate Muslims by suggesting that Israel has no obligation to surrender occupied Palestinian lands and refusing to intervene in the Kashmir dispute.
 
Management Style? 'More 19th Century'
 Subsequently, the Security Council's decision to impose an air embargo on Libya exposed him to further criticism from the Arab press.
The organization's staff unions are also becoming increasingly suspicious about his long-term administrative plans, asserting that he is failing to keep them informed of his intentions.
Earlier this month, Edward Freeman, head of the largest union, which represents 32,000 of the United Nations systems 54,000 employees, called Mr. Boutros-Ghali's secretive management style "more 19th century than 21st century" and accused him of planning new staff cuts next year.
Such complaints seem unlikely to affect Mr. Boutros-Ghali, who says that where administrative change is concerned, his experience in the Egyptian bureaucracy taught him "stealth is essential."
The Secretary General is equally frank about his biggest challenge -- money -- and particularly American money since the United States is currently almost $1 billion behind in regular and peacekeeping dues.
"Resources could cause this organization to fail just when it should succeed," he said.

HEADLINE: Abandoned Oil and Gas Wells Become Pollution Portals

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, May 2

 BODY:
From the Louisiana bayous to the arid plains of Texas and Oklahoma, thousands of oil and gas wells, abandoned at the end of their productive life, have become conduits for noxious liquids that bubble up from deep below the earth's surface to kill crops and taint drinking water.
For state governments in America's oil patch, these abandoned wells have become an expensive legacy left by a fading industry. 
 The Federal Environmental Protection Agency estimates that there are about 1.2 million abandoned oil and gas wells nationwide and that some 200,000 of them may not be properly plugged. In Texas alone, officials calculate there are 40,000 to 50,000 abandoned wells that could pose pollution problems.
Often drilled to depths of a mile or more, oil wells typically tap into sandy formations permeated with a brine that is up to four times saltier than sea water and that is laced with radioactivity, heavy metals and other toxins. Without extensive and costly plugging, that brine can flow up the well shaft and seep into fresh water aquifers or sometimes reach the surface.
Occasionally the brine from abandoned wells hits the surface with explosive force. In the last few years it has erupted through a parking lot in San Angelo, Tex. Mixed with natural gas, it spewed into the backyard of a home in Bartlesville, Okla., and oozed onto a freeway construction site in Tulsa.
 
Slow, Insidious Process
 But the damage is usually slower and more insidious. A single unplugged exploration hole in West Texas leaked brine for 22 years before being discovered, polluting the ground water beneath 400 to 600 acres of land, a 1990 study by the Bureau of Economic Geology at University of Texas found.
Many of the problem wells date to a freewheeling time before the oil business kept records or was regulated. In Texas, state records indicate that the sites of some 386,000 wells were never registered.
And it was not until the mid-1960's that the oil-producing states enacted regulations to protect fresh water supplies by requiring that hundreds of feet of cement be poured into the wells at different levels in the process of closing them properly. A majority of the wells listed as plugged in Texas records were plugged before the rules were in place.
 
Plugging Style of Past
 "We've found leaking wells from the old days that were rock-plugged, bucket-plugged, tree-stump-plugged and even one plugged with nothing more than a glass jug because back then they didn't give a darn and they just stuck whatever they had down the hole," said Wayne Farrell, director of the San Angelo-Tom Green County Health Department in West Texas.
Oilfields are primarily the province of state, rather than Federal, regulators. They have usually been overseen by agencies like the Texas Railroad Commission or the Oklahoma Corporation Commission whose primary purpose is to promote the oil industry rather than protect the environment.
The dangers posed by abandoned and improperly plugged wells began to attract attention from state officials only in the mid-1980's. The oil industry was a cherished source of revenue, and there was little research to distinguish contamination in oil fields from the naturally occurring salinity common in places like West Texas.
Since 1990, both Texas and Oklahoma have created funds specifically dedicated to plugging abandoned wells by imposing new taxes or fees on companies drilling or operating oil wells. Louisiana, which has 1,493 abandoned, unplugged wells listed as awaiting action, eliminated money in its budget for plugging wells this year because of a state budget shortage.
With exhausted fields and low prices driving down production, the number of wells abandoned by bankrupt operators has increased rapidly since the mid-1980's. Last year, Oklahoma began plugging 260 wells that were orphaned when a single company went bankrupt. The average cost is $4,000 a well.
Lena Guerrero, chairwoman of the three-member Texas Railroad Commission, said: "In a very short time Texas has gone from denial, to saying maybe there's a problem but there's no money to fix it, to now where we're saying there's a real problem and we can find the resources."
Declining production has brought other problems as well. In depleted fields, wells commonly pump more than five barrels of brine for every barrel of oil, and those vast quantities of brine are often forcefully injected back into the ground. The goal is to dispose of the brine and increase pressure in the oil-bearing formation so that more crude can be extracted from a nearby active well. But if an improperly plugged well has penetrated the formation, the added pressure helps push the brine up that shaft.
 
Threat to Wildlife, Too
 Ken Kramer, director of the Texas Sierra Club, said that abandoned wells "pose the most extensive and most critical environmental problems caused by oilfield activities, but they are not the only ones." The storage of brine and other wastes in open pits is another source of water pollution as well as a hazard to wildlife, he said.
"But among those problems," he said, "the seepage of brine from unplugged wells into fresh water aquifers can be the most difficult to identify and clean up because it is hidden pollution, taking place underground."
In the oil patch of Oklahoma and West Texas, brine formations lay at depths of 1,000 to 8,000 feet, where they are under tremendous pressure. Many strata of virtually impermeable rock lay between the brine and the fresh water aquifers, which are near the surface down to depths of 500 feet. Water moves laterally across the aquifers, slowly but across great distances, to streams and creeks.
The future health of these aquifers is a growing concern in Texas because they feed big river systems like the Colorado and the Brazos. Major cities, ranches, farms and electric power plants all the way to the Gulf Coast depend on these rivers.
The short-term problems are visible on Ralph Hoelscher's West Texas farm, where there are patches of land so salty that even weeds will not grow.
Last year, Mr. Hoelscher planted salt-tolerant Bermuda grass in a field his family has farmed since the turn of the century. But after a heavy rain all the plants in a quarter acre patch were dead. Months later their roots still looked as if they had been burned by acid and the ground was caked white with salt.
Mr. Hoelscher thought he had found the cause in 1989, when a plow knocked something below ground and brine started flowing. It was a well, listed as properly plugged, that had been simply capped with a steel plate and covered with dirt.
Then he discovered that there was a row of 10 unplugged exploration wells along one side of his property. The 1990 study by the University of Texas found 1,000 of these wells in Tom Green County, where Mr. Hoelscher farms.
 
Legal Solutions Difficult
 With so many potential culprits, seeking recourse through the courts is often impossible for someone like Mr. Hoelscher. Even if the source of contamination can be identified, the companies responsible for the problem well often ceased to exist long ago.
Having the evidence and knowing some companies responsible still does not mean a legal solution is at hand. When the freshwater aquifer that supplied the central Oklahoma town of Cyril, population 1,200, was declared unsafe because of brine pollution in 1989, there was little doubt that the oilfield below it was at fault.
Brine pumped up with oil had been disposed in open pits from the 1920's to 1960, when that use of pits was prohibited. There were at least 44 abandoned, unplugged wells in the field, and since 1972 brine had been pumped through injection wells at high pressures.
But the town's $11 million Federal suit brought against two oil companies was dismissed this week when a judge ruled that the statute of limitations had expired.
For now the sole remedies lie with state efforts to plug problem wells with money collected from current operators. But there may be a time limit on this strategy.
Last week there were 623 drilling rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States. That was the lowest number since Baker Hughes Inc., the Houston-based oilfield service company, began keeping count in 1940.
Under current plans to plug 200 wells a year, it could take Oklahoma a century to take care of its estimated 15,000 to 20,000 abandoned or improperly unplugged wells. And Texas, with the most ambitious oilfield cleanup program of any state, intends to plug 1,000 wells a year. Under that schedule, the job could be done in 50 years, presuming that no more wells are abandoned.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Centrist Council Exults In Success of a Member

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, May 2

 BODY:
In some quarters, the Democratic Leadership Council has been denounced as a reactionary group of white, male, Southern politicians who would ruin the Democratic Party by rejecting its traditional constituencies and embracing Republican thinking.
But when Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas returned here today to speak to his old colleagues, it was as the leader of a newly matured movement that has now all but hijacked the rest of the party, forcing it onto a centrist policy track that its leaders hope will take the Democrats back to the White House this year. 
 Along the way, the council has broadened its base somewhat, gained some black members and forced the rest of the Democratic Party, which has lost five of the last six Presidential elections, to take it seriously.
It has been a swift change for the group, which held a somewhat fractious convention in Cleveland last year that left liberals uncomfortable and some black Democrats complaining that they had been muscled out of the process.
 
The Politics of Success
 The change results from the politics of success. As Mr. Clinton, one of the group's founders and a former chairman, has emerged as the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, other party members have fallen in line. And now the council, considered an insurgent rump group little more than a year ago, has significant influence over Mr. Clinton's policy agenda.
In his speech at the council's annual meeting here today, Mr. Clinton credited the group with his success, but then began a treatise on the subject that has made the group most uncomfortable: race.
"I know we have been hurt by a leadership without a strategy to restore our economic strength," he said of the Bush Administration. "I know that we have been hurt by a leadership that was irresponsibly divisive, denying of America's problems."
Some of the fiercest critics of the leadership council have now endorsed Mr. Clinton, including Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, who formed the rival Coalition for Democratic Values, which takes more liberal positions, and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who spent much of his Presidential campaign criticizing Mr. Clinton and his wing of the party as phony Democrats.
He now says that was all posturing, but Mr. Harkin, who withdrew from the race in March, is perhaps the best example of a liberal Democrat who has shelved his differences with Mr. Clinton to take a stab at party unity. At a rally in Pittsburgh last week, Mr. Harkin conceded that he "took some good shots at Clinton myself" during what he called a primary process of "constructive debate."
"But that constructive debate is over and past," he added.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the two-time Presidential candidate who once said D.L.C. stood for "Democratic Leisure Class," is the notable exception. He has refused to endorse Mr. Clinton and had another squabble this week with council leaders who had invited him to address their convention.
But many of the party's other old-school liberals, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, have climbed aboard the Clinton bandwagon, signing onto a set of policies that are nearly indistinguishable from the platform of the leadership council they once viewed as suspect.
 
Uniting Two Positions
 Mr. Clinton took a long step today toward melding the traditional Democratic approaches to racial issues with the more centrist ones advocated by the council, calling national service programs, beefed-up community policing and tenant participation in management of public housing as examples of ways to head off future problems like those in Los Angeles and other cities this week.
A 19-page document distributed as a "discussion guide" at the group's meeting, titled "The New Choice: Draft for a Democratic Platform," read like a Clinton campaign document. Its introduction declares, "We are prepared to offer America a new governing agenda that expands opportunity, rewards responsibility and fosters community."
Mr. Clinton's own policies, as embodied in the standard speech he delivers on the campaign trail, are nearly identical to the positions set forth by the council, in part because many of Mr. Clinton's closest advisers are affiliated with the group.
"Bill Clinton is the person who told me that change is never easy," said Al From, the executive director of the council. "Some of the ideas that we proposed went against the old orthodoxies of the Democratic Party. We wanted to change the status quo and you take hits along the way when you do that."
The centerpiece themes of Mr. Clinton's standard speech, including his discussion of personal responsibility, are lifted almost entirely from the council's manifestoes. He and the council also agree on allowing parents to choose public schools, enforcing child support orders, allowing capital gains tax breaks for original investment, tying welfare benefits to education or job-training goals and starting national service and apprenticeship programs for young people.
Mr. Clinton has won warm approval for many of these ideas as he campaigns. Indeed, some of his most reliable applause lines seem borrowed from the council's speech writers.
"His argument carried the day," said Robert J. Shapiro, vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute, the research arm of the leadership council, said of Mr. Clinton. "When the campaign began, a lot of people thought this was a debate we had been through before between left and center. The Progressive Policy Institute and the D.L.C. spent the last three years thinking through this debate, which is not left-right but old-new.
"One of the reasons Governor Clinton succeeded and everyone else fell very quickly was some people were in a debate that the country wasn't listening to anymore," he added.
 
Claiming Victory
 As if to shore up that impression, the leadership council, never shy about self-promotion, asked the poll-taker Daniel Yankelovich to study on how well its ideas were working. The study assembles information drawn from national polls and concludes that most Americans favor demanding more from welfare recipients and instituting a national service program, and they share an underlying anxiety that the country is headed in the wrong direction.
The euphoric organizers of the group are confident their message will play best with voters in the fall general election, who tend to be more independent and less liberal than traditional Democratic primary voters.
"Our assumptions had always been its greatest strength was against Republicans," said Doug Ross, a Democratic organizer. He helped Mr. Clinton win the Michigan primary by testing themes of racial unity and personal responsibility with black voters in inner-city Detroit and white voters in suburban Macomb County.
"The challenge always was, 'How do you get through Democratic primaries dominated by traditional Democratic activists?' " he said. "How do you get it past the primaries?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Social Policy;
Clinton Blames Bush and Republicans for Racial Turmoil

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, May 2

 BODY:
Using his sharpest language yet on the nation's social ills, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas today placed the blame for the failures in race relations with President Bush and preceding Republican administrations.
Citing the rioting in Los Angeles and violence in other cities, the Democratic Presidential candidate turned a speech before the Democratic Leadership Council here into a treatise on America's cynicism and racial division that he said threatened the nation's future. 
 And late today, Gov. Clinton announced that he would travel to Los Angeles on Sunday night. Mr. Clinton, accompanied by Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, will meet with black, Hispanic and Korean leaders before leaving the city Monday night.
 
An Incomplete Message
 In his speech, Mr. Clinton said Mr. Bush fell short of the message he should have delivered when he called for an end to the civil disobedience on Friday, and announced plans to Federalize the National Guard and begin a Federal investigation of the Los Angeles police brutality case.
"The Republicans, when they needed to prove Michael Dukakis was soft on crime, brought out Willie Horton," he said. "The Republicans, when they needed to cover up for their senseless economic strategy that is driving income down for most American families while they work harder, blame it on quotas so there can be racial resentment instead of honest analysis of our economic falsehoods."
He said Republicans urged unity but "send their Vice President out across the country to talk about welfare in a way that makes it clear they intend to use it as a wedge to divide the American people instead of an instrument to liberate the poor."
Mr. Clinton, who had resisted attacking President Bush on civil rights as the Los Angeles riots were growing, dropped all pretense of being apolitical on the matter today. But he also criticized Democrats who complain of having too few choices, do not vote and allow the Government to become "paralyzed and divided."
Mr. Clinton took pains to contrast his message to the one delivered by the President on Friday night, urging special attention for black Americans who have been victims, not just the perpetrators, in the Los Angeles violence.
"After all, more than any other racial group in this country, it is their children who are shot on the streets, their neighborhoods that are savaged by crack cocaine, their businesses and dreams who are crushed," he said.
 
Mainstream and Undertow
 Mr. Clinton's speech today represented a full synthesis of his typical speeches on racial issues and his thinking on the race riots in Los Angeles. Troubled communities, he said, must be rescued through individual as well as Government commitment.
"We have made a great deal of progress for those of us who live in the mainstream of America," he said. "But what has happened beneath that? Beneath that, there are those who are not part of our community, where values have been shredded by the hard knife of experience, where there is the disintegration of family and neighborhood and jobs and the rise of drugs and guns and gangs."
Mr. Clinton said he supported a waiting period for the sale of handguns and an increased reliance on community-based policing and prison boot camps as a way to curb urban crime over the long term. But most of his message today, delivered to a rapt crowd of 1,000 conference participants who had come to hear Mr. Clinton deliver a traditional campaign speech, focused on the underlying social causes for the violence in Los Angeles.
 
Fear Born of Isolation
 "White Americans all too often fear that violence has only a black face," said Mr. Clinton, who spoke from notes but without a prepared text. "They see it on the news. They see it in their movies. They are gripped by the isolation of their own experience where, especially in many of our larger areas, too many white Americans still simply have no friends of other races, and do not know any differently. Blacks fear that too often violence has a black face and no one cares."
Mr. Clinton added, "We should be afraid, my fellow Americans, but we must face our fears and stop running from them."

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: World View;
Europe Is Aghast, Fearing Unrest There; Japan Takes Moral High Ground

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 2

 BODY:
The terrifying images of racial violence in Los Angeles have hit people in both Europe and Japan with an intensity that similar scenes in the Balkans, Afghanistan and South Africa never did.
Europeans had persuaded themselves that those places were in a different world, but America and American mass culture are not. They know that what has gone wrong in the United States could go just as wrong in Europe. Racial, ethnic and social tensions have erupted into violent conflict in Britain, France and Germany, though on a lesser scale, and could do so again. 
 So Europeans were as rapt before their television sets as millions of people in Japan, a society that regards the multiracial character of the United States with fear and, at times, undisguised contempt. Prominent Japanese politicians have tried to explain the decline of American industrial and trading power, in part, as a result of tangled ethnic strains that, they say, make Americans less well educated and far less motivated than the more homogeneous Japanese.
 
Guns Have Shock Value
 No other country in the world except possibly Afghanistan has more guns per capita than the United States. The pictures of store owners in Los Angeles firing randomly at crowds with shotguns and rifles have a shock value all their own because when people die in European riots, they usually die from beatings or knife wounds, not gunshots.
Even before Los Angeles, many European and Japanese politicians and commentators had begun thinking of the United States as a country in decline, pointing to the advantages of their own social and economic systems and rejecting American criticisms of their policies.
President Bush "is a generous man who is coming from an extremely conservative political philosophy," President Francois Mitterrand of France said on Friday, adding that American society was conservative and devoted to the free market. "Now we see some of the results of that," he said.
What effect the riots, and Mr. Bush's response to them, will have on the American Presidential campaign is no clearer to Europeans at this stage than it is to Americans.
But for Mr. Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, both in somewhat shaky political condition themselves, one lesson is that continental Europe's expensive welfare-state safety nets are well worth the cost, despite frequent American criticisms that they are unsustainable in the long run.
 
Embassy Guard Increased
 In South Korea, concern for Koreans caught up in the destruction led the National Assembly today to urge the United States to offer compensation to those who had suffered damage. The Foreign Ministry in Seoul even said that it would send a senior official to survey the situation.
The United States Ambassador said the guard was increased around American installations and military housing areas in Seoul, evidently aimed at preventing conflict between Koreans and black American soldiers.
Asylum-seekers have been flocking to Germany at the rate of a thousand a day this year from the Balkans and elsewhere to find safety and economic security, but many Germans seem likely to take Los Angeles as one more reason to resist letting more immigrants settle there.
"I could not believe the violence," Ali Kaynak, a resident of the Kreuzberg district of Berlin, told the Reuters news agency after the annual May Day protests there on Friday.
The Mitteldeutsche Zeitung of Halle, in the eastern part of Germany, wrote: "In America's cities, a social time bomb is exploding. The boom in the 80's benefited only the rich. Over 33 million U.S. citizens, 13 percent of the population, are considered impoverished. In the ghettos of the big cities a generation is growing up that can expect hardly any support from welfare in the future."
 
The Verdict Shocks
 The Neue Presse, in Hanover, observed: "What has to happen is a radical attempt to correct fundamental American injustices. Whether U.S. politicians are prepared or able to do this remains to be seen."
Everywhere, people who saw the videotape of the Los Angeles police beating Rodney G. King, the black motorist, and almost everybody with a television set did, have been shocked by the jury verdict that acquitted the officers, an outcome Mr. Mitterrand described as "scandalous."
In Japan, intense newspaper and television coverage had even stronger overtones of moral superiority, confirming Japanese in their view that their exclusionary society and legal system, which does not have juries in criminal cases, were better than their American equivalents.
"This Los Angeles jury could not have done more damage to their country's image abroad if they had tried," wrote the English-language Japan Times today.
Since the Los Angeles jury reached its verdict on Wednesday, the world's front pages and television screens have been dominated by the pictures of the consequences on the streets of Los Angeles: blacks beating whites, Asian shop owners shooting at black looters, white police officers and soldiers with rifles pinning blacks to the ground.
"God Help America" was the headline on the mass-circulation Daily Mirror in London this morning, but the subliminal message was really "God help us all."
The Guardian wrote in an editorial: "Afghanistan is quaintness from another era. The nationalist tumult of Europe is the Balkan problem of school history dressed in T-shirts and unfathomable passions. But here, from Los Angeles, is something we are all conditioned, every watching day, to relate to; something coming to get us."
The conservative Le Figaro in Paris said this morning: "The United States has not yet succeeded in economically integrating all its blacks or all its Hispanics. That, nothing else, is the problem. And what is happening there today could explode here tomorrow."
 
Ghettos in Europe, Too
 Paris and London also have their ethnic and racial ghettos. Paris has mainly Muslim quarters full of immigrants from its former North African colonies; the streets of Brixton in London are now filled with black people from the Caribbean, while Bradford, Manchester and Birmingham have many neighborhoods populated by people from South Asia.
When Brixton and the Toxteth district of Liverpool erupted in violence in 1981, the British Prime Minister of the day, Margaret Thatcher, reminded each citizen of "his duty to obey the law," much as Mr. Bush warned the "mob" in Los Angeles Friday night that the violence had to stop.
Mrs. Thatcher's successor, John Major, has not commented on the Los Angeles riots, but his Government plans to start an Urban Regeneration Agency next week to signal its determination to try to prevent a repetition of the violence here, something that newspapers warn could happen any warm day.
"As our own lesser riots and the rise of neo-fascism in Europe have shown," The Independent wrote today, "the danger of racial conflict is ever present. We are in no position to throw stones."
But as many Europeans and Japanese see it, the problems of Los Angeles are as much economic as racial in nature. For El Pais, the Spanish daily, the violence showed that, after the passing of Communism and the end of the cold war, the free market was not the answer to everything if it meant that the law of the jungle prevailed.
A South African tabloid newspaper that reflects white opinion there, The Citizen, had this to say today: "Our advice to the United States is: Sort out your own racial problems and leave us to sort out ours. As L.A. has shown, you are not a great example to us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Hanyang University in Seoul, South Korea, yesterday, people read newspaper reports of the rioting in Los Angeles, where many Koreans have been victims of the violence. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Fresh Air Fund Provides Summer Relief

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Nine-year-old Charles Aviles usually spends steamy June afternoons playing football on the sidewalks of the South Bronx, but last summer he left his hardscrabble neighborhood for two weeks on a Pennsylvania farm. He rode horses, golfed and hooked his first baby flounder.
The family Charles was staying with treated him to carnival rides and baseball games and walks in the woods. 
 "I saw a deer, the one with the horns," Charles said. "It looked like Rudolph the red-nosed reindeer, but it was big."
This year, Charles will return to Pennsylvania. He is one of thousands of poor city children who will spend two weeks with families recruited by the Fresh Air Fund, which starts its 116th annual fund-raising campaign.
 
More Working Women
 The Fresh Air Fund, a nonprofit agency, has provided free summer vacations to underprivileged children from New York City since 1877, but it has struggled in the last two decades as more women have gone to work outside the home and fewer families have volunteered to host inner-city children.
In 1971, 16,000 children boarded buses to escape heat-baked neighborhoods for small towns across the region. But by 1989, the number of children had fallen to its low of 6,700. In the last two years, the numbers have begun to creep back up. About 7,200 children participated last year.
The Fresh Air Fund has improved recruitment in part by finding new ways of tapping the volunteerism of working women, students and retired people who may not be able to take a child into their home, said Jenny Morganthau, the Fund's executive director.
Volunteers from the 316 communities in 13 states that host the children help publicize the program, interview prospective families and visit their homes, and escort children on bus rides from city to country.
"Women still volunteer," Ms. Morganthau said, "they just volunteer differently."
This year, the people who run the Fund hope they will be able to give more children a respite from the city, where fearful mothers often keep their sons and daughters inside to protect them from the dangers of the street.
"Because of the recession and government cutbacks, there are fewer things for the kids to do in the summer," Ms. Morganthau said. "You read about kids getting shot. They need places where they can be safe."
Charles Aviles's mother, Deborah Washington, said she is nervous about letting her sons out of her sight. "A lot of people like to fight," she said. "It's just a bad neighborhood. They like to be shooting and stuff."
Charles said the South Bronx is nothing like the farm in Pennsylvania.
"I hear gunshots here every night," he said. "There I heard crickets. I saw stars. We went jumping on the trampoline and they got a new swing set. When I get back this summer they're going to have a family picnic for me."
Host families can invite children from 6 to 12 years old, for a two-week visit. The children come from poor families and register through 54 community and social-service organizations in the city's five boroughs.
 
No Pay
 Host families are not paid and there are no financial requirements to participate. About 60 percent of the children are invited back by the same families summer after summer, Ms. Morgenthau said. Children can be invited back until they are 16.
The Fresh Air Fund also sends 2,500 inner-city youngsters, ages 8 to 15, to camps on 3,000 wooded acres of the Sharpe Reservation in Fishkill, N.Y. This year, the fund is raising money for a new camp for 12- to 15-year-old youths that will focus on education and literacy. The camp will help 300 disadvantaged teen-agers study and plan for careers. So far, the Fund has raised $4.4 million toward its $6 million goal for the camp.
The Fresh Air Fund relies primarily on private donations to support its work. It costs $314 for the Fund to send a child to a family and $819 to send a child to camp. The Fund has raised $1.7 million of the $3.5 million it needs this year to support its programs.
"The main goal is to serve more children," Ms. Morganthau said, "and to do that we have to recruit more families and raise more money."
Tax-deductible contributions may be sent to The Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y., 10018. Families who want to be hosts may call (800) 367-0003. To volunteer for other duties, call (212) 221-0900.

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES;
California Governor Facing Tough Time

 BODY:
In a difficult time for governors, Pete Wilson of California may be having the toughest time of all. He came to office 16 months ago as a rising star in the Republican Party, with a reputation as a pragmatic conciliator and consensus builder who could change a troubled state and a virtually paralyzed state government. 
 But economic and political realities have constrained Mr. Wilson, and his job performance rating has plummeted. High unemployment and severe fiscal problems have burdened him, and so have natural disasters: earthquakes, fires and drought. Now the rioting in Los Angeles presents yet another challenge for the Governor. [Magazine, section 6. The rioting broke out after the magazine had gone to press.]

HEADLINE: Purnell H. Benson, 78, Stock Market Expert

 BODY:
Purnell Handy Benson, a professor emeritus of business at Rutgers University and an expert on the fluctuations of stock prices, died on Monday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Madison, N.J.
A family spokesman said that Dr. Benson died of a bone marrow disease. 
 Dr. Benson joined the faculty of the Rutgers University Graduate School of Management in 1967, teaching marketing and price theory. After retiring in 1984, he lectured at the graduate business schools of New York University and Columbia University.
In the early 1980's, Dr. Benson traced "disturbances" in the normal supply and demand functions in stock prices to the growing use of computerized trading programs. He became a vocal advocate of regulations to control program-induced stock market trading, lecturing at economic conferences and publishing his views in various newspapers.
He is also author of a college textbook, "Religion in Contemporary Culture," published by Harper & Brothers in 1960.
Surviving are his wife, Mary A.; a son, John C. of Wilton, Conn.; two daughters, Alice V. of Brooklyn Heights and Janice Sabky of Madison; two brothers, Jack of Fairfield, Conn., and George of Laconia, N.H., and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Job Recovery In New York Called Slowest

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Amid scattered signs that the nation is beginning to recover from the recession, the states in the New York region remain mired in such a deep slump that economists say they will not regain their previous peak employment levels until much later in the decade.
"Morale is very bad among business people," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist for the Chemical Bank Corporation, who does not expect the New York region to reach the bottom of its slump until late this year. He said prospects for recovery were dim. 
 "The engines of growth are just not there," he said.
In one of the gloomiest appraisals, DRI/ McGraw Hill, an economic consulting and forecasting concern in Massachusetts, said New York and Connecticut were the only states that had yet to hit bottom in the recession. It said New York would not hit its trough until summer, and Connecticut in the fall.
 
Catching Up by 1996 and Later
 Besides California, it said all 10 states hit hardest by the recession were in the Middle Atlantic and New England regions. In each case, it said the states had entered the recession before the rest of the nation and would take longer to recover.
The study, comparing the severity of the recession in different states, found it to be far worse across the New York region and New England than in any other section of the nation. It said the job losses over the last three years would not be recovered in New York and New Jersey until 1996, and not in Connecticut until the end of 1999.
Employment losses across the region have been huge. Federal statistics show that New York State has lost 500,000 private jobs since the beginning of 1988, roughly half the gains that it experienced in the prior eight years. That loss is 6.5 percent of the total private employment in 1988 in New York State, 7.7 million.
Most of the cuts came in New York City, where the Federal Government said 337,000 jobs were eliminated out of a total of 3 million, an 11.2 percent loss, wiping out all of the employment increase between 1976 and 1988.
 
Computers Rely on Variables
 In New Jersey, employment has been reduced by 287,000 out of 4.1 million since 1989, about a 7 percent loss, according to Government statistics. The losses amount to 44 percent of all employment growth in the state in the prior nine years.
In making its forecasts, the group entered a host of variables into its computers, including labor and housing costs, population growth, taxes, school standards, past profits and other business conditions. The data provided assumptions for what would aid or hinder economic growth.
It said Connecticut, having hit its peak of employment in the first three months of 1989, would not recover to that level until the last three months of 1999. New York and New Jersey both reached their peak employment in the first six months of 1989, it said, and will not fully recover until the first three months of 1996.
In contrast, it said the nation had reached its peak of employment in the third quarter of 1990, experienced 15 months of decline until the end of 1991, and would fully recover its losses by this September.
"We've had relatively mild recessions in the past, but this is what the Rust Belt went through in the 1970's and 1980's," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York.
 
Things Look Good Elsewhere
 The forecasts come amid mounting evidence that recovery, albeit slow and uneven, has begun in most of the nation. The National Bureau of Economic Research, a private agency in Washington that determines for the Government when recessions begin and end, said this one began in July 1990 and ended in April.
Other indicators offer guarded cause for optimism. People's confidence in business conditions, job security and their family finances, as measured in a monthly survey by The Conference Board, jumped in March and April.
The Conference Board, a business research group in New York City, does not report its results for each state, but said the April gain in consumer confidence was even sharper in the Middle Atlantic states, including New York and New Jersey, than in the nation as a whole.
"This is classical," said Fabian Linden, director of the monthly consumer confidence study. "People begin to feel things are getting better even before they really do."
 
Broadway May Be Indicator
 Hints of an upturn can be found on Wall Street, where brokerage firms are awash in heavy stock trading, huge profits and rich executive bonuses, and on Broadway, where theater attendance is at its highest levels in years.
But analysts say the isolated glimmers pale amid the New York region's deep, abiding economic woes.
"Somebody has to be the last one out of a recession, and the numbers here don't bode well," said William A. McEachern, a professor of economics at the University of Connecticut.
"The contours of this recession are different than anything in the past," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. Because the downturn has carved deeply into the business of military contractors on Long Island, high-technology electronics companies in Westchester and New Jersey, and banks, advertising agencies and other service concerns across the region, it has undermined the same industries that have fared best in past recessions.
In its study, DRI/McGraw Hill said some states had been bypassed entirely by the current recession, while a few had sustained damage as severe as that in the New York region and New England. It said six Western states, Idaho, Utah, South Dakota, Montana, Arizona and Colorado, had experienced no employment losses.

HEADLINE: An Airline That Failed Still Helps Candidates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
One of Senator Kent Conrad's last campaign contributions before he announced his retirement last month was a $3,000 check from Eastern Airlines.
Eastern Airlines? 
 Yes, the same airline that has been out of business for more than a year.
"I'm surprised that nobody has noticed it and asked any questions before because it is unusual," said John Sicilian, the general counsel for the bankrupt airline.
The airline may be bankrupt, but its political action committee still has about $50,000, and the carrier's management is looking for candidates to give the money to, Mr. Sicilian said Friday.
 
Unemployment Is Concern
 The political committee is not part of the airline's estate, Mr. Sicilian said, so creditors have no claim on it.
The officials who oversee the committee decided to write a check to Senator Conrad, a North Dakota Democrat, because of his support last year for extending unemployment benefits, an issue important to the carrier's thousands of former employees, Mr. Sicilian said in an interview from his Miami office.
Eastern's political action committee has given $29,000 to eight senators, all Democrats, and House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, since the beginning of 1991, according to Federal Election Commission records. The airline went out of business in January 1991.
Corporations are prohibited from giving money to candidates for Federal offices, but many form political action committees to which officers and other employees contribute.
 
Returning the Check
 Senator Conrad's campaign received the check from Eastern on March 30, just four days before the North Dakota Senator announced that he was going to honor a campaign pledge and not seek re-election.
Senator Conrad, who had more than $1 million in his campaign fund at the time, is returning the contribution to Eastern, said Laurie Boeder, a spokeswoman for the Senator.
The Senator's North Dakota contributors were given the option of having their contributions returned to them or given to the Democratic Party in the state, she said.
Out-of-state contributors, like Eastern, are being contacted to see what they want done with their donations, she said.

HEADLINE: Lock Step With New York City Economy, Budget Treads Path of Booms and Busts

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The $29.5 billion budget proposed last week by Mayor David N. Dinkins left some New Yorkers with the impression that the city government had finally turned a corner after more than three years of fiscal distress.
But upbeat developments -- including a $455 million surplus this year that will allow the city to avoid borrowing and pay for some new programs next year -- obscured a more enduring problem, many fiscal monitors say. For at least two decades, they say, the city's financial structure has been fundamentally out of balance. 
 Each year since the late 1970's, mayors have managed to balance the budget, as they must by law. But in good times, new services and thousands of city workers have been added, while in bad times, many of those same services and employees have been lopped off.
What successive city administrations have been unable to do, the fiscal experts contend, is create a stable long-term balance between the size of the government and the size of the economy on which it rests.
 
Altering How Business Is Done
 Experts call that relationship "structural balance," and they say it is the cornerstone of fiscal stability. Many fiscal monitors say they are afraid that the relatively sanguine budget proposed by Mr. Dinkins could derail discussion, and perhaps action, on the administration's fledgling efforts to confront the underlying imbalances in the municipal government's finances.
"Basically every expert I know believes that the city hasn't changed the way it does business for over 20 years of recurring fiscal crises," said Elinor B. Bachrach, the deputy state comptroller for New York City.
While many factors, from the city's tax structure to its wide array of services, have helped create the imbalance, in many ways the problem boils down to one overriding point: The city is required by law to spend all the money it takes in each year, and that leaves it hostage to the volatile swings of the local economy.
When the economy is robust, tax revenues pour in. Municipal officials must spend any surplus. When the economy contracts, so does the city government, usually through the kind of painful layoffs and service cuts that Mr. Dinkins has been forced to impose since he took office.
 
Off the Roller Coaster
 "From the perspective of structure, New York City government has not changed very much in the last 20 years," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses. "It just tends to get bigger and smaller in cycles, in waves. Unless we address the structural issues, we will just get a repeat of what we had before."
For the last 20 years, New York City's economy has ridden a roller coaster. In the deep recession from 1969 to 1977, the city lost more than 600,000 jobs -- nearly one-sixth of all jobs in the city -- and one-tenth of its population. The size of the local government was slashed; more than 60,000 municipal workers lost jobs during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
Then, beginning in the late 1970's and through most of the 1980's, the local economy soared. More than 50,000 additional workers were hired.
By 1989, the city was in recession again. Last year, the local economy lost more jobs -- 195,000 -- than in any year since the Depression. Once again, tax revenues fell and the municipal government began shedding workers through layoffs and attrition.
 
Between Boom and Bust
 Since taking office two years ago, the Dinkins administration has reduced the size of local government by eliminating about 12,500 municipal jobs financed with city money. The Mayor proposed cutting another 1,100 jobs in the budget he released on Monday.
The veering between boom and bust has been compounded by New York's tax structure, which depends heavily on taxes highly sensitive to the local economy, experts say.
Most cities and towns raise about 75 percent of their tax money from the property tax, according to a report last year by the Financial Control Board, the state agency that monitors the city's financial affairs. The property tax is considered among the most stable and predictable. About 20 percent of most local governments' revenues are raised from sales and consumption taxes and about 5 percent from income taxes, according to the report.
But in New York, the tax mix that has evolved over years is quite different. Partly to capture more of the business and personal wealth in the city, government relies much more heavily on income and sales taxes, which are more sensitive to the swings of the economy. Personal and corporate income taxes produce 29 percent of New York's tax revenues, and sales and consumption taxes provide 27 percent, the control board said. The property tax accounts for 44 percent of the city's tax base.
 
Striving for Stability
 Fiscal experts say that the combustible mix of a volatile economy and a reliance on economically sensitive taxes has left the city doomed to repeat the pattern of expanding and contracting unless it makes fundamental structural changes.
They say the city must begin stabilizing tax revenues and expenses, so that the size of government does not grow too much during good times or shrink too much during bad. Independent fiscal monitors, along with the Dinkins administration, have proposed many solutions, all intended to make the government more resilient to the cycles.
Several fiscal monitors say state law should be changed so that the city would be permitted to save during growth periods. Many also say that the city should continue to reduce its work force and re-think what services it provides.
Many fiscal experts say that the city should aggressively change how manages its workers, obtaining more productivity from a smaller work force. Some experts also contend that the state should take over the city's cost of welfare and Medicaid, a total of more than $2 billion.
 
Trying to Overcome Tradition
 There are huge obstacles to such fundamental changes, including state laws, municipal bond covenants, Civil Service rules, union contracts, tradition and, of course, politics.
Philip R. Michael, the city's budget director, said he supported the idea of a rainy day fund to protect against busts. He and other fiscal experts said the city must also practice restraint in booms. In particular, they said, it should avoid spending so much on new city workers.
Alair A. Townsend, a deputy mayor and budget director under Mayor Edward I. Koch, said the city should consider spending surpluses on "one-shot expenditures" that do not create recurring expenses, like painting city bridges or buying library books.
But politics and pressing needs -- from fighting AIDS to sheltering the homeless -- make restraint difficult. "It is a very difficult political exercise to engage in," Mr. Michael said. "We all know the needs are immense, the real needs, so to hold back is a very difficult thing."
 
Long-term, Good Politics
 Fiscal monitors, whose roles were created during the city's flirtation with bankruptcy in the 1970's, contend that creating a financially stable government would have substantial political rewards.
"Radical abrupt budget cuts are not good for any politician," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board. "These ups and downs that lead to quarter after quarter of budget cuts make the life of a politician more difficult, make the lives of city workers more difficult and make the lives of most citizens more difficult."
"Trying to come to terms with volatility really will make everyone happier," Mr. Proctor said. "It's not a pointy-headed notion."
The Dinkins administration has proposed many steps to alter the city's fiscal landscape, including trimming capital spending to decrease long-term debt, consolidating several city programs, closing some city jails and reducing the number of apartments the city owns and manages.
 
Taking Baby Steps
 Mr. Proctor described those efforts as modest, but moving in the right direction. Some other fiscal monitors said the city should become much more aggressive. It is not enough, they said, to simply make government smaller by reducing the work force. The city also has to rethink its mission, jettisoning some traditional functions and obtaining significant concessions from municipal unions to obtain more productivity.
Mr. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission said, for example, that the city should consider eliminating the Department of Mental Health because a state agency performs a similar function. Other fiscal monitors said that many other municipal operations should be reconsidered: Should the city be in the business of financing and managing housing? Should it continue to subsidize cultural institutions? Can it afford to own and operate 11 municipal hospitals?
Mr. Horton dismissed the city's efforts thus far to manage its labor force better. "Inroads into municipal productivity have been very elusive," he said. "We just don't see a scintilla of evidence that the city is serious about this."
Mr. Michael, the budget director, acknowledged that there was "a chorus out there who say we ought to do more about restructuring."
 
'Bumps Along the Road'
 "The problem is that some do not have ideas on how to do it, and others have ideas that have been tried and have failed," he said.
Mr. Michael said he was hopeful that steps laid out by the city would start addressing the long-term imbalance in its finances. "We think we have a plan that does it," he said. "Clearly, there will be bumps along the road. Head counts are coming down, restructuring is going on and we have a plan that tries to bring the budget into balance over four years."
Mr. Proctor said that Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Michael had at least made a beginning. "The city has started to do the very things they have to do to achieve structural balance," he said.
"The administration very courageously is running an experiment that has never been tried before," he added. "I hope it succeeds."

HEADLINE: Alas, We Had the Hype Right Here

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
THE wonder horse always looked somewhat delicate to carry racing into the millennium, skinny legs and all. Arazi was surprisingly small for such a macho star, Paul Newman encountered on the street, but then after all the hype we did see the finely tuned muscles appear under the vibrant skin and the clear eyes shine. He did have an easy grace.
"He's almost feminine," said D. Wayne Lukas, the trainer, who enjoys being provocative. He won this race in 1988. "Secretariat and Seattle Slew looked like stud horses, big, arrogant. If you didn't know it was Arazi, you would never say, 'Who was that little chestnut horse?' " 
 But everyone came to know that it was Arazi, and only Arazi, who would matter here, despite some lip service to the cultural and economic presence of the rap star-horse owner, Hammer. Arazi, it was hoped, would lead the $2 bettor out of the OTB parlor and into the sunlight of the rail, would lure the bored millionaire into the barn area, and, most important, would induce the world's movers and sheiks to spend their play dough at the American yearling sales.
Arazi flew here last week on wings of hype. His success in France under markedly different conditions, and his one overwhelming American victory -- at the Breeder's Cup Juvenile, said Lucas, he "looked like a Ferrari with its accelerator stuck" -- have been mythologized for the good of the game. Purists are uncomfortable with comparisons to Secretariat -- Big Red's 1989 death still occasions a moment of silence -- but had Arazi fulfilled his destiny, he would have been Little Red.
"We need to refocus on the horse," said Thomas Meeker, the president of Churchill Downs. "When I first came here in 1985, the big Kentucky Derby celebrity was Don Johnson of 'Miami Vice,' not a very nice fellow, and last year it was General Schwarzkopf, which was great, but still not a horse."
Not just any horse, of course, but one we can think of in human terms.
"We can only anthropomorphize so far," warned William Nack of Sports Illustrated, who wrote a passionate biography of Secretariat. "But Secretariat was bright, a ham. He had courage when he was a baby. Arazi seems to have a sense of himself that shows glimmers of that."
Everyone here seems to agree that people need heroes even if the heroes aren't quite people. But no one seems to have a clear idea of why this should be, other than the race for money.
One of the livelier middle-class trainer-owners, the working heart of the industry, is Shelley Riley, a large, handsome blonde from northern California who favors bold floral print dresses and an earthy style. This was her first visit to a prestige race. She had originally purchased her entry, Casual Lies, for $7,500. He came in a surprising second.
"They love Casual Lies in California," she said. "They chant Cas-U-Al, Cas-U-Al, Cas-U-Al. A hero. A people's horse. But when it comes time to bet, they put their money on the Japanese horse, which I guess was financially smart."
That Japanese horse was A.P. Indy, scratched early yesterday with a bruised hoof. A land developer, Tomonori Tsurumaki, bought him for $2.9 million. A.P. stands for AutoPolis, a Japanese leisure center. A.P. Indy would have been the second favorite.
The morning's scratch lost its sting by late afternoon when Arazi simply never turned Red. That ignominious eighth place will sire a hundred reasons, all true. Arazi had jet lag, he was too small, too delicate, too unused to dirt tracks and left turns. He should have stayed in America, to be raised in roughhouse American ways, like the third-place Dance Floor, owned by Hammer, and trained by Lukas, Mr. Sound Bite himself, who said he thought celebrity owners were good for the game and that Hammer being black was a plus. "And he's making a profit, he's in the black, no pun intended."
Hammer is considered a fortuitous hero at Churchill Downs, whose management admits having been slow to reach out to the blacks. Hammer responded to the Los Angeles riots by saying "people are more important than horses," but he seemed caught in an odd promotion with his Kentucky Fried Chicken sponsors. The fast-food chain "bet" Hammer 50,000 pounds of chicken that Dance Floor would not win yesterday. If Dance Floor did win, they would donate those tons of chicken to "the nation's hungry."
Alas, because Dance Floor didn't win, some poor people will be a little hungrier. Because Arazi didn't win, some rich people will be a little sadder. Maybe next year, we'll have human heroes again.

HEADLINE: Give Shape to Summer

 BODY:
The tickle of warm grass under bare toes . . . The taste of lemonade sipped in the shade of a tree . . . The heft of a ripe, red tomato just plucked from the vine . . . A secret wish on a shooting star.
The summers of childhood are never forgotten. As much as schoolbooks and spinach, they shape the adults we become. This summer, as it has for 115 summers, the Fresh Air Fund hopes to give shape to summer for children who have no other outdoors than New York City's meanest streets. 
 How many children can briefly escape the polluted air, trash-strewn sidewalks, blistering asphalt playgrounds, the drug pushers and gunfire? It all depends on how many adults help.
At a minimum, the fund wants to help nearly 11,000 children this summer, 7,200 of them to stay with volunteer families in rural and suburban communities from Virginia to Canada. There's room for 2,500 children to spend two weeks hiking, fishing and learning to swim in campgrounds in Fishkill, N.Y. Plus 1,200 teen-agers could participate in the fund's year-round camping program, which includes educational activities and career preparation.
The host families open their homes and hearts without charge but transportation, insurance and administration cost $314 per child. Sending a youngster to the two-week camp costs $819. All told, the fund, which is building a new campsite and seeking more host families, hopes to raise $3,512,000.
Even in this recession, millions of New Yorkers find ways to break free of the city each summer, to enjoy cherished quiet with family and friends, old and new. The city's poorest children need such escape, too. Tax-deductible contributions and inquiries about becoming a host family may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018, (800) 367-0003.
