HEADLINE: U.S. vs. Needy Students

 BODY:
One would think the Administration of the self-styled Education President would embrace ways to help needy students get through college. Instead, the Bush Administration has gone to court to block the way the Massachusetts Institute of Technology spends $20 million a year on scholarships. Why? Because the Justice Department thinks M.I.T. is violating antitrust laws.
It's a destructive claim, unworthy of litigation. At least it warrants being contested. But Justice now wants to deny even a fair hearing; it asks for summary judgment. That risks turning the unwarranted into the outrageous. 
 The Justice Department says M.I.T. and eight other premier universities have been engaged in a conspiracy. They agree to offer students only enough aid to meet their need. Justice thinks that's price-fixing -- despicable, automatically illegal and therefore undeserving of a trial.
M.I.T. admits that an agreement existed. The purpose was to prevent a bidding war that would deplete the funds available for needy students. But so what, according to the Justice logic; the letter of the antitrust laws should be upheld.
The argument fails on the merits. The antitrust laws are designed to stop price-fixing by commercial enterprises that exploits consumers. They are not intended to stop nonprofit organizations from cooperating in charitable endeavors. Giving scholarship aid to needy students is surely a charitable activity. At the very least, the Government is obliged to prove the cooperative agreements somehow aided a commercial purpose.
At the crux of the dispute is a simple question: What did M.I.T. do with the money it saved by avoiding a bidding war? The Government assumes that it went to improve faculty salaries. If that were so, the suit would be justified.
But the assumption appears to be dead wrong. Dennis Carlton, a University of Chicago economist, in a study commissioned by M.I.T., shows that the universities that agreed to provide aid only to meet financial need used the savings for more financial aid. Needy students, not faculty, benefited. Indeed, Congress uses the same policy to dispense Federal financial aid.
Meanwhile, the very filing of the suit in May 1991 has done grievous damage. Colleges, under threat of suit, have abandoned cooperation. Forced to bid for students, many can no longer afford a "need-blind" admissions policy -- the practice of admitting academically qualified applicants regardless of need.
Several M.I.T. trustees grew up on the wrong side of the tracks themselves and owe their scientific education to generous scholarships. They believe in need-blind admissions, which is why they have refused to capitulate to Justice and are fighting this bizarre case. They deserve the support of all who care about scholarship and scholarships.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 520 words

HEADLINE: Routine Wastelands

 BODY:
The smoke has drifted away and the sirens have stopped in Los Angeles, but there and in every big city a high-pitched alarm still pierces the air. Until Americans heed it, there will be more fires and more next times.
This time, New Yorkers shivered with relief that the rumors of trouble for their city were mainly wrong. Other cities were not so lucky, and in Los Angeles, site of vast, new barren wastelands, people numbly count casualties and costs. 
 In his immediate responses to the rioting, President Bush skillfully gave equal weight to order and justice. He did not hesitate to express his own shock at the acquittal of the Los Angeles policemen shown on videotape brutally beating Rodney King. Federal forces now help maintain order.
But even as the explosion dies down, it exposes a frightening tear in the social fabric. The King beating videotape ignited obvious horror in whites and blacks. What was not so obvious to white America was why the acquittal hit blacks with such locomotive force.
They know, better than most people, that it was a perverse manifestation of an even deeper wrong. Injustice is one thing; what's worse is a systematic lack of justice, of protection. America consigns great numbers of young black men to lawless lives. It writes off great stretches of urban landscape as routine wastelands.
Officials alarmed by the fiery rioting last week were right to appeal for people to live by the rule of law -- a rule of law nowhere evident among the policemen who beat Rodney King so savagely, and not perceptible on the jury that acquitted them.
Nor is the rule of law much evident in South Central Los Angeles, or in Chicago's Cabrini-Green or in New York's Bedford-Stuyvesant. The public has largely ceded these places to criminals. Neighborhoods have become wastelands, governed by random violence -- if not that of drug dealers with machine guns.
In Los Angeles notably, the revealing icon of the rule of law is the helicopter, droning ceaselessly overhead, watching to see that crime does not spill out of the sectors of sanctioned lawlessness.
People who live in the crime-ridden inner cities already know the rest of America thinks them unworthy of protection. The King verdict pushed their noses deeper into the disrespect, implying that the social contract does not apply to them at all.
Last month Senator Bill Bradley, in a courageous speech, reminded the public of the danger in thinking of the inner cities as islands unto themselves: "The future of American cities is inextricably bound to the issue of race and ethnicity . . . That means the economic future of the children of white Americans will increasingly depend on the talents of nonwhite Americans."
The smoke in Los Angeles last week showed just how tenuous that future can be. It will remain so until society insures that the social contract applies to all its citizens. The most obvious requirement is to protect people from police who have gone out of control. The larger requirement is to protect against the day-to-day horrors of life in the wastelands, the routine wastelands.

HEADLINE: RIOT IN LOS ANGLES: The Overview;
CLEANUP BEGINS IN LOS ANGELES; TROOPS ENFORCE SURREAL CALM

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2

 BODY:
With 13,000 police and troops patrolling the streets of the nation's second-largest city, life in Los Angeles assumed a surrealistic sense of the normal today after one of the deadliest and most destructive racial disorders in American history.
As the night curfew ended at dawn, cleanup crews began spreading through the hard-hit South-Central area to salvage what they could from some of the 3,767 buildings burned in the three days of arson and looting. 
 On Crenshaw Boulevard in the heart of a mostly black area, a racially mixed band of volunteers picked up brooms and shovels at the office of State Senator Diane E. Watson and moved through the charred rubble as the police and troops protected gas stations and food stores. Post offices in the area opened for the first time since Wednesday, and residents stood in long lines for their mail.
 
A Night of Fewer Fires
 As they did so, 4,500 Army and Marine troops assembled in nearby bases in case of further trouble, and special weapons teams from the Federal Bureau of Investigation waited in hotels and other locations.
But they were not needed today.
There were only 47 building fires overnight, only a few more than normal in this city of 3.5 million, and just sporadic gunfire on this third day of trouble after rioting began Wednesday when a suburban jury acquitted four white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of a black motorist last year.
A Federal grand jury began hearing evidence today and has issued subpoenas in an effort to determine whether civil rights laws were violated in the beating of the motorist, Rodney G. King, Associate Attorney General Wayne Budd announced.
 
The Riots' Toll
 By the time the grand jury hearings got under way this morning, the local authorities had put the death toll at 44, including 7 people shot by the police, making it one of the deadliest riots in the United States in this century. In addition, there were 1,765 injuries, 198 of them critical, and 6,345 arrests. In July 1967, racial violence in Detroit left 43 people killed, more than 2,000 injured and 7,000 arrested. Hundreds of people were killed in draft riots in New York City during the Civil War.
The office of Mayor Tom Bradley estimated property damage at $500 million.
This evening, the Mayor announced that he had appointed Peter Ueberroth to head the reconstruction effort. As chairman of the Los Angeles Olympic Committee, Mr. Ueberroth, a former Baseball Commissioner, was in charge of the 1984 Olympic Games here.
At a news conference attended by Gov. Pete Wilson, Mr. Ueberroth called for cooperation from government leaders, as well as Presidential candidates, the ethnic communities in the city, foundations and volunteer groups and private companies, including foreign ones. He gave no details of any proposed recovery measures. He said the results could provide a blueprint for other cities facing urban blight.
Governor Wilson, meanwhile, announced that President Bush had signed a declaration of disaster, activating Federal relief efforts for victims of the looting and arson. Such aid typically includes grants and low-cost loans to cover property losses.
At City Hall this morning, Mayor Bradley expressed relief that the violence had abated and urged merchants to reopen their stores if possible. In areas unaffected by the violence, stores were doing business as normal, and the Mayor said the police would provide protection for stores and gasoline tankers coming to supply service stations.
"The Police Department has assured us all the stores that want to reopen, that want to distribute their products, that they can do so," the Mayor said, adding that contributions of food to the Salvation Army and Red Cross were also needed.
Mr. Bradley also said Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York telephoned Friday "to commiserate and to offer any help that he could provide."
 
Criticizing the Response
 As residents tried to restore their lives, questions arose about the week's events and the official response to them, questions about why it took so long to deploy National Guard and Federal troops and about the long-term economic consequences for this recession-wracked region.
"The response of the National Guard is slow," said Deputy Mayor Mark D. Fabiani. "In the 60's, Federal troops saved several cities from destruction. The numbers of National Guard troops on the street were not the number that were promised at any time."
If there was insufficient force at first, the military presence was smothering today. California National Guard troops in black and green camouflage and Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies surrounded the county Hall of Justice and the county court house downtown. Nearby, Los Angeles police in riot gear had cordoned off City Hall. Armored vehicles in desert camouflage were positioned at major intersections in the Civic Center area.
President Bush ordered in the Federal troops on Friday to supplement 6,000 National Guard members activated earlier. The Federal troops were not immediately sent into the streets today, but were dispatched to military bases in southern Los Angeles County and northern Orange County late Friday night as backup forces. They included 2,500 Army infantry soldiers and 1,500 marines.
"What we are doing is positioning our forces in a contingency mode in case something is needed in the future," said Lieut. Col. Stan Kensic, spokesman for the military command center at the Los Alamitos Army Reserve base near Long Beach, 15 miles south of downtown Los Angeles. The Army and Marine forces, as well as the National Guard, were put under the command of Maj. Gen. Marvin Covault, commander of the Army's Seventh Infantry Division (Light), based at Fort Ord, Calif., near Monterey.
The National Guard troops at the downtown Federal Building and the Hall of Justice were drawn from the 649th Military Police Company, which spent five months in Saudi Arabia last year and was assigned to control prisoners of the Persian Gulf war. "This is just another mission, and they don't have Scuds," said Sgt. Michael O'Brien of San Luis Obispo, Calif.
 
Businesses, Closed and Open
 The dusk-to-dawn curfew remained in effect this weekend. On Friday night, Los Angeles's normally glittering nightlife ceased. The rock music palaces, dance halls and bars along the Sunset Strip, on Hollywood Boulevard and Santa Monica Boulevard were silent and dark, some of them boarded up against vandals. County beaches were closed.
Yet today the Universal Studios tour, a major tourist attraction in the eastern end of the San Fernando Valley area of the city, was open and, a security guard said, "operating normally." And 45 minutes south of South-Central Los Angeles, there was a 45-minute wait at the most popular rides at Disneyland in Anaheim, in Orange County. The amusement park has been operating normally every day.
But it was anything but normal along Crenshaw Boulevard. Amid piles of charred litter, a line of about 50 people waited at a check-cashing store, one of the few business operating. Traffic moved fitfully, with half the signal lights out. Utility crews fanned out to restore electricity, under heavy police and military guard.
At Senator Watson's offices, Jackie Trost, a white woman from Beverly Hills, helped supervise cleanup activities. "I just came out to help the community," she said. "This is not just a black community. This is everybody's community. People want to help."
Estrellita Braddic, deputy press secretary to Senator Watson, said: "The ones who were doing the burning the looting are not here today. These are the ones who want to reclaim the community. We are all equals today. Hopefully, this will be a trend."
With donations from a bank, Senator Watson hoped to open a trailer to dispense free food and medicine beginning Monday.
 
An Official's Account
 At City Hall, an official who participated in organizing the city's response to the rioting said today that Mayor Bradley and Governor Wilson had grown increasingly concerned over the past three days about the posture of the city's police chief, Daryl F. Gates, feeling that he lacked a sense of urgency. Chief Gates initially resisted calling the National Guard on Wednesday night as the riots widened, the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity, but by Thursday morning the Chief agreed that troops were needed.
By early Friday, however, largely as a result of forces beyond Chief Gates's control, only 500 of the 2,000 activated troops were in the city. The other 1,500 were assigned to help the county sheriff, Sherman Block, to police outlying areas.
"The Governor was as frustrated as the Mayor was," the official said, adding that they began considering other options, including intervention by Federal troops, which would take control out of Chief Gates's hands. The official said the two men enlisted the help of Warren M. Christopher, who was chairman of the independent commission that investigated the black motorist's beating last year and who decades earlier had worked to quell riots as a deputy attorney general in the Johnson Administration.
From his home in Beverly Hills, Mr. Christopher telephoned Bush Administration officials, including Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, to discuss which military units to call in, the official said.
"At that point," he said, "the Mayor decided that you can't show enough force."
At 11:30 A.M. Thursday, the official said, the Mayor and the Governor met in the Emergency Operations Center in the basement of City Hall, where 3,500 more National Guard troops were promised by Friday afternoon. But by 6 P.M. Friday there were still only 3,000 Guard troops in the city. Then, over the objections of Chief Gates, Mr. Bradley and Mr. Wilson asked the President for the Federal forces.
 
Views on the Street
 Senator Watson also faulted Chief Gates. "A man of his cunning should have known there would have been this kind of reaction to this acquittal," she said in an interview today.
But on the streets there was disagreement over the police and military response. "It takes time to assess," said Conyers Brown, a retired television repairman who was in front of his Bronson Avenue home washing his 1986 Continental near some of the worst burning. "You don't just rush in. If you move too fast, you could have aggravated the situation."
Nearby, Larnel Harris, also black, said that while he could understand why the police hesitated, given the circumstances of the trial, the troops should have been brought in immediately. "I understand the reluctances by the Police Department because that could have started a shooting battle between the police and the community," said Mr. Harris, who served 10 years as a police officer with the Navy. "But the troops are more neutral."
The jails of Los Angeles County, the city and nearby cities, meanwhile, were crowded with the 6,345 people arrested by 5:30 this morning. The state Supreme Court extended to 96 hours the normal 48-hour deadline for charging defendants.
 
Special Court Sessions
 The Municipal Court planned special weekend sessions for arraignments, one courtroom for felonies and another for misdemeanors.
At the Los Angeles County Coroner's office, the task of identifying the 44 dead and notifying the next of kin proceeded.
"We're using fingerprints, driver's licenses and dental records to try to learn who these people are," a spokesman for the coronor's office, C. Scott Carrier, said Friday night. "One of the hardest things is to get to some of these people, their next of kin, who live in South Los Angeles. We can't get down there."
It was impossible to assess the economic consequences of the violence, but higher unemployment was a certainty. Of most immediate concern was the Los Angeles region's huge tourism industry, which accounts directly for 360,000 jobs.
Joel Kotkin, a writer who has long been a booster of Los Angeles as a place to do business, said: "It's a terrible blow. We could have withstood an 8.5 earthquake better than this."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 5, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Sunday headed "Deadly Riots" referred incorrectly to past riots in the Watts section of Los Angeles, in which 34 people died. They occurred in August 1965.

HEADLINE: OUT THERE: GUANGZHOU;
Let a Thousand Lipsticks Bloom

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS KRISTOF

DATELINE: GUANGZHOU, China

 BODY:
Few Chinese houses have doorbells, but that has not stopped the emergence here of a growing army of 10,000 women who are called "elegant and fragrant ladies."
That is what the Chinese call their Avon Ladies, and they are peddling cosmetics with a determination that has made Avon one of the most successful and best-known companies here in southern China. 
 If rampaging Red Guards symbolized the revolutionary spirit of China in the late 1960's and early 1970's, then the equally tenacious "elegant and fragrant ladies" capture the bourgeois spirit of China in the 1990's. Avon opened for business here in September 1990, sold what was to have been six months of inventory in the first four weeks, and has been booming ever since.
"We came at the right time," said Samantha Kong, sales director of Avon's office in Guangzhou, also known as Canton. "People here aspire to look good, as they do anywhere, but they have no one to teach them how."
In many ways, Avon is a perfect fit with the local culture. Incomes are rising rapidly, local women are showing increasing interest in makeup, consumers have a strong preference for American products, and there is an enormous pool of entrepreneurs who are eager to earn extra money by selling cosmetics part time.
"I use myself as a model," said Tian Ruihua, a 25-year-old hotel secretary who began selling for Avon just a month ago. "So when my friends ask how I make myself up, I tell them that I use Avon products."
In her first month, Ms. Tian sold the equivalent of $278 worth of cosmetics to her friends and earned a 30 percent commission worth more than $83. That sum, which would be an excellent monthly salary in China for a full-time job, represented three hours of work.
One-third of Guangzhou's Avon ladies earn monthly commissions of more than $275, and the star saleswoman, Zhao Lizhen, earned $6,600 in her best month.
"When some Avon ladies sell a lot of cosmetics and make a pile of money, then other people notice," said Li Qilan, a 25-year-old whose self-confidence has turned her into a super saleswoman. "Then the others want to sell for Avon, too."
For now, Avon operates only in Guangdong Province, the southern Chinese region that for the last dozen years has enjoyed some of the highest economic growth rates in the world. Guangzhou is the capital of Guangdong Province.
The number of Avon ladies is expected to double to 20,000 within a year.
In China, far more than in the United States, Avon has cachet; indeed, most American products do. Many Chinese manufacturers now try to come up with foreign-sounding brand names and English-lettered packaging to lure customers.
Avon's image has been bolstered by the company's Chinese name, yafang, meaning elegant and fragrant. Calling the Avon representatives "ladies" (there are no Avon men, although husbands can help unofficially) also helps impart sophistication, because the Chinese word that is used for lady or Miss, xiaojie, was rarely used in China until recent years and still sounds cosmopolitan and exotic.
Part of Avon's appeal, and of cosmetics generally, is that they tap a widespread yearning among Chinese to shed backward customs and enjoy the sophistication for which Hong Kong is widely envied. One successful pickup line in Guangzhou might be: "Miss, are you from Hong Kong?"
Cosmetics have reappeared in China only gradually since the early 1980's. Consequently, many women have to learn on their own how to use eye shadow instead of being taught by mothers or elder sisters. This need for tutoring gives Avon ladies, who offer beauty tips as well as mascara, a special advantage over department stores.
While Avon encourages its saleswomen to go door to door, this almost never seems to happen. Instead, the "elegant and fragrant ladies" typically bring their supplies to the workplace and offer products and advice to fellow workers. Some factories welcome such beauty classes as a kind of cultural program that will make employees more educated and sophisticated.
"We sell mostly to friends and to people in our 'work units,' " said Chen Jianhong, a 37-year-old government worker who moonlights for Avon. "I once studied a bit about beauty and makeup, so now I show my friends how to look better and also sell them some cosmetics."
Avon targets only the relatively prosperous consumers who can afford nearly $4 for a lipstick or face cream -- two of the best-selling products. By comparison, a typical monthly income for a factory worker is $40 or so. This makes Avon one of the handful of American companies to have cashed in successfully on the Chinese consumer market.
Avon is trying to expand sales of baby products to go along with cosmetics. It could be a large market. Most urban Chinese families are not allowed to have more than one child and consequently often fawn over their "little emperors" and buy them almost anything available.
"I'm going to focus on selling baby products," said Ms. Tian, the hotel secretary. "People will just gobble them up."

HEADLINE: Talking: Down Payment;
Saving To Buy a First Home

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
SAVING for a down payment when living expenses seem to constantly outstrip income is one of the perennial problems facing young couples eager to buy a first home. Moreover, interest rates on savings are now so low that a small nest egg is unlikely to grow into anything usable for a long time.
 "You get nothing from leaving your money in the bank," said Stuart Richardson, a graphic designer who will be married in Glen Cove, L.I., in October. Even worse, he added, "there are always so many bills coming in." 
Nevertheless, financial counselors and mortgage specialists insist there are still ways to make a saving plan work. Some believe part of the problem facing many young couples is lack of knowledge about managing personal finances, not lack of wherewithal.
 "I see couples coming in with a combined income of nearly $100,000 telling me it's impossible to save," said Susan Blevins, sales manager with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Madison, Conn.
 Marilyn Ashley agrees. She is a budgeting couselor for the Philadelphia office of Acorn, a national advisory and advocacy service for low- and moderate-income families that specializes in home purchase issues. The acronym "acorn" stands for the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now.
 "They're always so sure they'll never have enough," she said. "But once we start working with them they are amazed."
 A good way to start, say these professionals, is with a meticulous accounting of every penny spent. Ms. Ashley has her clients make up a four-week cash-flow chart that records all expenditures and income in detail.
 The charts have shown expenditures of as much as $120 a month on dry cleaning. Or the grocery receipts may show that the couple is not buying food and household supplies in a cost-effective manner. In such cases, Ms. Ashley will suggest ways of budgeting more carefully. If the couple is drawing cash too frequently with automatic teller cards or going on credit-card binges, she will recommend that they leave the cards at home.
 "If you write down every single thing you spend you can see immediately what's really going on," she said. Many of these young people are having a particularly difficult time, Ms. Ashley said, because they are imbedded in a culture that fosters instant gratification. For this reason she has her clients continue the financial log for several months, sending it to her for review.
 Couples who have managed to buy a first home agree that spending discipline is the key, along with a willingness to compromise living standards.
"You have to make the house your top priority, otherwise it will never work," said Paul Petro, an electrician from Milford, N.J. He and his wife, Maureen, took three years to save $20,000 for a down payment. "It was a question of no vacations, no new car and a lot of cutting down," Mr. Petro said.
 Other couples, in which both spouses work, agree to live on only one salary while banking the other. That can be difficult, particularly in high rent areas like New York.
 But what the issue really comes down to is the couple's priorities. If they have their hopes focused on a high-rise condominium on Third Avenue or a suburban town house town near a golf course, they may be willing to live temporarily in a cheap walkup railroad flat to build their down payment fund faster.
Since self-control seems to be part of the problem, some couples might use a savings plan that makes it hard for them to binge. One solution, said Ms. Ashley, is to open a savings account and have a fixed sum transferred into it each month automatically.
 An even more attractive modification was begun in March by Arbor National Mortgage of Westbury, L.I. Aware that many bridal couples are being showered with appliances and household items they really don't need and may already own, Arbor started its Home Bridal Registry to which friends can make cash contributions.
 THIS starts a couple on a down payment savings plan. Arbor contributes the first $100 to a savings account, which can be opened at any Chase Manhattan branch. It also provides cards that can be folded into wedding invitations saying the couple would be delighted with contributions to the account in lieu of another gift. Guests are told how and where to send the money.
 The couple is free to withdraw the funds at any time and is not compelled to buy a home with an Arbor mortgage (although Arbor is combining the idea with special incentives to encourage them to do so). The account can also be tied into an automatic monthly or quarterly transfer arrangement from their checking account. (For more details, call 800 272-6791.)
 "It's a classy way to help motivate the guests," ssid Diane Kuzma, a sales representative from East Northport, L.I., who will use the registry for her wedding in October.
 The plan could be easily set up independently, as could the one devised by Maria and Eric Callahan of West Milford, N.J.
 They were paying for their own wedding but were also eager to buy a home, so they decided to scale back, holding a wedding that was not as lavish as first planned.
 "We made a nice profit on the gift money that way," said Mrs. Callahan, an advertising manager. To avoid the temptation of spending it on other things, they also set up a special savings account.
 However, there may soon come a time when the interest being generated by a savings account may seem too paltry. When that happens, the couple should look for investments with higher earning power that will not jeopardize the principal.
 So many are now being offered that the couple may be overwhelmed by the possibilities. Their best course is to seek expert counsel, from parents, older siblings, colleagues at work, their bank manager or a professional investment specialist.
 The key fact to remember, is that higher returns usually meanhigher risks. Only government bonds and federally insured bank deposits are considered absolutely safe.
 Another alternative is to look into special home-loan programs that allow first-time buyers to get a mortgage with only a small down payment. Conventional loans require a down payment of 20 percent, a hurdle many young couples cannot leap no matter how carefully they save. Some programs offer loans with only 5 percent down. They are available through Federal and state agencies and even some private lenders. Infomation about these programs is available at most banks.

HEADLINE: Talking: Down Payment;
Saving To Buy a First Home

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
SAVING for a down payment when living expenses seem to constantly outstrip income is one of the perennial problems facing young couples eager to buy a first home. Moreover, interest rates on savings are now so low that a small nest egg is unlikely to grow into anything usable for a long time.
 "You get nothing from leaving your money in the bank," said Stuart Richardson, a graphic designer who will be married in Glen Cove, L.I., in October. Even worse, he added, "there are always so many bills coming in." 
Nevertheless, financial counselors and mortgage specialists insist there are still ways to make a saving plan work. Some believe part of the problem facing many young couples is lack of knowledge about managing personal finances, not lack of wherewithal.
 "I see couples coming in with a combined income of nearly $100,000 telling me it's impossible to save," said Susan Blevins, sales manager with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Madison, Conn.
 Marilyn Ashley agrees. She is a budgeting couselor for the Philadelphia office of Acorn, a national advisory and advocacy service for low- and moderate-income families that specializes in home purchase issues. The acronym "acorn" stands for the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now.
 "They're always so sure they'll never have enough," she said. "But once we start working with them they are amazed."
 A good way to start, say these professionals, is with a meticulous accounting of every penny spent. Ms. Ashley has her clients make up a four-week cash-flow chart that records all expenditures and income in detail.
 The charts have shown expenditures of as much as $120 a month on dry cleaning. Or the grocery receipts may show that the couple is not buying food and household supplies in a cost-effective manner. In such cases, Ms. Ashley will suggest ways of budgeting more carefully. If the couple is drawing cash too frequently with automatic teller cards or going on credit-card binges, she will recommend that they leave the cards at home.
 "If you write down every single thing you spend you can see immediately what's really going on," she said. Many of these young people are having a particularly difficult time, Ms. Ashley said, because they are imbedded in a culture that fosters instant gratification. For this reason she has her clients continue the financial log for several months, sending it to her for review.
 Couples who have managed to buy a first home agree that spending discipline is the key, along with a willingness to compromise living standards.
 "You have to make the house your top priority, otherwise it will never work," said Paul Petro, an electrician from Milford, N.J. He and his wife, Maureen, took three years to save $20,000 for a down payment. "It was a question of no vacations, no new car and a lot of cutting down," Mr. Petro said.
 Other couples, in which both spouses work, agree to live on only one salary while banking the other. That can be difficult, particularly in high rent areas like New York.
 But what the issue really comes down to is the couple's priorities. If they have their hopes focused on a high-rise condominium on Third Avenue or a suburban town house town near a golf course, they may be willing to live temporarily in a cheap walkup railroad flat to build their down payment fund faster.
 Since self-control seems to be part of the problem, some couples might use a savings plan that makes it hard for them to binge. One solution, said Ms. Ashley, is to open a savings account and have a fixed sum transferred into it each month automatically.
 An even more attractive modification was begun in March by Arbor National Mortgage of Westbury, L.I. Aware that many bridal couples are being showered with appliances and household items they really don't need and may already own, Arbor started its Home Bridal Registry to which friends can make cash contributions.
 THIS starts a couple on a down payment savings plan. Arbor contributes the first $100 to a savings account, which can be opened at any Chase Manhattan branch. It also provides cards that can be folded into wedding invitations saying the couple would be delighted with contributions to the account in lieu of another gift. Guests are told how and where to send the money.
 The couple is free to withdraw the funds at any time and is not compelled to buy a home with an Arbor mortgage (although Arbor is combining the idea with special incentives to encourage them to do so). The account can also be tied into an automatic monthly or quarterly transfer arrangement from their checking account. (For more details, call 800 272-6791.)
 "It's a classy way to help motivate the guests," ssid Diane Kuzma, a sales representative from East Northport, L.I., who will use the registry for her wedding in October.
 The plan could be easily set up independently, as could the one devised by Maria and Eric Callahan of West Milford, N.J.
 They were paying for their own wedding but were also eager to buy a home, so they decided to scale back, holding a wedding that was not as lavish as first planned.
 "We made a nice profit on the gift money that way," said Mrs. Callahan, an advertising manager. To avoid the temptation of spending it on other things, they also set up a special savings account.
 However, there may soon come a time when the interest being generated by a savings account may seem too paltry. When that happens, the couple should look for investments with higher earning power that will not jeopardize the principal.
 So many are now being offered that the couple may be overwhelmed by the possibilities. Their best course is to seek expert counsel, from parents, older siblings, colleagues at work, their bank manager or a professional investment specialist.
 The key fact to remember, is that higher returns usually meanhigher risks. Only government bonds and federally insured bank deposits are considered absolutely safe.
 Another alternative is to look into special home-loan programs that allow first-time buyers to get a mortgage with only a small down payment. Conventional loans require a down payment of 20 percent, a hurdle many young couples cannot leap no matter how carefully they save. Some programs offer loans with only 5 percent down. They are available through Federal and state agencies and even some private lenders. Infomation about these programs is available at most banks.

HEADLINE: Bare-Fisted Violence or Subtle Threats?

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB with DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
John Gotti's taste in clothing runs to what might be called the full Broadway look -- expensive double-breasted suits and silk ties of bright, bleeding colors complemented, of course, with matching pocket squares.
 Thomas Gambino dresses with the tailored restraint of the English or Milanese aristocracy, in dark, demure suiting made all the more understated by deep, monochromatic ties and French-cuffed white shirts. 
Mr. Gotti's most prominent charitable donations are the fire crackers he buys for the annual Fourth of July picnic in the Howard Beach, Queens, neighborhood where he maintains a simple split-level house.
 Mr. Gambino, who lives in a converted 19th-century mansion in the East 60's off Fifth Avenue, is president of the Gambino Medical and Science Foundation, which donated $2 million last year to Long Island Jewish Medical Center for bone marrow transplant work.
 At the heart of Mr. Gotti's enterprises are murder and bare-knuckle violence; at the heart of Mr. Gambino's, domination of a lucrative industry -- enforced, prosecutors say, by threats implied rather than executed.
 The group Mr. Gotti leads, the Gambino crime family, was molded by and named for Mr. Gambino's father, Carlo. Now with Mr. Gotti's conviction and likely lifetime imprisonment, the family faces a critical question: Will its new leader come from the "blue collar" wing of the family, led by Mr. Gotti, or the "white collar" wing of Mr. Gambino.
 In pure economic terms, the issue of who controls the family is significant for the New York metropolitan area and could ultimately affect some of the city's biggest legal businesses, including construction, garbage disposal, and garment manufacturing, as well as a host of illegal enterprises. The Gambino family, made up of 400 "made men" and thousands of associates, is a major force, with annual income that has been estimated at between $300 million and $500 million.
 Both Mr. Gotti and Mr. Gambino have not yet given up the struggle with prosecutors. Mr. Gotti's lawyers have vowed to appeal his sentence, and Mr. Gambino, who until pleading guilty in February to illegally gaining control of garment center trucking had never been convicted of a crime, steadfastly denies law-enforcement assertions that he is a long-standing captain in the Gambino family.
 The Gambino family is also fighting for its life. After years of successful state and Federal prosecutions, it faces the emergence of tough drug and street gangs made up of members of ethnic groups newer to the city, and the constant competition of the second largest old-line mob, the Genovese family, which has been relatively unscathed by a half decade of mob prosecutions.
 "I think the new leadership and how we handle it is critical as to whether there will be a powerful mob in the year 2000 or whether there will not be," said Michael Cherkasky, whose investigations unit of the Manhattan District Attorney's Office prosecuted Mr. Gambino.
 With the guidance of Mr. Gotti's turncoat underboss, Salvatore Gravano, law-enforcement officials are now trying to figure who is likely to take over after Mr. Gotti's sentencing in June -- one of the family's 21 captains or a particularly powerful soldier. But beyond the selection of one relatively unfamiliar name or another lies the underworld version, however sordid, of a corporate changing of the guard, with men representing different sides of the corporation's personality and vision vying for control of its future.
 Nowhere are these conflicting cultures personified more vividly than in these two men -- Mr. Gotti, 52 years old, the foul-mouthed dropout from Franklin K. Lane High School who became the erstwhile "Teflon Don," and Mr. Gambino, 62, the college-educated connoisseur of Italian wines whose assets include at least $75 million in cash, bonds, and blue chip stock.
 Prosecutors have not been as successful in determining Mr. Gotti's wealth, but on the witness stand Mr. Gravano said he turned over $1.2 million a year in proceeds from construction shakedowns.
 Testimony and evidence from the recent trials of Mr. Gotti and Mr. Gambino, who have long had dealings with each other, starkly underscores the differences between the two wings of the Gambino mob, differences shaped by organizational history, environment, family upbringing, and personality in much the same way as the differences between the business school graduates and the engineers that might vie for control of a major industrial corporation.
The United States Attorney for the Eastern District, Andrew J. Maloney, whose office successfully prosecuted Mr. Gotti, said he came from the family's "roughest wing" .
 "They were the shooters and the hijackers," said Mr. Maloney, describing the faction headed by Mr. Gotti's mentor, the family's late underboss, Aniello Dellacroce.
 
Gotti's Management Style
 The bottom line of Mr. Gotti's business philosophy came in one particularly chilling comment recorded and transcribed by Federal agents: "And every time we got a partner that don't agree with us, we kill him. You go to the boss and your boss kills him. He kills 'em. He O.K.'s it."
 It is a philosophy that often seemed to have other priorities than profits. Laura Ward, a Brooklyn Federal prosecutor who helped try Mr. Gotti, said the most surprising information that came out at his trial about the workings of the family was that loan sharks were allowed to keep all of their money rather than sending a sizable proportion up to the boss.
 Mr. Gotti's violent tendencies contrast with Mr. Gambino's creation: an elaborately detailed business cartel based on what one economist referred to as "the importance of being unimportant."
 In the trial of Mr. Gambino, which received far less national attention, a remarkably different view of business, one in which the limelight was to be shunned, in which 9 to 5 hours took the place of the all-night schmoozing of the Gotti faction, and in which physical force gave way to what prosecutors said were threats implied by the name recognition that accompanied "Gambino."
 As prosecutors outlined it, mob trucking companies took claim to every sweatshop in the city, even going so far as to divide Chinatown loft buildings floor by floor. Any piece of any garment going in or out of any shop would have to be carried by the trucker assigned to it by the mob.
 A manufacturer or sweatshop owner who used another trucker, or a taxicab, to handle pick-ups of piecework and finished garments simply received a bill from his assigned trucker anyway and was expected to pay for services not rendered.
 Nothing offered at this trial was as lurid as the 19 murders of which Mr. Gravano spoke in Brooklyn. The "salesmen" who worked for the garment trucking companies would merely tell customers that "the Gambinos" wanted things done a certain way, and customers would get the picture, according to prosecutors.
 As Elliot Spitzer, the lead prosecutor in the Gambino case, put it in his opening statement, "These defendants are businessmen. You'll hear that and you'll see it. But these are businessmen with a powerful partner, organized crime. It wields an iron fist inside a velvet glove."
 For Mr. Gambino, whose family controlled 60 percent of this trucking business, the profits were enormous, according to prosecutors.
 Mr. Gambino and his brother Joseph, also a defendant, each received an annual salary of about $2 million. Additionally, the Gambinos shared in the proceeds of a consortium of trucking companies whose profit margins were an astronomical 40 percent, according to Mr. Cherkasky.
 From 1989 to 1992, the Gambinos' four trucking companies had a gross revenue of $35 million. When the Government raided the operations, the largest of these companies, Consolidated Carriers, had $12 million in its company bank account.
 Prosecutors contend the scheme added as much as 7 percent to the price of each article of clothing. But they said manufacturers would not complain because of the Gambino name. Moreover, the cost of trucking is relatively small, compared to labor and material.
 Prosecutors said that Thomas Gambino wanted to avoid going to prison at all costs. In the middle of the trial, he and his co-defendants reached a deal with the Government: they admitted to an illegal scheme to monopolize trucking in the garment center, agreed to pay a $12 million fine, and to gradually get out of the business. They did not acknowledge threats, or mob involvement. Mr. Gambino still faces a Federal racketeering prosecution .
On tape, Mr. Gotti is remarkably stoic about the prospect of spending the rest of his life behind bars.
 Despite their differences, the two Gambino factions have much in common, according to prosecutors, including involvement in such crimes as gambling and loan-sharking.
 Mr. Gambino's uncle and mentor, Paul Castellano, who headed the family until he was murdered on Mr. Gotti's orders, in some ways bridged the gap between the two factions. He freely used thugs to enforce a web of illegal activities, said
 Mr. Maloney. But, he said, Mr. Castellano was also a businessman.
 "He wasn't a tough guy," said Mr. Maloney. "In some tapes he talked of how he wasn't really meant to be in this kind of life."
 Yet some prosecutors say that rather than deal with relatively sophisticated mob infiltration of legitimate business, they would rather tackle a crime family headed by a boss in Mr. Gotti's mold. The white collar faction is more of a long-term problem because it filters into the fabric of legitimate society and is much harder to prosecute, they said.
 The blue-collar wing, on the other hand, tends toward simpler crimes that are clearly illegal. "If you're dealing with drugs, you can catch them in one conversation and put them away for life," said Mr. Cherkasky.
 Ms. Ward was more dubious. More violent factions may commit simpler crimes, she said, but witnesses may be too afraid to come forward.
 The timing and circumstances under which Mr. Gotti's successor will be chosen are unclear. Mr. Gotti himself was selected with the approval of all the mob's captains after the murder of Mr. Castellano. When or where a similar succession meeting will take place this time is something that investigators are unsure about, adding that the mobsters themselves may be unsure at this point.
 Ronald Goldstock, the deputy attorney general in charge of the state Organized Crime Task Force, said that regardless of which faction the new boss comes from, he will be chosen from a stock depleted by years of successful prosecutions and a steady withering of quality in the family's ranks. The strongest candidates for the job may be smart enough not to want it, he said.

HEADLINE: Focus: Chicago;
Recession Snips a Hotel Off a Complex

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WHILE it is not exactly what the developer had in mind, a building is finally going up on North Michigan Avenue at Chestnut Street. Delayed for a year, the steel and concrete framing at 840 North Michigan outlines a structure less than a quarter the size of the one first planned.
Until late in 1990, the developer, U.S. Equities of Chicago, had envisioned a 28-story, 400,000-square-foot building with four stories of retail space topped by a 288-room Park Hyatt hotel. But Japanese financing from the Mitsui Trust and Orix was withdrawn in 1990 and other lenders refused to consider a project including a hotel in Chicago's overbuilt and under-occupied market. 
 Thus last October, with a new financing package in place from two European banks, U.S. Equities broke ground for a four-story 90,000-square-foot retail structure with spaces leased to international retailers, the Dutch-owned F.A.O. Schwarz, the German-owned Escada women's clothing stores and the British-owned Waterstone Booksellers.
"In the 1980's we would have built to the max," said Camille Julmy, a U.S. Equities vice president in charge of the project. "Now, maybe small is better, and being fully leased is best."
The property, with a seven-story building on the site, was bought in 1979 by the developer and two Chicago lawyers, Marshall Holleb and Robert Gerstein, who are joint-venture partners in the new development. They had to wait until 1990 to begin redeveloping the site because of two long-term leases in the old building.
By June 1990 the building had been vacated and demolition began. When the project was halted, the site had been cleared, two retail tenants were committed, working drawings by architects for the building were 80 percent completed and city permits for the foundations had been issued.
But Mr. Julmy said the hotel project was abandoned because "lenders didn't want to touch a hotel in Chicago." Recently published occupancy figures for last year showed a slump to 54.5 percent from 58 percent in 1990. BDO Seidman, an accounting firm, said an occupancy rate of 60 to 64 percent is considered the breakeven point for most hotels.
Mr. Julmy revised his plans, and he began outlining to lenders a smaller-scaled retail building that was already 80 percent leased to F.A.O. Schwarz and Escada.
But the conversations were renewed at a bad time. In 1990, many American banks, like Chase Manhattan, with whom U.S. Equities has had a long-time relationship, were reducing financing and the U.S. Equities project was refused several times.
Mr. Julmy said the creditworthiness of the project's tenants ultimately helped persuade Barclays Bank of England and Hypobank of Germany to provide construction financing. Indeed, Wolfgang Ley, founder and chairman of Escada, became an equity partner in the development.
Real estate professionals said it is notable that any development project obtained financing recently and they cite the robust health of retailing on North Michigan Avenue to explain why U.S. Equities' building was financed while others were not.
Retail experts routinely put Michigan Avenue in a class with Madison Avenue in New York and Rodeo Drive in Los Angeles. With 2.3 million square feet of retail space along what is called the "Magnificent Mile," the avenue is one of the most concentrated retail strips anywhere in the country.
THE site now under development stands in the heart of it. Directly across the street is the 610,000-square-foot Water Tower Place, the second-highest revenue-producing mall in the country, according to a retailing consultant, Howard Green of Troy, Mich. Last year's sales there were $640 a square foot.
On the mile-long North Michigan, total sales in 1991 were $965 million, according to the Greater Michigan Avenue Association, an increase of 3.5 percent over the previous year.
Such major stores as Bloomingdale's, Lord & Taylor, Marshall Field, Henri Bendel and Saks Fifth Avenue are represented on the avenue along with Gucci, Chanel, Louis Vuitton, and Tiffany.
In this company, competition for shoppers' attention is high. All three retailers leasing space in the U.S. Equities project will have high-visibility ground-floor space to capture the attention of strolling shoppers, in addition to space on one or more of the upper floors.
Instead of an entrance off a common lobby, each store will have a street entry with ground-floor display windows and an independent internal circulation of stairs or escalators.
At one time, the developer considered cooperating with I. Magnin's, the retailer next door, to create a mall with Magnin's as the anchor tenant. But that plan was abandoned in favor of the current configuration.
Now, Magnin's has announced it will be closing its 130,000-square-foot store, which is owned by Inland Real Estate, this June. Magnin's is owned by Macy's, which is in bankruptcy proceedings.
Tony Casasio of Inland Real Estate and local retail brokers say the space is unlikely to remain vacant for long, given the desirability of its location.
When the hotel was eliminated, the building was redesigned by Lucien Lagrange of this city's Lucien Lagrange & Associates. Large portions of service area, including below-grade parking for about 40 cars, some loading docks and all the tower elevator cores, were done away with, leaving more area for retail space.
The third tenant, Waterstone Booksellers, is a British chain that recently opened its first American store in Boston. It will have the less prominent entry on Chestnut Street and will occupy space on the ground-floor and second-floor levels as well as in the basement.
Waterstone will lease 20,000 square feet.
The developer would not disclose per-square-foot construction costs or rents for the project, but brokers with leasing experience on North Michigan say ground-floor rents are roughly $100 a square foot. For stores with ground-floor and upper-story space, blended rents are roughly $55 a square foot.
The common wisdom among brokers is that there are two kinds of shoppers on North Michigan, those who stay inside and shop the three vertical malls and those who stay on the street to shop the storefronts.
Belief in that theory would explain why retailers are willing to open stores with the same merchandise within blocks of one another. The Gap, Banana Republic and now F.A.O. Schwarz will all have stores on the avenue and in Water Tower Place.
F.A.O. Schwarz will retain its 3,000-square-foot store in Water Tower Place even after it opens a 32,000-square-foot space in the U.S. Equities project with space on the first, second and third stories. The toy retailer, which is owned by KBB, a Dutch retail group, has been expanding in recent years, opening stores in Union Square in San Francisco in 1989 and on Boylston Street in Boston in 1991. The new store in Chicago will be second in size second only to New York City's Fifth Avenue outlet.
Escada's 38,000-square-foot store in the new building will bring the clothier's dozen product lines under one roof. While several department stores on North Michigan already sell Escada products, the company has opened its own stores and expects to have nine open by the end of the year, including the flagship store at 7 East 57th Street in New York. The retailer is taking the premium space, with a corner entry and retail space distributed over all four stories of the building.
Completion of the building is planned for next fall, in time for the beginning of the Christmas selling season, when many retailers make as much as half their annual sales and profits.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
The Recession Snips Off a Chicago Hotel

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
While it is not exactly what the developer had in mind, a building is finally going up on North Michigan Avenue at Chestnut Street. Delayed for a year, the steel and concrete framing at 840 North Michigan outlines a structure less than a quarter the size of the one first planned.
Until late in 1990, the developer, U.S. Equities of Chicago, had envisioned a 28-story, 400,000-square-foot building with four stories of retail space topped by a 288-room Park Hyatt hotel. But Japanese financing from the Mitsui Trust and Orix was withdrawn in 1990 and other lenders refused to consider a project including a hotel in Chicago's overbuilt and under-occupied market. 
 Thus last October, with a new financing package in place from two European banks, U.S. Equities broke ground for a four-story 90,000-square-foot retail structure with spaces leased to international retailers, the Dutch-owned F.A.O. Schwarz, the German-owned Escada women's clothing stores and the British-owned Waterstone Booksellers.
"In the 1980's we would have built to the max," said Camille Julmy, a U.S. Equities vice president in charge of the project. "Now, maybe small is better, and being fully leased is best."
The property, with a seven-story building on the site, was bought in 1979 by the developer and two Chicago lawyers, Marshall Holleb and Robert Gerstein, who are joint-venture partners in the new development. They had to wait until 1990 to begin redeveloping the site because of two long-term leases in the old building.
By June 1990 the building had been vacated and demolition began. When the project was halted, the site had been cleared, two retail tenants were committed, working drawings by architects for the building were 80 percent completed and city permits for the foundations had been issued.
But Mr. Julmy said the hotel project was abandoned because "lenders didn't want to touch a hotel in Chicago." Recently published occupancy figures for last year showed a slump to 54.5 percent from 58 percent in 1990. BDO Seidman, an accounting firm, said an occupancy rate of 60 to 64 percent is considered the breakeven point for most hotels.
Mr. Julmy revised his plans, and he began outlining to lenders a smaller-scaled retail building that was already 80 percent leased to F.A.O. Schwarz and Escada.
But the conversations were renewed at a bad time. In 1990, many American banks, like Chase Manhattan, with whom U.S. Equities has had a long-time relationship, were reducing financing and the U.S. Equities project was refused several times.
Mr. Julmy said the creditworthiness of the project's tenants ultimately helped persuade Barclays Bank of England and Hypobank of Germany to provide construction financing. Indeed, Wolfgang Ley, founder and chairman of Escada, became an equity partner in the development.
Real estate professionals said it is notable that any development project obtained financing recently and they cite the robust health of retailing on North Michigan Avenue to explain why U.S. Equities' building was financed while others were not.
Retail experts routinely put Michigan Avenue in a class with Madison Avenue in New York and Rodeo Drive in Los Angeles. With 2.3 million square feet of retail space along what is called the "Magnificent Mile," the avenue is one of the most concentrated retail strips anywhere in the country.
The site now under development stands in the heart of it. Directly across the street is the 610,000-square-foot Water Tower Place, the second-highest revenue-producing mall in the country, according to a retailing consultant, Howard Green of Troy, Mich. Last year's sales there were $640 a square foot.
On the mile-long North Michigan, total sales in 1991 were $965 million, according to the Greater Michigan Avenue Association, an increase of 3.5 percent over the previous year. Such major stores as Bloomingdale's, Lord & Taylor, Marshall Field, Henri Bendel and Saks Fifth Avenue are represented on the avenue along with Gucci, Chanel, Louis Vuitton, and Tiffany.
In this company, competition for shoppers' attention is high. All three retailers leasing space in the U.S. Equities project will have high-visibility ground-floor space to capture the attention of strolling shoppers, in addition to space on one or more of the upper floors.
Instead of an entrance off a common lobby, each store will have a street entry with ground-floor display windows and an independent internal circulation of stairs or escalators.
At one time, the developer considered cooperating with I. Magnin's, the retailer next door, to create a mall with Magnin's as the anchor tenant. But that plan was abandoned in favor of the current configuration.
Now, Magnin's has announced it will be closing its 130,000-square-foot store, which is owned by Inland Real Estate, this June. Magnin's is owned by Macy's, which is in bankruptcy proceedings.
Tony Casasio of Inland Real Estate and local retail brokers say the space is unlikely to remain vacant for long, given the desirability of its location.
When the hotel was eliminated, the building was redesigned by Lucien Lagrange of this city's Lucien Lagrange & Associates. Large portions of service area, including below-grade parking for about 40 cars, some loading docks and all the tower elevator cores, were done away with, leaving more area for retail space.
The third tenant, Waterstone Booksellers, is a British chain that recently opened its first American store in Boston. It will have the less prominent entry on Chestnut Street and will occupy space on the ground-floor and second-floor levels as well as in the basement.
Waterstone will lease 20,000 square feet.
The developer would not disclose per-square-foot construction costs or rents for the project, but brokers with leasing experience on North Michigan say ground-floor rents are roughly $100 a square foot. For stores with ground-floor and upper-story space, blended rents are roughly $55 a square foot.
The common wisdom among brokers is that there are two kinds of shoppers on North Michigan, those who stay inside and shop the three vertical malls and those who stay on the street to shop the storefronts.
Belief in that theory would explain why retailers are willing to open stores with the same merchandise within blocks of one another. The Gap, Banana Republic and now F.A.O. Schwarz will all have stores on the avenue and in Water Tower Place.
F.A.O. Schwarz will retain its 3,000-square-foot store in Water Tower Place even after it opens a 32,000-square-foot space in the U.S. Equities project with space on the first, second and third stories. The toy retailer, which is owned by KBB, a Dutch retail group, has been expanding in recent years, opening stores in Union Square in San Francisco in 1989 and on Boylston Street in Boston in 1991. The new store in Chicago will be second in size second only to New York City's Fifth Avenue outlet.
Escada's 38,000-square-foot store in the new building will bring the clothier's dozen product lines under one roof. While several department stores on North Michigan already sell Escada products, the company has opened its own stores and expects to have nine open by the end of the year, including the flagship store at 7 East 57th Street in New York. The retailer is taking the premium space, with a corner entry and retail space distributed over all four stories of the building.
Completion of the building is planned for next fall, in time for the beginning of the Christmas selling season, when many retailers make as much as half their annual sales and profits.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Immigrants' Tales

BYLINE: By LEAH D. FRANK

 BODY:
"VAGABOND STARS," a musical at the Queens Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, takes a look at the Yiddish immigrants of the early part of the century and chronicles their trials and tribulations.
It is a well-worn theme, but like the "boy meets girl, boy loses girl" plot that propels so many stories, its retelling is satisfying in part because it is so well known. 
 Since 1607, when the first English settlers pushed the Indians out of Jamestown, more than 42 million people have migrated to the United States. The journey itself was difficult enough, and for many it involved economic hardship and physical and emotional trauma. Yet, getting into America was frequently as hard, if not harder, than getting to America in the first place.
One result of human conflict is the synthesizing of real-life drama into theater, film, art and literature. In this country, 70 percent of the immigrants who arrived between 1890 and 1910 were refugees from Eastern and southern Europe, and when they came they brought with them centuries of music and drama that they had incorporated into an expression of their emotions about their adopted land.
The vast multicultural movement gave rise to vaudeville, Yiddish theater, contemporary musicals like "Fiddler on the Roof" and even recent movies like "Moonstruck." A simple listing of the artistic legacy of the vast immigration would fill volumes.
"Vagabond Stars," a musical by Nahma Sandrow, Raphael Crystal and Alan Poul, and adapted from Ms. Sandrow's book "Vagabond Stars: A World History of Yiddish Theater," nestles comfortably into the theatrical body of immigrant tales.
In a series of sketches and songs, "Vagabond Stars" looks at the excitement and the loneliness of being a stranger in a strange land, where the only connection to the old country is a series of letters that form tattered, fragile links to former lives.
The creators of "Vagabond Stars" have adapted material from turn-of-the-century New York Yiddish theaters, and the show has the flavor of the pulsating Lower East Side with its romance, dreams, yearnings, hard work and bittersweet memories.
As directed by Christopher Catt, the numbers flow easily between song and sketch and between pathos and humor, and the five-member cast exudes an infectious aura of good will. In fact, if there is a problem with this production, it is that everything about it is too nice. The passion of a transplanted people is turned into something as insubstantial as spun-sugar candy. It is pretty and sweet, but completely umemorable.
The two women, Cynthia Firing and Guylaine Laperriere, have voices that carry all of the nuances within the songs. Eugene Flam, Fred Goldberg and John Patti are also capable vocalists. The five of them, designated points of a shining star, do their best to convey a sense of the diversity within the major influx of Jewish immigration. That they never manage to be anything more interesting than cute is a production flaw rather than a performance failure.
The stage is small and narrow, but the designer, Sarah Lambert, has pegged the flavor of the material by using scraps. They include bits of photographs of the Lower East Side with its crowded streets, posters from the Yiddish theater and headlines in Yiddish from The Jewish Forward. She has turned the curtain into a huge section of a passport, with its stamps and "official" signatures.
"Vagabond Stars" is pleasant, mild entertainment. In the comfortable cabaret setting of the Queens Theater's small downstairs space in the New York State Pavilion, it turns into a mellow evening of reminiscing. It will continue through May 24.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY Q & A: KEVIN MORIARTY;
How to Raise Funds in Difficult Times

BYLINE: By TINA TRASTER

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IT is not the best of times to be raising funds for a charitable organization. The recession has squeezed the foundations and individual donors who support charities. The scandal that has shaken the United Way, involving the forced resignation of its national president, William Aramony, has produced public unease and tightened purse strings.
But Kevin Moriarty, the executive director of the Fund for Educational Advancement, has learned optimism and the need to find new and creative solutions in his 20 years of fund raising. The fund raises money to send children to parochial schools in the Archdiocese of Newark. 
 Mr. Moriarty, a slim 46-year-old man whose hands move with the verve of a symphony conductor, said in an interview in his office here that creativity was the key to successful fund raising. "Candy and paper drives are being replaced by more sophisticated methods," he said.
He described some of these methods, which ranged from tree plantings to insurance policies; offered cautionary tales of fraudulent fund-raisers, and described how fund-raisers go about their business.
Mr. Moriarty joined the fund in 1988, four years after it was founded. In 1991, the organization gave $400,000 in tuition assistance to nearly 1,900 students in 200 schools throughout Hudson, Bergen, Union and Essex Counties that are part of the archdiocese.
Earlier, Mr. Moriarty spent 10 years at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange as a fund-raiser and director of community relations and did fund raising in the development department at St. Peter's College in Jersey City, his undergraduate alma mater. He also has a master's in business administration from Rutgers. Mr. Moriarty, who was recently widowed, lives in Verona.
Q. How would you define fund raising?
A. It is a form of selling. You need to sell your organization, sell the need. And the best way to do that is to translate the need on the human level, to define your need in terms of individuals. For example, the Jerry Lewis telethon does this successfully by making kids visible.
At F.E.A., students who are funded with scholarships stay in contact with their donors. They send handmade Christmas cards. They see their donors at an annual dinner.
Q. Is fund raising an art or a science?
A. It's both. Initially, it's a science. Before you are a fund-raiser, you are a matchmaker. You have certain needs, and you have to find the people who are interested in the needs. The art is the ability to communicate, to speak and write well.
Q. What is the best matchmaking method?
A. There about 30,000 foundations in the United States, and they all have tight guidelines as to where they give money, or what kinds of organizations they support, or amounts they give.
Q. Do you always rely on precedents?
A. Seldom do we spend time sending up trial balloons. The research materials available to fund-raisers are quite good and accurate. From these you can determine whether or not an organization will even entertain a request. Same on the corporate level. In fact, professionals at foundations or corporations will be offended if you come in and start asking for money for causes that do not remotely interest them.
Then you try to meet with someone, because you have a much better chance of asking for a grant in person than through the mail. The foundation or corporation will probably expect a formal proposal, which should include why you're asking for money, how much, what is the need, your operating budget.
Q. It seems fund-raisers are omnipresent. Is there a danger of burdening donors to a point of excess?
A. There are a lot of people out there looking for money. And it makes it more difficult for professional fund-raisers because people are bogged down with fancy direct-mail pieces and they are blitzed with phone calls around dinner time.
Q. What does that mean for professional fund-raisers?
A. We have to become more creative in our approach. A lot of fund-raisers send people little incentive gifts, a book, for example. So the mentality is 'You owe me something.' Except the person that receives something didn't ask for it.
Q. Where are the most innovative fund-raising ideas coming from?
A. Locally, it's from the hospitals. Recently, Hackensack Medical Center raised $170,000 during a one-night fund-raising event. They brought together 50 restaurants and created a taste of New Jersey, with different ethnic restaurants each presenting a top dish. They opened it to the public and charged $150 a head. Now other hospitals are organizing a similar event.
Q. Isn't insurance being used as a tie-in?
A. Absolutely. And it's being used more and more by universities. They get their alumni to take out life insurance policies in which the college or university is the beneficiary. The premium is tax deductible. There's also another way. If a donor makes a major gift to a university, the donation is tax deductible. He can then take the money he saves on income tax and use it to buy a life insurance policy.
Q. What new kinds of drives has the Fund for Educational Advancement undertaken?
A. One is called "Greening of the Garden State," a tree planting program that students from the Catholic schools participate in. Students solicit $5 donations for four trees. The schools keep $2.20; the F.E.A. keeps 50 cents. It's a lot more profitable than candy drives, where schools keep about 45 cents per bar.
We're also exploring a program that turns the students into "business executives." There is a health food company from Fairfield, Conn., that wants to launch a line of health snacks. The company wants to send professional marketers to the high schools to teach students how to distribute the product. If the students are successful, the schools will get a 10 percent cut of the profit.
Q. How is technology changing fund raising?
A. Television has dramatically impacted fund raising, both in good ways and bad. For example, the advent of cable, with its ability to target audiences, lets organizations like hospitals run localized telethons.
On the other hand, television has been exploited by disreputable evangelists. They have pulled off significant scams that take advantage of religious faith, for example, by promising people they will receive material benefits in this lifetime commensurate with what they donate.
Computer technology has also changed fund raising. It has refined direct mail. There may even come a time when requests for charity are sent via modem. This might be very effective to a targeted group.
Q. Are there other common scams?
A. Yes. One involves telemarketers who call and say they are with a newspaper for policemen or firemen or disabled veterans and they are selling ads. They use groups like the police, because every normal American has an affinity toward them. And they convince you to buy a $100 ad. They even come over and collect the check. But many of these so-called newspapers are bogus. They have no circulation. I've researched it.
Q. Given the recent scandals associated with fund raising, are donors becoming more careful?
A. There is good reason for anyone who is giving money to be concerned that it is going where it should. They should ask. Fund-raising organizations should be an open book, their operating expenses and budgets should be publicly accessible. Charities should be willing to show how much of the donation goes to administrative costs.
United Way always said 84 cents of every dollar went to community service. Whether it did or not is something a donor should be able to find out.
Q. What fund-raising methods are fruitless?
A. It's not worth wasting a lot of time and money on drives that will not produce a significant amount of income. For example, an organization decides to have a luncheon or flea market, and it mobilizes 50 people who form committees and work on the drive for four to five weeks, and in the end, they raise $5,000.
Well, you could say it's a success because it raised $5,000. But for all the time and manpower invested, you could mobilize 50 people much more cost effectively. Amateurs tend to gravitate toward projects that require a lot of work but do not produce enough income to address the need. And then it becomes hard to gear up people to have another drive.
Q. What motivates individuals and corporations to give to charity?
A. Except for some tremendously wealthy individuals who look for places to get tax relief and for some who desire positive public relations, I believe it is the human spirit and a social conscience that drives people to give.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kevin Moriarty, the executive director of the Fund for Educational Advancement, in his Newark office. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)
