HEADLINE: As Convention Nears, Uncertainty Clouds Impact

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
With the Democratic National Convention to open in Madison Square Garden 10 weeks from today, just what it will mean to New York City remains unclear. Even as the preparations shift into high gear, estimates of the impact on the local economy say more about the art of financial projection than about the count-the-dollars precision of an audit.
No one is sure, for instance, how to assess the official estimate that the city will somehow get between $200 million and $300 million worth of "media coverage" from a few days of international absorption with what goes on inside the Garden. 
 The first wave of coverage will begin this week when 1,000 out-of-town journalists arrive for a tour of out-of-the-way spaces inside the Garden that are being turned into meeting rooms where delegates can gather and press rooms where reporters can set up their portable computers. A similar tour for Democratic state chairmen is scheduled for next week.
 
Fiscal Forecast
 One question as the convention approaches is how much money it will bring to New York City. Roughly 20,000 Democratic delegates, alternates, guests and staff members are expected, along with 15,000 reporters, editors, producers and technicians assigned to cover them on and off the convention floor.
The city estimates that each of them will spend $353 a day. Factoring in everything from balloons and confetti to hotel renovations that are being rushed through in time for the delegates' arrival, the city is predicting that the convention will make the local economy $473 million richer, including $27 million in tax revenue. But forecasting how much the delegates will spend is like betting on sunshine for the Fourth of July.
Compounding the uncertainty is something that San Francisco discovered when it played host to the Democratic National Convention in 1984: political conventions are different from other kinds of conventions.
"I remember merchants saying they didn't see the numbers in the cash registers they were expecting," said Sharon Rooney of the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau, who at the time was working in Ghirardelli Square, an indoor mall with boutiques and restaurants near Fisherman's Wharf. "It may have been because the attendees were in so many free parties."
Still, the Democratic National Convention Committee says the convention was worth $55 million to San Francisco, and the 1988 convention pumped $70 million into the economy in Atlanta.
As for New York, economists who have reviewed the city's figures for this year say the assumptions behind the numbers are not unreasonable. But even John Altschuler, the economist who arrived at the $353-a-day figure the city used, said anticipating spending patterns is "metaphysical" -- more art than science.
 
Some High, Some Low
 The city's Finance Commissioner, Carol O'Cleireacain, who was not involved in preparing the estimates, found some figures on the city's four-page economic prospectus for the convention high. But she said they were offset by other numbers that seemed low. "As the British say, what you gain on the turns you lose on the roundabouts," she said.
No one expects those attending the convention to be working from "New York on $70 a Day." But preparing estimates for the city, which has some of the country's most expensive hotels, is tricky. The International Association of Convention and Visitors Bureaus says the nationwide average for convention delegates last year was $688 for a four-day gathering; the city is figuring on about $1,400.
The uncertainty does not end there. One figure that Ms. O'Cleireacain said should probably have been higher was the amount that journalists would spend. The city's estimate is $37.06 million, based on 15,000 reporters and technicians spending at least seven days in New York. She said that about half of the journalists covering the convention would spend at least a week in town before it began, for a total of two weeks, twice as long as the city estimated.
She also said the city's figures assumed that news organizations spent money "as if they were regular tourists" -- in other words, the figures did not take into account big-budget items like equipment rentals and satellite fees for television and radio.
Rosemary Scanlon, an economist with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, questioned the way that the city tallied the $189.8 million cost of renovating two midtown hotels, the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers and the Sheraton Manhattan. She said the full cost should not have been included, since some renovation work would have been done even if the Democrats had not chosen New York for the convention.
 
Pricing the Spotlight
 Other benefits of playing host to the convention are not so easy to quantify, even though the convention planners have tried. One such benefit, mentioned often by convention planners and city officials, is the psychological bonus that comes from being in the spotlight. This applies only if everything goes according to plan, as it did when the Democrats met in Madison Square Garden in 1976.
This time around, the city is counting on the four-day convention to provide between $200 million and $300 million worth of favorable publicity in the form of live national television coverage and newspaper articles.
"Assuming there are no major disasters while the convention is going on and it doesn't become like Chicago in 1968," said Louis Masotti, an economist who teaches at the University of California at Irvine, "the long-term effect could be revisits from people who had crossed New York off their list."
Marshall Murdaugh, the executive director of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, is already concerned that tourists will be frightened away by what he calls "the big-event syndrome." At the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles and the 1984 World's Fair in New Orleans, he said, attendance fell far short of expectations, as was the case during the Bicentennial celebration in 1976.
"In Philadelphia, Boston, Washington," he said, "on July 5 you could have shot a cannon through hotel lobbies and not hit anybody because a lot of people, fearing the promise of crowds, just stayed home."
The city now has 70,000 hotel rooms. Noting that the convention is going to use only 22,000 of them, Mr. Murdaugh said: "We don't want people staying away because they think the city is sold out."

HEADLINE: Store Chain In Bankruptcy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CANTON, Mass., May 3

 BODY:
The convenience store chain Cumberland Farms Inc. has filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors.
Hurt by the recession and slumping real estate values, the privately held company had been trying for several months to work out a new arrangement with its lenders, said Foster Macrides, vice president for human relations. 
 The effort collapsed when the biggest lender, the Industrial Bank of Japan Trust Company, balked at the plan, Mr. Macrides said. Cumberland's 70 other real estate lenders and trade creditors had supported the plan, the company said.
Cumberland made its filing on Friday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Worcester, Mass.
"We wanted to restructure to give us some breathing room," Mr. Macrides said. "We've been operating in a recessionary economy, especially here in the Northeast. And real estate values have suffered some declines."
The Chapter 11 filing gives Cumberland time to rework its finances while protected from meeting obligations to creditors.
"It's business as usual during this period," Mr. Macrides said.
Cumberland operates 973 convenience stores and gas stations in 12 states and employs 8,000. It also owns and operates Gulf Oil in the Northeast, and sells gasoline to some 2,500 service stations.
Mr. Macrides said the company did not anticipate any layoffs or store closings.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Lights, Action, Nascar: Charlotte's New Nightspot

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO

 BODY:
You could refer to what will happen at Charlotte Motor Speedway two weeks from now as the dawn of an era in stock-car racing. But considering the schedule of events on May 16, it's more of a sunset on the age when racing lasted only as long as the daylight.
On that date, Charlotte Speedway, a 1.5-mile superspeedway in the heart of stock-car country, will turn on the switch of a $1.7 million, 1.2 billion candlepower lighting system and at about 8:58 P.M. Eastern time, the Winston, a 105-mile series of sprint races, will be held under those lights. 
 This will not be the first time that an event on Nascar's most prestigious circuit will take place at night. Bristol International Raceway in Tennessee and Richmond International Raceway in Virginia hold a Winston Cup race at night each year.
 
Trend for Long Tracks?
 But Charlotte is longer than those two tracks combined, and if its owners can prove that a superspeedway can successfully and economically be illuminated, it could light the way for other long tracks on the Winston Cup circuit to do the same.
And that could open up room for new tracks on the crowded 29-race Winston Cup schedule.
Most of the hundreds of tracks in the United States are small ovals of less than a half-mile in length, said Humpy Wheeler, president and general manager of Charlotte Motor Speedway, and just about all of them run weekly programs on Friday and Saturday nights, featuring local heroes on the bottom rungs of the sport. "So it's just a logical extension of the grass-roots of racing," Wheeler said, describing Charlotte's decision to go to lighting.
By being able to race at night, Wheeler said, his track could hold a race in summer, normally too hot for a daytime event.
 
In Case of Rain
 Charlotte's main race is the Coca-Cola 600, run on Memorial Day weekend. "If we ran into problems, say, with the 600 and we only had 210 miles in and it rained, we could finish the race under the lights," Wheeler said.
"And track rentals near urban areas are a big source of revenue," he said, adding that last year the track was rented for 254 days, close to its limit. "This will literally be able to double our track rental," Wheeler said.
Even though Charlotte's 600-mile race draws more than 100,000 spectators, it exists in the shadow of a certain race held that weekend in Indiana. But the lights could help eliminate that shadow.
"We might look at moving back the starting time," Wheeler said, referring to the 600-mile race. With the Indy 500 starting at noon and ending about 3 P.M., a later start in Charlotte could eliminate much of the conflict in television scheduling.
 
Extensive but Inexpensive
 There are 1,200 fixtures -- each with a 1,500-watt bulb -- in Charlotte's lighting system, which was designed and installed by Musco Lighting, an Iowa firm that also lit the movie "Dances With Wolves" and the Statue of Liberty rededication.
Despite all that illumination, needed to be so bright because the cars don't use headlights, Wheeler estimated his electric bill would be only $200 per hour. "We knew that going in," said Wheeler. "That's the first thing we checked." He credited the efficiency of Duke Power, the local utility, for the low cost.
Paul Sawyer, president of Richmond Raceway, spoke about the benefits of night racing last September, a few hours before the lights went on for his Winston Cup race.
"I'm not saying I'm setting a trend," Sawyer said, "but the way I look at it, I've never been in favor of Monday rain dates."
He had to use one in 1988, and it caused traffic nightmares because the track is on one of the main highways linking Richmond to its suburbs. "I had people sitting in line three hours, and they never could get in the raceway because of the traffic," Sawyer said.
Now, by being able to schedule a race Saturday night, Sawyer has a Sunday rain date to fall back on.
He thinks that if more Winston Cup tracks light up and go to Saturday race dates, some of the weekends kept open as rain dates could be used for events at new tracks.
Sawyer rebuilt the Richmond track in 1988. Between his race in February and the one in September, he tore it down completely and replaced it with a modern three-quarter-mile track that now has about 60,000 seats.
His isn't the only first-class oval track in the country. At least two others -- Pennsylvania International Raceway in Nazareth and New Hampshire International Speedway in Loudon -- want a Winston Cup race, but Nascar can't find room on the schedule.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Racing under Charlotte's lights could signal a change in Nascar events. (Charlotte Motor Speedway)

HEADLINE: Freezing Government, Cont'd.

 BODY:
Is President Bush interested in making government more efficient? Or does he aim to paralyze it? Those questions arise now that he has extended for an additional 120 days a 90-day freeze on new Federal regulation.
The first 90 days suggest an answer: The moratorium smacks of an election-year conversion to improve Mr. Bush's standing with conservatives and business interests that abhor regulation. Having presided over three years of increased regulation by regulators of his own choosing, he suddenly decided in January that they were doing their jobs too well, and ordered them to stop. 
 It's difficult to say what the first 90 days achieved; officials concede as much. Mr. Bush claims the moratorium already promises savings of more than $15 billion a year in reduced regulatory costs to businesses and consumers. He makes no mention of the added costs of dirtier air, less information for investors and watered-down consumer protection.
No doubt justified savings will be realized. But Mr. Bush's billions include speculative benefits, disputed even by some businesses that stand to benefit, and pure flim-flam. Example: Under the Clean Air Act, fumes at gas stations in cities that have smog problems must be contained. By killing a proposed rule that new cars be fitted with a canister to capture the fumes at the gas pump, the Administration placates the auto industry -- but transfers the cost to gas stations and oil companies.
Mr. Bush says he aims only to eliminate regulations that are unnecessarily burdensome -- and, goodness knows, there are plenty. During the 90-day pause, agencies were told to review all existing regulations while they halted work on any new ones that block economic growth. There is nothing wrong with revisions to meet changed conditions. But that should be constant, not a crash program in the fourth year of a floundering Administration.
Going far beyond useful review, eager executors of Mr. Bush's stop order are using it to sabotage law that the President is sworn to uphold, most notably the Clean Air Act, which he has trumpeted as his main environmental accomplishment.
A key provision of that act requires industries to get new permits before they increase air pollution, with "opportunity for public comment" before permission is granted. But the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed regulation has been stalled by Vice President Quayle's defiant attempt to insert a loophole that would bypass the requirement for public review.
Far from streamlining regulation, such efforts produce paralysis, which hurts industry planners as much as anyone. By the end of the new extension, the regulatory process will have been frozen for seven months. It's hard to see how that serves the public interest. It's easier to see how it fuels Mr. Bush's campaign for re-election.

HEADLINE: Toyota Plant in Kentucky Is Font of Ideas for U.S.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Ky.

 BODY:
The ideas about factory work that the Toyota Motor Corporation was promoting around horse country here at first seemed too simple to be significant, the formulations of people who had only just noticed that thoroughbreds thrive on bluegrass.
But as Toyota rules were tested -- as the company installed cords for workers to pull for help, which they do an average of 3,500 times a day, and systems were developed to improve efficiency and prevent assembly line mistakes -- the brilliance of their simplicity was difficult to deny. 
 As more and more Camrys were built, accolades for the car poured in. Experts from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology came and concluded that Toyota's methods could help a factory make everything more efficiently, from cars to copiers, jet engines to dishwashers.
In the four years that Toyota has been making engines and cars here, tens of thousands of manufacturing executives and production engineers have journeyed here. Indeed, 20,000 came last year alone, convinced that what is happening here can change the American way of mass production.
"The principles of the Toyota production system apply everywhere," said Gary McClimans, a partner in Arthur Andersen & Company's manufacturing consulting practice. "Virtually every U.S. manufacturer is trying some elements of the Toyota system."
Not that the Toyota plant is perfect. Critics charge that its employees are overworked and that its cars contain relatively few American-made parts.
But by now, the terms of Japan's production techniques -- just-in-time inventories, zero defects and continuous improvement -- are familiar to American manufacturers. And the pressing need to make America a more efficient producer has heightened interest in the plant.
"Anybody who competes with the Japanese has to come and see this," said James P. Womack, a Boston manufacturing consultant who was involved in the M.I.T. study.
Richard Delott, a longtime engineer at the Whirlpool Corporation, came to Georgetown last February. He had first studied the Toyota system in the mid-1980's, when Whirlpool started adopting Japanese manufacturing principles in its factories. Mr. Delott marveled at several things, including the elaborate programs that teach workers and supervisors to learn multiple tasks.
"Without a doubt, Toyota has become the benchmark of the world," said Heinz Prechter, chairman of the ASC Corporation, a Southgate, Mich., supplier that makes sunroofs and convertibles for Toyota, the Big Three and several European auto makers. "They truly have the vision, and what we need in this country is to find a way to be as good or better."
In this election year, the General Motors Corporation is searching for efficiencies by closing plants and preparing to eliminate more than 70,000 jobs, and politicians are debating whether Japan has captured -- perhaps unfairly -- nearly a third of the American car market. But what is often overlooked is that Japanese auto makers have successfully transplanted their work habits to America, hired tens of thousands of people here and built showcase factories.
 
'Lean Production' Eliminates Waste
 Toyota has succeeded by turning the mass-production principles behind Henry Ford's assembly line on their head. The result is what an M.I.T. researcher has dubbed "lean production."
Where Ford believed that the cheapest way to build Model T's was to churn out huge numbers by having workers repeatedly perform a single task, Toyota discovered in the early 1950's that a smaller number of workers, each capable of doing several jobs, can turn out cars with less inventory, less investment, and fewer mistakes.
Predictably, Toyota's biggest impact so far has come in auto making. The manufacturing ethic of Toyota has rippled from its own plant to its 174 suppliers in the United States and to hundreds of other suppliers.
For example, when a United Technologies Corporation plant in Morganfield, Ky., won the job of making the Camry's plastic center console, which divides the front seat, Toyota asked workers to scrutinize their tasks by calculating how many seconds each movement took. The aim: to eliminate every bit of "muda," the Japanese word for waste.
Under Toyota's watchful eye, ordinary line workers held stopwatches, analyzed videotapes and proposed improvements that yielded startling efficiencies. The time it took to change dies in some plastic-injection-molding machines dropped from an hour to less than half an hour. Encouraged to pitch in with their own ideas, workers invented a heating process that eliminated costly minutes of down time for the presses.
"Since I arrived here in 1983, nothing has changed our plant as much as the way Toyota taught us to look at all the little things," said Ken Franklin, the plant manager.
Critics, including the United Automobile Workers union, some Big Three executives and important lawmakers, however, have charged -- and Toyota has denied -- that Toyota's American operations add little value or domestic content because the plant merely assembles kits made in Japan.
 
Amount of U.S. Parts In Camrys Is Disputed
 "What's happening at Georgetown is the final assembly of cars and engines and not much more," said Sean McAlinden, a senior researcher at the University of Michigan. "No more than 25 percent of the car's value is added at Georgetown."
Toyota says nearly 75 percent of the parts in its Camrys are American made and points to a growing number of supplier plants that employ workers in a more effective, creative manner than do many American factories.
The union also says it believes that the Toyota system is a well-disguised plot to make the 4,125 employees here work faster. Specifically, the Toyota production system has been opposed by an advocacy wing of the union, which represents workers at three joint-venture plants between Japanese auto makers and Detroit. The U.A.W. has never tried to represent Toyota workers here, but it was thwarted at the Nissan Motor Company and the Honda Motor Company.
Classic mass production tries to maximize output by running machines with as few interruptions as possible. Each worker has one or two tasks, repeated over and over. Skilled specialists set up and maintain machines, but the goal is always the same: to keep machines running.
By contrast, workers in a lean-production environment learn numerous jobs and shoulder broader responsibility, including maintenance, inspection and machine setup. With a flexible work force that can perform a variety of skills, Toyota and other lean producers are able to stop machines often. They must do so to keep batches of parts or partially completed cars small.
As workers change the type of part each machine makes, they also note and record every minor glitch, no matter how slight. If necessary, they can stop production to get help to correct a problem.
By making relatively small batches of parts that are delivered only as needed, inventory costs are kept small. Moreover, if a defective part is spotted, the manufacturing error is corrected instantly.
To encourage immediate reporting of problems, managers constantly praise workers who pull the "andon" (the Japanese word for "lantern") cord. The cord causes a light to flash, signaling a team leader that a worker needs help; if the problem cannot be resolved in one minute -- as most problems can be -- the assembly line stops automatically. About 93 percent of the time, the line keeps moving.
"The cord is a team member's communication device to make sure a problem is taken care of," said Mike DaPrile, Toyota's assembly plant manager.
The Georgetown plant, with its network of suppliers nearby, more closely matches how Toyota operates in Japan. By shortening the distance between supplier and assembler, the amount of inventory cost is reduced. Parts arrive constantly.
 
Pressure on Suppliers To Make No Mistakes
 "If we ship 601 parts when the order calls for 600, we get gigged," said Michael Sherman, a manager of Braun Engineering in Detroit, which makes a part for the Camry's disk brakes. "If parts arrive early we get gigged. Every mistake is a demerit. When we started a few years ago our score was 62 percent. Within 18 months it was 99 percent and it stayed that way. If your score is low and doesn't improve you can lose the business."
By contrast, Mr. Sherman added, Braun routinely built tens of thousands of extra parts for Detroit auto makers -- increasing costs enormously.
By way of criticism, many American supply companies that have not landed contracts with Japanese companies -- Toyota in particular -- say that the Japanese qualifications for suppliers exclude most American companies and that the Japanese companies tend to favor their "keiretsu," the family of suppliers with which they are affiliated in Japan.
Nowhere does lean production differ more boldly from mass manufacturing than in its philosophy toward workers.
To insure that no job is too difficult -- or too easy -- a team of workers calculates how many seconds each task should take. Then, according to the speed of the assembly line, red lines are drawn signifying where the car should be when work begins and where it should be when the work is done.
Workers are trained not to start work before the car reaches the first line and to complete the job before it reaches the second line. If the task can be completed in less time or cannot be completed in the time allotted, then the job is redesigned.
Last October, the members of Toyota's team A-110 threw a party to celebrate staying within the red lines. They were rewarded with red cream soda, red chewing gum and red-hot candy, and names were drawn for two tickets to a Cincinnati Reds game.
The Toyota system has spread to the company's suppliers. "Our associates operate machines, set them up, inspect for quality, perform minor maintenance, clean up, offer suggestions," said Carl Lay, vice president of corporate relations for the Ambrake Corporation in Elizabethtown, Ky., a joint venture between the Akebono Brake Industry Company, a Japanese brake maker, and G.M.
In some American plants, union work rules would make such a system impossible.
Ambrake operates no time clocks, and it enjoys an absentee rate of less than five-tenths of 1 percent. Absenteeism of 10 percent or more is not unusual in United States auto plants.
"Here it's more like a family," said Diana Hobbs, 40 years old, of rural Hardin County, Kentucky, who assembles brakes. "Supervisors listen to you and everyone works together." At textile plants where she worked previously, she continued, "if I had a problem, there was no one to discuss it with."
Not all American workers have flourished in Japanese-owned auto plants. For example, Dennis Pawley, now executive vice president for manufacturing at the Chrysler Corporation, worked for two years as manager of the Mazda Motor Corporation's plant near Detroit. He left because, he said, his Japanese superiors ignored his contributions.
 
Low-Tech Tricks By the Thousand
 Since the 1950's, Toyota and Japanese manufacturers that studied Toyota have perfected thousands of little low-tech tricks, like visual markings or cartoon sketches that are posted everywhere to prevent almost every conceivable factory floor foul-up.
Toyota suggests, for example, that all dies needed in a set for making a particular part should be painted one color. That way it is easy to see if the wrong die is being used. A machine operator knows the safest and most efficient place to stand because yellow foot-prints mark the spot.
Instead of laser inspection used in some American plants, Toyota has introduced "poke-yoke" fixtures that prevent defective parts from fitting into a machine or moving on a conveyor. The Japanese word "poke-yoke" roughly translates as "fool proof."
Toyota's assembly and engine plant has been an economic godsend to a region hurt by falling farm employment, particularly in tobacco, and cutbacks in areas like coal mining. Toyota jobs, with average pay of about $17 an hour, are highly prized. Workers from 111 of Kentucky's 120 counties commute by car, a few almost three hours each way.
"I'm one of the fortunate who have been able to stay in central Kentucky," said Gene Murphy, who had worked for Clark Equipment until the plant closed in the mid-1980's. He is assistant plant manager of the Vuteq Corporation in Georgetown, a subsidiary of Chuba Industries of Japan that makes sunroofs and rear windows for the Camry. He has many Japanese friends and a son who studies Japanese at school, and he named his bassett hound Inu -- Japanese for "dog."
"It's easy to be a manager for a Japanese company," Mr. Murphy said, "because you are striving for common goals with the people you manage. The work is oriented toward them and toward customers, not just making production schedules."

 1. If the worker spots a flaw in the production process, he pulls a cord to alert his group leader.
 2. The group leader is notified when a quality-control board lights up.
 3. She responds in one of two ways: stopping the production line or having the flaw fixed while the car is still on the production line.

 Duties: Installing wheels and tires.
 The worker is limited to one task at a time, and does not call attention to flaws made during the production process.

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: The President;
WHITE HOUSE LINKS RIOTS TO WELFARE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The White House said today that the riots last week in Los Angeles were a result of social welfare programs that Congress enacted in the 1960's and 70's, but it refused to say publicly whether President Bush would offer any detailed alternative to those "failed" policies in coming weeks.
Other senior officials said that Mr. Bush favored an extensive lobbying campaign to enact and expand conservative social legislation that Congress has not enacted. 
 While the White House may also propose some additional programs, they are likely to be small, and the Administration does not contemplate "dramatic" new Federal spending should they be put into effect, the officials said.
 
Plans for Visit May Change
 One official also said Mr. Bush may now travel to California on Wednesday evening, a half-day before he had been scheduled to go there, to create time for a "hands-on" tour of areas affected by the Los Angeles riots.
After a meeting this morning with several Cabinet members, the President ordered the Deputy Secretary of Education, David Kearnes, to go to Los Angeles to coordinate Federal relief efforts.
The White House said today that it would supply $100 million in Federal disaster aid to riot victims and an additional $200 million to rebuild damaged areas and that the Small Business Administration would provide up to $400 million in loans to rebuild businesses. Property damage is still being assessed, but Mayor Tom Bradley has estimated it at $500 million.
Mr. Bush told reporters this morning that his Administration had "some very good proposals out on the table right now, proposals who clearly have come of age," and said that he would consider them in detail later this week.
"I'm very pleased that it has calmed down out there," he said.
But the main thrust of the White House response was political, which is the way it was described by the President's spokesman.
 
Taking Aim at 60's Programs
 "We believe that many of the root problems that have resulted in inner city difficulties were started in the 60's and 70's and that they have failed," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said. Pressed for examples, he said, "I don't have a list with me."
Mr. Bush and other Republicans have often asserted that the Great Society programs fostered by President Lyndon B. Johnson, a Democrat, in the 1960's, at the time of the last major urban riots, made poverty and other social problems worse instead of better.
Mr. Fitzwater contended today that "liberal Democrats" in Congress had prevented Mr. Bush and his Republican predecessor, President Ronald Reagan, from winning approval of many changes in welfare policies and social programs that might have helped avert last week's disturbances.
The remarks placed the White House response to the Los Angeles disturbances squarely in an election-year political context, only days after Mr. Fitzwater had berated Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, for criticizing Mr. Bush's initial reaction to the riots.
On Thursday, Mr. Fitzwater had called Mr. Clinton "Slippery Bill" and accused him of playing politics with a national tragedy. This weekend, Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said that Mr. Clinton's comments "stooped to partisan demagoguery" on the issue.
But today, Mr. Fitzwater said that he was trying to show reporters "what our direction is" by creating a stark contrast between "destructive" social programs supported by past Democratic Congresses and Mr. Bush's "conservative agenda that creates jobs and housing and home ownership and involvement in the community."
"This is a political year, and there's no doubt about it that everybody is going to have their own solutions," he said. "And so, it's time to hit it head on, so here's how we look at it."
Many of the social programs of the 1960's and 1970's, especially the most expensive and comprehensive ones, have become part of the fabric of American life. They include yearly increases in Social Security retirement benefits to keep pace with inflation; Medicare health insurance for the elderly and disabled; Medicaid medical care for the poor; aid for schools pegged to the number of poor children who attend them, and food stamps, which subsidize grocery purchases for about 1 in 10 Americans.
Mr. Bush criticized some of those programs, without explicitly naming them, in a commencement speech one year ago today at the University of Michigan. In it, he called the Johnson Administration's Great Society a noble crusade that backfired, addicting welfare recipients to Federal checks, breeding lassitude and weakening citizens' "moral sensitivity" to their families and fellow men.
 
A Conservative Agenda
 By contrast, the conservative proposals that Mr. Bush said today that he would push for generally couple Federal aid to the poor with programs that stress self-reliance and provide financial incentives to work and learn.
The proposals include ones to give Federal tax breaks to businesses that invest in inner cities, give tenants greater control of public-housing projects and give parents education vouchers that could be used to place their children in private schools.
"Bush believes, and we believe, that those proposals are basically sound," said an official who would speak only if he was not named, adding that the President plans a "reinvigorated" effort to secure their enactment.
A few programs, like one that allows poor tenants to buy apartments in public-housing projects, have become law in pared-back form. But even Mr. Bush's advisers agree privately that most have received only tepid support from the President.
In recent weeks, the Bush Administration has sought to reduce one major social-welfare program, proposing on March 20 to eliminate from the budget for the 1993 fiscal year $547.7 million to build new public housing.
The Administration argued that public housing would cost more to build than equivalent private housing and that low-income tenants could be provided housing through other programs that are less wasteful.
The proposal was part of $3.6 billion in Federal programs that Mr. Bush is seeking to wipe out of the budget as part of an effort to depict the Democratic Congress as free-spending and irresponsible. Mr. Bush proposed the cuts after Congress refused to enact the complete version of an economic-growth package that he proposed in his State of the Union Message in January.

HEADLINE: After the Cold War -- Views From Japan;
Tokyo in the New Epoch: Heady Future, With Fear

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 4

 BODY:
No country prospered more during the cold war than Japan, and perhaps no country is more wistful for that era's comforting certainties. While the United States and Europe were preoccupied with throw weights and satellite photographs, Japan was able to focus almost entirely on building an economy that became the envy of the world, largely undistracted by, and often profiting from, the superpower rivalry.
For several years now the Japanese have known that those heady days were coming to an end. Nonetheless, the cold war's demise caught this country strangely ill prepared, forcing it to recast its dealings with its main ally, the United States, and break out of a four-decade stalemate in its diplomatic relations with its most powerful Asian neighbors. 
 Though still bound to be dominated by economic issues, the 1990's will also be a test of Japan's ability to overcome its reflexive isolationism, to become an independent political power without arousing those who are already deeply anxious about its economic might.
 
New Security Rationale Sought
 For the United States, Japan's search raises a question that officials on both sides of the Pacific are just beginning to discuss publicly: What is the new rationale for a security alliance intended to give Japan protection in return for America's biggest, strongest Pacific outpost against Communism?
Though the Bush Administration insists that it remains deeply committed to a forward deployment here, especially as long as tensions remain on the Korean Peninsula, many here believe that it is only a matter of time before America's 56,000 troops here are reduced to a largely symbolic force.
"What we are concerned with is an America turning inward, politically and economically," said Takakazu Kuriyama, a former Deputy Foreign Minister and now Ambassador to the United States.
Others share his fear, not least because America's presence reassures Japan's neighbors.
 
Is Japan Next U.S. Rival?
 But the prospect of a reduced American role in the Pacific is only part of what leaves the Japanese uneasy. In the Japanese press and on television it often seems the conventional wisdom that America has a psychological need for a rival, and that Japan is next in line. Such views may be more widely repeated than deeply held; polls show that while there is a deepening distrust and disillusionment with the United States, Japanese still regard America as their closest -- and perhaps only -- true friend in the world.
But it is a measure of Japan's insecurity on this point that books with titles like "The Coming War With Japan" are always much bigger sellers here than in the United States, and a recurrent theme in manga, the thick comic books read by millions of Japanese workers on the subways, is an American military once again at battle with Japanese forces.
Without question, such popular views have a subtle effect on the way Japanese view their own future relations with the rest of the world, making them feel that they are increasingly being cast out to fend for themselves. But some believe that such a change is overdue, that America's domination of Japanese security policy has delayed Japan's maturation as a truly independent state.
"In a sense we are politically in transition, from being dependent on U.S. policy to an independent status," said Saburo Okita, a former Foreign Minister. "But our politics have been so dependent that we still cannot make our own decisions."
Nothing has made that clearer than the two continuing debates that have seized Japan this year: whether to demand a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council and whether to create a peacekeeping force that could be sent on United Nations missions, violating a taboo against "collective security" arrangements that dates to the end of World War II.
The Tokyo Government has not wanted to appear to be openly seeking the Security Council seat, even though countries with far less economic power sit there today. But there is also an underlying fear that Japan, if given a bully pulpit, may have little to say. "We might be ashamed to raise our hand," Seiki Nishihiro, a former Deputy Defense Minister, said during a recent conference.
 
Peacekeeping
Fear of Sending Troops Abroad
 The debate over a peacekeeping force has been marked by ambivalence of another sort. Ever since the Persian Gulf war, the Government has tried to push through a bill that would create a lightly armed organization that could be sent out entirely under United Nations command. From the outside it appears innocuous. Yet twice the bill has been defeated, and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's tenure in office may depend on his ability to pass it in the next few months.
While few will say so explicitly, the debate over the peacekeeping bill seems to be motivated by a broader question: Does the Japanese public yet trust its Government enough to send the military abroad, without fear that it could once again veer toward the expansionist militarism that got the country into World War II?
Over the last year, it has become increasingly clear that the Japanese public does not share the political leadership's enthusiasm for post-cold-war self-assertiveness. In surveys, on television and just in conversation, many Japanese say that while they agree that Japan must find new ways to contribute to the world, they are deeply uncomfortable with the idea of breaking the taboos that have kept their military forces at home and focused the Government on economic development, not geopolitics.
Such questions are arising only now because for four decades Tokyo's foreign policy has followed Washington's so closely that Japan has developed few of the institutions needed to chart its own course -- a powerful foreign ministry, an independent intelligence network, a confident military. Unlike Germany, Japan in the postwar era never entered regional collective security arrangements, even with other American allies like South Korea.
As a result, many Japanese leaders concede that the country still finds itself almost paralyzed diplomatically. Though it has tried to help bring about a settlement in Cambodia, not long ago the Japanese who is running the United Nations peacekeeping operation there, Yasushi Akashi, accused his country of moving too slowly and helping too little in sending personnel and logistical assistance to the area. To get the peacekeeping bill through Parliament, the governing Liberal Democratic Party may have to agree to send no one for several years, presumably until after the Cambodia peacekeeping operation expires. Or the Government may bow to demands from the opposition that forces be sent on a case-by-case basis, meaning a parliamentary debate each time.
Such domestic deal-making may be the biggest impediment to Japan's broader international role. The constant factional struggle in the Liberal Democratic Party has led party leaders to talk about the direction of the country's foreign and security policy in only the vaguest of terms. Japan's neighbors say the clubby, often secretive ways that political decisions are made in Japan add to their distrust of a broader global role for the country.
"The prerequisite for taking a larger political role," said Gerald Hensley, the Defense Minister of New Zealand, "is whether they can clean up their own political system, thus commanding more international confidence. And they must learn to act more generously."
 
Security
Dependence on U.S. Begins to Crumble
 When he commanded the American occupation of Japan, Gen. Douglas MacArthur described his vision of the country as a "Switzerland of the Pacific," a neutral nation that took no sides in the region's many conflicts. It was an image that still resonates deeply with many Japanese, who associate the country's 40-year territorial expansion -- first into Sakhalin and Korea, then into China and Southeast Asia -- with phenomenal destruction and crushing poverty.
General MacArthur's vision of neutrality was quickly jettisoned in reaction to the Communist takeover in China, the growing confrontation with the Soviet Union and the wars in Korea and Indochina. Soon a new bargain was struck: Japan would provide the United States with bases on Japanese soil in return for American protection. Though the security treaty was the subject of violent street protests in 1960, it has since come to be the fabric underlying Japanese foreign policy.
At America's urging, Japan used the prospect of invasion by the Soviet Union to justify the buildup its own military forces, reinterpreting its Constitution to allow defensive forces. As Japan geared up a military budget that now tops $30 billion a year, making it among the largest in the world, Japanese industry profited greatly, building ships and aircraft under American license and gaining considerable technology and manufacturing experience.
"In reality no one really believed there was much of a Soviet threat," a senior Japanese diplomat said recently. But it was a "convenient arrangement," he said.
It was particularly convenient for Japanese businessmen, who always enjoyed hearing the American Ambassador to Tokyo throughout the 1980's, Mike Mansfield, repeat that Japan and America had "the most important bilateral relationship in the world." They knew it meant that the security relationship would almost always overshadow American concerns about economic competitiveness.
"When you read some of the history, it is incredible how much of Japan policy for 40 years centered around making sure that Japan didn't go to the other side, the side of military neutrality," said James Fallows, who is completing a book about Japan and Asia. "As a politically relevant fact, that only ended a year ago."
The first concrete evidence that the traditional thinking was crumbling came in 1989, when Congress objected to technology transfers to Japan for the co-development of a new fighter jet, called the FSX. That began a spiral of resentments that reached a zenith when Japan rejected requests that it provide personnel -- not necessarily military personnel -- in the gulf war.
To Washington that constituted evidence that the alliance was one-sided. "Japan lost a lot of supporters here," a senior American military official said several months ago.
 
U.S. Presence
New Threats Seen As Old Ones Ease
 Critics of America's military presence here say the military is simply inventing missions to justify the presence, overstating threats and magnifying the power of potential rivals.
But whenever American military officials travel through the region, they insist that Japan has taken on renewed importance in the Pentagon's strategy, especially after the loss of Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Station in the Philippines. Potential threats, they argue, are real and plentiful.
"Russia is still one," said Lieut. Gen. Richard E. Hawley, who commands all the American forces in Japan. "You don't see the same changes in the Russian military structure when you sit in Japan and look west as you do when you sit in Berlin and look east."
"China is a major power center," he continued, "and that alone is simple justification for continued U.S. presence in this part of the world."
Perhaps the most unpredictable threat of all, and the one cited most often these days, is North Korea. Its suspected efforts to build nuclear weapons have rattled Japan's leadership and become the focus of what may be the closest political cooperation between Tokyo and Washington in years, as the two try to convince North Korea that the price it must pay for economic aid and recognition is abandonment of its nuclear ambitions.
"To talk about an American decline of interest here is both wrong and dangerous," James R. Lilley, a former Ambassador to China and now Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, said during a recent Asian tour. "It gives potential predators a false sense of opportunity and an inducement to be aggressive."
"Let's not give Kim Jong Il any ideas," he said, referring to the heir-apparent in North Korea.
 
Militarism
Fear of Revival Of Adventurism
 American and Japanese officials are more hesitant to talk about the other, rarely stated benefit of keeping American troops posted here: It reassures Asian nations that worry about a revived Japanese military.
But as the peacekeeping bill demonstrates, the concern seems overblown. There is virtually no detectable appetite for military adventurism in Tokyo, and little support, except from the Japanese right wing, for building anything other than purely defensive ability. Year after year, the Japanese military has been unable to win support for refueling planes or for small aircraft carriers, both of which Japanese fear would be viewed as potentially offensive weapons. Japan does not even have its own surveillance satellites, a source of considerable frustration in Tokyo since the North Korean nuclear scare began.
Most vocal in support of an American presence to keep a check on Japan are countries like Singapore, where this year schoolchildren were herded through an exhibit at the national museum with graphic images of Japanese atrocities during the occupation of the city 50 years ago. Singapore's Defense Minister, Yeo Ning Hong, said recently that should the United States gradually reduce its presence in the Pacific, "Japan may feel compelled to re-arm to safeguard its trade routes beyond the 1,000 nautical miles south of Tokyo," the current limit for Japanese forces.
That could prompt the Chinese and the Koreans, Mr. Yeo said, to "build up their respective armed forces to counter and contain any Japanese rearmament," setting off "a whole chain reaction of destabilization."
But the true concern about American withdrawal from the region involves a far more subtle form of Japanese influence. With newly built factories stretching from southern China to Indonesia, Japan is already the overwhelming economic power in the region. Japanese-style capitalism and Japanese work habits rival the Sony Walkman as Japan's most conspicuous export. The United States, in the view of many Southeast Asians, plays a critical if economically unrewarding role, assuring that Japan's influence stays on the factory floor.
"The more respectable argument is not that Japan will re-militarize in the absence of America but simply that if America pulls back, the Japanese will slowly move to fill the gap," said Mr. Hensley, the New Zealand Defense Minister. "Everyone will feel uncomfortable. Not because of memories of World War II -- most people are too young to remember it -- but because America and Great Britain, while they have made mistakes in Asia, have thought and acted globally. They pay into the system as well as take out. And so far, the Japanese have not paid in."
 
Old Disputes
New Relationships Are Elusive
 In their dealings in Asia, the Japanese have also seemed oddly hamstrung by their older cold-war habits.
Many Tokyo officials say they are embarrassed that smaller nations like South Korea managed to break free of traditional anti-Communist restraints over the last two years, forming new relationships with Russia, China and even the hard-line Communist regime in North Korea. But Japan still seems locked in its old disputes.
Its longtime territorial dispute over four northern islands, taken by the Soviet Union in the last days of World War II, has virtually frozen any prospect of anything but grudging Japanese economic aid to the former Soviet republics. Relations with China and South Korea, always on a knife's edge, are once again being colored by new charges that Japan is ducking responsibility for war atrocities -- this time by deflecting demands that it compensate Korean and Chinese women who were forced to provide sex to Japanese troops. It now appears unlikely that Emperor Akihito will take a long-expected trip to China this year, the first ever by a Japanese emperor.
Not everyone is unhappy keeping the Japanese slightly off balance in Asia.
"No matter what kind of nice face they put on it, people are still suspicious as hell of the Japanese," said K. S. Sandhu, a Malaysian who heads the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies in Singapore. "The fact is that they are perfectionist about everything they do, and if they decide again to become influential politically or militarily, they will do it to a fine art."
The Japanese have their own complaints about the new era, and the chief one is that if an American comes to visit Japan these days, someone has to lock the treasury door. Though Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d chastised Japan last year for what he called its inability to break out of "checkbook diplomacy," Japanese say a check is all America really seems to want, whether the project is the liberation of Kuwait or the building of the superconducting supercollider in Texas. In each case, they complain, Japan is often excluded from the critical moments of decision.
Some fear that Japan is heading into a Faustian bargain, that a more assertive Japan will mean the abandonment of the postwar military restraints that have become the core of the country's self-image.
Many Japanese recognize, however, that their political re-engagement is now inevitable, the logical conclusion to a particularly mercantile phase of Japanese history.
"Since 1945, the whole country was directed to bringing a recovery to the Japanese economy," said Akio Tanii, the president of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the world's largest consumer electronics company. "We have come to the point where we are not the student any longer. We have something to teach. The problem is we don't know where to start."

One issue facing it is whether to play a greater role in maintaining an international peacekeeping force. Self-Defense troops held maneuvers last year. (Robin Moyer/Gamma-Liaison)

HEADLINE: A Neocapitalist Basks With Reagan

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SIMI VALLEY, Calif., May 4

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev journeyed to an easier, sunnier summit today to share super-power nostalgia with Ronald Reagan and had a word of warning about the lingering "demons" of nationalism threatening the world.
Cautioning that the evil of an "all-embracing xenophobic hatred" is contained in the new wave of "nationalist exclusiveness," the former Soviet President surveyed the world scene from the California mountainside that is the site of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library. 
 "Nationalist extremism is a serious threat we face on the way to more civilized relations within and among states," Mr. Gorbachev said in accepting warm praise and the first Ronald Reagan Freedom Award from the former President.
 
The Feelings Are Mutual
 Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Reagan greeted each other as super-power retirees satisfied with their deeds but still interested in garnering some attention on the world stage.
"We were able to make a difference," Mr. Gorbachev told Mr. Reagan in summarizing the disarmament treaties and tumultuous world developments that saw the end of the cold war and the Communist empire during their years of power.
For his part, Mr. Reagan hailed Mr. Gorbachev as a man "whose shining legacy will live forever," and he urged fast approval of proposals for United States economic help to Russia and the other post-Communist republics.
"If we do not help, who will?" asked Mr. Reagan, who obviously enjoyed his duties as library host and referred several times to Mr. Gorbachev as "my friend."
Visiting some of the balmiest and most affluent California terrain, Mr. Gorbachev opened a two-week tour of the United States with an impressive lesson in fund-raising from the Reagan Library. Five hundred guests paid $5,000 each for the privilege of Mr. Gorbachev's company, with most of the funds earmarked for the library.
The fiscal details of the Gorbachev trip have not been disclosed beyond a gentle mention from United States consultants that they hope to raise up to $2 million in traversing the United States in Forbes Magazine's corporate jetliner, Capitalist Tool.
Mr. Gorbachev's scheduled speeches include an address to Congress and an appearance Wednesday at Westminster College in Fulton, Mo., where in 1946 Churchill issued his Iron Curtain warning about Soviet totalitarianism.
Mr. Gorbachev told a gathering of business and political leaders here that "blind commitment to ideology" was at the heart of the long cold war. "It is no less dangerous when ideological dogmas are replaced by the demons of nationalist exclusiveness, which so easily transform into all-embracing xenophobic hatred," he said.
Using the theme of "We the people" from the United States Constitution, the former Kremlin leader declared: "You the people -- I say this today as I address the Americans and citizens of other countries -- you were the first to reject cold-war stereotypes, the image of the enemy and automatic animosity toward the other side."
In recent interviews Mr. Gorbachev has been critical of Pentagon strategists who have asserted that the United States should be committed to policies of strategic dominance in the post-Communist world.
Down the mountainside, a dozen people picketed in behalf of the John Birch Society with signs declaring: "Socialism is not dead" and "Gorbachev -- world class criminal" and "Gorbachev to the gulag."
There were kinder words at the security-laced ceremony in the library garden, particularly for Mr. Gorbachev's wife, Raisa. She was praised by Mr. Reagan as "a wonderful representative of Russian womanhood."
 
Enter the Women, Smiling
 Mrs. Gorbachev and Nancy Reagan, well remembered for their mutual animosity in the shadow of their husbands' summit meetings, today displayed mutual friendliness in their public appearances, as they had at news photo sessions on Saturday and Sunday. "Mrs. Reagan and Mrs. Gorbachev kissed," declared the only "news" pool report on private events issued by the library; it was written by Charles Z. Wick, a devoted Reagan partisan and former head of the United States Information Agency.
Mr. Gorbachev described his reunion with Mr. Reagan as "a very emotional moment."
"Together we covered perhaps the most difficult part of the road back from the edge of the abyss that the world was facing in the early 1980's," he said.
"A high price has had to be paid for the historically necessary emancipation of the many nations living in our vast country," he said of the former Soviet domain. "We must not despair. Today the country has more free people than ever before."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The R.V. Indicator Turns Upbeat

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Sales of recreational vehicles, those homes on wheels that clog the nation's highways during the summers, appear to be picking up, figures compiled by the industry's trade association show. That may signal some good news for the nation's economy; many in the industry at least view R.V. sales as a reliable leading indicator.
"The pattern has held for 20-plus years," said H. Wayne Dahl, president of the Holiday Rambler unit of Harley-Davidson Inc. "Recreational vehicle sales are among the first things to fall off in a recession, and they have always led the recovery." Although Harley-Davidson is best known for its rumbling motorcycles, 25 percent of its revenues come from Holiday Rambler, which makes high-priced motor homes and other vehicles.
 
A Cyclical Business
 David Humphreys, who is president of the Recreational Vehicle Industries Association in Reston, Va., said: "We knew the industry had a history of ups and downs, but at first we didn't believe that we were a leading indicator. But Chase Economics and the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center found that we were one of the most leading indicators they could find." 
 Part of the reason, he said, is that the purchase of an R.V. can be readily deferred. People have to buy cars and trucks eventually for basic transportation, but nobody needs an R.V. So when the economy turns down and people start worrying about their jobs, they avoid frills like an R.V. Now, with the worst of the recession evidently past, and vacation season approaching, buyers are returning to showrooms to look at products ranging from folding camp trailers starting at $4,000 to luxury cruisers costing more than $100,000.
For investors, the sales upturn offers opportunities, but most analysts are recommending a selective approach that favors the smaller companies in the industry over the bigger names like Winnebago.
The association, which represents R.V. manufacturers and their suppliers, says shipments to dealers totaled 62,100 units in the first two months of this year, an increase of 84 percent over the 33,800 shipped in the comparable 1991 period. This includes vans that have been converted to include sleeping areas, but which lack the kitchens and bathrooms of fully equipped vehicles.
The year-to-year comparison is distorted by the effects of the Persian Gulf war last year, as well as by the fact that dealers were consciously drawing down their inventories; still, it gives an indication of the turn.
Mr. Humphreys notes that with dealer inventories slim, wholesale shipments should translate quickly into retail sales. That should produce more orders for factories. R.V.'s are largely hand built, so factories can crank up production fairly quickly by adding labor.
John DeWolf, an economic forecaster who is a consultant to the association, said R.V. sales usually lead the overall economic recovery by about half a year. "They pick up about six months ahead of industrial production," he said. He attributed this year's increased sales largely to lower interest rates. Since R.V. loans can have terms as long as 15 years, interest rates are an important factor.
Mr. DeWolf is forecasting that recreational vehicle sales, excluding converted vans, will increase 12.4 percent this year, to 191,200 units, from 170,100 last year. That would still be well below the peak of 223,100 in 1988.
But the sunny outlook has not so far been extended to the stocks of the companies that make the vehicles. Most stocks in the group peaked late in March and have been drifting lower since then.
Fleetwood Enterprises, the industry leader, which was profitable all through the sales trough, hit $48 on March 20, but has since slumped below $40 and closed yesterday at $38, up 62.5 cents for the day. Winnebago Industries, once a darling of investors, has struggled up to $6.25, but yesterday it closed at $4.625, down 62.5 cents. Winnebago, unlike most of the industry, is expected to remain in the red for the rest of its fiscal year, which ends in August.
Ellen T. Horing, who follows the recreational vehicle industry for Gabelli & Company, suggests that some of the smaller companies, like Coachman Industries and the Skyline Corporation, might provide a conservative bet on the industry.
Coachman returned to profitability in the first quarter, posting earnings of 5 cents a share in contrast to a loss of 57 cents a year ago. Unlike some of the larger companies, it has held on to most of its gain from the first quarter. After peaking at $8.875 it slipped, closing yesterday at $7.625, down 50 cents. Skyline closed yesterday at $16.875, up 12.5 cents; it went as high as $18.875 in late March.

HEADLINE: Pricing Plans Shift at Hertz And Alamo

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Hertz Corporation, the world's largest rental-car company, expanded its new simplified pricing system yesterday to many business customers, lowering its rates in most cases. Alamo Rent A Car Inc., the fifth-largest rental-car company, quickly followed with a similar offer.
Two weeks ago, Hertz and Alamo lowered rates on rental cars used on weekends, mostly by vacation travelers. The new rates, effective today, do not require weekend use of the car and are for businesses travelers not covered by corporate rental contracts. 
 Availability is limited, and to be eligible the renter must be at least 25 years old and present a current airline ticket. About 80 percent of auto- rental customers hold airline tickets, according to industry estimates.
 
Variety of Rates
 The new Hertz rates for an advance booking of at least three days start at $24.99 a day for an economy car, and $28.99 for the same car booked as late as two hours before pickup.
Other book-ahead daily rates range from $28.99 for a subcompact to $42.99 for a full-size car, while same-day daily rates are generally $3 more in each category. On average, the lowest new economy rate is about $5 a day lower than previously, according to Joseph Russo, a Hertz spokesman. The new rate for an economy car in New York, booked the same day, is $38.99, down from $54.
The new rates will be the same for most locations, although they will be slightly lower in Florida and higher in New York, Boston, Chicago and Detroit. In the past, the same car could rent for many different prices depending on the city, and the rate would change as frequently as the old air fares did.
 
Pickup in Airline Traffic
 The latest moves by Hertz and Alamo follow similar announcements of pricing overhauls by airlines, led by American Airlines, and by the ITT Sheraton Corporation, the hotel chain. Car-rental executives said that airline traffic appears to be picking up in the wake of the airlines' new fare structure, and the new rental offers are an attempt to grab a bigger share of the expanding market.
Hertz scored a jump on its competition when it announced its new rates early yesterday, effective at its 800 corporate locations nationwide. An Alamo spokeswoman said Alamo had intended to announce its new rates later this week but accelerated its plans in the wake of Hertz's announcement.
Although the new rate structure is intended to be permanent, Hertz said, the rates are valid through June 30, after which they may be raised or lowered, as market conditions warrant. The 800 locations covered by the announcement have more than 90 percent of Hertz's fleet of 230,000 cars.
 
Alamo's New Rates
 Alamo's new rates, in effect at its 102 locations through Aug. 31, range from $26 for a one-day advance on a subcompact, or $29 if booked the same day, to $44 for a luxury car booked a day in advance, or $47 the same day.
Alamo officials described the rates announced yesterday as "phase 2 in what we hope to be a long line of phases." It introduced phase 1 on April 20, cutting its rate to $15 for compact cars, $19 for a midsize vehicle and $29 for a Cadillac Sedan de Ville -- but requiring the use of the car through a Saturday night. That strategy, Alamo officials said, was aimed at gaining market share among cost-conscious domestic travelers.
In response to that move, Hertz and Avis Inc. reduced their economy rate to $14.99 at about 100 locations, also requiring a Saturday stay-over. But Craig R. Koch, president of Hertz's North American Rent A Car division, said yesterday that the Saturday stay-over rate did not address the needs of midweek business renters not covered by corporate contracts.
 
Mileage for Frequent Fliers
 Rentals under Hertz's new structure will also earn mileage for customers enrolled in the frequent-flier programs of American, Northwest, United and USAir, as well as points in Marriott's Honored Guest Program. Alamo rentals qualify for mileage under the frequent-flier programs of Alaska Airlines, Delta and United.
Avis yesterday described the Hertz announcement as "playing catch-up," noting that for the last month it has had a program aimed at small businesses, requiring no advance booking and available even to local business people.
Mr. Russo said that Hertz had a similar program but that those programs -- unlike the simplified rate structure announced yesterday -- required signed contracts negotiated by the renter's company.

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: The '92 Campaign;
Crisis Casts New Light on Candidates

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, May 4

 BODY:
With its rubber-processing plants and its Goodyear Boulevard and Goodyear Heights, there's no mistaking what city this is: it can only be Akron.
Yet with its mix of black and white faces, its rich and poor schools vying for dwindling money, its overall harmony in day-to-day life, it could be any small to medium-sized city in America. And like the others, it has spent the last few days moving to the rhythms of Los Angeles, one minute holding its breath, the next sighing with relief, the next trying to figure out what it all means for people here and, this being an election year, for Presidential politics. 
 "To tell you the truth, I was on the fence, leaning toward Clinton," said Earl Antibus, 72 years old. "But I think Bush handled this thing real well, real well."
Asked his opinion of Gov. Bill Clinton, the likely Democratic nominee, David Eldridge, a 32-year-old pharmacist, said: "I forgot all about Clinton. Let me think for a minute."
Indeed, in three dozen interviews and chats here over two days, the opinion of Mr. Clinton was the lowest it has been in informal interviews with hundreds of voters in various parts of the country over the last three months. As always, there were reservations about Mr. Clinton's character, though no more so here than elsewhere. In part, his problem seemed to be his having been out of the mainstream of dramatic events, a spectator, not a leader.
"I've always voted Democratic, but I don't know," said Mary Sattler, who works for the Adult Literacy Council setting up computer programs. "The verdict was sad. Those four people should have been convicted. But it's not justified to have violence for the sake of violence. I don't know if Clinton is up to the job or not. He doesn't turn me on." Then she added, "I guess I shouldn't put it that way, with the adultery and all."
 
Lack of Trust
 Ms. Sattler meant that as a joke. But similar wisecracks about allegations that Mr. Clinton had an extramarital affair cropped up so often that many people seemed unable to trust him in a crisis.
"We've gone back, lost ground ever since Reagan," said Delores Campbell, who described herself as a homemaker. "We've become more divided. I'm looking at Perot. I'm not sure about Clinton. It's a big job and he's got so much to overcome."
Asked if she meant questions about the Governor's character, Mrs. Campbell replied, "Yes."
At that point, friends of Mrs. Campbell, who is black, pointed out that Mr. Clinton, being from the South, had experience with issues pertaining to blacks. "Well, that's true," she said. "That's true."
All this is not to say that Mr. Clinton was without any support in this city, whose residents will vote in a Presidential primary on June 2. Some other blacks agreed that his roots in the South were a plus, that he had a background in dealing with the problems of blacks. And some whites, disenchanted with President Bush, said Mr. Clinton was the only realistic alternative.
"I think Reagan and Bush have failed, and that leaves it up to Clinton," said W. J. Pennell, who, at 63, is retired. "I think he's put down too much. He's been Governor. He's up to it."
Race relations here in Akron, a city of 230,000 people in northeastern Ohio, have been generally good over the years. Blacks, who make up about 22 percent of the population, had few racially based complaints about the mayor and police chief, both of whom are white.
 
Some Uneasiness
 Still, there is some uneasiness among blacks. Even as rubber processing has declined with the automobile industry, Akron has managed to increase the number of job holders by 8,000. But the city, helped by the presence of the University of Akron, has done so primarily in high-technology and office jobs, where those with less education often cannot compete.
White people here, asked about the 1992 election, tended to shake their heads and say with a cavalier shrug that there is no one they like. But blacks were not cavalier at all, often working themselves into anger when answering the question, believing that there was no one -- no one -- who was going to make a difference for American blacks.
"The only thing America understands is violence and money," said Anthony R. Hudson, 30, a black man who works with the Ohio University Young Scholars program. "We live in a government, not a democracy. The media tells us which candidates are acceptable for us to choose from. They won't even let us hear all of them. None of the candidates are going to do anything about the problems of blacks. Not Bush, that's for sure. Not Clinton. Not Perot. I don't know what we can do."
For many people of Akron, black and white, the last few days have been the same: sitting transfixed by television images of beatings and burning buildings, running to call friends and family members in California, listening to Sunday sermons for calm. Almost universally, the not-guilty verdict was condemned here. The empathy of whites for how their black neighbors must feel seemed genuine.
"I spent an hour talking about it with my class," said Mary Anne Drobnak, 58, a fifth-grade teacher, who laughed at herself for driving around, not on, streets in black neighborhoods immediately after the verdict, though no violence broke out here. "The verdict was so unfair. It was all I could do to keep from crying."
 
'The Right Tone'
 But also universally, the looting and particularly the violent attacks were also condemned as unjustified. While Mr. Bush was criticized for not doing enough to build housing and create jobs, that fight can come another day. For now, the top priority of most whites and many blacks here is restoring law and order in Los Angeles, and Mr. Bush got high points, indeed, for his Friday night address to the nation.
"I think Bush struck the right tone," said Lori Dinkins, 31, a black woman who works on a word processor. "There's no excuse for beating innocent people."
In a pastoral letter, the Rev. Ronald J. Fowler, pastor of the Arlington Church of God, a black church here, called for tax incentives for businesses to hire and train marginally skilled people. He also called for requiring public employees to receive multicultural training.
"Bush's speech was a good one, maybe a day late and a dollar short, but a good one," Mr. Fowler said. "He's right. We cannot let lawlessness prevail. But let's see what he and the party platform say on domestic issues and what they will do to help those who are marginalized economically. That's the big problem for the country. That's what will sway my vote."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
The Attack of the 8-Legged Vampires of Doom!

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: EASTON, Conn.

 BODY:
THIS is $ weep$ month for television, that vital time when someone somehow counts how many people watch which show.
Coincidentally, sweeps month happens to be when TV uncovers the hottest, sexiest, scariest stories of the year, the ones about women stealing their sisters' husbands, engagement-ring ripoffs, supermarket scams, sex after 60 and how your dinner plates just might be poisoning the children tonight. 
 Coincidentally, Our Towns today has uncovered a dangerous suburban health situation that could strike your family without warning. Reader discretion is advised:
TICKS! They're back! And they could be sucking your blood right now. (Insert here film of hectic hospital emergency room.)
On the surface, bucolic Fairfield County seems an unlikely setting for a reign of terror by a plague of insects. (Pan across scenic woods and tidy homes, then zoom in on a toppled tricycle.) But few homeowners dare walk their pricey property this spring for fear of this creature. (Get a file photo of a tick. How big are they anyway? A poppyseed? O.K., blow up the tick pic. He should fill the entire screen. Can you make all eight legs wiggle? Then we'll cut to Dolly Curtis in her garden.)
Dolly Curtis is a TV producer. She never saw the voracious insect that ate part of her foot. "I never saw it." (Cut to Kirby Stafford.)
Kirby Stafford is a state scientist studying the tick crisis: "They begin to move every May. Last year was bad. Each female lays up to 2,500 eggs." (Quick cutaway to the forest and back.) "The ticks hang on leaves to grab passing creatures. They crawl up and burrow in. Their mouths secrete a cement to hold on. They suck for days. You never feel the bite." (We won't use any scientific stuff about bacteria, ticks in colonial times and only one tick in five actually carrying Lyme disease. What was it, 4,000 Lyme cases a year in New York and Connecticut?)
Every year thousands of people contract Lyme disease with its chronic fatigue, inflamed joints and flu-like pains. (Mrs. Curtis again.) "My foot was swollen for weeks."
Lyme disease wasn't discovered until 1975 here in Connecticut. Now these diseased ticks are spreading. (Map of the United States shows Wisconsin, Minnesota and the top of Illinois growing dark.) Any mammal in the woods can carry diseased ticks. Even household pets. (Curtis.) "Everyone in Connecticut is at risk."
Early diagnosis of Lyme disease is crucial. One telltale clue: a red circle around the bite. But thousands of Lyme victims may be misdiagnosed by inattentive doctors. (Tomorrow, we'll cover the run on doctors' offices.)
Now, in the face of immense official inaction, Lyme disease victims are organizing. (Curtis again.) "One day I noticed how many neighbors on the same street were sick -- Joy Haller, Barbara Paolini, John Stanczyk, his son, his grandson and his sister. They said, 'Dolly, you should get a support group started.' So I did."
The group meets every few weeks at the Congregational Church hall to exchange sympathy, share stories and hear experts. Attendance is mounting. The next session is May 11. Josephine Kusnierczak attends every one. "It's scary," she says. "I love to garden. Next thing my leg is red and swelling. At first, they didn't know what it was. Then I took antibiotics for weeks. I still tire easily. And I don't sit outside anymore. You worry where these little guys are all the time."
(Cut to John Stanczyk.) "This'll be another bad year. I've taken four ticks off the dog already."
The economic impact of the tick plague may be severe. Not one Japanese tourist bus has visited this tiny rural community since the infestation began. The nearby headquarters of the giant General Electric Company keeps 24-hour guards at the gate, still. And companies across the state have laid off thousands in recent years. Given current government budget problems, any immediate remedy seems unlikely.
One thing is certain though: One solution to this seriously major suburban problem would be to kill every mouse in Connecticut. Also all the deer and every bird that ever touches the ground. Then remove every tree, bush and blade of grass and all the stone walls. Seal the border with New York. Burn every hint of leaf litter and send people in moon suits to spray the entire landscape with lethal insecticides with a half-life equal to the average copy of National Geographic.
An alternative would be for people to wear bug repellent and long pants in the woods.
(Great, great, but drop that last sentence. It's misleadingly simple. We might lose viewers for the Deadly Diets segment.)
