HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Issues;
Perot Tells Money Managers How to Fix U.S. Education

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, May 4

 BODY:
For nearly a decade, Ross Perot has linked what he believes are the nation's lax schooling standards with America's eroding strength in global industrial competition.
And in a speech on those issues here today before a national convention of professional money managers, Mr. Perot provided a preview of how his blunt assessments of America's troubles, blended with pledges of quick action and a rapid-fire Texas humor, might sound if he decides to run as an independent candidate for President. 
 "We spend $400 billion a year on education, including college, so we are buying a first-class ticket," the billionaire Texas businessman said. "But we are not getting first-class results."
In the Depression, he said, the biggest problems with students in schools were talking in class, chewing gum, making noise, running in the halls and not putting paper in the waste basket. The troubles today are drug abuse, alcohol abuse, pregnancy, suicide, rape, robbery and assault.
 
'Talking About Reality'
 "You say, 'All right, gee, we don't want this guy in the White House,' " Mr. Perot said. " 'He's talking about reality.' If you don't want reality, you don't want me there. I could give you a whole list of reasons not to vote for me."
Alluding to his dark view of school life in America today, and the lagging performance of students compared with those in other industrialized nations, he said, "If you can live with this, you don't want me around."
Mr. Perot, who led a statewide campaign in 1983-84 to improve management of public schools in Texas, described in his remarks an effort that has generally been credited with improved standards for teachers and students in the state.
He said that 36 percent of Texas adults are not high school graduates, 63 percent of mothers receiving Federal Aid for Dependent Children do not have high school diplomas, "and here's the really sad one," 85 percent of the inmates in Texas prisons are high school dropouts.
"It costs more to send a young man to prison than to go to Harvard," he said. Early-childhood programs that develop self-esteem and encourage learning in children were the best investment the nation can make in education, he said.
 
Economic Concerns
 "We've got to build early childhood development centers," he said. "They work. They are the most cost-effective thing you can do."
Referring to children in economically depressed and crime-ridden areas, he said, "If you don't love them, if you don't care about them and you have no other reason to do it, just do it for hard-headed business reasons. You are providing a future taxpayer."
Organizers of the conference here said that Mr. Perot was invited to speak several months ago to the gathering of the Association of Investment Management and Research because of his efforts on behalf of Texas public schools. The speech before 800 people, who gave Mr. Perot enthusiastic applause when he finished, was not listed as a campaign event by Mr. Perot's staff.
John D. Messner, partner in a San Diego money management firm, Meridian Capital, said after the speech that Mr. Perot had the makings of a serious threat to President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton.
"He struck a chord -- education is important to everyone," Mr. Messner said. "Perot is saying some of the same things as Paul Tsongas."

HEADLINE: RIOTS IN LOS ANGELES: The Democrats;
Clinton Tours City's Damaged Areas and Chides Bush

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 4

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton inspected the devastation of South-Central Los Angeles today and sparred with the Bush Administration over political responsibility for the riots in America's second-largest city.
The long-distance exchange with Administration officials in Washington illustrated the potential risks and benefits of Mr. Clinton's effort to use the riots as evidence of what he describes as President Bush's neglect of race relations, urban problems and domestic social policy in general. 
 Over the weekend, Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, complained that Mr. Clinton, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, had exploited the riots for political gain. Mr. Kemp said the Arkansas Governor had "stooped to partisan demagoguery" by "accusing President Bush and the Republican Party of helping cause the riots."
And today the Administration instead attributed to the disturbances in Los Angeles in part to liberal policies adopted after the riots of the 1960's. "We believe that many of the root problems that have resulted in inner-city difficulties were started in the 60's and 70's, and that they have failed," said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman.
Surrounded by dozens of photographers and journalists, Mr. Clinton walked the streets of the South-Central area and Koreatown and inspected the damage: smoky rubble, ashes, twisted metal and shards of glass where dozens of thriving restaurants and stores once stood.
The Arkansas Governor said he was astonished by Mr. Kemp's criticism but "not particularly concerned about it." Mr. Kemp himself has prodded the White House to show more interest in poverty and the "underclass," the people living outside the mainstream of American society.
Taking note of that, Mr. Clinton said today: "Jack Kemp has been the most critical member of the Cabinet on President Bush's inaction. My guess is that he got some heat for being so critical of the President, and he was just trying to make up some political ground on the home court."
Indeed, as Mr. Clinton noted, he and Mr. Kemp have much in common. Both assert that government programs alone cannot solve deep-rooted social problems and say that poor people must shun welfare and take responsibility for their own lives.
"The key to any long-term progress is the economic and political empowerment of the people who are most disadvantaged," Mr. Clinton said as he paused in a tour of Vermont Avenue, one of the streets most damaged by the riots.
 
Uncharacterisic Caution
 Otherwise, Mr. Clinton, who is usually full of self-confidence, seemed uncharacteristically cautious today in his remarks on the rioting. While seizing an opportunity to underline the differences between himself and the President, Mr. Clinton evidently also realized that he would be vulnerable to criticism if he made simplistic comments blaming Mr. Bush for the problems here.
Mr. Clinton said, "I hope my trip here will play a constructive role in trying to rebuild Los Angeles and rebuild America." He said his meetings with black, Hispanic and Korean Americans had given him many ideas for actions that the Government could take to aid in reconstruction.
Mr. Clinton listed several steps he would take, if President, to help poor residents of Los Angeles and other cities. The money saved from cuts in military spending should be invested in construction of housing, streets and bridges and water and sewer systems, he said. In addition, he said, the Federal minimum wage, now at $4.25 an hour, should be automatically increased each year to keep pace with inflation. And he said Los Angeles should train its residents for construction jobs and other work for use in rebuilding the city.
"It is imperative that we have an economic expansion agenda from the national Government, that we increase investment in our cities and our infrastructure, that we do what we can to stimulate redevelopment of businesses in this area of Los Angeles, businesses that could be owned by all ethnic groups," the Governor said.
Mr. Clinton said local leaders told him they did not want a repetition of the events after the riots in the city's Watts section in 1965, "when somebody came up with a grandiose plan and then everybody forgot about it." It is essential for community leaders to be involved in drafting the reconstruction plan, he said, because "people want to be empowered to control their own destiny."
Mr. Clinton, who surveyed the damage with Representative Maxine Waters, the local Congresswoman, said he had no concern that he or other Democratic candidates would suffer by association with the rioters who tore up wide areas of this city after the acquittal last week of four white Los Angeles policemen in the beating of a black motorist. "I have a good law-and-order record," Mr. Clinton said.
Asked what he would do as President to prevent such civil unrest, Mr. Clinton said: "What you have got to do is to provide real hope and economic opportunity, and then set an example for one another. When something like this happens, it obviously means that a lot of people feel they are not part of the common community."
Residents of the riot area welcomed Mr. Clinton's visit. "It's a good thing he gets to see first-hand how this community has been affected by the revolt and the anger over the jury decision" to acquit the police officers, said Margaret Bush-Ware, executive director of Youth Opportunities Unlimited, a job training program in South-Central Los Angeles.
Mr. Bush, who dispatched Federal troops and law-enforcement officers to the Los Angeles area on Friday, plans to visit the city on Thursday as part of a previously scheduled trip to California.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Bill Clinton inspecting riot damage yesterday in South-Central Los Angeles with Representative Maxine Waters and community leaders. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Revival on Broadway Is Broadway;
Theater District Businesses Give the Season Rave Reviews

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
In a parking lot on West 46th Street, the measure of Broadway's success often comes down to this: At what time can Frank Gonzalez play chess?
With remarkable speed and even more remarkable dexterity, five guys -- none named Moe -- wheel the BMW's, Mercedes-Benzes and Lincoln Continentals of harried theatergoers into spaces prudent drivers might consider best suited for Volkswagens. 
 When the lot is filled, Mr. Gonzalez, the lot manager, settles into his white clapboard booth for his nightly chess game with his employees. If he starts by 7:30,he knows the theaters are doing well.
These days, he's playing at 7 o'clock. And all Broadway is smiling.
"Good? Things are very good," said Mr. Gonzalez. "In the 12 years I've been here, I've never seen so many shows open all at the same time."
As surely as producers live or die on reviews, Mr. Gonzalez's Restaurant Row parking lot -- like scores of midtown restaurants, hotels and gift shops -- thrives or busts on Broadway's ticket sales. Stories from the businesses say a lot about the health of one of New York's most vital areas. This spring, after a grim year of darkened marquees and empty seats, the sales are booming. In April, Broadway attracted more than 830,000 theatergoers and the box-office receipts, $30.1 million, were the highest of any four-week total in New York theater history, according to the League of American Theaters and Producers.
George Wachtel, director of research for the league, projects that by the end of the season on May 31, Broadway will have generated $562 million in economic activity for midtown, $45 million above last season.
With 28 productions at the end of April, seven more than in the same period last year, the Great White Way has the hurly-burly feel of a gold-rush boomtown once more. Cafes are bustling, restaurant reservations are up and armadas of limousines are again commandeering entire blocks outside theaters.
"There seems to be so much more going on," said Jon Dietrich, a salesman at One Shubert Alley, the theatrical gift shop off West 45th Street. "Everyone who comes in these days is filled with excitement. It's in the air. And it keeps us all up."
 
The Electricity Factor
 The message on the chalkboard inside Sam's restaurant on West 45th Street told the whole story: "Falsettos -- break a leg. Love, Sam."
It was opening night for the musical at the John Golden Theater across the street, and the restaurant workers, most of them actors themselves, were waiting in tense anticipation for the newspaper reviews.
When the first editions arrived at 10 P.M., Craig Dawson, a waiter, ripped to the review, read for a moment, and then sighed. In relief. A rave.
"With ticket prices the way they are, people won't buy until a play is considered a sure-fire success," said Mr. Dawson, 41 years old. "We're so dependent on the street, we have to keep our finger to the pulse of the business."
The owner, Sam Sapienza, said the pulse was throbbing.
Mr. Sapienza, whose father opened the restaurant as a speakeasy in 1929, likes to measure the block's vigor by its electrical use. Last year, with three theaters closed, was a low-watt year. Not as dark as the dire year of 1975, when a musicians' strike closed nine theaters and wiped out some of his restaurateur friends. But dim.
This year, West 45th Street's seven theaters are all open, including the Imperial, where "Les Miserables" has been a money-making fixture.
"The lights are up," the 62-year-old owner said. "And when the lights are up, everybody's alive."
 
In Front of 'Streetcar'
 As the sun set below a pale blue sky, Frank Gonzalez had his workers in high gear, gunning cars in reverse, swerving down narrow parking lanes, briskly attending to the growing line of customers.
Mr. Gonzalez, a 40-year-old resident of Jackson Heights, Queens, orchestrated this operation like an an air-traffic controller, packing his 50-foot by 25-foot lot as tightly as a sardine can.
"What play?" he asked a woman as she pulled her white Toyota into the lot entrance.
"Two Trains something," she replied.
" 'Two Trains Running,' " Mr. Gonzalez says. "About 10:30."
Then, turning to a worker, he shouted, "Two Trains, el blanco," and the car was backed into the middle of the pack, somewhere behind "Falsettos" but well in front of "A Streetcar Named Desire."
By 7:10 about eight spaces remained vacant and Mr. Gonzalez conceded that this was a slow night, by boomtown standards. But with a sudden spurt of activity, Mr. Gonzalez was positioning pawns by 7:30.
He lost the chess game, but took it philosophically. "You can't win them all," he said. "At least business is good."
 
'No Mascara Left'
 It was 10:38 P.M., so the two women eyeing the mugs and t-shirts at One Shubert Alley must have just left "The Secret Garden."
"How was it?" asked Mr. Dietrich, the salesmen.
"I've got no mascara left," said a still teary-eyed Linda Golderg as she dug deep into her purse to pay for the musical's taped soundtrack. "I just love to cry."
Nestled between the Booth and Shubert theaters, the tiny gift store, with its knickknacks and music boxes and soundtracks, is a good barometer of tourism's economic, and emotional, health.
For Ms. Goldberg, 38, a self-proclaimed "I hate New York person" from Baltimore, Broadway offered an escape from a city she expected to be unwelcoming.
A manager with Baltimore Gas and Electric, she was attending a conference on labor relations. Asked to introduce herself, she leapt to her feet and announced: "One of my skills is that I can remember the lyrics of every song I hear and I'm looking for someone to go to the theater with."
At which point Janet Courtemanche, 43, from Boston, leapt to her feet and said: "That's me!"
So there they were, two women crying their eyes out at "The Secret Garden," cementing a friendship. "New York, New York," said Ms. Goldberg. "It's an amazing town."
 
No Answers, but Sales
 Among the theatergoers rushing from parking lots and restaurants to curtain time on a recent evening, questions seemed to outpace explanations for Broadway's revival. Had long-dormant theater lovers loosened their wallets because they believed the recession was over? Was the ticket-buying surge a result of better productions, more popular revivals, or just more tourists?
Could it be, as David Letterman recently suggested, the naked ushers?
It was Jessica Lange's star power that brought David Breault, a visitor from Tallahassee, Fla., to the Barrymore Theater and "A Streetcar Named Desire" on a recent night.
"I thought it would be cool to see her," he said with a tug at his studded black-leather jacket. Unfortunately, his discount ticket placed him somewhat closer to the ozone layer than the orchestra pit. "It seemed like a good performance," he reflected. "It would have been nice if we could have seen her expressions."
For Lurana Amis, like many New Yorkers, the question of whether to plunk down big money for seats hinged as much on economic as aesthetic issues.
For five years, the Bronx resident has gone to plays with a group of friends at least twice a month, spending, she said, about $30 each night. But over the past year, "nameless fears" about layoffs and recession have almost kept her away several times. Almost.
"I didn't want to come tonight," Ms. Amis, 53, who teaches French at the Horace Mann School in the Bronx, said as she walked to "Two Trains Running." She had heard the play was depressing. A friend had canceled. But here she was. "I know that by 11 o'clock, I'll be happy," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: There are many measures to gauge the success of Broadway, but regardless of the micrometer used, there is no doubt sales are booming. Outside the Music Box, theatergoers gathered to see the new hit "A Small Family Business."; One measure used to review Broadway's health is finding out what time Frank Gonzalez, above, a parking lot manager, has begun his chess game. The earlier he makes his opening pawn move, the sooner theatergoers have filled his lot on West 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. (Photographs by Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: With Pot of Fiscal Gold, Proposals for Mining It

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
In preparation for the fiscal year that begins July 1, the Dinkins administration is seeking various forms of financial help from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
The state-run corporation was set up to borrow money for New York City during the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's by issuing bonds that are backed by city sales-tax revenues. 
 Bonds that the corporation issues on the city's behalf receive a better interest rate than the city could obtain on its own because the corporation has a better credit rating. The corporation's credit rating is better because it has first lien on the city's tax revenues and greater flexibility in repaying its debt.
The city has proposed three ways of obtaining money through the assistance corporation:
 
Mirror Bonds
 At one point this year, the city planned to borrow hundreds of millions of dollars through mirror bonds to close billions of dollars of budget gaps over the next four years.
Under the plan, the city would have sold its own bonds and used the proceeds to buy back old notes that M.A.C. holds.
The assistance corporation could have then used that money from the city to pay the interest on its own outstanding corporation bonds, freeing some sales tax revenues that the city would normally pay toward retiring the M.A.C. bonds.
The Dinkins administration had planned to use $250 million worth of mirror bonds to help balance the budget for the 1993 fiscal year, but Mayor David N. Dinkins said last week that a large budget surplus would allow the city to avoid the borrowing. Bond raters had warned that such borrowing would lower the city's credit rating. The city still plans to use $300 million in mirror-bond financing to balance its budget in the 1994 fiscal year.
 
Cash Surpluses
 The assistance corporation has generated a $300 million cash surplus by refinancing its bonds to take advantage of lower interest rates. In February, the corporation promised to give the city $100 million of the surplus.
That money has been used to close budget gaps. Aides to Mayor Dinkins have said that he wants to use the remaining $200 million as a bargaining chip with municipal labor unions in exchange for getting improved worker productivity. But Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and the City Council want to spend that surplus on the schools.
 
Bonds for Capital Projects
 Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has proposed a joint financing arrangement to issue bonds with the city that would allow the administration to restore up to $600 million in proposed cuts to the capital budget without increasing the city's overall cost of borrowing.
Mr. Rohatyn has said that he wants the money to be spent for school-construction programs.
The City Council wants to take advantage of Mr. Rohatyn's offer and to have the city borrow $400 million through the assistance corporation to finance school rebuilding.
But aides to Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that they were not convinced that the corporation could do that without increasing the city's overall cost of borrowing for capital projects, which is expected to account for more than 20 percent of every city tax dollar by 1996.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Is Pressed to Use M.A.C. Money on Schools

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Pressure increased on Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday to support a plan for committing hundreds of millions of dollars in Municipal Assistance Corporation money to the public schools as the City Council joined Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez in endorsing similar plans.
But the administration held its ground as mayoral aides said that the city could not afford to borrow more through the corporation and that any M.A.C. surplus should be used as a bargaining chip in trading raises for a smaller city work force. 
 The Council proposed spending $500 million in assistance corporation money to expand computer education, upgrade school libraries and restore $200 million in capital spending cuts for school construction. Under the plan, $100 million would come from a $200 million surplus that the assistance corporation has generated by refinancing its bonds at lower interest rates and $400 million would come from new M.A.C. borrowing.
 
'Good News'
 Aides to Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said they have been working on the proposal since March and had discussed it with the Governor and Schools Chancellor, who last week announced a similar plan.
James Vlasto, a spokesman for the Schools Chancellor, said: "We are delighted by the endorsement of the Council to make education a major priority in this budget. It appears they are doing just that and coming on the heels of Governor Cuomo's announcement Friday, it is good news."
The Council's call for the administration to commit itself to using assistance corporation money for schools sets the stage for the first major battle over the Mayor's proposed budget for the 1993 fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
While Mr. Dinkins proposes the city's budget, it is subject to the approval of the Council. At the same time, the chairman of the assistance corporation, appointed by the Governor, has considerable influence over the city's finances. As pressure mounts for the Mayor to use the M.A.C. money for education, he is finding himself increasingly isolated on the issue.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has indicated that he would like the money to go toward education programs, but he has not set that as a condition for the city's receiving it. Mr. Rohatyn was traveling abroad yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
 
Presented to Rohatyn
 Mr. Vallone said yesterday that he had presented the Council's proposal to Mr. Rohatyn last week and that Mr. Rohatyn was very warm to it. In fact, Mr. Vallone seemed convinced that the Mayor would eventually give in.
Mr. Vallone, when asked if he had discussed the plan with the Dinkins administration, said, "I think we are all in agreement on this."
But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said that while the administration was still studying the Council's proposal, many of the plan's education programs were not consistent with the Mayor's goal of using the surplus assistance corporation money to streamline government, possibly through actions like early retirement and automation.
 
'Vitally Important'
 "Everyone recognizes that education is vitally important, but we have to balance the needs of schools against the overall financial requirements of the city," Mr. Steisel said.
Shrinking the city's work force will bring large savings that Dinkins administration could use to finance raises for the city's municipal labor unions, almost all of which are without a contract. But Mr. Dinkins has said there will be no raises without increases in productivity.
Under the Council's proposal, $30 million would be spent to renovate library space and buy new books, $142 million for school computer labs, $200 million to build new schools, $20 million for special education, $16 million for basic school supplies, and $75 million for school maintenance to repair broken boilers, leaky roofs and boarded windows.

HEADLINE: The Growing Business of Helping Things Grow

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., May 4

 BODY:
It is springtime, and nature must once again be made to behave.
No riot of chickweed, henbit or dandelion may on the lawn appear. No bag worm in the spruce or arborvitae, no leaf miners in the birch nor lace bugs in the azaleas are allowed. These and other signs of nature taking its course, especially including tall, unkempt grass, are subdued by determined homeowners backed by an army of lawn and garden maintenance workers now deep in their annual routine of mulching, feeding, mowing, pruning, poisoning, aerating and de-thatching until each flower and fruit, each blade and leaf are in their right order. 
 "It's a constant battle to stay on top of nature, because nature is always trying to come back," said Josephine Peiser, whose two-acre garden in Princeton is a showcase of flowers and plantings.
Along with her own labor, Mrs. Peiser calls upon that of Bill Turner, the owner of Princeton Gardeners, one of hundreds of lawn and garden services that help take some of the work out of working the soil.
 
Two Kinds of Clients
 According to figures kept by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, the number of commercial garden services holding permits for applying garden chemicals has more than doubled with the growth of the New Jersey suburbs, from 1,700 in 1979 to 3,500 in 1990.
"I didn't know when I was a freshman in college that I was going to end up in this business," Mr. Turner commented. "But they made me take a course in agricultural sciences and one in horticulture, and I found out I liked it."
Now, with a bachelor of science degree in ornamental horticulture from Delaware Valley College in Doylestown, Pa., Mr. Turner employs 10 people to serve nearly 400 customers in central New Jersey, "doing everything outside the house but wash the windows."
Not surprisingly, while New Jersey's economy was busily adding jobs in technology, health care, real estate and financial services during the decade, employment was also growing sharply in agriculture, where the number of jobs rose by 16,000 between 1980 and 1990 on the strength of demand from homeowners for help in keeping the lawn mowed and the red bugs out of the yews.
"The people who hire a lawn service come in two groups," said Bob Olszack, owner of Nassau Lawn and Garden Service, also of Princeton. "There are the people who are just so busy they want someone to keep the grass cut and that's about it, and there are the ones who want you to give them a garden that looks like it came out of a gardening magazine."
 
A Rake, a Mower, a Business
 Ten years ago, Mr. Olszack planned to become a commercial airline pilot, but airline deregulation made employment there less dependable than the turning of the seasons and the yearly renewal of the war on crabgrass and clover.
Like their customers, lawn services seem to break into two groups -- the licensed, perhaps even specially trained garden experts with crews of a dozen or more and someone to answer the phone, and the far larger category of freelance gardeners and leaf sweepers who threw the lawnmower in the back of a pickup, had some cards printed and went into business.
"The fly-by-nights don't have to pay for licensing or fees," said Mr. Turner. "Most of them don't have insurance or anything. State law says if you have a commercial truck you have to have your name on the door, but some of those guys are impossible to identify."
But Willie Smith, a laid-off Trenton factory worker who put himself in business mowing grass in the summer and raking leaves in the fall, argued that there was room in a growth field for the small fry.
"Those guys charge $30 an hour, and I charge $10," he said, leaning on his black Ford with the rakes and shovels standing like pennants in their racks. "They buy their fertilizer at the same place I do, and then they raise the price of it for their customers. So there's a lot of old people that I go to who can't afford to pay what the big boys charge."
A typical lawn is 15,000 square feet and requires five fertilizer treatments a year at about $70 each, Mr. Turner said. Along with mowing and some tree pruning, the annual cost typically runs to more than $1,000. It can go as high as the $8,000 Mrs. Peiser calculated she and her husband spent maintaining their cultivated two-acre garden.
"There are some people who just have the men come in their trucks to mow the lawn, but clearly it needs more than that," she said of her yard. "I think that if all we did was cut the grass, it would all look rather sad."
Lately there has been a lot of interest in organic fertilizers, composed mainly of "tankage," which is the bone meal and anything else left over from cattle slaughter. But organic fertilizer costs twice as much as the chemical variety, Mr. Turner said, and does not include weed killers.
"People ask about it," he said, "but when I tell them that they'll have to pay $30 an hour for one of my men to pull weeds by hand, they forget it."
As it is, Americans put as much fertilizer on lawns, golf courses and cemeteries as the third world uses for growing food, said Beverly Eliot, who runs the Lawn Institute, a nonprofit research farm near Memphis.
"I know that could be made to sound negative, but it should not be seen that way," she said. "Lawns are the frames for your house, they give it curb appeal and raise values. They are excellent guards against erosion; they help keep ground water clean by holding and absorbing runoff. And they're soft, so they help prevent injuries. Just ask football players if they would rather play on artificial turf or natural grass."

HEADLINE: Sweden Agrees to Let Volvo Raise Its Stake in Procordia

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Volvo A.B. reached agreement yesterday with the Swedish Government over the auto maker's links with Procordia A.B., saying it would increase its stake in Procordia but would not merge with the food and drugs company.
The pact appears to end a three-month standoff between Volvo and the Swedish Government, which began on Jan. 25 when Volvo and Procordia announced plans to merge. If completed, the merger -- an exchange of shares valued at $6.6 billion -- would have been one of Europe's largest. 
 Under the terms of yesterday's compromise, Volvo will become the dominant shareholder of Procordia, and the Government will reduce its stake. The deal will increase Volvo's voting stake in Procordia to 45 percent, from about 42.7 percent, and cut the Government's holding to 40.4 percent, from 42.7 percent.
In addition, the Government said it planned to sell its remaining Procordia shares, preferably to a large number of investors in Sweden and abroad. But if the Government does arrange to sell off more than 5 percent of the total shares to any individual buyer or group, Volvo will have the right of first refusal on the sale.
As a consequence, Volvo could eventually acquire all of Procordia.
For the center-right Government of Prime Minister Carl Bildt, the deal allows it to pursue its goal of selling off Government stakes of Swedish companies while protecting the interests of taxpayers, who are effectively Procordia shareholders. The Government had objected to the proposed Volvo-Procordia merger, saying the complex stock-swap favored Volvo shareholders to the detriment of Procordia holders, a view shared by most securities analysts.
Moreover, Government critics of the merger plan said it had little industrial logic, besides giving Volvo access to the healthy cash flow from Procordia's eclectic stable of businesses, ranging from Nicorette, a gum to help people quit smoking, to its Pinkerton Tobacco subsidiary in America, which markets Red Man chewing tobacco. In the 12 months that ended in September, Procordia earned $545.5 million before taxes on sales of $6.51 billion.
For its part, Volvo wanted access to Procordia's cash to help it ride out the rough cycles in the car and truck business. But Volvo also argued that it would assist Procordia financially during the upswings in the auto market and that Volvo's global contacts would ease Procordia's way into foreign markets.
"We wanted the whole deal, and the Government said no," said Tomas Ericson, a vice president of the Volvo North America Corporation. "But this is an agreement that both parties are happy with."
Volvo, a small-scale producer, is considered one of Europe's less efficient car makers. It has also had to contend with recessions in its three main markets -- the United States, Britain and Sweden -- as well as tougher competition in Europe from Japanese car makers.
Last year, Volvo had an operating loss of 1.17 billion crowns ($210.7 million) on revenue of 77.22 billion crowns ($13.93 billion).
The link with Procordia has been one step in Volvo's effort to cope with the financial strain of an increasingly competitive global auto market. The other more significant step has been Volvo's integration with the French state-run auto maker, Renault S.A.
Volvo holds a 20 percent stake in Renault; the French Government holds 80 percent of the shares.
Volvo said last week that its alliance with Renault would mean annual savings of 4 billion crowns ($666 million) by the late 1990's, roughly twice the previous estimates of cost savings.
"There is only one direction, toward tighter cooperation," Pehr Gyllenhammar, Volvo's chairman, said at the company's annual meeting last week.

HEADLINE: Fernandez, Citing Los Angeles, Urges a School 'Marshall Plan'

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday called for an "educational Marshall Plan" to rebuild and recharge the nation's decaying urban schools, arguing that a small investment in Los Angeles's classrooms might have averted the losses in life and property left by the rioting last week.
In making his appeal, at a hearing in the Bronx, the Chancellor joined other political leaders yesterday who invoked the bitter lessons of Los Angeles to buttress the case for some programs they have long sought. 
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, for example, mentioned the turmoil in Los Angeles at a news conference in Albany yesterday to renew his call for a residency law that would require police officers, firefighters and all other uniformed workers hired in the future in New York City to be city residents.
"When I grew up in New York City, the public servants who protected us, taught us and cared for us in the clinics lived in the same city with us," Mr. Cuomo said. The residency law, he said, would increase the chances "that your public servants would reflect the population they serve."
 
'Options for Young People'
 And Mayor David N. Dinkins, without mentioning Los Angeles specifically, seemed to allude to the rioting by urging government to "provide options for young people" so that they do not feel "a desire to turn to violence." He also renewed his call for stricter Federal laws to control guns.
Mr. Fernandez and Mayor Dinkins made their remarks in testifying before a hearing on school violence that was held by Representative Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx. Mr. Serrano has sponsored a bill that would provide $100 million a year for three years to selected schools for buying metal detectors to screen for weapons and starting programs that help youngsters settle conflicts peacefully.
While expressing his support, Mr. Fernandez said that metal detectors would not solve the underlying despair that led to the Los Angeles rioting. He argued that too many young people see moldering school buildings, "battle fatigued" teachers, overcrowded classrooms, outdated textbooks and too few extracurricular activities and come to believe that the system does not care about them.
His remarks seemed to have a particular pungency in the dingy faded auditorium of James Monroe High School in the east Bronx, where the hearing was held.
 
Words Aimed at Washington
 While Mr. Fernandez is battling against cuts in the city's school budget, he principally aimed his message at the deeper pockets of the Federal Government. It was not the first time that he has used the metaphor of the Marshall Plan, the vast United States effort that was proposed by Secretary of State George C. Marshall to rebuild the economies of Europe after the devastation of World War II. But the remark seemed to have special significance to an audience for whom the television pictures of the churning fires of Los Angeles's storefronts were still vivid.
The Federal Government, he recalled, managed to find tens of billions of dollars quickly to bail out the savings and loan industry and tens of billions of dollars to wage the war against Iraq.
The United States, he said, must come up with similar determination and financing to rebuild the nation's schools so that students do not have "to attend schools that look like this."
"If those things don't happen, we'll lose that generation that you see out there," he told the panel as an audience of Monroe's students listened.
Long wary about metal detectors, Mr. Fernandez said that heightened security measures alone would not stop violence.
"What resolves the problem is getting rid of the frustration our kids have," he said.

HEADLINE: Dow Soars 42.04 to Hit New High

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks surged yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to another record, as Wall Street welcomed the return of calm in Los Angeles and the return of investors, who fled on Friday, back into the stock market.
The Dow gained 42.04 points, closing at 3,378.13, surpassing the previous record of 3,366.50, set on April 16. It marked the 18th time since Jan. 1 that the Dow bettered its previous high, a streak of advances that has fed on the seemingly endless procession of hints -- without outright confirmation -- that an economic recovery has begun. 
 The Dow soared more than 30 points in the opening hour of trading, and floated easily in record terrain for the rest of the day, reaching above 3,390 in the early afternoon. Other indexes also advanced strongly, although none broke a record.
 
'Big Sigh of Relief'
 "There was a big sigh of relief," said Robert Walberg, an analyst at MMS International, referring to the market's reaction to the peace that has descended on Los Angeles, in contrast with the dangerously uncertain situation when the market closed on Friday afternoon. "Everybody came back in early, and that gave us a nice pop."
Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation, argued that an even greater factor in the market's advance was the realization by many investors, after some faintly positive economic indicators were released late last week, that a feeble recovery might benefit stocks better than anything else.
"Wall Street is about to get the best possible of all worlds," Mr. Johnson said. "And that is a no-boom, no-bust trajectory that lasts."
 
Lower Interest Rates?
 In a slow, drawn-out recovery, Mr. Johnson said, the Federal Reserve Bank may again choose to lower interest rates, as long as inflation remains low. That will especially benefit growth-oriented stocks, which have fallen in recent weeks while the Dow has continued to climb.
Trading volume on the Big Board yesterday was moderate, as 174.5 million shares changed hands, compared with 177.4 million on Friday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.38 points, to 416.91, only a few points away from its high of 420.77, which was set on Jan. 15.
The Nasdaq Composite index, a leading indicator of over-the-counter stocks, went up 5.40 points, to 583.54, far below its record high of 644.92, set on Feb. 12. The American Stock Exchange index was also up, by 1.83 points, to 391.61, some distance from its record high of 418.99, also set on Feb. 12.
Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston, said that the market also reacted positively to rumors that the Federal Reserve Bank would again cut its discount rate.
"We're still in this odd period," Mr. Freedman said. "The worst of the economic bad news is over, but we're still waiting for the earnings to take off. There's still a lot of cash out there that's ready to come into the market.
"The environment is still good for stocks," he concluded. "There is nothing like low inflation and low interest rates for the stock market."
Mr. Freedman predicted greater gains in the market over the coming weeks. Mr. Walberg and Mr. Johnson were more cautious.
Health-care stocks, which drifted downward in recent weeks, were among yesterday's big gainers. Merck rose 3 5/8, to 147 1/2. Johnson & Johnson went up 1 5/8, to 97 3/8. Bristol Myers Squibb rose 1 3/4, to 76 1/2.
Brokerage industry stocks also gained broadly yesterday, after falling considerably in recent weeks. Morgan Stanley rose 2 3/4, to 52 1/8, while Salomon rose 1 7/8, to 33 1/8. Merrill Lynch went up 5/8, to 50 1/2.

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
Newspapers Seek Way Out of Income Drought

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The unusually down-to-business tone of this year's annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association became apparent early Sunday morning, a day before the convention formally began at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan.
A workshop was scheduled for 8:30 A.M., and it was so jammed with eager publishers that extra chairs had to be brought into the room, and there were not enough hand-out materials to meet the demand. 
 After two years of deep recession for newspapers, the workshop topic was one calculated to be irresistible, even to publishers who had come to New York early for a weekend on the town.
The title: "What's worked in revenue generating, cost containment and new products."
In other words, how to make more money.
Though there is a pronounced optimism among many newspaper publishers about the prospects for economic recovery, there is also an intense interest in finding new ways to generate revenues and cut costs after a painful advertising drought.
At 7 A.M. yesterday, another workshop advised publishers on how to start what are known in the industry as frequent reader programs, in which papers build circulation by offering special discounts at local businesses to those who subscribe for at least six months.
Harry M. Whipple, an expert in such programs, explained how The Arizona Daily Star in Tucson and The Tucson Citizen are going even further and joining with financial institutions to issue Visa and other credit cards to subscribers, then splitting with the financial institutions the commission paid by the retailers. And a plan is under way for the papers to start offering discount telephone rates through MCI and Sprint.
In a report to the association yesterday morning, Cathleen P. Black, the group's chief executive, said that marketing was one of the areas of primary focus for the association, along with public policy issues, technology and diversity.
Her appeal for more diverse newspaper staffs to the overwhelmingly white and male association was made not just on moral or even journalistic grounds, but on practical dollars-and-cents grounds as well.
Ms. Black said that diversity was vital to whether newspapers would be able to attract and keep the readers and advertisers they must have if the industry is to prosper in an increasingly diverse society.
"Diversity is right, it's good business, and it's long overdue," she said.
Similarly, Robert F. Erburu, the association's chairman and chairman of the Times Mirror Company, used his address to focus on "the importance of good journalism" after two years in which "events have focused much of our attention on the financial side of the business."
Mr. Erburu said that journalistic excellence was an obligation and the highest purpose of newspapers. He argued that sacrificing good journalism for the sake of profit was ultimately bad business.
"Our newspapers will fail as surely from a lack of principle as from a lack of revenue," Mr. Erburu said.
 
Return of a Hostage
 What will almost certainly prove to be the most dramatic and emotional segment of the convention was an appearance by Terry A. Anderson, the reporter for The Associated Press who was held prisoner in Lebanon for nearly seven years by Muslim fundamentalist kidnappers.
Mr. Anderson was released in December, and has spent most of his time since then relaxing, traveling, and recovering from his long ordeal.
Mr. Anderson said he would soon begin work on a book about his experience. He said the book would probably take about a year, and he had no plans as yet beyond that project.
In an informal conversation format, Louis D. Boccardi, president of The Associated Press, asked Mr. Anderson how he had survived his years of imprisonment.
"God had a great deal to do with it," Mr. Anderson said.
In a remarkably unbitter account of his experience, Mr. Anderson described how, after deserting Catholicism as a young man, he had returned to the faith six months before he was kidnapped in 1985. His captors allowed him a Bible, which he read through "like a book" 50 times.
He described how his jailers would prepare him to be moved to another location by wrapping him "like a mummy" with broad plastic tape, leaving only a breathing hole for his nose. Unable to move at all, he would then be thrown into the trunk of a car or into a cramped secret compartment of a truck bed, where he would have to spend hours inhaling exhaust fumes in sweltering heat.
In the only comment Mr. Anderson made that sounded at all self-congratulatory, he said with some pride that the fumes had made him violently sick and that it had taken "an enormous effort of will" not to throw up, because with his mouth taped he knew he would choke on his own vomit.
When Mr. Boccardi referred to Mr. Anderson as courageous, he countered that Terry Waite, the Anglican church envoy, was courageous because he chose to go to Lebanon to try to free hostages and was taken prisoner.
"I had no choice," Mr. Anderson said, describing his view of himself as having demonstrated "will and some strength," but not -- to his mind -- courage.
Asked if he hated his captors, Mr. Anderson said he did not.
"I have no room for it; I have no time for it," he said. "Bitterness will not hurt them one ounce, it will only hurt me."
The nation's newspaper publishers signaled their opinion of Mr. Anderson with two prolonged standing ovations.
 
A Better Sense of Humor
 "There's not as much gallows humor this year," said Frank A. Daniels Jr., publisher of The News & Observer in Raleigh, N.C.
The anticipation of better profits and a recovering economy have indeed lifted the collective spirit of the newspaper industry.
But while there may not be as much gallows humor, there is still humor.
The staple joke at this year's convention stems from the imminent merger of the American Newspaper Publishers Association (A.N.P.A.) with the Newspaper Advertising Bureau (N.A.B.) and several other industry associations into a new umbrella organization to be called The Newspaper Association of America (N.A.A.).
The merger, which is scheduled for June 1, is expected to create nearly $5 million in cost savings annually and improve overall service.
While the merger has not generated serious opposition, its new name has created what may prove to be an unfortunate acronym.
Wags are already referring to the new Newspaper Association of America as, "Naaaaaaa!"

HEADLINE: Pizza and Persistence Win in Hungary

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
It is close to midnight and George F. Hemingway, a one-man American locomotive for the nascent market economy in Hungary, is swinging his Isuzu Trooper through the gloomy streets here, pointing out the extent of his business empire.
"That's mine," says the burly entrepreneur from Los Angeles, gesturing toward a gourmet food store called Bon Bon Hemingway. "That's mine also," he adds, as he passes a sports outfitter named USA Sport. "Mine too," he declares, indicating a Chinese restaurant that, he reckons, serves Europe's finest caramelized bananas. "And this is my big favorite," he roars, lurching to a halt beside Hungary's first Pizza Hut. 
 Outside the restaurant, which opened in April, is a long line; inside, a vision of Hollywood, complete with shocking lilac walls, a fresco of Superman, portraits of Humphrey Bogart and a mannequin of Marilyn Monroe. As Mr. Hemingway strides in, the manager scurries up with a computer printout: 1,980 pizzas served that day and more than $6,500 earned.
"He's not selling pizza; he's selling the speed and glitz of U.S. culture," said Peter Rona, the chief executive of the First Hungary investment fund.
Agnes Pankotai, a student, explained her willingness to line up for pizza. "It's the only thing like it in a city of two million people and it's exciting," she said. But the price of about $2.60 for the cheapest pizza is something "most Hungarians can only afford about once a month," she added.
Still, Mr. Hemingway, who made his fortune selling pizza and real estate in California, said, "I never did business like this in the U.S." Beaming, he reflected: "You know, I first came here in 1984 and could see that socialism was not the system of the future. It was clear there would be something else and I thought, hey, it'll probably be capitalism."
The same thought has occurred to many other Western business executives since the countries of the former Soviet bloc began their painful transition to market economies two and a half years ago. But while the majority of potential investors have pondered the political instability, inflation, yo-yoing currencies and Communist mind-sets, Mr. Hemingway has acted.
 
Faith and Computers
 "All you need in Eastern Europe," the 44-year-old businessman insists, "is a basic faith and a very good computer system."
In fact, his success seems to reflect two central factors: an unusual perseverance in the face of initially stifling bureaucracy and the emergence of Hungary as the East European country offering the best prospects of doing business.
"If there's anywhere in East Europe to make a buck, it's Hungary," said Marc L. Holtzman, the chief executive of Central European Associates, a Budapest-based consulting firm. "But it's no good coming for four nights and leaving. You have to roll up your sleeves and dig in because a transaction that might take two months in the U.S. takes a year here. That's what Hemingway has done -- dig in."
His Hungarian empire comprises 137 restaurants in Budapest, 31 in the provinces, a hotel, 87 food stores, several sports shops with the exclusive license for L.A. Gear, a computer company, an agricultural publishing concern and a furniture importer. With an exclusive fast-food franchise from Pepsico, Mr. Hemingway plans to open 15 Pizza Huts and 22 Kentucky Fried Chicken outlets in the next three years. And with a franchise from Allied-Lyons P.L.C., he has 40 Dunkin' Donuts on the drawing board.
 
Long-Distance Commuting
 Mr. Hemingway has had to face difficulties typical of Eastern Europe -- a deep recession and soaring unemployment that have cut into consumer spending, and restaurant employees with little tradition of or commitment to attentive, speedy service. But commuting twice a month between Hollywood Hills and Budapest, he has been in the vanguard of a growing private sector that has thrived on the determination of the Hungarian authorities to unshackle the economy.
Where it required 12 permits to open a barber shop two years ago, today none is needed. Where just 10 percent of the economy was in private hands in 1989, 40 percent is now privately held, including a large underground economy, said the former governor of the central bank, Gyorgy Suranyi.
William H. Strong, chief executive of Salomon Brothers in London, mentioned Hungary's clear corporate and tax laws, ethnic homogeneity and far-reaching deregulation. "Hemingway typifies the spirit of entrepreneurism that Hungary is endorsing more strongly than its neighbors," he said. Salomon is currently raising $20 million to back Mr. Hemingway's East European expansion.
A lawyer, Mr. Hemingway formerly worked for McKenna & Fitting, a Los Angeles law firm, and made his fortune in pizzas and real estate in California. He learned Hungarian from his mother, who was born in Budapest, and first invested in Hungary in the mid-1980's, setting up a chocolate factory.
"It was horrendous," he recalls. "There was fear everywhere, and the Government was very ambivalent about foreigners. I couldn't even get aluminum foil for my chocolates."
Persevering, he acquired from the state a chain of stores that he renamed Bon Bon Hemingway and a large stable of dingy but nicely situated self-service restaurants. Some have already been converted into ethnic restaurants, serving, among other things, Chinese, Korean, Japanese and Czechoslovak fare. Others are to be converted to Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Dunkin' Donut restaurants.
"It was never a question of can I do it or not," Mr. Hemingway said. "It was that I wanted to do it. Too many potential investors here do not have that enthusiasm to carry them through the difficulties."
In all, he has invested more than $20 million of his own money in Hungary, including $1.1 million in the first Pizza Hut restaurant. Since 1990, his activities have been grouped in Hemingway Holding A.G., a company quoted on the Vienna stock exchange in which his California holding company owns 51 percent. Girozentrale, an Austrian bank, recently recommended the shares in a report, citing "very promising profitability" for the company's activities in Hungary.
Certainly Pizza Hut has made an impressive debut, with lines of as many as 150 people regularly stretching outside the restaurant. Mr. Hemingway's gamble on decor and computers allowing waiters to punch orders directly into a portable electronic ordering system appear to have impressed Hungarians.
Mr. Hemingway has been trying hard to teach the notion of service, something foreign to the people of East Europe after 40 years or more of Communism. When a waitress approaches and quickly retreats after a customer says he does not want dessert, Mr. Hemingway leaps to his feet.
"What do you mean by going away?" he asks the waitress. "How about suggesting an ice cream, or coffee, or some cakes?" As she slinks off, he says, "You have to teach everything -- how to smile, how to move, how to seat people. The people here are smarter than in California, but they're slower. So you work on the speed. You say, 'Excuse me, you're moving in slow motion.' "
 
Margins of 25%
 This is not a problem from which Mr. Hemingway suffers. His first Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant -- decorated in what he calls California Art Deco -- is scheduled to open across the street later this year. By 1995, he expects to be operating at least 77 fast-food restaurants and reckons he can operate them with 25 percent profit margins. In the United States, a typical profit margin at a fast-food franchise is far less.
As yet, there is scant political resistance to this Americanization of Budapest. "We do have some criticism that it's not good to have a Pizza Hut or a Burger King on every corner downtown," said Attila Tarkany Szucs, the deputy managing director of the State Property Agency. "But fast food is still welcome, and Mr. Hemingway has a good reputation."
Yet in other East European countries, where he hopes to expand, Mr. Hemingway has not fared so well. He recently met with Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus of Czechoslovakia and came away disillusioned.
"Mr. Klaus kept talking about the first wave and the second wave and third wave of privatization and which wave I should come in on," Mr. Hemingway said. "I got the same wave stuff in Bulgaria. But I'm not interested in waves. In fact I'm getting an allergy to the wave word in Eastern Europe. I want to know how to do business. I want to know when I can open a Pizza Hut on Wenceslas Square."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Slow Trading; Gold Shows Mixed Results

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday in dealings quieted by holidays in two important foreign markets -- Japan, where Constitution Day was observed, and Britain, which has an annual bank holiday in May.
Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $337.30 an ounce, off $1.70 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.45 an ounce, to a late bid of $336.80. 
 Analysts said the dollar opened higher in domestic dealings. Traders tried to bring the dollar down, but it recovered on technical buying by the end of the session.
Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA, called the day's trading "the calm before the storm." He said the Thursday meeting of Germany's central bank council and Friday's release of American unemployment data for April could pull the dollar out of its recent tight trading range.
There are some rumors that Germany's central bankers might lift interest rates, putting American rates at even more of a disadvantage. Similarly, speculation is brewing that the Federal Reserve might lower American interest rates by the end of the month.
"Interest-rate differentials are capping the dollar's upside momentum, while some buying is capping the downside," Mr. Chandler said. Noting that "overnight rates here are about 3.75 percent; in Germany they're 9.60 percent," Mr. Chandler said "that illustrates why the dollar can't rise."
Higher rates abroad make foreign debt securities more attractive to investors, increasing their need for foreign currencies. In the past, relatively high American rates lured investors and enhanced the value of the dollar.
In Europe, the dollar was quoted at 132.55 yen, down from 133.13 yen on Friday in Tokyo. In New York the dollar settled at 133.20 yen, up from 132.65 on Friday.
In Europe, the British pound was quoted at $1.7795, down from $1.7840 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.7790 to buy a pound, down from $1.7865 on Friday.
In Zurich, the late bid for gold was $336.85, up from $336.35 late Thursday. Zurich markets were closed Friday.
Silver prices rose in domestic trading. On the Comex in New York, silver settled at $4.002 an ounce, up from $3.997 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
A Worker Share Of Rise in Output

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

DATELINE: WOOSTER, Ohio

 BODY:
CHRISTOPH SCHMID'S message is a little unusual for the chief of a Midwestern manufacturer. His company, Luk Inc., supplies the Big Three American auto makers with the majority of the clutch plates they use in their stick-shift transmissions, a highly competitive business. But Mr. Schmid says that rising labor costs for Luk's 311 employees here are not a major problem -- and certainly not a reason to shutter the plant and decamp for Mississippi or Mexico.
Not that Luk, a German company, outbids the other manufacturers for workers in this partly rural, partly industrial town, still encircled by grain fields. Quite the contrary. The various manufacturers swap wage information so that all use roughly the same scale of $7 to $15 an hour. But while others stress sticking close to this pay scale and holding down labor costs, Mr. Schmid preaches generous extra payments to reward his workers for their productivity. He insists that Luk can offset this extra outlay through constant investment and retraining, so that the factory can produce more clutch plates per worker. 
 "We are going to go above Rubbermaid in pay in a few years; not significantly, but above them," Mr. Schmid said, referring to the manufacturer of housewares that is Wooster's biggest employer. "Fortunately, our shareholders focus on productivity, and ours is rising at 6 percent a year."
Output per worker at Rubbermaid, one of the nation's most profitable companies, is also rising smartly. And Rubbermaid is channeling back to its workers at least some of the added income that they generate from their increased production -- mostly as contributions to pension accounts. But while Mr. Schmid, president of the Luk subsidiary here, says he is willing to offset higher labor costs by striving for greater productivity, Walter W. Williams, Rubbermaid's chairman, tries to hold the line on compensation. Rubbermaid's managers tell workers that the payoff for productivity is job security. And if the workers insist on higher pay, then the company might shift some operations to Rubbermaid factories elsewhere with lower labor costs. And this the company has done.
The Rubbermaid approach has held sway among United States companies for more than a decade. But as Corporate America has made itself more productive and thus more competitive in world markets, pressure has risen on management to share the gains with workers, as Luk says it is doing.
"Once the economy recovers from recession, then the issue will be whether American companies will raise workers' earnings," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist. "If they don't, then managers and shareholders will get the new income from productivity gains, and not workers, and incomes will continue to stagnate for most of the population."
But if Mr. Schmid's approach previews the future, then the Luk operation here offers a significant insight. Breaking with the past, the new income from greater productivity will not be distributed as higher base pay, but as bonuses, profit-sharing and other special payments that can be canceled if sales or productivity decline. Mr. Schmid, a 45-year-old German engineer who has been a Luk executive in Wooster for a decade, says that bonuses and other variable payments represent 25 percent of the company's labor costs.
The pay of Jeannie Boyd, a 34-year-old operator of computerized punch presses, illustrates how productivity at Luk translates into income. Her base wage -- what she gets whether she is working or on vacation or out sick --is $7.55 an hour, having risen by 25 cents in each of the last three years. The raises failed to keep pace with inflation, but Ms. Boyd also earns an additional $1.80 to $2.40 an hour, depending on how many clutch plates she processes. And every three months she gets a bonus check, representing her share of the company's gains from productivity. Her 1991 income was $23,000, with roughly $15,000 of it in base pay.
When sales drop, then work subcontracted to outsiders -- data processing, for example -- is pulled back to sustain productivity, and people are retrained: an assembly line worker might become an accounting staff member, for example, or a packer might learn to run a machine. Luk has not increased its staff in three years, but like Rubbermaid it has not laid anyone off in years.
Mr. Schmid insists that the retraining and flexible use of workers make moving to Mexico a moot point. Although worker pay here is several times higher than at Luk's Mexico operation, so is productivity, and personnel costs in Wooster represent 18 percent of total costs compared with 19 percent in Mexico.
"I don't have to and won't, but if I did go up $2 an hour in wages, that is not going to kill me," Mr. Schmid said. "It would take something out of the bottom line short-term, until I could find ways to offset this with efficiencies."

PUB-DATE: May 5, 1992,

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 478 words

HEADLINE: The Fight for Mr. Bush's Mind

 BODY:
Following the waves of urban violence 25 years ago, President Johnson announced an "unconditional war on poverty." Later this week George Bush flies to Los Angeles to deliver his response to urban violence 1992. He lacks Lyndon Johnson's passion for the poor. He surely lacks for easy access to funds. What he does have is a priceless opportunity to face up to a subject he rarely touches -- the racial and economic divisions laid bare by the violence.
In the last few days, Mr. Bush has sensibly balanced justice and order. But what of substance? Even now, his aides struggle for his mind. 
 On one side are people like Housing Secretary Jack Kemp who urge that he make a strong speech complete with a forceful anti-poverty agenda. On the other are cost-conscious budgeteers like Richard Darman and some political advisers, who worry that a program to help the disadvantaged would reap little or no political gain.
And then there is Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater, who yesterday blamed the violence on the social programs of the 1960's and 70's (read the Democrats). It would be silly and wrong for Mr. Bush to continue that line. Silly because it's such a pinched, ideological response to a national tragedy. Wrong because many Great Society programs -- Head Start and the Job Corps, to name two -- have been consistently successful.
Unfortunately, should he choose to take a higher road than Mr. Fitzwater, Mr. Bush does not so far have much to offer. His urban policies filled only 25 pages of a 433-page budget, and half of that concerns drugs and law enforcement. The rest consists of initiatives from Mr. Kemp.
For years the Housing Secretary has promoted "empowerment" -- the idea that giving inner-city residents more control over their lives offers greater hope than dependency. To that end, Mr. Kemp would allow poor families to buy apartments in public housing projects. He would also establish 50 "enterprise zones" in depressed urban areas. Businesses that invest would receive tax breaks; their workers would receive tax credits.
The idea has two big flaws. In similar state-run schemes, many businesses have ended up hiring workers from outside the target zone. And there's a real danger that once Congress gets through with it, the pork will be spread too thin to make much difference. That was the fate of Lyndon Johnson's Model Cities program.
Still, unlike others in Mr. Bush's camp, Mr. Kemp recognizes the crisis in urban America. He deserves credit for his principled effort to bring conservative ideas to bear on the central problems: jobs and poverty.
There's a lesson here for the President. For 12 years, he has acted as though he believes all the Reagan-era oratory that this is "morning in America." Mourning, as Los Angeles shows, is more like it, and the country waits to see what Mr. Bush wants to do about it.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 485 words

HEADLINE: For the 90's, National Security Begins at Home

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Indefensible Defense" (editorial, April 12) is a welcome addition to the all-too-muted debate on reduced defense expenditures. For the most part, our national decision makers have failed to recognize the extent of the reduced threat to our national security following the collapse of the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact.
What is needed now is a revised definition of national security that factors in the well-being and skills levels of our human resources as well as the dangerous pathologies of drugs, AIDS, domestic violence, substandard housing and inadequate health care. A new definition of national security must also take into account our industrial base, levels of productivity, rates of capital formation, rebuilding of infrastructure and the state of research and development for civilian purposes. 
 All of these contribute to the foundations of American strength (and are reflected in our ability to defend ourselves in the future). But they are also important in their own right.
Further, the transition from military production to peaceful production requires a national bipartisan plan for conversion which minimizes the pain on those workers whose livelihoods will be affected, including subsidized training for new employment opportunities.
We cannot use the excuse of job dislocation to obstruct the transition from a military-propelled to a civilian-dominated economy. It is ironic to hear conservatives who stridently oppose welfare for the most needy among us become the vociferous advocates of obsolete military production to pander to voters in their own constituencies. From our perspective, that amounts to welfare for the producers and their employees.
Less fortunate Americans, including many of our minorities, have seen their dreams deferred for half a century as our leaders increased defense expenditures at the expense of housing, education, universal health care and job training. Regardless of class or race, Americans supported the notion of a militarily dominant America in face of threats to our survival as a free nation.
Now things have radically changed, and it is time to get on with the fulfillment of the American dream -- for every single American.
Honest men and women can differ over which weapons systems to eliminate or reduce, but we can no longer differ on reordering our priorities to put the prosperity, health and safety of people at home at the top of the list.
We of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People intend to hold our national leaders responsible for the speed and scope of
this urgently needed transition. The elections in November will be the first test of their commitment and will. It will be a challenge for every concerned American, regardless of party, race, region or gender. Let the debate begin.
 
BENJAMIN L. HOOKS
Executive Director, N.A.A.C.P.
Baltimore, April 16, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 285 words

HEADLINE: For the 90's, National Security Begins at Home;
Making the Adjustment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leslie H. Gelb (column, April 17) laments our inability to earn the peace dividend because of the absence of conversion plans. Consequently, he points out, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's $1.5 trillion military spending bill over the next five years is less a response to imagined new enemies than a jobs bill.
Unfortunately, the problem is more general. The inability to accept the dislocation of workers and entrepreneurs also makes us leery of bringing the free trade agreement with Mexico to a vote, of pushing for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and probably even leads us to the forcible repatriation of political refugees from Haiti. 
 For some reason, we seem to have given up trying to devise an effective adjustment program. Yet the Scandinavians have reportedly done reasonably well with worker retraining; the Japanese manage to shift production from sunset to sunrise activity within the same company, and Chile has devised a temporary, large-scale public-works program. Though our own experience with adjustment assistance, sometimes called "burial assistance," has been mixed, that is no reason to give up. Precious little effort has been expended on studying past successes and failures.
We need to create a system that gets workers and entrepreneurs to shift into new activities, instead of giving them additional time and incentive to resist change. The budgetary resources would not be a problem; foreign aid spent at home would be popular both in this country and abroad, be cost effective and pay large returns on several fronts around the globe.
 
GUSTAV RANIS
Frank Altschul Professor of International Economics, Yale
New Haven, April 24, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 325 words

HEADLINE: For the 90's, National Security Begins at Home;
Transportation Focus

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Indefensible Defense" (editorial, April 12) calls for major cutbacks in large, obsolete weapons programs. You leave out making a responsible transition from military to commercial activity. You are talking about layoffs for tens of thousands and destruction of many communities across the country at a time of feeble recovery, if any, from deep recession.
Why not use most of the billions saved by cutbacks for a national initiative that uses much of the talent we have? I am thinking of the speech in which John F. Kennedy set this country on its course to the moon. Areas that contain a vast range of technology are energy and transportation. How about unifying this country's efforts in transportation and related energy research under a national transportation initiative? 
 The initiative would have as its goal making this country the world's center of transportation expertise. With new technologies on the horizon, superconductivity and new fuels, this seems an opportune time to provide a national focus to develop technologies associated with air, land and sea transportation of goods and people.
This initiative would have to be coordinated at the national level by a public corporation or Government agency. One important part would be to involve our aerospace industry. Also, of course, it should include the repair and upgrading of our transportation infrastructure, which badly needs attention.
Think of building an intercity network of high-speed surface and tube trains, running between stations fed by an urban-suburban network of electric, clean-running, highly efficient vehicles. Think of all the opportunities for improved commuter transportation, centered on safe, small vehicles and road-unclogging mass transit.
Think of spending billions for a better society, instead of killer weapons.
 
RICHARD L. SCHAPKER
Montgomeryville, Pa., April 17, 1992
 
The writer is a mechanical engineer.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
Easy Clinton Victory Is Expected In Capital's Democratic Primary

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Already well on his way to capturing the Democratic Presidential nomination, Gov. Bill Clinton is the runaway favorite to win the District of Columbia primary on Tuesday.
The only real issues in the contest are how many of the 17 delegates at stake the Arkansas Governor can win and whether, in the process, he can spark an enthusiastic voter turnout. 
 Ninety percent of the District's voters are Democrats, the vast majority of them black. Thus, Tuesday's primary, more than any other this year, offers Mr. Clinton a clear-cut opportunity to demonstrate his strength with black voters.
In most other primaries this year Mr. Clinton has enjoyed solid backing from black voters, whose support is crucial to Democratic Presidential candidates. But the turnout of blacks has been low, often lagging behind that of whites, whose turnout in the current climate of voter unease is at its lowest level in years.
 
Emphasis on Black Support
 Mr. Clinton seems intent on making the best of Tuesday's opportunity to show strength with black voters. Although he has a big lead in delegates and is his party's likely Presidential nominee, the Arkansan has invested a considerable amount of time campaigning here, making three swings, the latest on Sunday.
The other major Democratic candidate on the ballot is former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. He did not spend as much time in the city as Mr. Clinton, though he made a final appearance today, calling for racial healing after the riots last week in Los Angeles.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts is also on the ballot, and a few diehard supporters are campaigning for him even though he suspended his campaign six weeks ago.
Then there is an "uncommitted" line on the ballot.
In some primary contests earlier this year, sometimes to Mr. Clinton's embarrassment, "uncommitted" has drawn large numbers of votes, another reflection of the deep political unease within the electorate. But more recently, as Mr. Clinton has moved closer to becoming his party's nominee, the uncommitted vote has begun to shrink.
 
Support From Labor Group
 When Mr. Clinton visited Washington on Sunday, he spoke at two black churches and met with some local labor leaders, the two main forces in Democratic politics here.
The labor leaders, members of the Metropolitan Washington Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., endorsed the Governor. He also picked up the endorsement of the city's Mayor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, one of the few top-tier local political figures who had not previously endorsed him.
Just about the only remaining high-profile local Democrat who has not endorsed Mr. Clinton is the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the nonvoting delegate to the Senate for the District of Columbia. Mr. Jackson has taken no public stand in the Washington primary except to make sure that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown do not waver in their support for statehood for the District.
Republicans will also hold a primary on Tuesday. But since they account for barely 10 percent of the city's vote and President Bush already has his party's nomination in his pocket, the contest is expected to go all but unnoticed.
Mr. Bush's sole opponent, Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist and television commentator, is now talking only of being a "voice" in national politics.
