HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Jumped 18.3% In Late April

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 5

 BODY:
Sales of North American-built cars and light trucks rose 18.3 percent in late April. While automotive analysts said the gain fell short of a full-fledged recovery, it provided a lift to beleaguered auto makers and retail dealers.
Sales of domestic cars rose 10.8 percent in late April, to 235,864, and domestic light-truck sales rose 31 percent, to 163,389. The total sales of domestic vehicles, 399,253, compared with 300,075 in the corresponding period of 1991. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for domestically built cars was 6.1 million for the April 21-30 period. The seasonally adjusted annual rate for all of April was 6.0 million, compared with 5.5 million for the month a year earlier. The industry considers cars assembled in the United States, Canada and Mexico to be domestically made.
 
 
Weak Sales a Year Earlier
 Because vehicle sales were so weak in April 1991, the fairly large percentage increases were not enough to raise sales to a level that analysts would call healthy or robust.
Over all, the industry sold 1.12 million vehicles in April, a year-to-year increase of 8.2 percent. That consisted of 718,429 cars, an increase of 3.4 percent, and 401,575 light trucks, up 18 percent.
"We're stuck in neutral," said Harvey Heinbach, the automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch. "The rate does understate the fact that retail buyers have replaced fleet buyers somewhat, but it's still disappointing."
Wendy Needham, automotive analyst for Smith Barney in New York, said: "A lot of positive things are going on that the gross numbers are masking, such as overall profitability. The quality of the sales is better this year."
There were nine selling days in the late-April period this year, compared with eight selling days in 1991. Percentage increases for the period account for the difference in the number of selling days.
Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, acknowledged that sales had been stalled at about the same rate since last fall. But, he said, "we remain convinced that the recovery in the economy, which is very real, will soon make an appearance in the auto industry."
D. Kim Hackett, owner of Pontiac and Saturn franchises in Orlando, Fla., said, "The economy is coming on strong." He said Saturn sales had doubled from a year ago, when the models were just becoming available, and Pontiac sales were up 30 percent in April. He said that instead of buying station wagons, customers had been choosing the Pontiac Trans Sport mini-van.
The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, reported a 10.7 percent increase in late-April sales of domestically built cars, to 110,754, and a 21.1 percent increase for domestically built light trucks, to 58,871. For the entire month, G.M. sold 6.7 percent more domestically built cars, or 252,818, and 11.5 percent more domestically built light trucks, or 133,331. Over all, G.M. sold 398,745 vehicles in April, including domestics and imports, a 6.9 percent increase from April 1991.
The Ford Motor Company posted a 5.5 percent increase in domestic car sales for late April, to 58,088, and a 19.2 percent increase in light trucks, to 49,824. For the month, domestic car sales rose 9.4 percent, to 142,461, and purchases of light trucks rose 20.3 percent, to 126,070. Over all, Ford sold 275,812 domestic and imported vehicles in April, a 13.2 percent increase from April 1991.
 Robert L. Rewey, Ford's vice president of sales operations, said, "April was the fifth month in a row that our truck and total vehicle sales both increased versus the prior year."
The Chrysler Corporation sold 49,219 domestic cars in April, an increase of 5.2 percent from a year earlier, and 94,660 domestic trucks, an increase of 38.5 percent. Chrysler does not report sales on a 10-day cycle. Chrysler said its total April sales, which rose 23.8 percent to 150,227, were the best in nearly two years.
 
Bigger Share for Big Three
 Benefiting from price increases for vehicles sold by Japanese auto makers, the Big Three gained market share last month. G.M., Ford and Chrysler sold 71.3 percent of all vehicles, compared with 68.3 percent a year ago. Japanese auto makers, including those with manufacturing operations in the United States, sold 23.3 percent, compared with 24.8 percent last year. The share of all other importers was 5.4 percent, down from 6.9 percent a year earlier.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's vehicle sales for the month rose 9.1 percent, to 81,756. About 37 percent of Toyota's cars and trucks were built in the United States.
The Nissan Motor Company sold 48,640 cars and trucks, about even with its sales a year earlier. The Honda Motor Company sold 62,689 cars, down 9.4 percent from the April 1991 total of 69,177. The Mazda Motor Corporation sold 39,238 cars and light trucks, up 28.4 percent. And the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation sold 16,159 cars and trucks for the month, down 14 percent from a year earlier.

HEADLINE: U.S. Court Suspends Capital Law Aiding Minority Businesses

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court today ordered a temporary suspension of the District of Columbia's minority set-aside contracting law, saying it violated the civil rights of a white-owned business.
The decision jeopardizes a 15-year city policy and tens of millions of dollars in contracts that Washington awards annually to minority-owned businesses. 
 "The district will need to make major changes in its letting of contracts," the court said in an opinion written by Judge A. Raymond Randolph of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly said the decision reflected the "economic retrenchment" minorities have suffered during the Reagan-Bush years.
But she said as a safeguard against such a ruling, her office had already been planning other ways to encourage minority businesses and will hold a series of seminars on how to compete for government contracts.
The decision requires a lower court to temporarily block application of the law to the O'Donnell Construction Company, which is owned by whites. While the appellate court left the decision on making the injunction permanent to the lower court, it said that so far Washington had failed to show the law did not violate the company's constitutional right to equal protection under the law.
The law requires agencies to set aside 35 percent of city contracts for minority-owned businesses. Although the law calls the 35 percent figure a "goal," the court said that figure was in practice a quota.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Riots Inflamed a Festering South-Central Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 5

 BODY:
As officials develop plans for the future of the ravaged South-Central area, residents say that rebuilding and restocking stores there will not be nearly enough to address the resentment generated over the years by the community's racially fractured, barely functional economy.
Even before last week's spasm of violence, South-Central Los Angeles was close to an economic wasteland, with few stores, banks or well-paying jobs for its predominantly black and Hispanic residents. Per capita annual income, at $7,600 for the core of South-Central in 1990, was 52.6 percent lower than for Los Angeles County as a whole. There is one supermarket for every 40,646 residents in South-Central's core, as against one for every 23,224 residents in the county. 
 Living just a few miles from the glittering office towers of downtown Los Angeles and the palm-lined boulevards of Beverly Hills, the 523,000 residents of South-Central's 25 square miles have always been aware of such disparities.
"We may have access to stores, but everything is second-rate," said Mary Bolden, a black resident of South-Central. "You have to learn to settle for that or go without, and that brings on anger."
 
Widening Chasm
 The inequities, economists and other analysts said, have only grown in the last two decades. While most of California boomed, South-Central suffered from a flight of well-paid manufacturing jobs, an exodus of middle-class blacks and a reluctance among large businesses to operate there.
"What's happened is the culmination of frustration on two fronts, the first being a series of events over the last decade showing that blacks have disproportionately been treated in a disrespectful manner by the police," said James Johnson, the director of the Center for the Study of Urban Poverty at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The other has to do with the steadily declining access to mainstream economic opportunities. Over the last two decades blacks in those communities have become increasingly isolated economically."
The face of the South-Central area has been changed by a rapid influx of Hispanic residents and a decline in the black population. From 1980 to 1990, the area lost more than 48,000 black residents, while the Hispanic population grew by 146,000, bringing the racial mix to about 55 percent black and 45 percent Hispanic in 1990, from 65 percent black and 17 percent Hispanic a decade earlier, according to the United States Census Bureau.
 
No Consensus on Remedy
 Racial tensions are growing in the area. Black residents have become increasingly resentful of the rapidly growing Hispanic population, which economists said is taking the majority of the region's low-wage jobs.
And as the riots made clear, many black and Hispanic residents harbor considerable hostility toward Korean immigrants, who have become the area's merchants but employ few people from the neighborhood in their family-run stores.
As a result, South-Central residents and economists said, there is no single political power base or clear consensus on what needs to be done to rebuild the area. That fractiousness, they said, is certain to slow the effort being headed by Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, to rebuild the area and address the underlying economic problems. Mr. Ueberroth said last weekend that the rebuilding effort could be effective only if the diverse community, as well as government officials and businesses, came together and made a commitment to working together over the long term.
 
'Can't Get Any Worse'
 Mr. Ueberroth, who organized the nearly flawless 1984 Summer Olympic Games but who is little known in minority neighborhoods, has won commitments from several local banks to provide small-business loans and from supermarket companies to repair and reopen their stores. But it remains uncertain how much financial support Mr. Ueberroth will obtain from governments and corporations, or what specific steps he plans beyond repairing the physical damage from the riot.
The looting, arson and violence, which destroyed thousands of businesses and caused as much as $1 billion in damage, exposed the fragile nature of the local economy.
"The Rodney King incident was the match that lit the fire that exposed the increasing disparity between the haves and have-nots," said Carlton Jenkins, the managing director of Founders National Bank, the only black-owned commercial bank in Los Angeles. "It's been a situation festering for some time in the economically disenfranchised communities who live every day with the knowledge that they've gotten everything they're ever going to get."
With the area's few grocery stores and most of its convenience stores destroyed or closed because of arson and looting, residents were unable to find food and other essential goods, forcing them to travel miles away from home, line up for handouts or go without. People who needed to cash paychecks or welfare checks found the area's few banks and most of its check-cashing services shut down. Many residents were unable to get to their jobs for days because bus service was canceled.
"Thank God my supervisor understands," said Tajuana Falls, a South-Central resident who could not get to her job as a clerk at the county courthouse because she had been unable to pick up her paycheck or buy her bus pass. "It can't get any worse than this."
The unemployment rate in the core of the South-Central area in 1990 was 7.1 percent, according to a survey by the Census Bureau, as against 5.8 percent for all of Los Angeles County. Among black teen-agers, the rate in South-Central was 43.8 percent, and among blacks aged 25 to 54, the rate was 9.1 percent, the Census Bureau said. Many economists think the census data substantially understate the unemployment rate in South-Central.
 
Manufacturers Relocated
 In any case, economists said, the unemployment statistics understate the economy's deteriorating condition. Mr. Johnson of the University of California at Los Angeles said that from 1978 to 1982 alone, South-Central and neighboring areas lost 70,000 high-paying, previously stable manufacturing jobs of the sort that supported the black middle class. During that nationwide recession, companies like General Motors and Bethlehem Steel relocated or closed their plants.
Mr. Johnson said new jobs had replaced many of the lost manufacturing jobs but that most of the new jobs, in industries like garment making, did not pay nearly as well and were often filled by Hispanic immigrants, some of them in the United States illegally.
"It's hard to get a job here because all these foreigners are coming in and working for $2.50 an hour, and they don't even speak English," said Patrick Burns, a black construction worker who said he had not had a job in three years.
Because the area has few large shopping centers, it has few retail and other service jobs compared to the city as a whole. And because many of the small stores are owned by Koreans and other Asian immigrants who bring enough money to finance their own operations and who tend to employ mostly family members, few jobs are available with neighborhood retailers.
Many residents and business executives say that unless political leaders reshape the rebuilding effort to address underlying problems like the declining quality of the city's schools and the lack of job training and bank financing available to South-Central residents, nothing will change.
"These folks come out of school unable to read, much less read a blueprint at an aerospace company," said Mr. Jenkins, the banker. "There's also the glass-ceiling concept, which suggests that the best opportunities are in minority-owned businesses. But if you look at the number of minority-owned businesses, you know they can't absorb many people looking for work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For the 523,000 residents of South-Central Los Angeles, the road back appears exceedingly long. The economic disparities between it and other sections of Los Angeles were severe even before the rioting. A merchant yesterday set out merchandise in front of his burned-out store. HEADLINE: In Mississippi Education Battle, New Governor Loses on First Veto

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 5

 BODY:
In its continuing effort to improve the state's historically poor record of supporting education, the Mississippi Legislature has voted to override the new Governor's veto of a sales tax increase to $168 million for school buildings, books and supplies.
The dramatic defeat for Gov. Kirk Fordice, the state's first Republican governor in 115 years, came as an unusual weekend session of the Legislature extended into Monday. On a vote of 82 to 38, the House finally provided the necessary two-thirds margin for an override. The voting capped months of bickering in which Mr. Fordice, who had campaigned on a platform of no new taxes, had vetoed the measure without offering any alternative. 
 The outcome provided an occasion for partisan cheering by Democrats and was an omen of tough sledding ahead for Mr. Fordice, who Democratic State Auditor Steve Patterson said had shown "a lack of sophistication in being able to negotiate" with the Democratic-controlled Legislature. He and others argued that with his rigid and conservative ideology, Mr. Fordice had misread voters.
"Anytime you lose on an issue that is as visible and as important as this is, it's not going to strengthen your hand as Governor," said William Winter, a former Democratic Governor who is credited with starting the movement in the state to increase spending on education. "It is happening in the first session at the start of his first term when he should be at the height of his power. This is not a good beginning."
But public education advocates among both Republicans and Democrats suggested that the override was less a vote against Republicans or Fordice and more a vote for public education that reflected the efforts of parent groups, teachers and higher education institutions. Most said it sent a signal that there was a sentiment for continuing change and improvement in public education that began more than a decade ago under Democratic governors.
Mississippi ranks 49th in the average per pupil spending for education by the states.
Jack Reed, a member of the state Board of Education who was the unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor in 1987, said the override of a veto so early in a new governor's term was "unusual" but added that it was not something that Mr. Fordice could not recover from. The Governor had failed to see that parents and not just educational professionals were for the tax increase, he said.
"But the veto override was surprising, and it was unusual," he said.
For his part Mr. Fordice said the long-term political impact of this early defeat would not be clear until November, when many legislators who voted to override the veto will seek re-election in redrawn legislative districts. He said he was convinced that the true will of the public against such an increase would become evident then.
"Some people say that I come out ahead politically no matter what because I stuck by my position," Mr. Fordice said in a telephone interview. "But we won't really know until November, and I think this vote will still be fresh in people's minds. But whatever happens, I'm not changing."
The Governor said he had opposed the sales tax increase that will go into effect on June 1 because its timing could "smother the improvements that are starting to show in an economy that has been down".
The 58-year-old Mr. Fordice, a construction company owner who is a conservative, defeated the incumbent Governor, Ray Mabus, a Democrat, in a surprise victory last November. Mr. Mabus came into office in 1987 amid a wave of new, young and fiscally conservative Democrats who were educated in the North and who many believed would represent the future leadership. But he and others in that group, like former Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana, proved unable to last more than a single term.
The new law will increase the state sales tax to 7 percent from 6 percent on June 1 and produce $168 million for school buildings, books and supplies, as well as increases in discretionary money for the state's four-year and two-year colleges. Critical elements in its passage was the measure's requirement that new revenue be earmarked for these purposes, said Andy Mullins, a spokesman for the State Board of Education, as well as a requirement that school districts cut local property tax rates in the coming years to reflect the infusion of increases.
Legislative leaders like House Speaker Tim Ford, a Democrat from Tupelo, have pointed to these two features of the sales tax increase as making lawmakers more comfortable with them in an election year.
Even Lieut. Gov. Edward Briggs, a Republican, said Mr. Fordice had failed to counter the tax increase proposal with an affirmative approach to address declining revenue for education.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Decoding the Remarks By Fitzwater on Riots

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
President Bush's political supporters and opponents agree that when his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Monday that the social welfare programs of the 1960's and 1970's were responsible for the Los Angeles riots, Mr. Fitzwater was talking in code. But they disagree about what he meant.
The supporters say Mr. Fitzwater was referring to an attitude that they say prevailed during the Great Society era, with Democratic encouragement, that poor people were not responsible for deviant behavior. 
Those who oppose the President hold that the spokesman was trying, without saying so directly, to appeal to voters who feel that Democratic programs were tilted to favor blacks.
Both sides agree that Mr. Fitzwater could not have been talking, in purely factual terms, about the giant health programs like Medicare and Medicaid, or Social Security retirement benefits that keep pace with inflation, or college scholarships and loans, or grants to grade schools and high schools based on the number of poor children attending them. They have become so much a part of the fabric of American society that it is difficult for legislators or policy makers in either party to imagine life without them.
 
Some Programs Praised
 And Mr. Fitzwater, who refuses on the record to elaborate on what he meant in his statement to reporters Monday, was certainly not thinking about the small Great Society programs like Head Start, the Job Corps and community health centers, which are widely praised by members of Mr. Bush's own Cabinet.
The President's press secretary may have been referring to Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the Government's main welfare program. It costs the Government about $15 billion a year, 3 percent of the $500 billion spent on Social Security and Medicare. But A.F.D.C. was started in the 1930's, and the most significant change, the law that requires welfare mothers to seek education and job training, was enacted in 1988 with bipartisan support and Mr. Bush's blessing.
Charles Murray, a social scientist whose book "Losing Ground: American Social Policy 1950-1980" (Basic, 1986) provided the policy justification for Republican cuts in social programs in the 1980's, is one of those who holds that general criticism of those programs is really an attack on an attitude prevalent in the 1960's that is still held by some Democrats.
"It's a mistake to try to demonize any particular program," Mr. Murray said in an interview today. But taken together, he added, the laws, court decisions and regulations that went on the books between 1964 and 1972 served to blame society for the problems of poor young people and to make it socially acceptable in some circles to become reliant on the public dole.
But Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the Democratic chairman of the Budget Committee, reflected the view of many Bush critics that Mr. Fitzwater's statement was meant to generate racial antagonism. "This Administration has been very adept at playing the race card," Mr. Sasser said.
Whatever Mr. Fitzwater meant, the argument over whether social programs provide a critical safety net for the poor or merely foster dependency draws attention away from Mr. Bush's most serious political weakness, the poor state of the economy, and from his failure to press for programs that he himself says are the solutions to the problems of the cities.
Since John F. Kennedy talked about a rising tide lifting all boats, every President has held that the single best cure for poverty is a thriving economy. Here, for example, is an exchange from a Bush news conference last fall:
Question: Do you think you are going to do more for the Americans who are without jobs now and who are really poverty stricken?
Answer: I think we are beginning to see this economy move, and I think that, of course, is by far the best answer to jobs.
Yet, by almost any measure, the economy has done worse under Mr. Bush than under any other President since World War II.
In Mr. Bush's first three years in the White House, the economy grew a total of only 1.8 percent after adjusting for inflation. Even if the Administration's forecast for growth this year, 2.3 percent, turns out to be accurate, the four-year figure of 4.1 percent growth will be far and away the worst since the war.
Average economic growth for the 10 four-year terms beginning withPresident Harry S. Truman's in 1949 and ending with President Ronald Reagan's last term was 13.7 percent. The weakest periods, 7.3 percent growth in Dwight D. Eisenhower's second term and 7.6 percent in the Richard M. Nixon-Gerald R. Ford term, were almost twice as strong as the Bush record.
Looked at another way, the number of jobs in the country increased by only three-tenths of 1 percent from the time Mr. Bush became President through last March. Even if the economy picks up this year, the total number of jobs created in Mr. Bush's term will be less than half the worst previous four-year term.
 
Little White House Push
 Even Mr. Bush's strongest advocates hold that strengthening the economy is more important than realigning social programs. "A good economy," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, "is the best way to help individuals. It makes it possible for more people to escape the blighted areas."
Nonetheless, lawmakers say, the President has hardly lifted a finger to win Congressional passage of measures like enterprise zones, tax breaks for businesses starting up in poor neighborhoods, that he is now advocating as a solution for the problems of the cities.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said he might support some of Mr. Bush's initiatives in the social policy area but had never really been called on to do so.
"You could be a United States Senator for the last three years without knowing there was any Bush domestic agenda," Mr. Moynihan said. "I have never once felt it in terms of I've got to go to this hearing, or I've got to deal with this proposal."

HEADLINE: Dow Drops by 18.78, but Broader Market Is Mostly Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The majority of stock prices rose yesterday, even as the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average retreated from Monday's record, losing 18.78 points to close at 3,359.35.
On Monday, the main market barometer climbed 42.04 points, to a record 3,378.13, the 18th new high this year. But yesterday, traders said, institutional investors turned away from blue-chip stocks and spread their buying among other sectors, including technology and transportation issues. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by 935 to 783 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume came to 200.6 million shares, up from 174.5 million Monday.
The active trading indicated that institutional investors refocused their attention from the Dow average -- which consists of big-name stocks like I.B.M., Coca-Cola and McDonald's -- to other areas. Most of the other market indexes gained.
The broader New York Stock Exchange index rose 0.08 point, to 229.50; the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks gained 4.53 points, to 588.07; the American Stock Exchange index rose 1.56 points, to 393.17, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index lost 0.07 point, to 416.84.
Traders said they did not view the Dow's decline as a harbinger of a sell-off, although some investors sold stocks to capture profits at the record level. The decline was exaggerated late in the day by a flurry of computer-driven program sell orders.
"We had more buyers all day than sellers," said Dudley Eppel, a senior vice president at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. "The Dow got hit for a change instead of being the leader."
 
Effects of Riot
 Monday's market rally was attributed partly to the end to rioting in Los Angeles. Traders had been worried about the riot's effects on the mood of the nation.
Also, investors were encouraged by the apparently steady but slow economic recovery, which could leave room for the Government to push down interest rates further. "It's the best environment -- slow growth, lower rates, no inflation," said Tony Cecin, equity trading director at Piper Jaffray Inc. in Minneapolis.
He said investors with sizable cash holdings were still being forced into the stock market to avoid low rates from fixed-income securities.
Among actively traded Big Board issues yesterday, I.B.M. continued upward, gaining 1 3/8, to 93 7/8, and leading other technology stocks higher. Hewlett-Packard was up 1 1/4, to 81 3/4; Texas Instruments rose 1 1/4, to 36, and Compaq gained 3/8, to 25 1/4.
In the over-the-counter market, Intel, the computer chip maker, rose 1 7/8, to 54 3/8. Among other technology stocks posting gains, Novell was up 1 1/8, to 54 3/8; Adobe Systems 2 1/2, to 47 1/2, and Microsoft 2 1/2, to 116 1/2.
Losers that helped depress the Dow included Caterpillar, off 2 5/8, to 53 1/2; Procter & Gamble, down 2, to 101 5/8, and United Technologies, down 1 1/2, to 53 1/4.
ITT rose 2 3/4, to 66 3/4, in heavy trading. The hotel, insurance and industrial-products conglomerate announced that its board had authorized a stock repurchase program for up to 25 million common shares.
Transportation stocks as a group were higher. AMR, parent of American Airlines, rose 2, to 68 7/8, and Southwest Airlines gained 2 3/4, to 41 3/4. Roadway Services rose 1 3/4, to 77 1/4, while Burlington Northern was 1 3/8 higher, to 45 7/8.

HEADLINE: CANADA TO DIVIDE ITS NORTHERN LAND

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 5

 BODY:
Maps of Canada are about to be redrawn after a vote that carves up Canada's north, setting the boundaries of what is to become a self-governing homeland for Eskimos.
By a 54 percent majority, the voters of the Northwest Territories took the momentous step on Monday, authorizing the split-up of their huge area into two separate territories divided by a zigzag line stretching from the Saskatchewan-Manitoba border practically to the North Pole. 
 The eastern portion, extending nearly to Greenland, covers 772,260 square miles, a third larger than the state of Alaska, and is inhabited by about 17,500 Eskimos, or Inuit, as they call themselves. It is this area that is to be administered by the Eskimos. They call the territory Nunavut, meaning Our Land.
For the Ottawa Government the next steps will be to draft legislation creating the new land and work with community leaders on plans for the transition, including a crash program of training Eskimos for administrative jobs in the Nunavut government.
 
'Speak With One Voice'
 "This is a very positive development for Canada," said Stephen Kakfwi, minister of intergovernmental and aboriginal affairs for the government of the Northwest Territories. "It shows that Canadians have the potential and capacity to support very strong change in favor of aboriginal people."
Rosemarie Kuptana, president of the Inuit Tapirisat of Canada, the national political voice of the Eskimos, said the results "demonstrate that Inuit speak with one voice on Nunavut." Tapirisat is brotherhood.
Canada now consists of 10 provinces and two territories, the Yukon and the Northwest Territories. Provinces represent somewhat more evolved political units than the territories. The main practical difference is that provinces own their own land and mineral resources; land in the territories is owned by the federal Government.
Under the new arrangement, which is expected to come into effect after a seven-year transition, there will be three territories instead of two: the existing Yukon, Nunavut, and what's left of the Northwest Territories, populated by Indians of the Dene Nation in the Mackenzie Valley, Eskimos known as Inuvialuit around the Beaufort Sea, and whites, mainly around Yellowknife, the territorial capital.
The creation of Nunavut is tied to an agreement signed last December in which the Eskimos will get outright title to nearly 20 percent of the land in the new territory and are guaranteed $1.4 billion over 14 years as an economic jump-start for the new homeland.
One final formal obstacle to Nunavut is a vote scheduled for next November to ratify the land agreement. But the high turnout of Eskimos voting on Monday suggested that the November poll will be overwhelmingly affirmative.
Of 55,000 inhabitants of the Northwest Territories and 27,000 who were eligible to vote, those who actually took part in Monday's plebiscite numbered 15,484, a turnout of 56.5 percent.
In the eastern Arctic, where most of the Eskimos live, 72 percent voted and 87 percent said yes to the proposed boundary. In the western part of the Northwest Territories, where most of the local opponents of the split-up of the territory resides, 74 percent voted no.
 
Opposed by Dene Indians
 Many of the nonnatives in the west saw the division as a needless expense and a threat to jobs. The territorial government in Yellowknife is the town's biggest employer, but its functions would be cut once the new Nunavut comes into being with its own governing structures.
Some of the fears were expressed by Shirley M. McGrath, past president of the Chamber of Commerce of Yellowknife, who noted in an interview that businesses are closing at a rapid rate and "if we look at losing a lot of government jobs as well, then what do we have left?"
The Dene Indians opposed the boundary as well because it cuts through some of their traditional hunting and burial grounds.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Willkommen To Amerika's Sky

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHEN word got out that BMW was thinking of assembling cars in South Carolina, the only question anyone asked was "How soon can you come?" But whenever Lufthansa has hinted that it would like to fly Americans around the United States on American-made aircraft operated by American pilots, the company has been no more welcome than a snowstorm in Miami.
There are explanations for this apparent contradiction. For one thing, it's the law. The Civil Aviation Act of 1938 prohibits foreign control of a United States airline. For another, it makes for a plausible bargaining strategy: Investment rights remain a useful chip in Washington's sometime effort to increase global airline competition. 
 But Clark Onstad, a Washington lawyer and consultant to airlines who was a senior aviation official in the Carter Administration, thinks the time is ripe to make an exception. What is more, he is sure that President Bush has the legal authority to do it without Congressional approval.
The case for foreign ownership, Mr. Onstad argues, is as plain as the red ink dribbling off the airline industry's balance sheets. Three carriers (Eastern, Pan Am, Midway) met their maker last year. Three others (Continental, America West, T.W.A.) are in Chapter 11 bankruptcy. And two giants (Northwest, USAir) are vacuuming the seats for loose change. Only three major carriers -- American, United and Delta -- seem certain to weather the recessionary storms.
Fresh capital from abroad could not transform an ugly duckling into a high-flying swan. But Mr. Onstad contends that well-placed investments could see cash-starved carriers through next winter, giving them a fair chance to prove their mettle in the post-recession economy.
Of course, this capital need not come from foreign airlines. But they are the likeliest deep pockets because they want what even bankrupt American carriers have to offer -- access to the world's largest national market.
Foreign carriers already have the right to buy minority stakes in United States airlines. And several have: KLM owns stock in Northwest, S.A.S. in Continental, Ansett in America West, J.A.L. in Hawaiian. But under the Department of Transportation's interpretation of the law, foreign companies are not permitted to own enough to assert control over key airline policies -- everything from pricing to routes to aircraft selection.
Mr. Onstad argues that this interpretation of the statute is unnecessarily restrictive. The law specifies that an airline's president and two-thirds of the directors be American citizens, and that no more than 25 percent of voting stock be in foreign hands. But he believes that the Administration could allow foreigners to own preferred stock that gave them veto power over all material decisions, save those affecting United States security interests.
The Transportation Department has never given anyone a reason to believe it would entertain such a deal. Indeed, the department held up a far less radical proposal for an alliance between Northwest and the Dutch airline KLM before caving in to pressure from free-market types in the White House. Why might the regulators change now?
Foreign carriers have recently made it very, very clear that they would not open their purses simply to buy good will. Just after the Persian Gulf war, Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner reportedly tried and failed to persuade the Japanese carrier J.A.L. to buy a passive interest in a distressed United States airline.
Perhaps more important, the political stakes have grown. Three carriers including one of the biggest, Continental, are flying today at the sufferance of their creditors. And the fare war touched off by American Airlines' price restructuring last month is going to make it very difficult for them to amass enough cash during the summer season to make it through next winter.
Presumably, any airline liquidation would embarrass officials charged with shielding airline deregulation from vocal Congressional critics. But an election-year liquidation of Continental, the largest employer in George Bush's hometown of Houston, or America West, a major economic force in the Republican stronghold of Phoenix, would be an embarrassment indeed.
If the Administration chose to give the green light to a salvage job by a Lufthansa or a British Airways or a Singapore Airlines, there is little chance it could be thwarted by competitors or the distressed carrier's labor unions. Federal courts have proved very reluctant to second-guess regulators who buttress their decisions with even a shred of logic. The trickier tactical question is how to avoid a precedent that would weaken the bargaining leverage for, say, United to negotiate its entry into Europe's domestic airline markets.
But there is one clean place to draw the line: bankruptcy. Foreigners willing to revitalize a failing carrier might be welcomed. Those who simply sought competitive advantage in America would have to wait for their own governments to open their home markets.

HEADLINE: Overseas Press Club Gives Award to Terry Anderson

 BODY:
Terry A. Anderson, the Associated Press correspondent held hostage in Lebanon for nearly seven years by pro-Iranian kidnappers, will be honored tonight by the Overseas Press Club of America with the President's Award for "distinguished and exemplary service" in journalism.
"His courage and deep faith in God during 2,455 days as a hostage of terrorists in Lebanon earned Terry Anderson the admiration and respect of journalists and the public alike and will serve always as a reminder of the dangers confronting reporters all over the world," says the citation by the club's president, H. L. Stevenson, former editor in chief of United Press International. 
 Mike Wallace of CBS will present the awards to foreign correspondents, editors and photojournalists for their work in 1991 during the club's 53d annual awards dinner at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Purchasing Managers Raise Forecast for Manufacturing

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., May 5

 BODY:
Citing signs of an improving economy, the National Association of Purchasing Management today raised its forecast for growth in manufacturing this year.
In its semiannual forecast, the association said its members expected 5.1 percent growth in factory revenues in 1992, before adjustments for inflation, which were expected to be minimal. 
 The forecast was up from a 4.2 percent nomimal growth prediction made by the group in December.
 
 
Growth Expected to Continue
 "The recent growth in the economy will continue to improve during the balance of 1992," said the forecast, which was released at a conference of the group.
The association surveys the purchasing managers at more than 300 manufacturing and industrial companies across the United States. Its monthly survey of manufacturing is closely watched by the financial markets for signs of the direction of the economy and interest rates.
Traders in the markets were surprised on Friday when the group's index slipped to 51.3 percent for April, from 54.1 percent in March. But the chairman of the group's business survey committee, Robert Bretz, said the April figure was probably an aberration.
"The major reason for the April decline was seasonal adjustment factors," Mr. Bretz said. "They are strongest in April than in any other month. Actual indicators are almost the same as in March, particularly new order growth in April, which was strong in all industries."
 
 
High Rate of New Orders
 Mr. Bretz added that "given the high rate of new orders in April, one would have to believe that growth would continue into May when seasonal adjustments are not as high."
He also said the latest forecast for manufacturing revenue growth was consistent with overall economic growth in 1992 of 2.5 percent to 2.7 percent, after inflation.
"The turning point in the U.S. economy has arrived," said Joseph Duncan, corporate economist and chief statistician at Dun & Bradstreet.
The purchasing managers group said prices had declined fractionally since the end of 1991, and it expected inflation of less than 1 percent for all of 1992. "The rate of increase in labor and benefit costs is expected to slow again, to 2.9 percent, down from 4.1 percent predicted in December 1991," the report said.
The purchasing managers said the decline in overall manufacturing employment was likely to end this year. Only 30 percent of the group's members said they expected their companies' employment to be lower during the rest of the year, compared with 45 percent who expressed such a view in December 1991.
About 27 percent of the members said they expected to see higher employment during the rest of 1992. The report said that purchasing executives had turned optimistic for the next 12 months. "The 44 percent of members expressing satisfaction or optimism is up sharply from only 13 percent in December 1991 and is the most since the December 1988 semi-annual economic forecast, which was 48 percent," the report said.
Conversely, the number of members who are worried or pessimistic dropped to 4 percent, down from 12 percent in December.
Although there was a unanimous consensus that the dollar would continue to strengthen, export growth was also predicted to remain strong.

HEADLINE: Hachette Announces A Merger

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 5

 BODY:
Jean-Luc Lagardere, the humbled king of the French media business, today announced an unlikely merger of his publishing giant, Hachette S.A., and the Matra defense group in an apparent attempt to shore up Hachette's troubled finances.
Hachette's rapid growth during the 1980's in Europe and the United States -- its magazines include Elle and Woman's Day -- propelled its chairman, Mr. Lagardere, to the status of international media baron. 
 But the group has suffered several setbacks over the last year. Most damaging was the collapse last month of the French television station La Cinq, a failure that cost Hachette at least $637 million and contributed to the company's record 1991 losses of $350 milion.
 
Costly American Expansion
 Hachette's ambitious American expansion, which involved the purchase of Grolier encyclopedias and Diamandis magazines for $670 million in 1988, has also caused difficulties, for it incurred $1.9 billion of debt partly to make the acquisitions just as the recession in America began a long reduction in magazine advertising revenues.
Acknowledging his problems at a news conference, Mr. Lagardere, who is 64 years old and was only recently regarded as one of France's most successful entrepreneurs, said that the demise of La Cinq constituted "the most serious setback of my life." But he vowed to battle on, comparing himself to a boxer in the final round of a fight who rises from the floor to seek victory.
Analysts are skeptical. While insisting on anonymity, they noted that there was no apparent synergy between Hachette and Matra and said the move amounted to a last-ditch attempt to salvage Hachette's financial situation and allow Mr. Lagardere to hang on to power.
In a statement that was full of good intentions but conspicuously short on details, Hachette said it would complete the proposed merger with Matra this year, creating a group with annual sales of $9.6 billion in areas including book publishing, magazines, telecommunications and ground-to-air missiles.
The financial arrangements for the merger were not disclosed, and a Hachette spokeswoman, Eve Magnant, declined to elaborate.
Matra was already linked to Hachette through the MMB holding company, which is controlled by the Lagardere family. Indeed, Mr. Lagardere was chairman of both companies. But their activities were distinct.
While Matra also had a bad year in 1991 -- its profits tumbled 58 percent, to $45.8 million -- it has scant debt and a much stronger balance sheet than Hachette. Analysts said the merged company would therefore look more attractive to Hachette's creditors, which include Credit Lyonnais and the Banque Nationale de Paris.
It is unclear how other Matra shareholders will react to the company's effectively rescuing Hachette. Among such shareholders are the German automotive group Daimler-Benz. Trading in Matra and Hachette has been suspended since last week and is due to resume on Wednesday.
 
Recapitalization to Proceed
 Before the merger, Hachette said it would raise $236 million by selling assets, including its landmark building on the Boulevard St.-Germain in Paris. An 8.1 percent stake in the Italian media group Rizzoli -- once seen as an important platform of Europe-wide expansion -- has already been sold this week, for $74.9 million.
Hachette also said it would proceed with a $510 million recapitalization before the merger with Matra. The money is to be raised principally through a stock offering and an issue of convertible bonds, a plan that appears ambitious given the current generally cautious view on Hachette's stock.
Banks are tightening their hold on Mr. Lagardere since his recent failures, and officials close to the deal said Matra-Hachette would be controlled by a reconstituted MMB holding company, in which creditor banks would be strongly represented, Mr. Lagardere's stake diluted and his management kept on a tighter rein.
Moreover, under the terms of MMB's new incorporation, all Mr. Lagardere's personal equity would be liable in the event of failure, said the officials, who spoke on condition that they not be identified.

HEADLINE: Official Seeks Building Jobs For Students

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall, the president of the Board of Education, yesterday called on the agency that oversees construction of school buildings to offer apprenticeships to high school students and graduates that could lead to union membership in the construction industry.
In making his appeal, Mr. McCall invoked the specter of riot-torn Los Angeles and seized on an opportunity to provide jobs to the kind of poor and discontented young people that engaged in looting and burning. 
 "The lack of meaningful employment leads to the eruption of violent disturbances such as we have seen in recent days," Mr. McCall said in a memorandum sent to the trustees of the School Construction Authority.
The authority has become one of the city's biggest builders, with a $4 billion plan for erecting and renovating school buildings over five years, half of which has already been spent. Since the Board of Education dictates which buildings the authority puts up, it theoretically has a powerful lever to extract jobs out of an industry that has historically had a poor record of hiring black and Hispanic workers. More than 80 percent of the city's high school students are members of minority groups.
 
Budget Is Under Discussion
 The authority's budget is now under discussion by the City Council and the State Legislature and that is being seen as a wedge to revive interest in the apprenticeship plan, which was first discussed three years ago. Mr. McCall said some legislators, like Assemblyman Roger L. Green of Brooklyn, a former head of the Black and Puerto Rican Caucus, would be more receptive to providing construction money if they knew it would provide jobs for their constituents.
Meyer S. Frucher, a trustee of the authority, said he and a second trustee, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, had been working on an apprenticeship plan for more than a year, but the idea had been stalled by a recession in construction that has cost more than 50 percent of the 98,000 construction workers their jobs.
As a result, he said, the unions want to make sure that apprenticeships do not replace the jobs of some of their members, while the authority is concerned that an arrangement that merely adds apprenticeship jobs will make building schools more costly.
Louis Coletti, president of the New York Building Congress, an umbrella group of builders and unions, said he welcomed the idea of an apprenticeship program as a path out of poverty. But any program, he said, must be tied into the industry's existing apprenticeship program.
He said that 38 percent of union and nonunion construction workers were black and Hispanic. He cautioned that creating apprenticeships without being able to deliver real jobs would only yield disillusionment.
Mr. McCall did not accept such logic.
"Young people are already disillusioned," he said. "We want them to be prepared to compete for jobs when they are available."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Insomniacs for Dollars: Traders, TV and Numbers

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
AT 1:30 A.M. yesterday, the floor of New York's principal commodity exchanges on the eighth floor of 4 World Trade Center was eerily quiet.
The floors were bereft of the slips of paper that drift like snow during trading hours; the hundreds of video screens displayed nothing but dull green, and not a scream could be heard in darkened pits where huge quantities of everything from oil to orange juice raucously change hands during the day. 
 Only in the pit where an odd new financial instrument called U.S. Dollar Index Futures are traded was there a hint of action. And not much of a hint, if first impressions were any clue.
What attention of the half-dozen traders present seemed predominantly focused on a leggy Australian model appearing on a talk show. One lumbered over to answer a phone, then shouted a number. No response. "Gentlemen, wake me up when I have something to do," he said as he lay down on the top tier of the carpeted pit.
You could actually hear the clocks ticking, but appearances were deceiving. This exchange, Finex, a division of the New York Cotton Exchange, boasts that it is the world's only futures market to trade around the clock.
It offers contracts that are, in fact, nothing but a numbers game: players bet on the dollar's value by buying and selling an index of 10 other currencies. Unlike cocoa or cotton futures, nothing is ever delivered. Buyers and sellers just settle their wager at an assigned date -- which, as a practical matter, is the same thing that mavens in real commodities almost always do.
Arbitragers can profit from currency movements; hedgers, such as portfolio managers, can guard against them, and just plain gamblers can have a ball. It adds up: since night trading began on March 1, the self-described "night warriors," who account for a quarter of traders, have come to account for 40 percent of the $400 million in contracts traded each day.
The truth is that most people do sleep in "the city that never sleeps." This gaggle of insomniacs is a forced aberration.
To learn to cope with forced nocturnality, Richard Jaycobs, Finex's managing director, went to Philadelphia to see a night work consultant. Somehow, the lessons learned from nuclear plant employees did not seem relevant.
For one thing, television assumes weird and inordinate importance during trading lulls. "Don't make fun of the Weather Channel," begged Mr. Jaycobs as he dined with colleagues during the nightly break from 11 to 12:30, timed to coincide with lunchtime in Tokyo.
Ha! These are Wall Street guys who routinely brandish jokes to get them through million-dollar market turns, the perversity of economic statistics and, oh yes, terrible human tragedies. The only thing they hold sacred seems to be their favorite commercials. Each seemingly itches to chirp a favorite jingle for products ranging from used cars to cheap mortgages to sex phone lines.
On Monday night, eyes were focused on "Trading Places," a movie shot on the floor of the nearby orange juice exchange. They made scathing fun of the extras, all of whom they knew too well.
But the overall effect of TV has been enervating. Everyone has lost interest in "Branded," a former favorite shown at 4:30 A.M. "We inaugurated quiet time," pronounced Daniel Kelleher. With a slight giggle, he continued, "We read books and reflect on currency movements."
What they mainly do, of course, is work very hard. One who stands out is Gary Hoffman, who routinely puts in 32-hour shifts, trading Treasury notes days and the dollar index nights. "You probably don't remember it, but once I forgot to bring a change of shirt and deodorant," he said between bits of steak.
"We do remember that, actually," a friend said.
It would take the sort of person who bets point-by-point on pro basketball playoff games to appreciate the fun of all this financial volatility. Alan Osofsky, who owns a trading firm, puts it this way: "Just 15 seconds is an eternity. You could be out of business in a minute."
When things move, they move fast. If a world leader were assassinated, millions would change hands almost instantly. The fear of someone knowing something one does not is so omnipresent that people feel duty-bound to eavesdrop on phone conversations. As a result, they have learned that one trader provides a nightly running commentary of whatever is on TV to someone somewhere.
Not to say buying and selling high-priced esoterica is all these people do. Mr. Hoffman, for instance, coaches youth sports for some 20 hours a week. One trader, Mike Bryne, a recent college graduate, is less ambitious but knows what he likes.
"At 9:30 in the morning, you can find me in any of the local taverns," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newsday Seeks to Cut Work Force

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Newsday announced yesterday that it would seek to reduce its total work force by about 10 percent by offering enhanced severance pay to up to 300 employees who volunteer to resign.
Chiara Coletti, a spokeswoman for the newspaper, said the cost reduction had been prompted by the depressed economy on Long Island, which has significantly weakened advertising. 
 "We believe the 90's will not equal the 80's, even when a rebound occurs, and we're trying to be as realistic as possible," Ms. Coletti said. "This is a measure we're taking to continue avoiding more drastic measures."
 
3,000 Workers, Currently
 Since January 1990, Newsday has reduced its work force to 3,000 from about 3,300 through attrition and an early-retirement plan. Last summer, the paper offered voluntary unpaid furloughs to employees in an effort to reduce costs without layoffs.
The newspaper is offering a severance package of eight weeks' base pay plus two and a half weeks' base pay for each year of service, up to a total of 60 weeks' base pay. Some health insurance is also part of the package.
The severance package will first be offered to 282 circulation employees who oversee the Long Island edition's home delivery operation.
 
Target: Home-Delivery Jobs
 Ms. Coletti said the paper was restructuring its circulation department, which was established years ago to oversee a delivery force made up mostly of children who delivered the paper in the afternoon. In recent years, Newsday has shifted to early-morning home delivery by adult carriers, who need less supervision.
Ms. Coletti said that home-delivery employees would have from May 6 to June 22 to volunteer for the program, and that the paper's target for this group was about 200 positions.
From June 1 to July 15, the paper's other employees in all departments of Newsday's editions on Long Island and in New York City would be allowed to volunteer.
Asked what will happen if the target of 300 jobs is not reached, Ms. Coletti said, "I don't want to speculate."

HEADLINE: U.S. Extends Caribbean Loan Effort

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
The Treasury Department said today that it had extended by three years a Government-guaranteed loan program intended to encourage private investment in the Caribbean.
The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Federal agency, had been scheduled to stop guaranteeing loans this year after $100 million already in process had been delivered. 
 In a letter dated March 31 to Congress, however, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the program would be extended to allow $300 million more in loans over three years, said Richard Myers, a department spokesman.
The extension, first reported today in The Wall Street Journal, had been urged by Senator Bob Kasten, a Wisconsin Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee's Foreign Operations Subcommittee, the newspaper said.
 
Based on Puerto Rico Effort
 The program is an offshoot of a longstanding tax exemption for profits that American companies make on their operations in Puerto Rico.
In 1986, when Congressional opposition threatened the exemption, which costs $2.7 billion a year, Puerto Rico offered to funnel about $100 million a year of the profits to projects around the Caribbean.
Companies used part of their tax-free profits to buy tax-exempt bonds from agencies in Puerto Rico or from private financial institutions, which then lent the proceeds at low interest rates to finance projects like a hotel in Jamaica and a plant in the Dominican Republic that makes cream of coconut milk.
As an added inducement, the United States agency guaranteed repayment.
But as a budget-cutting measure, the Treasury has sought to replace the OPIC guarantee with the guarantee of a "quasi-governmental Puerto Rican insurance facility," Mr. Myers said. Still, the agency's guarantee program was extended because of difficulty in getting the Puerto Rico program up and running, he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Deutsche Bank Pursues Diversity for Its U.S. Unit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When Ronaldo H. Schmitz was an executive in the United States at BASF, the giant chemical company, he used Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, as a valued lender but a less-than-complete financial partner.
"The bank had its traditional competence as a lender, but for more sophisticated products I found that my American colleagues turned to American banks," he said. 
 Now, two years after having left BASF to become one of 13 managing directors at Deutsche Bank, the 54-year-old Mr. Schmitz is pushing the American branch to diversify its business and grow in areas more in demand among corporations -- and more profitable for the bank.
 
Looking to the Future
 Mr. Schmitz, who is based in Germany but spends much time in the United States running North American operations, is bold enough to foresee a time, several years hence, when the bank's American business will be bolstered by a listing on the New York Stock Exchange and perhaps the acquisition of a major American bank or securities firm.
Instead of a staid lender, the Deutsche Bank being assembled by Mr. Schmitz in North America will provide corporate customers a fuller package of services, including offerings of securities and financial advice.
Mr. Schmitz acknowledges that his models are Bankers Trust and J. P. Morgan, two New York companies that have thrived by concentrating on trading and financial advisory services for large corporations and wealthy individuals.
 
Growth in Assets
 Mr. Schmitz expects the assets of Deutsche Bank's North American banking business, which have expanded to nearly $14 billion from $6 billion five years ago, will grow more slowly in the future. But he expects the bank's impact in American financial markets to be greater.
To handle the growth, Deutsche Bank has been hiring. Recent recruits include John Ross, previously head of asset and liability management at the Bank of New York, who became treasurer of Deutsche Bank's newly created holding company for North American operations.
Also hired was Jeff Stuart, who came from Paribas, the French bank, to head the capital markets group, and John Stomber, who left the Security Pacific National Bank to head the interest-rate and currency-swap group.
In the securities business, Deutsche Bank plans to take more advantage of its familiarity with European markets, where it is a leader. Beside offering American investors securities of European companies, Horst Risse, chief executive of Deutsche Bank Capital, is working for a bigger role in distributing securities of American companies. A pending worldwide offering of stock by the First Chicago Corporation, for example, will include Deutsche Bank Capital as an underwriter.
Deutsche Bank is still dickering with the Federal Reserve over the terms by which it may combine the business of its C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell securities unit with that of the bank. But Mr. Schmitz said he was optimistic that the combination of Deutsche Bank's capital and connections with 24,000 European businesses, plus Morgan Grenfell's expertise in mergers and acquisitions, would be a powerful lure to American companies.
Mr. Schmitz said he also planned to develop or acquire a private banking business to serve the wealthy individual customers who, he said, "have been seeking us without any effort on our part."
Although Deutsche Bank earned $100 million from its American businesses last year, Mr. Schmitz warned that the bank could not always expect to benefit from the wider profit margins that have developed here as some banks, particularly Japanese, have pulled back from the market. When competition among lenders eventually increases and profit margins decline, he expects Deutsche Bank's new strategy to produce benefits.
As one of the world's few banks with a triple-A rating from every credit agency, Deutsche Bank should be well positioned to attract business from corporations that are increasingly desirous of doing business with financially strong banks that also have expertise in securities markets.
Deutsche Bank has about $8.5 billion of loans issued by its American branches in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, enough to make it one of the country's 50 largest banks.

Graph: "Growth in America" shows the amount of consolidated total assets of Deutsche Bank's North American operations from '97-'91. (Source: Deutsche Bank)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Are Up Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower in trading that was heavily influenced by rumors on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices were slightly higher after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $337.50 an ounce, up 20 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold had risen 15 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $336.95. 
 Currency trading was intially subdued by the absence of Japan, where financial markets were closed for the second consecutive day because of a national holiday.
In Britain, where markets also were closed Monday for a holiday, big banks responded to a signal from the Government by cutting their base lending rate by half a percentage point to 10 percent.
It was the lowest level in three years and helped spur trading even though the move had been expected. The central bank gave a hint last week when it eased its money market rates just a bit.
The pound strengthened on the news, but speculation about German interest rates appeared to dominate the market.
"The mark was strong due to speclation that the Bundesbank, at its Thursday council meeting, might raise interest rates," said Randolph Donney, director or research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
That possibility, coupled with speculation that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates here to give the economy another jolt, worked to undermine the dollar.
"People were making the leap in logic and selling dollars before they have actual proof that that's what the Fed has to do," Mr. Donney said.
The Labor Department report on unemployment rates for April, due out Friday, is expected to help the Fed determine the direction of monetary policy.
As yields rise overseas, United States investors have a greater incentive to invest money abroad, thereby increasing their need for foreign currencies at the expense of the dollar.
In Tokyo, financial markets were closed for Children's Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar closed at 133.10 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 132.90 yen, down from 133.20 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7825, from $1.7795 in Europe late Monday.

HEADLINE: 'Green' Wine Adds Spice to Summer

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
NOW that spring has come and summer beckons, light, thirst-slaking vinho verde -- green wine -- can't be far behind for the Portuguese communities in Mineola, L.I., and Newark's Ironbound section. It also holds appeal for other, economy-minded consumers and for Pasquale (Pat) Iocca.
Many in the wine world call Mr. Iocca the nation's No. 1 authority on Portuguese wines. Last week, guests at the International Wine Center, a Manhattan wine school, quickly saw why when he pronounced the name VEEN-you VEHRD; even buffs call this white wine VAIR-dee. 
 The occasion, Mr. Iocca said, was "the single largest tasting of vinho verde ever held in the United States." Tapping his resources as wine product manager at the Portuguese Trade Commission, he easily rounded up 19 bottles -- 12 costing under $6.
Some say the word "green" (the wine is actually pale yellow) alludes to the bracing acidity, the fizz (injected carbon dioxide) and the fresh, youthful personality. Others point to Portugal's verdant northwest corner, just south of the Spanish border, which exported 126,100 cases to the United States in 1991, up from 28,416 cases in 1980.
Mary Ewing Mulligan, director of the center, laid the groundwork for Mr. Iocca's lecture. "Vinho verde is not a single type of wine but a whole region, with three distinct microclimates and four different grape varieties used singly or in combination," she said.
Their varied styles shattered the conventional notion that vinho verde has only one aroma and one flavor.
Vinho verde's astringency, sometimes unrelieved by barely detectable sweetness, needs toning down by food. The wine, an acquired taste, is understandable to fans of lean, appetite-whetting versions of muscadet, Chablis, Sancerre, Vouvray, dry and half-dry German rieslings, pinot grigio from Italy's Alto Adige region, New York seyval blanc and Washington semillon.
To preserve the fruitiness, large and most small-estate producers make vinho verde in steel and glass-lined cement vats, rather than in wooden barrels. The wine is about 9 percent alcohol, as against the 12 to 13 percent in most wines, and is made to be drunk young, ideally within a year of the vintage, two at most.
"You will find four or five but more commonly one or two big brands in stores outside America's Portuguese communities," Mr. Iocca said in an interview. He recommended Casal Garcia (about $5), Aveleda ($4.50), Casal Mendes ($4) and Gazela ($4.50). "These typical vinhos verdes are extremely skillfully made," he said.
They are not vintage-dated because the high-volume producers of the wine are used to quick sales and consumption. "I would prefer," he added, "that all, at least those for export, be vintage-dated."
The top grade, usually made only from the alvarinho grape, can be costly. Mr. Iocca called the estate-bottled, vintage-dated Palacio da Brejoeira (about $20) "the Lafite-Rothschild of vinhos verdes." He also recommended these estate-bottled brands: Quinta da Pedra ($16), Casa de Sezim ($9), Solar das Boucas ($9), Quinta de Sao Claudio ($8), Quinta do Outeiro do Baixo ($7.50) and Quinta d'Alem ($7).
Jose Meirelles, the Portuguese-born co-owner and chef of Les Halles, a Manhattan bistro, pours Grinalda, a famous brand, as his house wine and suggests it with oysters on the half shell. He likes it with a salad nicoise with a vinaigrette that has more extra-virgin olive oil than vinegar.
Jean Anderson, author of "The Food of Portugal" (William Morrow, 1986), said: "Vinho verde is sprightly and sturdy enough to stand up to spicy seasonings. I always use it for picnics."
She pours it with gazpacho; cold shrimp; deviled crab; vitello tonatto; a salad of cold roast squab, green beans and radicchio, with warm gravy from pan drippings; cold poached salmon with cilantro green sauce; broiled red snapper stuffed with fresh fennel; cold pork slathered with garlic and marinated in the wine before roasting, and pasta mixed with cooked broccoli florets and slivers of pimento and roasted red pepper and pine nuts.
The New York area's major suppliers include Lisbon Wines, 140-A Jericho Turnpike, Mineola (15 varieties), and Lisbon Liquors, 114 Ferry Street, Newark (10). In Manhattan, Garnet Liquors, 929 Lexington Avenue (68th Street), has three; Astor Wines and Liquors, 12 Astor Place, has four. Vinhos verdes are often discounted.
Lareira, a restaurant at 64-66 East Jericho Turnpike in Mineola, offers 10 different vinhos verdes.
The Portuguese also make red vinho verde. When asked to explain the contradiction, they shrug.

HEADLINE: The War Against the Poor

 BODY:
As if, after Los Angeles, there were any doubt: America's cities need help. So far, President Bush mainly offers them gratuitous insult. For the White House to assert that liberal social programs of the 60's and 70's set off rioting last week assaults the truth. The evidence, plain to anyone willing to take an honest look, shows that:
1. Lyndon Johnson's War on Poverty help cut the poverty rate nearly in half, and poverty among the elderly even more. 
 2. Instead of fighting poverty, Presidents Reagan and Bush have fought poverty programs. They have slashed Federal assistance to cities dramatically (see chart). During the Reagan-Bush 80's, poverty rates rose, and froze.
If the Administration were right, eviscerating social programs would have had a benign effect. Tell that to the nation's mayors. They can only hope that when the President tours Los Angeles tonight he will see clearly and not through a prism of callous doctrine.
The War on Poverty brought needy Americans food stamps, medical care, higher Social Security benefits, college tuition, legal services, prenatal care and early childhood education. To denounce programs like Medicare, Head Start and WIC denies the suffering of tens of millions who would stumble, or fall, without the help.
Such poverty programs, along with a healthy economy, brought the poverty rate down from 19 percent in 1964 to 11 percent in 1973. Even after the OPEC oil price hikes sent the economy spiraling downward, the poverty rate stayed low.
Compare that enviable record with the Reagan-Bush years. Even though the economy recovered for seven straight years, poor people did not. Poverty rates did not drop back to pre-recession levels.
Spending on direct aid for cities has fallen by more than 60 percent, after adjusting for inflation, since 1981. The Federal share of city budgets fell an astonishing amount, from 18 percent in 1980 to 6.4 percent in 1990 -- just as AIDS and crack sent social spending through the roof.
New York City's budget offers an eye-opening example. Last year the city spent one of every five municipal dollars on Medicaid, foster care and other express needs of the poor. That doesn't count a dime of spending for police and education.
Instead of blaming poor people, and the cities that try to help them, Mr. Bush might try finding compassionate solutions.
The first and most essential is to lift the backbreaking welfare burden off cities and share it with taxpayers.
The simplest, fairest remedy would be to set a uniform welfare benefit, and increase the share paid by the American public as a whole. Otherwise the current trend will continue, as localities cut benefit levels in order to control costs.
The poor, sick and homeless who roam city streets are not the citizens or the products simply of New York or Los Angeles or Detroit or Chicago. They are America's poor, sick and homeless. America has forgotten its collective responsibility to them during the Reagan-Bush years. To deny it now denies the realities President Bush will see tonight.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Relentless Change" shows direct Federal aid to cities in Reagan-Bush years, in billions, 1981-1991 (1982 dollars). (Source: National League of Cities)
